"31",35," I."
"32",35," Introduction"
"33",35,""
"34",35,""
"35",35,"The Time Traveller (for so it will be convenient to speak of him) was"
"36",35,"expounding a recondite matter to us. His pale grey eyes shone and"
"37",35,"twinkled, and his usually pale face was flushed and animated. The fire"
"38",35,"burnt brightly, and the soft radiance of the incandescent lights in the"
"39",35,"lilies of silver caught the bubbles that flashed and passed in our"
"40",35,"glasses. Our chairs, being his patents, embraced and caressed us rather"
"41",35,"than submitted to be sat upon, and there was that luxurious"
"42",35,"after-dinner atmosphere, when thought runs gracefully free of the"
"43",35,"trammels of precision. And he put it to us in this way—marking the"
"44",35,"points with a lean forefinger—as we sat and lazily admired his"
"45",35,"earnestness over this new paradox (as we thought it) and his fecundity."
"46",35,""
"47",35,"“You must follow me carefully. I shall have to controvert one or two"
"48",35,"ideas that are almost universally accepted. The geometry, for instance,"
"49",35,"they taught you at school is founded on a misconception.”"
"50",35,""
"51",35,"“Is not that rather a large thing to expect us to begin upon?” said"
"52",35,"Filby, an argumentative person with red hair."
"53",35,""
"54",35,"“I do not mean to ask you to accept anything without reasonable ground"
"55",35,"for it. You will soon admit as much as I need from you. You know of"
"56",35,"course that a mathematical line, a line of thickness _nil_, has no real"
"57",35,"existence. They taught you that? Neither has a mathematical plane."
"58",35,"These things are mere abstractions.”"
"59",35,""
"60",35,"“That is all right,” said the Psychologist."
"61",35,""
"62",35,"“Nor, having only length, breadth, and thickness, can a cube have a"
"63",35,"real existence.”"
"64",35,""
"65",35,"“There I object,” said Filby. “Of course a solid body may exist. All"
"66",35,"real things—”"
"67",35,""
"68",35,"“So most people think. But wait a moment. Can an _instantaneous_ cube"
"69",35,"exist?”"
"70",35,""
"71",35,"“Don’t follow you,” said Filby."
"72",35,""
"73",35,"“Can a cube that does not last for any time at all, have a real"
"74",35,"existence?”"
"75",35,""
"76",35,"Filby became pensive. “Clearly,” the Time Traveller proceeded, “any"
"77",35,"real body must have extension in _four_ directions: it must have"
"78",35,"Length, Breadth, Thickness, and—Duration. But through a natural"
"79",35,"infirmity of the flesh, which I will explain to you in a moment, we"
"80",35,"incline to overlook this fact. There are really four dimensions, three"
"81",35,"which we call the three planes of Space, and a fourth, Time. There is,"
"82",35,"however, a tendency to draw an unreal distinction between the former"
"83",35,"three dimensions and the latter, because it happens that our"
"84",35,"consciousness moves intermittently in one direction along the latter"
"85",35,"from the beginning to the end of our lives.”"
"86",35,""
"87",35,"“That,” said a very young man, making spasmodic efforts to relight his"
"88",35,"cigar over the lamp; “that . . . very clear indeed.”"
"89",35,""
"90",35,"“Now, it is very remarkable that this is so extensively overlooked,”"
"91",35,"continued the Time Traveller, with a slight accession of cheerfulness."
"92",35,"“Really this is what is meant by the Fourth Dimension, though some"
"93",35,"people who talk about the Fourth Dimension do not know they mean it. It"
"94",35,"is only another way of looking at Time. _There is no difference between"
"95",35,"Time and any of the three dimensions of Space except that our"
"96",35,"consciousness moves along it_. But some foolish people have got hold of"
"97",35,"the wrong side of that idea. You have all heard what they have to say"
"98",35,"about this Fourth Dimension?”"
"99",35,""
"100",35,"“_I_ have not,” said the Provincial Mayor."
"101",35,""
"102",35,"“It is simply this. That Space, as our mathematicians have it, is"
"103",35,"spoken of as having three dimensions, which one may call Length,"
"104",35,"Breadth, and Thickness, and is always definable by reference to three"
"105",35,"planes, each at right angles to the others. But some philosophical"
"106",35,"people have been asking why _three_ dimensions particularly—why not"
"107",35,"another direction at right angles to the other three?—and have even"
"108",35,"tried to construct a Four-Dimensional geometry. Professor Simon Newcomb"
"109",35,"was expounding this to the New York Mathematical Society only a month"
"110",35,"or so ago. You know how on a flat surface, which has only two"
"111",35,"dimensions, we can represent a figure of a three-dimensional solid, and"
"112",35,"similarly they think that by models of three dimensions they could"
"113",35,"represent one of four—if they could master the perspective of the"
"114",35,"thing. See?”"
"115",35,""
"116",35,"“I think so,” murmured the Provincial Mayor; and, knitting his brows,"
"117",35,"he lapsed into an introspective state, his lips moving as one who"
"118",35,"repeats mystic words. “Yes, I think I see it now,” he said after some"
"119",35,"time, brightening in a quite transitory manner."
"120",35,""
"121",35,"“Well, I do not mind telling you I have been at work upon this geometry"
"122",35,"of Four Dimensions for some time. Some of my results are curious. For"
"123",35,"instance, here is a portrait of a man at eight years old, another at"
"124",35,"fifteen, another at seventeen, another at twenty-three, and so on. All"
"125",35,"these are evidently sections, as it were, Three-Dimensional"
"126",35,"representations of his Four-Dimensioned being, which is a fixed and"
"127",35,"unalterable thing."
"128",35,""
"129",35,"“Scientific people,” proceeded the Time Traveller, after the pause"
"130",35,"required for the proper assimilation of this, “know very well that Time"
"131",35,"is only a kind of Space. Here is a popular scientific diagram, a"
"132",35,"weather record. This line I trace with my finger shows the movement of"
"133",35,"the barometer. Yesterday it was so high, yesterday night it fell, then"
"134",35,"this morning it rose again, and so gently upward to here. Surely the"
"135",35,"mercury did not trace this line in any of the dimensions of Space"
"136",35,"generally recognised? But certainly it traced such a line, and that"
"137",35,"line, therefore, we must conclude, was along the Time-Dimension.”"
"138",35,""
"139",35,"“But,” said the Medical Man, staring hard at a coal in the fire, “if"
"140",35,"Time is really only a fourth dimension of Space, why is it, and why has"
"141",35,"it always been, regarded as something different? And why cannot we move"
"142",35,"in Time as we move about in the other dimensions of Space?”"
"143",35,""
"144",35,"The Time Traveller smiled. “Are you so sure we can move freely in"
"145",35,"Space? Right and left we can go, backward and forward freely enough,"
"146",35,"and men always have done so. I admit we move freely in two dimensions."
"147",35,"But how about up and down? Gravitation limits us there.”"
"148",35,""
"149",35,"“Not exactly,” said the Medical Man. “There are balloons.”"
"150",35,""
"151",35,"“But before the balloons, save for spasmodic jumping and the"
"152",35,"inequalities of the surface, man had no freedom of vertical movement.”"
"153",35,""
"154",35,"“Still they could move a little up and down,” said the Medical Man."
"155",35,""
"156",35,"“Easier, far easier down than up.”"
"157",35,""
"158",35,"“And you cannot move at all in Time, you cannot get away from the"
"159",35,"present moment.”"
"160",35,""
"161",35,"“My dear sir, that is just where you are wrong. That is just where the"
"162",35,"whole world has gone wrong. We are always getting away from the present"
"163",35,"moment. Our mental existences, which are immaterial and have no"
"164",35,"dimensions, are passing along the Time-Dimension with a uniform"
"165",35,"velocity from the cradle to the grave. Just as we should travel _down_"
"166",35,"if we began our existence fifty miles above the earth’s surface.”"
"167",35,""
"168",35,"“But the great difficulty is this,” interrupted the Psychologist. ’You"
"169",35,"_can_ move about in all directions of Space, but you cannot move about"
"170",35,"in Time.”"
"171",35,""
"172",35,"“That is the germ of my great discovery. But you are wrong to say that"
"173",35,"we cannot move about in Time. For instance, if I am recalling an"
"174",35,"incident very vividly I go back to the instant of its occurrence: I"
"175",35,"become absent-minded, as you say. I jump back for a moment. Of course"
"176",35,"we have no means of staying back for any length of Time, any more than"
"177",35,"a savage or an animal has of staying six feet above the ground. But a"
"178",35,"civilised man is better off than the savage in this respect. He can go"
"179",35,"up against gravitation in a balloon, and why should he not hope that"
"180",35,"ultimately he may be able to stop or accelerate his drift along the"
"181",35,"Time-Dimension, or even turn about and travel the other way?”"
"182",35,""
"183",35,"“Oh, _this_,” began Filby, “is all—”"
"184",35,""
"185",35,"“Why not?” said the Time Traveller."
"186",35,""
"187",35,"“It’s against reason,” said Filby."
"188",35,""
"189",35,"“What reason?” said the Time Traveller."
"190",35,""
"191",35,"“You can show black is white by argument,” said Filby, “but you will"
"192",35,"never convince me.”"
"193",35,""
"194",35,"“Possibly not,” said the Time Traveller. “But now you begin to see the"
"195",35,"object of my investigations into the geometry of Four Dimensions. Long"
"196",35,"ago I had a vague inkling of a machine—”"
"197",35,""
"198",35,"“To travel through Time!” exclaimed the Very Young Man."
"199",35,""
"200",35,"“That shall travel indifferently in any direction of Space and Time, as"
"201",35,"the driver determines.”"
"202",35,""
"203",35,"Filby contented himself with laughter."
"204",35,""
"205",35,"“But I have experimental verification,” said the Time Traveller."
"206",35,""
"207",35,"“It would be remarkably convenient for the historian,” the Psychologist"
"208",35,"suggested. “One might travel back and verify the accepted account of"
"209",35,"the Battle of Hastings, for instance!”"
"210",35,""
"211",35,"“Don’t you think you would attract attention?” said the Medical Man."
"212",35,"“Our ancestors had no great tolerance for anachronisms.”"
"213",35,""
"214",35,"“One might get one’s Greek from the very lips of Homer and Plato,” the"
"215",35,"Very Young Man thought."
"216",35,""
"217",35,"“In which case they would certainly plough you for the Little-go. The"
"218",35,"German scholars have improved Greek so much.”"
"219",35,""
"220",35,"“Then there is the future,” said the Very Young Man. “Just think! One"
"221",35,"might invest all one’s money, leave it to accumulate at interest, and"
"222",35,"hurry on ahead!”"
"223",35,""
"224",35,"“To discover a society,” said I, “erected on a strictly communistic"
"225",35,"basis.”"
"226",35,""
"227",35,"“Of all the wild extravagant theories!” began the Psychologist."
"228",35,""
"229",35,"“Yes, so it seemed to me, and so I never talked of it until—”"
"230",35,""
"231",35,"“Experimental verification!” cried I. “You are going to verify _that_?”"
"232",35,""
"233",35,"“The experiment!” cried Filby, who was getting brain-weary."
"234",35,""
"235",35,"“Let’s see your experiment anyhow,” said the Psychologist, “though it’s"
"236",35,"all humbug, you know.”"
"237",35,""
"238",35,"The Time Traveller smiled round at us. Then, still smiling faintly, and"
"239",35,"with his hands deep in his trousers pockets, he walked slowly out of"
"240",35,"the room, and we heard his slippers shuffling down the long passage to"
"241",35,"his laboratory."
"242",35,""
"243",35,"The Psychologist looked at us. “I wonder what he’s got?”"
"244",35,""
"245",35,"“Some sleight-of-hand trick or other,” said the Medical Man, and Filby"
"246",35,"tried to tell us about a conjuror he had seen at Burslem, but before he"
"247",35,"had finished his preface the Time Traveller came back, and Filby’s"
"248",35,"anecdote collapsed."
"249",35,""
"250",35,""
"251",35,""
"252",35,""
"253",35," II."
"254",35," The Machine"
"255",35,""
"256",35,""
"257",35,"The thing the Time Traveller held in his hand was a glittering metallic"
"258",35,"framework, scarcely larger than a small clock, and very delicately"
"259",35,"made. There was ivory in it, and some transparent crystalline"
"260",35,"substance. And now I must be explicit, for this that follows—unless his"
"261",35,"explanation is to be accepted—is an absolutely unaccountable thing. He"
"262",35,"took one of the small octagonal tables that were scattered about the"
"263",35,"room, and set it in front of the fire, with two legs on the hearthrug."
"264",35,"On this table he placed the mechanism. Then he drew up a chair, and sat"
"265",35,"down. The only other object on the table was a small shaded lamp, the"
"266",35,"bright light of which fell upon the model. There were also perhaps a"
"267",35,"dozen candles about, two in brass candlesticks upon the mantel and"
"268",35,"several in sconces, so that the room was brilliantly illuminated. I sat"
"269",35,"in a low arm-chair nearest the fire, and I drew this forward so as to"
"270",35,"be almost between the Time Traveller and the fireplace. Filby sat"
"271",35,"behind him, looking over his shoulder. The Medical Man and the"
"272",35,"Provincial Mayor watched him in profile from the right, the"
"273",35,"Psychologist from the left. The Very Young Man stood behind the"
"274",35,"Psychologist. We were all on the alert. It appears incredible to me"
"275",35,"that any kind of trick, however subtly conceived and however adroitly"
"276",35,"done, could have been played upon us under these conditions."
"277",35,""
"278",35,"The Time Traveller looked at us, and then at the mechanism. “Well?”"
"279",35,"said the Psychologist."
"280",35,""
"281",35,"“This little affair,” said the Time Traveller, resting his elbows upon"
"282",35,"the table and pressing his hands together above the apparatus, “is only"
"283",35,"a model. It is my plan for a machine to travel through time. You will"
"284",35,"notice that it looks singularly askew, and that there is an odd"
"285",35,"twinkling appearance about this bar, as though it was in some way"
"286",35,"unreal.” He pointed to the part with his finger. “Also, here is one"
"287",35,"little white lever, and here is another.”"
"288",35,""
"289",35,"The Medical Man got up out of his chair and peered into the thing."
"290",35,"“It’s beautifully made,” he said."
"291",35,""
"292",35,"“It took two years to make,” retorted the Time Traveller. Then, when we"
"293",35,"had all imitated the action of the Medical Man, he said: “Now I want"
"294",35,"you clearly to understand that this lever, being pressed over, sends"
"295",35,"the machine gliding into the future, and this other reverses the"
"296",35,"motion. This saddle represents the seat of a time traveller. Presently"
"297",35,"I am going to press the lever, and off the machine will go. It will"
"298",35,"vanish, pass into future Time, and disappear. Have a good look at the"
"299",35,"thing. Look at the table too, and satisfy yourselves there is no"
"300",35,"trickery. I don’t want to waste this model, and then be told I’m a"
"301",35,"quack.”"
"302",35,""
"303",35,"There was a minute’s pause perhaps. The Psychologist seemed about to"
"304",35,"speak to me, but changed his mind. Then the Time Traveller put forth"
"305",35,"his finger towards the lever. “No,” he said suddenly. “Lend me your"
"306",35,"hand.” And turning to the Psychologist, he took that individual’s hand"
"307",35,"in his own and told him to put out his forefinger. So that it was the"
"308",35,"Psychologist himself who sent forth the model Time Machine on its"
"309",35,"interminable voyage. We all saw the lever turn. I am absolutely certain"
"310",35,"there was no trickery. There was a breath of wind, and the lamp flame"
"311",35,"jumped. One of the candles on the mantel was blown out, and the little"
"312",35,"machine suddenly swung round, became indistinct, was seen as a ghost"
"313",35,"for a second perhaps, as an eddy of faintly glittering brass and ivory;"
"314",35,"and it was gone—vanished! Save for the lamp the table was bare."
"315",35,""
"316",35,"Everyone was silent for a minute. Then Filby said he was damned."
"317",35,""
"318",35,"The Psychologist recovered from his stupor, and suddenly looked under"
"319",35,"the table. At that the Time Traveller laughed cheerfully. “Well?” he"
"320",35,"said, with a reminiscence of the Psychologist. Then, getting up, he"
"321",35,"went to the tobacco jar on the mantel, and with his back to us began to"
"322",35,"fill his pipe."
"323",35,""
"324",35,"We stared at each other. “Look here,” said the Medical Man, “are you in"
"325",35,"earnest about this? Do you seriously believe that that machine has"
"326",35,"travelled into time?”"
"327",35,""
"328",35,"“Certainly,” said the Time Traveller, stooping to light a spill at the"
"329",35,"fire. Then he turned, lighting his pipe, to look at the Psychologist’s"
"330",35,"face. (The Psychologist, to show that he was not unhinged, helped"
"331",35,"himself to a cigar and tried to light it uncut.) “What is more, I have"
"332",35,"a big machine nearly finished in there”—he indicated the"
"333",35,"laboratory—“and when that is put together I mean to have a journey on"
"334",35,"my own account.”"
"335",35,""
"336",35,"“You mean to say that that machine has travelled into the future?” said"
"337",35,"Filby."
"338",35,""
"339",35,"“Into the future or the past—I don’t, for certain, know which.”"
"340",35,""
"341",35,"After an interval the Psychologist had an inspiration. “It must have"
"342",35,"gone into the past if it has gone anywhere,” he said."
"343",35,""
"344",35,"“Why?” said the Time Traveller."
"345",35,""
"346",35,"“Because I presume that it has not moved in space, and if it travelled"
"347",35,"into the future it would still be here all this time, since it must"
"348",35,"have travelled through this time.”"
"349",35,""
"350",35,"“But,” said I, “If it travelled into the past it would have been"
"351",35,"visible when we came first into this room; and last Thursday when we"
"352",35,"were here; and the Thursday before that; and so forth!”"
"353",35,""
"354",35,"“Serious objections,” remarked the Provincial Mayor, with an air of"
"355",35,"impartiality, turning towards the Time Traveller."
"356",35,""
"357",35,"“Not a bit,” said the Time Traveller, and, to the Psychologist: “You"
"358",35,"think. _You_ can explain that. It’s presentation below the threshold,"
"359",35,"you know, diluted presentation.”"
"360",35,""
"361",35,"“Of course,” said the Psychologist, and reassured us. “That’s a simple"
"362",35,"point of psychology. I should have thought of it. It’s plain enough,"
"363",35,"and helps the paradox delightfully. We cannot see it, nor can we"
"364",35,"appreciate this machine, any more than we can the spoke of a wheel"
"365",35,"spinning, or a bullet flying through the air. If it is travelling"
"366",35,"through time fifty times or a hundred times faster than we are, if it"
"367",35,"gets through a minute while we get through a second, the impression it"
"368",35,"creates will of course be only one-fiftieth or one-hundredth of what it"
"369",35,"would make if it were not travelling in time. That’s plain enough.” He"
"370",35,"passed his hand through the space in which the machine had been. “You"
"371",35,"see?” he said, laughing."
"372",35,""
"373",35,"We sat and stared at the vacant table for a minute or so. Then the Time"
"374",35,"Traveller asked us what we thought of it all."
"375",35,""
"376",35,"“It sounds plausible enough tonight,” said the Medical Man; “but wait"
"377",35,"until tomorrow. Wait for the common sense of the morning.”"
"378",35,""
"379",35,"“Would you like to see the Time Machine itself?” asked the Time"
"380",35,"Traveller. And therewith, taking the lamp in his hand, he led the way"
"381",35,"down the long, draughty corridor to his laboratory. I remember vividly"
"382",35,"the flickering light, his queer, broad head in silhouette, the dance of"
"383",35,"the shadows, how we all followed him, puzzled but incredulous, and how"
"384",35,"there in the laboratory we beheld a larger edition of the little"
"385",35,"mechanism which we had seen vanish from before our eyes. Parts were of"
"386",35,"nickel, parts of ivory, parts had certainly been filed or sawn out of"
"387",35,"rock crystal. The thing was generally complete, but the twisted"
"388",35,"crystalline bars lay unfinished upon the bench beside some sheets of"
"389",35,"drawings, and I took one up for a better look at it. Quartz it seemed"
"390",35,"to be."
"391",35,""
"392",35,"“Look here,” said the Medical Man, “are you perfectly serious? Or is"
"393",35,"this a trick—like that ghost you showed us last Christmas?”"
"394",35,""
"395",35,"“Upon that machine,” said the Time Traveller, holding the lamp aloft,"
"396",35,"“I intend to explore time. Is that plain? I was never more serious in"
"397",35,"my life.”"
"398",35,""
"399",35,"None of us quite knew how to take it."
"400",35,""
"401",35,"I caught Filby’s eye over the shoulder of the Medical Man, and he"
"402",35,"winked at me solemnly."
"403",35,""
"404",35,""
"405",35,""
"406",35,""
"407",35," III."
"408",35," The Time Traveller Returns"
"409",35,""
"410",35,""
"411",35,"I think that at that time none of us quite believed in the Time"
"412",35,"Machine. The fact is, the Time Traveller was one of those men who are"
"413",35,"too clever to be believed: you never felt that you saw all round him;"
"414",35,"you always suspected some subtle reserve, some ingenuity in ambush,"
"415",35,"behind his lucid frankness. Had Filby shown the model and explained the"
"416",35,"matter in the Time Traveller’s words, we should have shown _him_ far"
"417",35,"less scepticism. For we should have perceived his motives: a"
"418",35,"pork-butcher could understand Filby. But the Time Traveller had more"
"419",35,"than a touch of whim among his elements, and we distrusted him. Things"
"420",35,"that would have made the fame of a less clever man seemed tricks in his"
"421",35,"hands. It is a mistake to do things too easily. The serious people who"
"422",35,"took him seriously never felt quite sure of his deportment; they were"
"423",35,"somehow aware that trusting their reputations for judgment with him was"
"424",35,"like furnishing a nursery with eggshell china. So I don’t think any of"
"425",35,"us said very much about time travelling in the interval between that"
"426",35,"Thursday and the next, though its odd potentialities ran, no doubt, in"
"427",35,"most of our minds: its plausibility, that is, its practical"
"428",35,"incredibleness, the curious possibilities of anachronism and of utter"
"429",35,"confusion it suggested. For my own part, I was particularly preoccupied"
"430",35,"with the trick of the model. That I remember discussing with the"
"431",35,"Medical Man, whom I met on Friday at the Linnæan. He said he had seen a"
"432",35,"similar thing at Tübingen, and laid considerable stress on the"
"433",35,"blowing-out of the candle. But how the trick was done he could not"
"434",35,"explain."
"435",35,""
"436",35,"The next Thursday I went again to Richmond—I suppose I was one of the"
"437",35,"Time Traveller’s most constant guests—and, arriving late, found four or"
"438",35,"five men already assembled in his drawing-room. The Medical Man was"
"439",35,"standing before the fire with a sheet of paper in one hand and his"
"440",35,"watch in the other. I looked round for the Time Traveller, and—“It’s"
"441",35,"half-past seven now,” said the Medical Man. “I suppose we’d better have"
"442",35,"dinner?”"
"443",35,""
"444",35,"“Where’s——?” said I, naming our host."
"445",35,""
"446",35,"“You’ve just come? It’s rather odd. He’s unavoidably detained. He asks"
"447",35,"me in this note to lead off with dinner at seven if he’s not back. Says"
"448",35,"he’ll explain when he comes.”"
"449",35,""
"450",35,"“It seems a pity to let the dinner spoil,” said the Editor of a"
"451",35,"well-known daily paper; and thereupon the Doctor rang the bell."
"452",35,""
"453",35,"The Psychologist was the only person besides the Doctor and myself who"
"454",35,"had attended the previous dinner. The other men were Blank, the Editor"
"455",35,"aforementioned, a certain journalist, and another—a quiet, shy man with"
"456",35,"a beard—whom I didn’t know, and who, as far as my observation went,"
"457",35,"never opened his mouth all the evening. There was some speculation at"
"458",35,"the dinner-table about the Time Traveller’s absence, and I suggested"
"459",35,"time travelling, in a half-jocular spirit. The Editor wanted that"
"460",35,"explained to him, and the Psychologist volunteered a wooden account of"
"461",35,"the “ingenious paradox and trick” we had witnessed that day week. He"
"462",35,"was in the midst of his exposition when the door from the corridor"
"463",35,"opened slowly and without noise. I was facing the door, and saw it"
"464",35,"first. “Hallo!” I said. “At last!” And the door opened wider, and the"
"465",35,"Time Traveller stood before us. I gave a cry of surprise. “Good"
"466",35,"heavens! man, what’s the matter?” cried the Medical Man, who saw him"
"467",35,"next. And the whole tableful turned towards the door."
"468",35,""
"469",35,"He was in an amazing plight. His coat was dusty and dirty, and smeared"
"470",35,"with green down the sleeves; his hair disordered, and as it seemed to"
"471",35,"me greyer—either with dust and dirt or because its colour had actually"
"472",35,"faded. His face was ghastly pale; his chin had a brown cut on it—a cut"
"473",35,"half-healed; his expression was haggard and drawn, as by intense"
"474",35,"suffering. For a moment he hesitated in the doorway, as if he had been"
"475",35,"dazzled by the light. Then he came into the room. He walked with just"
"476",35,"such a limp as I have seen in footsore tramps. We stared at him in"
"477",35,"silence, expecting him to speak."
"478",35,""
"479",35,"He said not a word, but came painfully to the table, and made a motion"
"480",35,"towards the wine. The Editor filled a glass of champagne, and pushed it"
"481",35,"towards him. He drained it, and it seemed to do him good: for he looked"
"482",35,"round the table, and the ghost of his old smile flickered across his"
"483",35,"face. “What on earth have you been up to, man?” said the Doctor. The"
"484",35,"Time Traveller did not seem to hear. “Don’t let me disturb you,” he"
"485",35,"said, with a certain faltering articulation. “I’m all right.” He"
"486",35,"stopped, held out his glass for more, and took it off at a draught."
"487",35,"“That’s good,” he said. His eyes grew brighter, and a faint colour came"
"488",35,"into his cheeks. His glance flickered over our faces with a certain"
"489",35,"dull approval, and then went round the warm and comfortable room. Then"
"490",35,"he spoke again, still as it were feeling his way among his words. “I’m"
"491",35,"going to wash and dress, and then I’ll come down and explain things...."
"492",35,"Save me some of that mutton. I’m starving for a bit of meat.”"
"493",35,""
"494",35,"He looked across at the Editor, who was a rare visitor, and hoped he"
"495",35,"was all right. The Editor began a question. “Tell you presently,” said"
"496",35,"the Time Traveller. “I’m—funny! Be all right in a minute.”"
"497",35,""
"498",35,"He put down his glass, and walked towards the staircase door. Again I"
"499",35,"remarked his lameness and the soft padding sound of his footfall, and"
"500",35,"standing up in my place, I saw his feet as he went out. He had nothing"
"501",35,"on them but a pair of tattered, blood-stained socks. Then the door"
"502",35,"closed upon him. I had half a mind to follow, till I remembered how he"
"503",35,"detested any fuss about himself. For a minute, perhaps, my mind was"
"504",35,"wool-gathering. Then, “Remarkable Behaviour of an Eminent Scientist,” I"
"505",35,"heard the Editor say, thinking (after his wont) in headlines. And this"
"506",35,"brought my attention back to the bright dinner-table."
"507",35,""
"508",35,"“What’s the game?” said the Journalist. “Has he been doing the Amateur"
"509",35,"Cadger? I don’t follow.” I met the eye of the Psychologist, and read my"
"510",35,"own interpretation in his face. I thought of the Time Traveller limping"
"511",35,"painfully upstairs. I don’t think anyone else had noticed his lameness."
"512",35,""
"513",35,"The first to recover completely from this surprise was the Medical Man,"
"514",35,"who rang the bell—the Time Traveller hated to have servants waiting at"
"515",35,"dinner—for a hot plate. At that the Editor turned to his knife and fork"
"516",35,"with a grunt, and the Silent Man followed suit. The dinner was resumed."
"517",35,"Conversation was exclamatory for a little while with gaps of"
"518",35,"wonderment; and then the Editor got fervent in his curiosity. “Does our"
"519",35,"friend eke out his modest income with a crossing? or has he his"
"520",35,"Nebuchadnezzar phases?” he inquired. “I feel assured it’s this business"
"521",35,"of the Time Machine,” I said, and took up the Psychologist’s account of"
"522",35,"our previous meeting. The new guests were frankly incredulous. The"
"523",35,"Editor raised objections. “What _was_ this time travelling? A man"
"524",35,"couldn’t cover himself with dust by rolling in a paradox, could he?”"
"525",35,"And then, as the idea came home to him, he resorted to caricature."
"526",35,"Hadn’t they any clothes-brushes in the Future? The Journalist too,"
"527",35,"would not believe at any price, and joined the Editor in the easy work"
"528",35,"of heaping ridicule on the whole thing. They were both the new kind of"
"529",35,"journalist—very joyous, irreverent young men. “Our Special"
"530",35,"Correspondent in the Day after Tomorrow reports,” the Journalist was"
"531",35,"saying—or rather shouting—when the Time Traveller came back. He was"
"532",35,"dressed in ordinary evening clothes, and nothing save his haggard look"
"533",35,"remained of the change that had startled me."
"534",35,""
"535",35,"“I say,” said the Editor hilariously, “these chaps here say you have"
"536",35,"been travelling into the middle of next week! Tell us all about little"
"537",35,"Rosebery, will you? What will you take for the lot?”"
"538",35,""
"539",35,"The Time Traveller came to the place reserved for him without a word."
"540",35,"He smiled quietly, in his old way. “Where’s my mutton?” he said. “What"
"541",35,"a treat it is to stick a fork into meat again!”"
"542",35,""
"543",35,"“Story!” cried the Editor."
"544",35,""
"545",35,"“Story be damned!” said the Time Traveller. “I want something to eat. I"
"546",35,"won’t say a word until I get some peptone into my arteries. Thanks. And"
"547",35,"the salt.”"
"548",35,""
"549",35,"“One word,” said I. “Have you been time travelling?”"
"550",35,""
"551",35,"“Yes,” said the Time Traveller, with his mouth full, nodding his head."
"552",35,""
"553",35,"“I’d give a shilling a line for a verbatim note,” said the Editor. The"
"554",35,"Time Traveller pushed his glass towards the Silent Man and rang it with"
"555",35,"his fingernail; at which the Silent Man, who had been staring at his"
"556",35,"face, started convulsively, and poured him wine. The rest of the dinner"
"557",35,"was uncomfortable. For my own part, sudden questions kept on rising to"
"558",35,"my lips, and I dare say it was the same with the others. The Journalist"
"559",35,"tried to relieve the tension by telling anecdotes of Hettie Potter. The"
"560",35,"Time Traveller devoted his attention to his dinner, and displayed the"
"561",35,"appetite of a tramp. The Medical Man smoked a cigarette, and watched"
"562",35,"the Time Traveller through his eyelashes. The Silent Man seemed even"
"563",35,"more clumsy than usual, and drank champagne with regularity and"
"564",35,"determination out of sheer nervousness. At last the Time Traveller"
"565",35,"pushed his plate away, and looked round us. “I suppose I must"
"566",35,"apologise,” he said. “I was simply starving. I’ve had a most amazing"
"567",35,"time.” He reached out his hand for a cigar, and cut the end. “But come"
"568",35,"into the smoking-room. It’s too long a story to tell over greasy"
"569",35,"plates.” And ringing the bell in passing, he led the way into the"
"570",35,"adjoining room."
"571",35,""
"572",35,"“You have told Blank, and Dash, and Chose about the machine?” he said"
"573",35,"to me, leaning back in his easy-chair and naming the three new guests."
"574",35,""
"575",35,"“But the thing’s a mere paradox,” said the Editor."
"576",35,""
"577",35,"“I can’t argue tonight. I don’t mind telling you the story, but I can’t"
"578",35,"argue. I will,” he went on, “tell you the story of what has happened to"
"579",35,"me, if you like, but you must refrain from interruptions. I want to"
"580",35,"tell it. Badly. Most of it will sound like lying. So be it! It’s"
"581",35,"true—every word of it, all the same. I was in my laboratory at four"
"582",35,"o’clock, and since then … I’ve lived eight days … such days as no human"
"583",35,"being ever lived before! I’m nearly worn out, but I shan’t sleep till"
"584",35,"I’ve told this thing over to you. Then I shall go to bed. But no"
"585",35,"interruptions! Is it agreed?”"
"586",35,""
"587",35,"“Agreed,” said the Editor, and the rest of us echoed “Agreed.” And with"
"588",35,"that the Time Traveller began his story as I have set it forth. He sat"
"589",35,"back in his chair at first, and spoke like a weary man. Afterwards he"
"590",35,"got more animated. In writing it down I feel with only too much"
"591",35,"keenness the inadequacy of pen and ink—and, above all, my own"
"592",35,"inadequacy—to express its quality. You read, I will suppose,"
"593",35,"attentively enough; but you cannot see the speaker’s white, sincere"
"594",35,"face in the bright circle of the little lamp, nor hear the intonation"
"595",35,"of his voice. You cannot know how his expression followed the turns of"
"596",35,"his story! Most of us hearers were in shadow, for the candles in the"
"597",35,"smoking-room had not been lighted, and only the face of the Journalist"
"598",35,"and the legs of the Silent Man from the knees downward were"
"599",35,"illuminated. At first we glanced now and again at each other. After a"
"600",35,"time we ceased to do that, and looked only at the Time Traveller’s"
"601",35,"face."
"602",35,""
"603",35,""
"604",35,""
"605",35,""
"606",35," IV."
"607",35," Time Travelling"
"608",35,""
"609",35,""
"610",35,"“I told some of you last Thursday of the principles of the Time"
"611",35,"Machine, and showed you the actual thing itself, incomplete in the"
"612",35,"workshop. There it is now, a little travel-worn, truly; and one of the"
"613",35,"ivory bars is cracked, and a brass rail bent; but the rest of it’s"
"614",35,"sound enough. I expected to finish it on Friday; but on Friday, when"
"615",35,"the putting together was nearly done, I found that one of the nickel"
"616",35,"bars was exactly one inch too short, and this I had to get remade; so"
"617",35,"that the thing was not complete until this morning. It was at ten"
"618",35,"o’clock today that the first of all Time Machines began its career. I"
"619",35,"gave it a last tap, tried all the screws again, put one more drop of"
"620",35,"oil on the quartz rod, and sat myself in the saddle. I suppose a"
"621",35,"suicide who holds a pistol to his skull feels much the same wonder at"
"622",35,"what will come next as I felt then. I took the starting lever in one"
"623",35,"hand and the stopping one in the other, pressed the first, and almost"
"624",35,"immediately the second. I seemed to reel; I felt a nightmare sensation"
"625",35,"of falling; and, looking round, I saw the laboratory exactly as before."
"626",35,"Had anything happened? For a moment I suspected that my intellect had"
"627",35,"tricked me. Then I noted the clock. A moment before, as it seemed, it"
"628",35,"had stood at a minute or so past ten; now it was nearly half-past"
"629",35,"three!"
"630",35,""
"631",35,"“I drew a breath, set my teeth, gripped the starting lever with both"
"632",35,"hands, and went off with a thud. The laboratory got hazy and went dark."
"633",35,"Mrs. Watchett came in and walked, apparently without seeing me, towards"
"634",35,"the garden door. I suppose it took her a minute or so to traverse the"
"635",35,"place, but to me she seemed to shoot across the room like a rocket. I"
"636",35,"pressed the lever over to its extreme position. The night came like the"
"637",35,"turning out of a lamp, and in another moment came tomorrow. The"
"638",35,"laboratory grew faint and hazy, then fainter and ever fainter. Tomorrow"
"639",35,"night came black, then day again, night again, day again, faster and"
"640",35,"faster still. An eddying murmur filled my ears, and a strange, dumb"
"641",35,"confusedness descended on my mind."
"642",35,""
"643",35,"“I am afraid I cannot convey the peculiar sensations of time"
"644",35,"travelling. They are excessively unpleasant. There is a feeling exactly"
"645",35,"like that one has upon a switchback—of a helpless headlong motion! I"
"646",35,"felt the same horrible anticipation, too, of an imminent smash. As I"
"647",35,"put on pace, night followed day like the flapping of a black wing. The"
"648",35,"dim suggestion of the laboratory seemed presently to fall away from me,"
"649",35,"and I saw the sun hopping swiftly across the sky, leaping it every"
"650",35,"minute, and every minute marking a day. I supposed the laboratory had"
"651",35,"been destroyed and I had come into the open air. I had a dim impression"
"652",35,"of scaffolding, but I was already going too fast to be conscious of any"
"653",35,"moving things. The slowest snail that ever crawled dashed by too fast"
"654",35,"for me. The twinkling succession of darkness and light was excessively"
"655",35,"painful to the eye. Then, in the intermittent darknesses, I saw the"
"656",35,"moon spinning swiftly through her quarters from new to full, and had a"
"657",35,"faint glimpse of the circling stars. Presently, as I went on, still"
"658",35,"gaining velocity, the palpitation of night and day merged into one"
"659",35,"continuous greyness; the sky took on a wonderful deepness of blue, a"
"660",35,"splendid luminous colour like that of early twilight; the jerking sun"
"661",35,"became a streak of fire, a brilliant arch, in space; the moon a fainter"
"662",35,"fluctuating band; and I could see nothing of the stars, save now and"
"663",35,"then a brighter circle flickering in the blue."
"664",35,""
"665",35,"“The landscape was misty and vague. I was still on the hillside upon"
"666",35,"which this house now stands, and the shoulder rose above me grey and"
"667",35,"dim. I saw trees growing and changing like puffs of vapour, now brown,"
"668",35,"now green; they grew, spread, shivered, and passed away. I saw huge"
"669",35,"buildings rise up faint and fair, and pass like dreams. The whole"
"670",35,"surface of the earth seemed changed—melting and flowing under my eyes."
"671",35,"The little hands upon the dials that registered my speed raced round"
"672",35,"faster and faster. Presently I noted that the sun belt swayed up and"
"673",35,"down, from solstice to solstice, in a minute or less, and that"
"674",35,"consequently my pace was over a year a minute; and minute by minute the"
"675",35,"white snow flashed across the world, and vanished, and was followed by"
"676",35,"the bright, brief green of spring."
"677",35,""
"678",35,"“The unpleasant sensations of the start were less poignant now. They"
"679",35,"merged at last into a kind of hysterical exhilaration. I remarked,"
"680",35,"indeed, a clumsy swaying of the machine, for which I was unable to"
"681",35,"account. But my mind was too confused to attend to it, so with a kind"
"682",35,"of madness growing upon me, I flung myself into futurity. At first I"
"683",35,"scarce thought of stopping, scarce thought of anything but these new"
"684",35,"sensations. But presently a fresh series of impressions grew up in my"
"685",35,"mind—a certain curiosity and therewith a certain dread—until at last"
"686",35,"they took complete possession of me. What strange developments of"
"687",35,"humanity, what wonderful advances upon our rudimentary civilisation, I"
"688",35,"thought, might not appear when I came to look nearly into the dim"
"689",35,"elusive world that raced and fluctuated before my eyes! I saw great and"
"690",35,"splendid architecture rising about me, more massive than any buildings"
"691",35,"of our own time, and yet, as it seemed, built of glimmer and mist. I"
"692",35,"saw a richer green flow up the hillside, and remain there, without any"
"693",35,"wintry intermission. Even through the veil of my confusion the earth"
"694",35,"seemed very fair. And so my mind came round to the business of"
"695",35,"stopping."
"696",35,""
"697",35,"“The peculiar risk lay in the possibility of my finding some substance"
"698",35,"in the space which I, or the machine, occupied. So long as I travelled"
"699",35,"at a high velocity through time, this scarcely mattered: I was, so to"
"700",35,"speak, attenuated—was slipping like a vapour through the interstices of"
"701",35,"intervening substances! But to come to a stop involved the jamming of"
"702",35,"myself, molecule by molecule, into whatever lay in my way; meant"
"703",35,"bringing my atoms into such intimate contact with those of the obstacle"
"704",35,"that a profound chemical reaction—possibly a far-reaching"
"705",35,"explosion—would result, and blow myself and my apparatus out of all"
"706",35,"possible dimensions—into the Unknown. This possibility had occurred to"
"707",35,"me again and again while I was making the machine; but then I had"
"708",35,"cheerfully accepted it as an unavoidable risk—one of the risks a man"
"709",35,"has got to take! Now the risk was inevitable, I no longer saw it in the"
"710",35,"same cheerful light. The fact is that, insensibly, the absolute"
"711",35,"strangeness of everything, the sickly jarring and swaying of the"
"712",35,"machine, above all, the feeling of prolonged falling, had absolutely"
"713",35,"upset my nerves. I told myself that I could never stop, and with a gust"
"714",35,"of petulance I resolved to stop forthwith. Like an impatient fool, I"
"715",35,"lugged over the lever, and incontinently the thing went reeling over,"
"716",35,"and I was flung headlong through the air."
"717",35,""
"718",35,"“There was the sound of a clap of thunder in my ears. I may have been"
"719",35,"stunned for a moment. A pitiless hail was hissing round me, and I was"
"720",35,"sitting on soft turf in front of the overset machine. Everything still"
"721",35,"seemed grey, but presently I remarked that the confusion in my ears was"
"722",35,"gone. I looked round me. I was on what seemed to be a little lawn in a"
"723",35,"garden, surrounded by rhododendron bushes, and I noticed that their"
"724",35,"mauve and purple blossoms were dropping in a shower under the beating"
"725",35,"of the hailstones. The rebounding, dancing hail hung in a little cloud"
"726",35,"over the machine, and drove along the ground like smoke. In a moment I"
"727",35,"was wet to the skin. ‘Fine hospitality,’ said I, ‘to a man who has"
"728",35,"travelled innumerable years to see you.’"
"729",35,""
"730",35,"“Presently I thought what a fool I was to get wet. I stood up and"
"731",35,"looked round me. A colossal figure, carved apparently in some white"
"732",35,"stone, loomed indistinctly beyond the rhododendrons through the hazy"
"733",35,"downpour. But all else of the world was invisible."
"734",35,""
"735",35,"“My sensations would be hard to describe. As the columns of hail grew"
"736",35,"thinner, I saw the white figure more distinctly. It was very large, for"
"737",35,"a silver birch-tree touched its shoulder. It was of white marble, in"
"738",35,"shape something like a winged sphinx, but the wings, instead of being"
"739",35,"carried vertically at the sides, were spread so that it seemed to"
"740",35,"hover. The pedestal, it appeared to me, was of bronze, and was thick"
"741",35,"with verdigris. It chanced that the face was towards me; the sightless"
"742",35,"eyes seemed to watch me; there was the faint shadow of a smile on the"
"743",35,"lips. It was greatly weather-worn, and that imparted an unpleasant"
"744",35,"suggestion of disease. I stood looking at it for a little space—half a"
"745",35,"minute, perhaps, or half an hour. It seemed to advance and to recede as"
"746",35,"the hail drove before it denser or thinner. At last I tore my eyes from"
"747",35,"it for a moment, and saw that the hail curtain had worn threadbare, and"
"748",35,"that the sky was lightening with the promise of the sun."
"749",35,""
"750",35,"“I looked up again at the crouching white shape, and the full temerity"
"751",35,"of my voyage came suddenly upon me. What might appear when that hazy"
"752",35,"curtain was altogether withdrawn? What might not have happened to men?"
"753",35,"What if cruelty had grown into a common passion? What if in this"
"754",35,"interval the race had lost its manliness, and had developed into"
"755",35,"something inhuman, unsympathetic, and overwhelmingly powerful? I might"
"756",35,"seem some old-world savage animal, only the more dreadful and"
"757",35,"disgusting for our common likeness—a foul creature to be incontinently"
"758",35,"slain."
"759",35,""
"760",35,"“Already I saw other vast shapes—huge buildings with intricate parapets"
"761",35,"and tall columns, with a wooded hillside dimly creeping in upon me"
"762",35,"through the lessening storm. I was seized with a panic fear. I turned"
"763",35,"frantically to the Time Machine, and strove hard to readjust it. As I"
"764",35,"did so the shafts of the sun smote through the thunderstorm. The grey"
"765",35,"downpour was swept aside and vanished like the trailing garments of a"
"766",35,"ghost. Above me, in the intense blue of the summer sky, some faint"
"767",35,"brown shreds of cloud whirled into nothingness. The great buildings"
"768",35,"about me stood out clear and distinct, shining with the wet of the"
"769",35,"thunderstorm, and picked out in white by the unmelted hailstones piled"
"770",35,"along their courses. I felt naked in a strange world. I felt as perhaps"
"771",35,"a bird may feel in the clear air, knowing the hawk wings above and will"
"772",35,"swoop. My fear grew to frenzy. I took a breathing space, set my teeth,"
"773",35,"and again grappled fiercely, wrist and knee, with the machine. It gave"
"774",35,"under my desperate onset and turned over. It struck my chin violently."
"775",35,"One hand on the saddle, the other on the lever, I stood panting heavily"
"776",35,"in attitude to mount again."
"777",35,""
"778",35,"“But with this recovery of a prompt retreat my courage recovered. I"
"779",35,"looked more curiously and less fearfully at this world of the remote"
"780",35,"future. In a circular opening, high up in the wall of the nearer house,"
"781",35,"I saw a group of figures clad in rich soft robes. They had seen me, and"
"782",35,"their faces were directed towards me."
"783",35,""
"784",35,"“Then I heard voices approaching me. Coming through the bushes by the"
"785",35,"White Sphinx were the heads and shoulders of men running. One of these"
"786",35,"emerged in a pathway leading straight to the little lawn upon which I"
"787",35,"stood with my machine. He was a slight creature—perhaps four feet"
"788",35,"high—clad in a purple tunic, girdled at the waist with a leather belt."
"789",35,"Sandals or buskins—I could not clearly distinguish which—were on his"
"790",35,"feet; his legs were bare to the knees, and his head was bare. Noticing"
"791",35,"that, I noticed for the first time how warm the air was."
"792",35,""
"793",35,"“He struck me as being a very beautiful and graceful creature, but"
"794",35,"indescribably frail. His flushed face reminded me of the more beautiful"
"795",35,"kind of consumptive—that hectic beauty of which we used to hear so"
"796",35,"much. At the sight of him I suddenly regained confidence. I took my"
"797",35,"hands from the machine."
"798",35,""
"799",35,""

"801",35,""
"802",35," V."
"803",35," In the Golden Age"
"804",35,""
"805",35,""
"806",35,"“In another moment we were standing face to face, I and this fragile"
"807",35,"thing out of futurity. He came straight up to me and laughed into my"
"808",35,"eyes. The absence from his bearing of any sign of fear struck me at"
"809",35,"once. Then he turned to the two others who were following him and spoke"
"810",35,"to them in a strange and very sweet and liquid tongue."
"811",35,""
"812",35,"“There were others coming, and presently a little group of perhaps"
"813",35,"eight or ten of these exquisite creatures were about me. One of them"
"814",35,"addressed me. It came into my head, oddly enough, that my voice was too"
"815",35,"harsh and deep for them. So I shook my head, and, pointing to my ears,"
"816",35,"shook it again. He came a step forward, hesitated, and then touched my"
"817",35,"hand. Then I felt other soft little tentacles upon my back and"
"818",35,"shoulders. They wanted to make sure I was real. There was nothing in"
"819",35,"this at all alarming. Indeed, there was something in these pretty"
"820",35,"little people that inspired confidence—a graceful gentleness, a certain"
"821",35,"childlike ease. And besides, they looked so frail that I could fancy"
"822",35,"myself flinging the whole dozen of them about like ninepins. But I made"
"823",35,"a sudden motion to warn them when I saw their little pink hands feeling"
"824",35,"at the Time Machine. Happily then, when it was not too late, I thought"
"825",35,"of a danger I had hitherto forgotten, and reaching over the bars of the"
"826",35,"machine I unscrewed the little levers that would set it in motion, and"
"827",35,"put these in my pocket. Then I turned again to see what I could do in"
"828",35,"the way of communication."
"829",35,""
"830",35,"“And then, looking more nearly into their features, I saw some further"
"831",35,"peculiarities in their Dresden china type of prettiness. Their hair,"
"832",35,"which was uniformly curly, came to a sharp end at the neck and cheek;"
"833",35,"there was not the faintest suggestion of it on the face, and their ears"
"834",35,"were singularly minute. The mouths were small, with bright red, rather"
"835",35,"thin lips, and the little chins ran to a point. The eyes were large and"
"836",35,"mild; and—this may seem egotism on my part—I fancied even that there"
"837",35,"was a certain lack of the interest I might have expected in them."
"838",35,""
"839",35,"“As they made no effort to communicate with me, but simply stood round"
"840",35,"me smiling and speaking in soft cooing notes to each other, I began the"
"841",35,"conversation. I pointed to the Time Machine and to myself. Then,"
"842",35,"hesitating for a moment how to express Time, I pointed to the sun. At"
"843",35,"once a quaintly pretty little figure in chequered purple and white"
"844",35,"followed my gesture, and then astonished me by imitating the sound of"
"845",35,"thunder."
"846",35,""
"847",35,"“For a moment I was staggered, though the import of his gesture was"
"848",35,"plain enough. The question had come into my mind abruptly: were these"
"849",35,"creatures fools? You may hardly understand how it took me. You see, I"
"850",35,"had always anticipated that the people of the year Eight Hundred and"
"851",35,"Two Thousand odd would be incredibly in front of us in knowledge, art,"
"852",35,"everything. Then one of them suddenly asked me a question that showed"
"853",35,"him to be on the intellectual level of one of our five-year-old"
"854",35,"children—asked me, in fact, if I had come from the sun in a"
"855",35,"thunderstorm! It let loose the judgment I had suspended upon their"
"856",35,"clothes, their frail light limbs, and fragile features. A flow of"
"857",35,"disappointment rushed across my mind. For a moment I felt that I had"
"858",35,"built the Time Machine in vain."
"859",35,""
"860",35,"“I nodded, pointed to the sun, and gave them such a vivid rendering of"
"861",35,"a thunderclap as startled them. They all withdrew a pace or so and"
"862",35,"bowed. Then came one laughing towards me, carrying a chain of beautiful"
"863",35,"flowers altogether new to me, and put it about my neck. The idea was"
"864",35,"received with melodious applause; and presently they were all running"
"865",35,"to and fro for flowers, and laughingly flinging them upon me until I"
"866",35,"was almost smothered with blossom. You who have never seen the like can"
"867",35,"scarcely imagine what delicate and wonderful flowers countless years of"
"868",35,"culture had created. Then someone suggested that their plaything should"
"869",35,"be exhibited in the nearest building, and so I was led past the sphinx"
"870",35,"of white marble, which had seemed to watch me all the while with a"
"871",35,"smile at my astonishment, towards a vast grey edifice of fretted stone."
"872",35,"As I went with them the memory of my confident anticipations of a"
"873",35,"profoundly grave and intellectual posterity came, with irresistible"
"874",35,"merriment, to my mind."
"875",35,""
"876",35,"“The building had a huge entry, and was altogether of colossal"
"877",35,"dimensions. I was naturally most occupied with the growing crowd of"
"878",35,"little people, and with the big open portals that yawned before me"
"879",35,"shadowy and mysterious. My general impression of the world I saw over"
"880",35,"their heads was a tangled waste of beautiful bushes and flowers, a long"
"881",35,"neglected and yet weedless garden. I saw a number of tall spikes of"
"882",35,"strange white flowers, measuring a foot perhaps across the spread of"
"883",35,"the waxen petals. They grew scattered, as if wild, among the variegated"
"884",35,"shrubs, but, as I say, I did not examine them closely at this time. The"
"885",35,"Time Machine was left deserted on the turf among the rhododendrons."
"886",35,""
"887",35,"“The arch of the doorway was richly carved, but naturally I did not"
"888",35,"observe the carving very narrowly, though I fancied I saw suggestions"
"889",35,"of old Phœnician decorations as I passed through, and it struck me that"
"890",35,"they were very badly broken and weather-worn. Several more brightly"
"891",35,"clad people met me in the doorway, and so we entered, I, dressed in"
"892",35,"dingy nineteenth-century garments, looking grotesque enough, garlanded"
"893",35,"with flowers, and surrounded by an eddying mass of bright,"
"894",35,"soft-coloured robes and shining white limbs, in a melodious whirl of"
"895",35,"laughter and laughing speech."
"896",35,""
"897",35,"“The big doorway opened into a proportionately great hall hung with"
"898",35,"brown. The roof was in shadow, and the windows, partially glazed with"
"899",35,"coloured glass and partially unglazed, admitted a tempered light. The"
"900",35,"floor was made up of huge blocks of some very hard white metal, not"
"901",35,"plates nor slabs—blocks, and it was so much worn, as I judged by the"
"902",35,"going to and fro of past generations, as to be deeply channelled along"
"903",35,"the more frequented ways. Transverse to the length were innumerable"
"904",35,"tables made of slabs of polished stone, raised, perhaps, a foot from"
"905",35,"the floor, and upon these were heaps of fruits. Some I recognised as a"
"906",35,"kind of hypertrophied raspberry and orange, but for the most part they"
"907",35,"were strange."
"908",35,""
"909",35,"“Between the tables was scattered a great number of cushions. Upon"
"910",35,"these my conductors seated themselves, signing for me to do likewise."
"911",35,"With a pretty absence of ceremony they began to eat the fruit with"
"912",35,"their hands, flinging peel and stalks, and so forth, into the round"
"913",35,"openings in the sides of the tables. I was not loath to follow their"
"914",35,"example, for I felt thirsty and hungry. As I did so I surveyed the hall"
"915",35,"at my leisure."
"916",35,""
"917",35,"“And perhaps the thing that struck me most was its dilapidated look."
"918",35,"The stained-glass windows, which displayed only a geometrical pattern,"
"919",35,"were broken in many places, and the curtains that hung across the lower"
"920",35,"end were thick with dust. And it caught my eye that the corner of the"
"921",35,"marble table near me was fractured. Nevertheless, the general effect"
"922",35,"was extremely rich and picturesque. There were, perhaps, a couple of"
"923",35,"hundred people dining in the hall, and most of them, seated as near to"
"924",35,"me as they could come, were watching me with interest, their little"
"925",35,"eyes shining over the fruit they were eating. All were clad in the same"
"926",35,"soft, and yet strong, silky material."
"927",35,""
"928",35,"“Fruit, by the bye, was all their diet. These people of the remote"
"929",35,"future were strict vegetarians, and while I was with them, in spite of"
"930",35,"some carnal cravings, I had to be frugivorous also. Indeed, I found"
"931",35,"afterwards that horses, cattle, sheep, dogs, had followed the"
"932",35,"Ichthyosaurus into extinction. But the fruits were very delightful;"
"933",35,"one, in particular, that seemed to be in season all the time I was"
"934",35,"there—a floury thing in a three-sided husk—was especially good, and I"
"935",35,"made it my staple. At first I was puzzled by all these strange fruits,"
"936",35,"and by the strange flowers I saw, but later I began to perceive their"
"937",35,"import."
"938",35,""
"939",35,"“However, I am telling you of my fruit dinner in the distant future"
"940",35,"now. So soon as my appetite was a little checked, I determined to make"
"941",35,"a resolute attempt to learn the speech of these new men of mine."
"942",35,"Clearly that was the next thing to do. The fruits seemed a convenient"
"943",35,"thing to begin upon, and holding one of these up I began a series of"
"944",35,"interrogative sounds and gestures. I had some considerable difficulty"
"945",35,"in conveying my meaning. At first my efforts met with a stare of"
"946",35,"surprise or inextinguishable laughter, but presently a fair-haired"
"947",35,"little creature seemed to grasp my intention and repeated a name. They"
"948",35,"had to chatter and explain the business at great length to each other,"
"949",35,"and my first attempts to make the exquisite little sounds of their"
"950",35,"language caused an immense amount of genuine, if uncivil, amusement."
"951",35,"However, I felt like a schoolmaster amidst children, and persisted, and"
"952",35,"presently I had a score of noun substantives at least at my command;"
"953",35,"and then I got to demonstrative pronouns, and even the verb ‘to eat.’"
"954",35,"But it was slow work, and the little people soon tired and wanted to"
"955",35,"get away from my interrogations, so I determined, rather of necessity,"
"956",35,"to let them give their lessons in little doses when they felt inclined."
"957",35,"And very little doses I found they were before long, for I never met"
"958",35,"people more indolent or more easily fatigued."
"959",35,""
"960",35,""
"961",35,""
"962",35,""
"963",35," VI."
"964",35," The Sunset of Mankind"
"965",35,""
"966",35,""
"967",35,"“A queer thing I soon discovered about my little hosts, and that was"
"968",35,"their lack of interest. They would come to me with eager cries of"
"969",35,"astonishment, like children, but, like children they would soon stop"
"970",35,"examining me, and wander away after some other toy. The dinner and my"
"971",35,"conversational beginnings ended, I noted for the first time that almost"
"972",35,"all those who had surrounded me at first were gone. It is odd, too, how"
"973",35,"speedily I came to disregard these little people. I went out through"
"974",35,"the portal into the sunlit world again as soon as my hunger was"
"975",35,"satisfied. I was continually meeting more of these men of the future,"
"976",35,"who would follow me a little distance, chatter and laugh about me, and,"
"977",35,"having smiled and gesticulated in a friendly way, leave me again to my"
"978",35,"own devices."
"979",35,""
"980",35,"“The calm of evening was upon the world as I emerged from the great"
"981",35,"hall, and the scene was lit by the warm glow of the setting sun. At"
"982",35,"first things were very confusing. Everything was so entirely different"
"983",35,"from the world I had known—even the flowers. The big building I had"
"984",35,"left was situated on the slope of a broad river valley, but the Thames"
"985",35,"had shifted, perhaps, a mile from its present position. I resolved to"
"986",35,"mount to the summit of a crest, perhaps a mile and a half away, from"
"987",35,"which I could get a wider view of this our planet in the year Eight"
"988",35,"Hundred and Two Thousand Seven Hundred and One, A.D. For that, I should"
"989",35,"explain, was the date the little dials of my machine recorded."
"990",35,""
"991",35,"“As I walked I was watching for every impression that could possibly"
"992",35,"help to explain the condition of ruinous splendour in which I found the"
"993",35,"world—for ruinous it was. A little way up the hill, for instance, was a"
"994",35,"great heap of granite, bound together by masses of aluminium, a vast"
"995",35,"labyrinth of precipitous walls and crumpled heaps, amidst which were"
"996",35,"thick heaps of very beautiful pagoda-like plants—nettles possibly—but"
"997",35,"wonderfully tinted with brown about the leaves, and incapable of"
"998",35,"stinging. It was evidently the derelict remains of some vast structure,"
"999",35,"to what end built I could not determine. It was here that I was"
"1000",35,"destined, at a later date, to have a very strange experience—the first"
"1001",35,"intimation of a still stranger discovery—but of that I will speak in"
"1002",35,"its proper place."
"1003",35,""
"1004",35,"“Looking round, with a sudden thought, from a terrace on which I rested"
"1005",35,"for a while, I realised that there were no small houses to be seen."
"1006",35,"Apparently the single house, and possibly even the household, had"
"1007",35,"vanished. Here and there among the greenery were palace-like buildings,"
"1008",35,"but the house and the cottage, which form such characteristic features"
"1009",35,"of our own English landscape, had disappeared."
"1010",35,""
"1011",35,"“‘Communism,’ said I to myself."
"1012",35,""
"1013",35,"“And on the heels of that came another thought. I looked at the"
"1014",35,"half-dozen little figures that were following me. Then, in a flash, I"
"1015",35,"perceived that all had the same form of costume, the same soft hairless"
"1016",35,"visage, and the same girlish rotundity of limb. It may seem strange,"
"1017",35,"perhaps, that I had not noticed this before. But everything was so"
"1018",35,"strange. Now, I saw the fact plainly enough. In costume, and in all the"
"1019",35,"differences of texture and bearing that now mark off the sexes from"
"1020",35,"each other, these people of the future were alike. And the children"
"1021",35,"seemed to my eyes to be but the miniatures of their parents. I judged"
"1022",35,"then that the children of that time were extremely precocious,"
"1023",35,"physically at least, and I found afterwards abundant verification of my"
"1024",35,"opinion."
"1025",35,""
"1026",35,"“Seeing the ease and security in which these people were living, I felt"
"1027",35,"that this close resemblance of the sexes was after all what one would"
"1028",35,"expect; for the strength of a man and the softness of a woman, the"
"1029",35,"institution of the family, and the differentiation of occupations are"
"1030",35,"mere militant necessities of an age of physical force. Where population"
"1031",35,"is balanced and abundant, much childbearing becomes an evil rather than"
"1032",35,"a blessing to the State; where violence comes but rarely and offspring"
"1033",35,"are secure, there is less necessity—indeed there is no necessity—for an"
"1034",35,"efficient family, and the specialisation of the sexes with reference to"
"1035",35,"their children’s needs disappears. We see some beginnings of this even"
"1036",35,"in our own time, and in this future age it was complete. This, I must"
"1037",35,"remind you, was my speculation at the time. Later, I was to appreciate"
"1038",35,"how far it fell short of the reality."
"1039",35,""
"1040",35,"“While I was musing upon these things, my attention was attracted by a"
"1041",35,"pretty little structure, like a well under a cupola. I thought in a"
"1042",35,"transitory way of the oddness of wells still existing, and then resumed"
"1043",35,"the thread of my speculations. There were no large buildings towards"
"1044",35,"the top of the hill, and as my walking powers were evidently"
"1045",35,"miraculous, I was presently left alone for the first time. With a"
"1046",35,"strange sense of freedom and adventure I pushed on up to the crest."
"1047",35,""
"1048",35,"“There I found a seat of some yellow metal that I did not recognise,"
"1049",35,"corroded in places with a kind of pinkish rust and half smothered in"
"1050",35,"soft moss, the arm-rests cast and filed into the resemblance of"
"1051",35,"griffins’ heads. I sat down on it, and I surveyed the broad view of our"
"1052",35,"old world under the sunset of that long day. It was as sweet and fair a"
"1053",35,"view as I have ever seen. The sun had already gone below the horizon"
"1054",35,"and the west was flaming gold, touched with some horizontal bars of"
"1055",35,"purple and crimson. Below was the valley of the Thames, in which the"
"1056",35,"river lay like a band of burnished steel. I have already spoken of the"
"1057",35,"great palaces dotted about among the variegated greenery, some in ruins"
"1058",35,"and some still occupied. Here and there rose a white or silvery figure"
"1059",35,"in the waste garden of the earth, here and there came the sharp"
"1060",35,"vertical line of some cupola or obelisk. There were no hedges, no signs"
"1061",35,"of proprietary rights, no evidences of agriculture; the whole earth had"
"1062",35,"become a garden."
"1063",35,""
"1064",35,"“So watching, I began to put my interpretation upon the things I had"
"1065",35,"seen, and as it shaped itself to me that evening, my interpretation was"
"1066",35,"something in this way. (Afterwards I found I had got only a half"
"1067",35,"truth—or only a glimpse of one facet of the truth.)"
"1068",35,""
"1069",35,"“It seemed to me that I had happened upon humanity upon the wane. The"
"1070",35,"ruddy sunset set me thinking of the sunset of mankind. For the first"
"1071",35,"time I began to realise an odd consequence of the social effort in"
"1072",35,"which we are at present engaged. And yet, come to think, it is a"
"1073",35,"logical consequence enough. Strength is the outcome of need; security"
"1074",35,"sets a premium on feebleness. The work of ameliorating the conditions"
"1075",35,"of life—the true civilising process that makes life more and more"
"1076",35,"secure—had gone steadily on to a climax. One triumph of a united"
"1077",35,"humanity over Nature had followed another. Things that are now mere"
"1078",35,"dreams had become projects deliberately put in hand and carried"
"1079",35,"forward. And the harvest was what I saw!"
"1080",35,""
"1081",35,"“After all, the sanitation and the agriculture of today are still in"
"1082",35,"the rudimentary stage. The science of our time has attacked but a"
"1083",35,"little department of the field of human disease, but, even so, it"
"1084",35,"spreads its operations very steadily and persistently. Our agriculture"
"1085",35,"and horticulture destroy a weed just here and there and cultivate"
"1086",35,"perhaps a score or so of wholesome plants, leaving the greater number"
"1087",35,"to fight out a balance as they can. We improve our favourite plants and"
"1088",35,"animals—and how few they are—gradually by selective breeding; now a new"
"1089",35,"and better peach, now a seedless grape, now a sweeter and larger"
"1090",35,"flower, now a more convenient breed of cattle. We improve them"
"1091",35,"gradually, because our ideals are vague and tentative, and our"
"1092",35,"knowledge is very limited; because Nature, too, is shy and slow in our"
"1093",35,"clumsy hands. Some day all this will be better organised, and still"
"1094",35,"better. That is the drift of the current in spite of the eddies. The"
"1095",35,"whole world will be intelligent, educated, and co-operating; things"
"1096",35,"will move faster and faster towards the subjugation of Nature. In the"
"1097",35,"end, wisely and carefully we shall readjust the balance of animal and"
"1098",35,"vegetable life to suit our human needs."
"1099",35,""
"1100",35,"“This adjustment, I say, must have been done, and done well; done"
"1101",35,"indeed for all Time, in the space of Time across which my machine had"
"1102",35,"leapt. The air was free from gnats, the earth from weeds or fungi;"
"1103",35,"everywhere were fruits and sweet and delightful flowers; brilliant"
"1104",35,"butterflies flew hither and thither. The ideal of preventive medicine"
"1105",35,"was attained. Diseases had been stamped out. I saw no evidence of any"
"1106",35,"contagious diseases during all my stay. And I shall have to tell you"
"1107",35,"later that even the processes of putrefaction and decay had been"
"1108",35,"profoundly affected by these changes."
"1109",35,""
"1110",35,"“Social triumphs, too, had been effected. I saw mankind housed in"
"1111",35,"splendid shelters, gloriously clothed, and as yet I had found them"
"1112",35,"engaged in no toil. There were no signs of struggle, neither social nor"
"1113",35,"economical struggle. The shop, the advertisement, traffic, all that"
"1114",35,"commerce which constitutes the body of our world, was gone. It was"
"1115",35,"natural on that golden evening that I should jump at the idea of a"
"1116",35,"social paradise. The difficulty of increasing population had been met,"
"1117",35,"I guessed, and population had ceased to increase."
"1118",35,""
"1119",35,"“But with this change in condition comes inevitably adaptations to the"
"1120",35,"change. What, unless biological science is a mass of errors, is the"
"1121",35,"cause of human intelligence and vigour? Hardship and freedom:"
"1122",35,"conditions under which the active, strong, and subtle survive and the"
"1123",35,"weaker go to the wall; conditions that put a premium upon the loyal"
"1124",35,"alliance of capable men, upon self-restraint, patience, and decision."
"1125",35,"And the institution of the family, and the emotions that arise therein,"
"1126",35,"the fierce jealousy, the tenderness for offspring, parental"
"1127",35,"self-devotion, all found their justification and support in the"
"1128",35,"imminent dangers of the young. _Now_, where are these imminent dangers?"
"1129",35,"There is a sentiment arising, and it will grow, against connubial"
"1130",35,"jealousy, against fierce maternity, against passion of all sorts;"
"1131",35,"unnecessary things now, and things that make us uncomfortable, savage"
"1132",35,"survivals, discords in a refined and pleasant life."
"1133",35,""
"1134",35,"“I thought of the physical slightness of the people, their lack of"
"1135",35,"intelligence, and those big abundant ruins, and it strengthened my"
"1136",35,"belief in a perfect conquest of Nature. For after the battle comes"
"1137",35,"Quiet. Humanity had been strong, energetic, and intelligent, and had"
"1138",35,"used all its abundant vitality to alter the conditions under which it"
"1139",35,"lived. And now came the reaction of the altered conditions."
"1140",35,""
"1141",35,"“Under the new conditions of perfect comfort and security, that"
"1142",35,"restless energy, that with us is strength, would become weakness. Even"
"1143",35,"in our own time certain tendencies and desires, once necessary to"
"1144",35,"survival, are a constant source of failure. Physical courage and the"
"1145",35,"love of battle, for instance, are no great help—may even be"
"1146",35,"hindrances—to a civilised man. And in a state of physical balance and"
"1147",35,"security, power, intellectual as well as physical, would be out of"
"1148",35,"place. For countless years I judged there had been no danger of war or"
"1149",35,"solitary violence, no danger from wild beasts, no wasting disease to"
"1150",35,"require strength of constitution, no need of toil. For such a life,"
"1151",35,"what we should call the weak are as well equipped as the strong, are"
"1152",35,"indeed no longer weak. Better equipped indeed they are, for the strong"
"1153",35,"would be fretted by an energy for which there was no outlet. No doubt"
"1154",35,"the exquisite beauty of the buildings I saw was the outcome of the last"
"1155",35,"surgings of the now purposeless energy of mankind before it settled"
"1156",35,"down into perfect harmony with the conditions under which it lived—the"
"1157",35,"flourish of that triumph which began the last great peace. This has"
"1158",35,"ever been the fate of energy in security; it takes to art and to"
"1159",35,"eroticism, and then come languor and decay."
"1160",35,""
"1161",35,"“Even this artistic impetus would at last die away—had almost died in"
"1162",35,"the Time I saw. To adorn themselves with flowers, to dance, to sing in"
"1163",35,"the sunlight: so much was left of the artistic spirit, and no more."
"1164",35,"Even that would fade in the end into a contented inactivity. We are"
"1165",35,"kept keen on the grindstone of pain and necessity, and it seemed to me"
"1166",35,"that here was that hateful grindstone broken at last!"
"1167",35,""
"1168",35,"“As I stood there in the gathering dark I thought that in this simple"
"1169",35,"explanation I had mastered the problem of the world—mastered the whole"
"1170",35,"secret of these delicious people. Possibly the checks they had devised"
"1171",35,"for the increase of population had succeeded too well, and their"
"1172",35,"numbers had rather diminished than kept stationary. That would account"
"1173",35,"for the abandoned ruins. Very simple was my explanation, and plausible"
"1174",35,"enough—as most wrong theories are!"
"1175",35,""
"1176",35,""
"1177",35,""
"1178",35,""
"1179",35," VII."
"1180",35," A Sudden Shock"
"1181",35,""
"1182",35,""
"1183",35,"“As I stood there musing over this too perfect triumph of man, the full"
"1184",35,"moon, yellow and gibbous, came up out of an overflow of silver light in"
"1185",35,"the north-east. The bright little figures ceased to move about below, a"
"1186",35,"noiseless owl flitted by, and I shivered with the chill of the night. I"
"1187",35,"determined to descend and find where I could sleep."
"1188",35,""
"1189",35,"“I looked for the building I knew. Then my eye travelled along to the"
"1190",35,"figure of the White Sphinx upon the pedestal of bronze, growing"
"1191",35,"distinct as the light of the rising moon grew brighter. I could see the"
"1192",35,"silver birch against it. There was the tangle of rhododendron bushes,"
"1193",35,"black in the pale light, and there was the little lawn. I looked at the"
"1194",35,"lawn again. A queer doubt chilled my complacency. ‘No,’ said I stoutly"
"1195",35,"to myself, ‘that was not the lawn.’"
"1196",35,""
"1197",35,"“But it _was_ the lawn. For the white leprous face of the sphinx was"
"1198",35,"towards it. Can you imagine what I felt as this conviction came home to"
"1199",35,"me? But you cannot. The Time Machine was gone!"
"1200",35,""
"1201",35,"“At once, like a lash across the face, came the possibility of losing"
"1202",35,"my own age, of being left helpless in this strange new world. The bare"
"1203",35,"thought of it was an actual physical sensation. I could feel it grip me"
"1204",35,"at the throat and stop my breathing. In another moment I was in a"
"1205",35,"passion of fear and running with great leaping strides down the slope."
"1206",35,"Once I fell headlong and cut my face; I lost no time in stanching the"
"1207",35,"blood, but jumped up and ran on, with a warm trickle down my cheek and"
"1208",35,"chin. All the time I ran I was saying to myself: ‘They have moved it a"
"1209",35,"little, pushed it under the bushes out of the way.’ Nevertheless, I ran"
"1210",35,"with all my might. All the time, with the certainty that sometimes"
"1211",35,"comes with excessive dread, I knew that such assurance was folly, knew"
"1212",35,"instinctively that the machine was removed out of my reach. My breath"
"1213",35,"came with pain. I suppose I covered the whole distance from the hill"
"1214",35,"crest to the little lawn, two miles perhaps, in ten minutes. And I am"
"1215",35,"not a young man. I cursed aloud, as I ran, at my confident folly in"
"1216",35,"leaving the machine, wasting good breath thereby. I cried aloud, and"
"1217",35,"none answered. Not a creature seemed to be stirring in that moonlit"
"1218",35,"world."
"1219",35,""
"1220",35,"“When I reached the lawn my worst fears were realised. Not a trace of"
"1221",35,"the thing was to be seen. I felt faint and cold when I faced the empty"
"1222",35,"space among the black tangle of bushes. I ran round it furiously, as if"
"1223",35,"the thing might be hidden in a corner, and then stopped abruptly, with"

"1225",35,"bronze pedestal, white, shining, leprous, in the light of the rising"
"1226",35,"moon. It seemed to smile in mockery of my dismay."
"1227",35,""
"1228",35,"“I might have consoled myself by imagining the little people had put"
"1229",35,"the mechanism in some shelter for me, had I not felt assured of their"
"1230",35,"physical and intellectual inadequacy. That is what dismayed me: the"

"1233",35,"other age had produced its exact duplicate, the machine could not have"
"1234",35,"moved in time. The attachment of the levers—I will show you the method"
"1235",35,"later—prevented anyone from tampering with it in that way when they"
"1236",35,"were removed. It had moved, and was hid, only in space. But then, where"
"1237",35,"could it be?"
"1238",35,""
"1239",35,"“I think I must have had a kind of frenzy. I remember running violently"

"1248",35,"curtains, of which I have told you."
"1249",35,""
"1250",35,"“There I found a second great hall covered with cushions, upon which,"
"1251",35,"perhaps, a score or so of the little people were sleeping. I have no"

"1260",35,"circumstances, in trying to revive the sensation of fear. For,"
"1261",35,"reasoning from their daylight behaviour, I thought that fear must be"
"1262",35,"forgotten."
"1263",35,""
"1264",35,"“Abruptly, I dashed down the match, and knocking one of the people over"

"1280",35,""

"1293",35,""
"1294",35,"“But probably the machine had only been taken away. Still, I must be"

"1298",35,"The freshness of the morning made me desire an equal freshness. I had"

"1322",35,""
"1323",35,"“I saw the heads of two orange-clad people coming through the bushes"

"1338",35,""
"1339",35,"“But I was not beaten yet. I banged with my fist at the bronze panels."
"1340",35,"I thought I heard something stir inside—to be explicit, I thought I"

"1349",35,"problem for years, but to wait inactive for twenty-four hours—that is"
"1350",35,"another matter."
"1351",35,""
"1352",35,"“I got up after a time, and began walking aimlessly through the bushes"
