"1366",35,""
"1367",35,"“Going through the big palace, it seemed to me that the little people"
"1368",35,"avoided me. It may have been my fancy, or it may have had something to"

"1374",35,"Either I missed some subtle point or their language was excessively"

"1383",35,"tethered me in a circle of a few miles round the point of my arrival."
"1384",35,""
"1385",35,""

"1388",35," VIII."

"1391",35,""
"1392",35,"“So far as I could see, all the world displayed the same exuberant"
"1393",35,"richness as the Thames valley. From every hill I climbed I saw the same"
"1394",35,"abundance of splendid buildings, endlessly varied in material and"
"1395",35,"style, the same clustering thickets of evergreens, the same"
"1396",35,"blossom-laden trees and tree ferns. Here and there water shone like"
"1397",35,"silver, and beyond, the land rose into blue undulating hills, and so"
"1398",35,"faded into the serenity of the sky. A peculiar feature, which presently"
"1399",35,"attracted my attention, was the presence of certain circular wells,"
"1400",35,"several, as it seemed to me, of a very great depth. One lay by the path"
"1401",35,"up the hill which I had followed during my first walk. Like the others,"
"1402",35,"it was rimmed with bronze, curiously wrought, and protected by a little"
"1403",35,"cupola from the rain. Sitting by the side of these wells, and peering"
"1404",35,"down into the shafted darkness, I could see no gleam of water, nor"
"1405",35,"could I start any reflection with a lighted match. But in all of them I"
"1406",35,"heard a certain sound: a thud—thud—thud, like the beating of some big"
"1407",35,"engine; and I discovered, from the flaring of my matches, that a steady"
"1408",35,"current of air set down the shafts. Further, I threw a scrap of paper"
"1409",35,"into the throat of one, and, instead of fluttering slowly down, it was"
"1410",35,"at once sucked swiftly out of sight."
"1411",35,""
"1412",35,"“After a time, too, I came to connect these wells with tall towers"
"1413",35,"standing here and there upon the slopes; for above them there was often"
"1414",35,"just such a flicker in the air as one sees on a hot day above a"
"1415",35,"sun-scorched beach. Putting things together, I reached a strong"
"1416",35,"suggestion of an extensive system of subterranean ventilation, whose"
"1417",35,"true import it was difficult to imagine. I was at first inclined to"
"1418",35,"associate it with the sanitary apparatus of these people. It was an"
"1419",35,"obvious conclusion, but it was absolutely wrong."
"1420",35,""
"1421",35,"“And here I must admit that I learnt very little of drains and bells"
"1422",35,"and modes of conveyance, and the like conveniences, during my time in"
"1423",35,"this real future. In some of these visions of Utopias and coming times"
"1424",35,"which I have read, there is a vast amount of detail about building, and"
"1425",35,"social arrangements, and so forth. But while such details are easy"
"1426",35,"enough to obtain when the whole world is contained in one’s"
"1427",35,"imagination, they are altogether inaccessible to a real traveller amid"
"1428",35,"such realities as I found here. Conceive the tale of London which a"
"1429",35,"negro, fresh from Central Africa, would take back to his tribe! What"
"1430",35,"would he know of railway companies, of social movements, of telephone"
"1431",35,"and telegraph wires, of the Parcels Delivery Company, and postal orders"
"1432",35,"and the like? Yet we, at least, should be willing enough to explain"
"1433",35,"these things to him! And even of what he knew, how much could he make"
"1434",35,"his untravelled friend either apprehend or believe? Then, think how"
"1435",35,"narrow the gap between a negro and a white man of our own times, and"
"1436",35,"how wide the interval between myself and these of the Golden Age! I was"
"1437",35,"sensible of much which was unseen, and which contributed to my comfort;"
"1438",35,"but save for a general impression of automatic organisation, I fear I"
"1439",35,"can convey very little of the difference to your mind."
"1440",35,""
"1441",35,"“In the matter of sepulture, for instance, I could see no signs of"
"1442",35,"crematoria nor anything suggestive of tombs. But it occurred to me"
"1443",35,"that, possibly, there might be cemeteries (or crematoria) somewhere"
"1444",35,"beyond the range of my explorings. This, again, was a question I"
"1445",35,"deliberately put to myself, and my curiosity was at first entirely"
"1446",35,"defeated upon the point. The thing puzzled me, and I was led to make a"
"1447",35,"further remark, which puzzled me still more: that aged and infirm among"
"1448",35,"this people there were none."
"1449",35,""
"1450",35,"“I must confess that my satisfaction with my first theories of an"
"1451",35,"automatic civilisation and a decadent humanity did not long endure. Yet"
"1452",35,"I could think of no other. Let me put my difficulties. The several big"
"1453",35,"palaces I had explored were mere living places, great dining-halls and"
"1454",35,"sleeping apartments. I could find no machinery, no appliances of any"
"1455",35,"kind. Yet these people were clothed in pleasant fabrics that must at"
"1456",35,"times need renewal, and their sandals, though undecorated, were fairly"

"1461",35,"making love in a half-playful fashion, in eating fruit and sleeping. I"
"1462",35,"could not see how things were kept going."
"1463",35,""
"1464",35,"“Then, again, about the Time Machine: something, I knew not what, had"
"1465",35,"taken it into the hollow pedestal of the White Sphinx. _Why?_ For the"
"1466",35,"life of me I could not imagine. Those waterless wells, too, those"
"1467",35,"flickering pillars. I felt I lacked a clue. I felt—how shall I put it?"
"1468",35,"Suppose you found an inscription, with sentences here and there in"
"1469",35,"excellent plain English, and interpolated therewith, others made up of"
"1470",35,"words, of letters even, absolutely unknown to you? Well, on the third"
"1471",35,"day of my visit, that was how the world of Eight Hundred and Two"
"1472",35,"Thousand Seven Hundred and One presented itself to me!"
"1473",35,""
"1474",35,"“That day, too, I made a friend—of a sort. It happened that, as I was"
"1475",35,"watching some of the little people bathing in a shallow, one of them"
"1476",35,"was seized with cramp and began drifting downstream. The main current"
"1477",35,"ran rather swiftly, but not too strongly for even a moderate swimmer."
"1478",35,"It will give you an idea, therefore, of the strange deficiency in these"

"1487",35,""
"1488",35,"“This happened in the morning. In the afternoon I met my little woman,"
"1489",35,"as I believe it was, as I was returning towards my centre from an"
"1490",35,"exploration, and she received me with cries of delight and presented me"

"1501",35,""
"1502",35,"“She was exactly like a child. She wanted to be with me always. She"
"1503",35,"tried to follow me everywhere, and on my next journey out and about it"
"1504",35,"went to my heart to tire her down, and leave her at last, exhausted and"

"1518",35,"tiny figure of white and gold so soon as I came over the hill."
"1519",35,""
"1520",35,"“It was from her, too, that I learnt that fear had not yet left the"

"1531",35,"blockhead that I missed the lesson of that fear, and in spite of"
"1532",35,"Weena’s distress, I insisted upon sleeping away from these slumbering"

"1534",35,""
"1535",35,"“It troubled her greatly, but in the end her odd affection for me"

"1549",35,""
"1550",35,"“The moon was setting, and the dying moonlight and the first pallor of"

"1557",35,"hastily. I did not see what became of them. It seemed that they"
"1558",35,"vanished among the bushes. The dawn was still indistinct, you must"
"1559",35,"understand. I was feeling that chill, uncertain, early-morning feeling"
"1560",35,"you may have known. I doubted my eyes."
"1561",35,""
"1562",35,"“As the eastern sky grew brighter, and the light of the day came on and"
"1563",35,"its vivid colouring returned upon the world once more, I scanned the"
"1564",35,"view keenly. But I saw no vestige of my white figures. They were mere"
"1565",35,"creatures of the half-light. ‘They must have been ghosts,’ I said; ‘I"
"1566",35,"wonder whence they dated.’ For a queer notion of Grant Allen’s came"
"1567",35,"into my head, and amused me. If each generation die and leave ghosts,"
"1568",35,"he argued, the world at last will get overcrowded with them. On that"
"1569",35,"theory they would have grown innumerable some Eight Hundred Thousand"
"1570",35,"Years hence, and it was no great wonder to see four at once. But the"
"1571",35,"jest was unsatisfying, and I was thinking of these figures all the"
"1572",35,"morning, until Weena’s rescue drove them out of my head. I associated"
"1573",35,"them in some indefinite way with the white animal I had startled in my"
"1574",35,"first passionate search for the Time Machine. But Weena was a pleasant"
"1575",35,"substitute. Yet all the same, they were soon destined to take far"
"1576",35,"deadlier possession of my mind."
"1577",35,""
"1578",35,"“I think I have said how much hotter than our own was the weather of"
"1579",35,"this Golden Age. I cannot account for it. It may be that the sun was"
"1580",35,"hotter, or the earth nearer the sun. It is usual to assume that the sun"
"1581",35,"will go on cooling steadily in the future. But people, unfamiliar with"
"1582",35,"such speculations as those of the younger Darwin, forget that the"
"1583",35,"planets must ultimately fall back one by one into the parent body. As"
"1584",35,"these catastrophes occur, the sun will blaze with renewed energy; and"
"1585",35,"it may be that some inner planet had suffered this fate. Whatever the"
"1586",35,"reason, the fact remains that the sun was very much hotter than we know"
"1587",35,"it."
"1588",35,""
"1589",35,"“Well, one very hot morning—my fourth, I think—as I was seeking shelter"
"1590",35,"from the heat and glare in a colossal ruin near the great house where I"
"1591",35,"slept and fed, there happened this strange thing. Clambering among"
"1592",35,"these heaps of masonry, I found a narrow gallery, whose end and side"
"1593",35,"windows were blocked by fallen masses of stone. By contrast with the"
"1594",35,"brilliancy outside, it seemed at first impenetrably dark to me. I"
"1595",35,"entered it groping, for the change from light to blackness made spots"
"1596",35,"of colour swim before me. Suddenly I halted spellbound. A pair of eyes,"
"1597",35,"luminous by reflection against the daylight without, was watching me"
"1598",35,"out of the darkness."
"1599",35,""
"1600",35,"“The old instinctive dread of wild beasts came upon me. I clenched my"
"1601",35,"hands and steadfastly looked into the glaring eyeballs. I was afraid to"
"1602",35,"turn. Then the thought of the absolute security in which humanity"
"1603",35,"appeared to be living came to my mind. And then I remembered that"

"1610",35,"behind me. It blundered against a block of granite, staggered aside,"
"1611",35,"and in a moment was hidden in a black shadow beneath another pile of"
"1612",35,"ruined masonry."
"1613",35,""
"1614",35,"“My impression of it is, of course, imperfect; but I know it was a dull"

"1623",35,"vanished down the shaft? I lit a match, and, looking down, I saw a"

"1629",35,"hand, going out as it dropped, and when I had lit another the little"

"1631",35,""
"1632",35,"“I do not know how long I sat peering down that well. It was not for"
"1633",35,"some time that I could succeed in persuading myself that the thing I"

"1640",35,""
"1641",35,"“I thought of the flickering pillars and of my theory of an underground"

"1649",35,"As I hesitated, two of the beautiful upperworld people came running in"

"1652",35,""
"1653",35,"“They seemed distressed to find me, my arm against the overturned"

"1667",35,""
"1668",35,"“Here was the new view. Plainly, this second species of Man was"

"1679",35,"sensitiveness of the retina."
"1680",35,""
"1681",35,"“Beneath my feet, then, the earth must be tunnelled enormously, and"
"1682",35,"these tunnellings were the habitat of the New Race. The presence of"

"1690",35,"though, for myself, I very soon felt that it fell far short of the"

"1692",35,""
"1693",35,"“At first, proceeding from the problems of our own age, it seemed clear"
"1694",35,"as daylight to me that the gradual widening of the present merely"
"1695",35,"temporary and social difference between the Capitalist and the Labourer"

"1699",35,"utilise underground space for the less ornamental purposes of"
"1700",35,"civilisation; there is the Metropolitan Railway in London, for"
"1701",35,"instance, there are new electric railways, there are subways, there are"
"1702",35,"underground workrooms and restaurants, and they increase and multiply."
"1703",35,"Evidently, I thought, this tendency had increased till Industry had"
"1704",35,"gradually lost its birthright in the sky. I mean that it had gone"
"1705",35,"deeper and deeper into larger and ever larger underground factories,"
"1706",35,"spending a still-increasing amount of its time therein, till, in the"
"1707",35,"end—! Even now, does not an East-end worker live in such artificial"
"1708",35,"conditions as practically to be cut off from the natural surface of the"

"1710",35,""
"1711",35,"“Again, the exclusive tendency of richer people—due, no doubt, to the"
"1712",35,"increasing refinement of their education, and the widening gulf between"
"1713",35,"them and the rude violence of the poor—is already leading to the"

"1717",35,"to the length and expense of the higher educational process and the"

"1723",35,"pursuing pleasure and comfort and beauty, and below ground the"
"1724",35,"Have-nots, the Workers getting continually adapted to the conditions of"
"1725",35,"their labour. Once they were there, they would no doubt have to pay"
"1726",35,"rent, and not a little of it, for the ventilation of their caverns; and"

"1728",35,"of them as were so constituted as to be miserable and rebellious would"
"1729",35,"die; and, in the end, the balance being permanent, the survivors would"
"1730",35,"become as well adapted to the conditions of underground life, and as"
"1731",35,"happy in their way, as the Overworld people were to theirs. As it"
"1732",35,"seemed to me, the refined beauty and the etiolated pallor followed"
"1733",35,"naturally enough."
"1734",35,""
"1735",35,"“The great triumph of Humanity I had dreamed of took a different shape"
"1736",35,"in my mind. It had been no such triumph of moral education and general"
"1737",35,"co-operation as I had imagined. Instead, I saw a real aristocracy,"
"1738",35,"armed with a perfected science and working to a logical conclusion the"

"1744",35,"supposition the balanced civilisation that was at last attained must"
"1745",35,"have long since passed its zenith, and was now far fallen into decay."

"1754",35,""
"1755",35,"“Then came troublesome doubts. Why had the Morlocks taken my Time"

"1757",35,"Eloi were masters, could they not restore the machine to me? And why"

"1768",35,""
"1769",35,""
"1770",35,""
"1771",35,""
"1772",35," IX."
"1773",35," The Morlocks"
"1774",35,""
"1775",35,""
"1776",35,"“It may seem odd to you, but it was two days before I could follow up"
"1777",35,"the new-found clue in what was manifestly the proper way. I felt a"
"1778",35,"peculiar shrinking from those pallid bodies. They were just the"
"1779",35,"half-bleached colour of the worms and things one sees preserved in"
"1780",35,"spirit in a zoological museum. And they were filthily cold to the"
"1781",35,"touch. Probably my shrinking was largely due to the sympathetic"
"1782",35,"influence of the Eloi, whose disgust of the Morlocks I now began to"
"1783",35,"appreciate."
"1784",35,""
"1785",35,"“The next night I did not sleep well. Probably my health was a little"
"1786",35,"disordered. I was oppressed with perplexity and doubt. Once or twice I"
"1787",35,"had a feeling of intense fear for which I could perceive no definite"
"1788",35,"reason. I remember creeping noiselessly into the great hall where the"
"1789",35,"little people were sleeping in the moonlight—that night Weena was among"
"1790",35,"them—and feeling reassured by their presence. It occurred to me even"
"1791",35,"then, that in the course of a few days the moon must pass through its"
"1792",35,"last quarter, and the nights grow dark, when the appearances of these"
"1793",35,"unpleasant creatures from below, these whitened Lemurs, this new vermin"

"1796",35,"felt assured that the Time Machine was only to be recovered by boldly"
"1797",35,"penetrating these mysteries of underground. Yet I could not face the"
"1798",35,"mystery. If only I had had a companion it would have been different."
"1799",35,"But I was so horribly alone, and even to clamber down into the darkness"
"1800",35,"of the well appalled me. I don’t know if you will understand my"
"1801",35,"feeling, but I never felt quite safe at my back."
"1802",35,""
"1803",35,"“It was this restlessness, this insecurity, perhaps, that drove me"
"1804",35,"farther and farther afield in my exploring expeditions. Going to the"
"1805",35,"south-westward towards the rising country that is now called Combe"

"1812",35,"a difference in use, and I was minded to push on and explore. But the"
"1813",35,"day was growing late, and I had come upon the sight of the place after"

"1815",35,"the following day, and I returned to the welcome and the caresses of"
"1816",35,"little Weena. But next morning I perceived clearly enough that my"
"1817",35,"curiosity regarding the Palace of Green Porcelain was a piece of"

"1819",35,"dreaded. I resolved I would make the descent without further waste of"
"1820",35,"time, and started out in the early morning towards a well near the"
"1821",35,"ruins of granite and aluminium."
"1822",35,""
"1823",35,"“Little Weena ran with me. She danced beside me to the well, but when"
"1824",35,"she saw me lean over the mouth and look downward, she seemed strangely"
"1825",35,"disconcerted. ‘Good-bye, little Weena,’ I said, kissing her; and then"
"1826",35,"putting her down, I began to feel over the parapet for the climbing"

"1835",35,""
"1836",35,"“I had to clamber down a shaft of perhaps two hundred yards. The"
"1837",35,"descent was effected by means of metallic bars projecting from the"

"1851",35,""
"1852",35,"“I was in an agony of discomfort. I had some thought of trying to go up"

"1862",35,""
"1863",35,"“I do not know how long I lay. I was arroused by a soft hand touching"

"1875",35,""
"1876",35,"“I tried to call to them, but the language they had was apparently"

"1886",35,""
"1887",35,"“Necessarily my memory is vague. Great shapes like big machines rose"

"1899",35,""
"1900",35,"“I have thought since how particularly ill-equipped I was for such an"
"1901",35,"experience. When I had started with the Time Machine, I had started"
"1902",35,"with the absurd assumption that the men of the Future would certainly"
"1903",35,"be infinitely ahead of ourselves in all their appliances. I had come"
"1904",35,"without arms, without medicine, without anything to smoke—at times I"

"1906",35,"thought of a Kodak! I could have flashed that glimpse of the Underworld"
"1907",35,"in a second, and examined it at leisure. But, as it was, I stood there"
"1908",35,"with only the weapons and the powers that Nature had endowed me"
"1909",35,"with—hands, feet, and teeth; these, and four safety-matches that still"
"1910",35,"remained to me."
"1911",35,""
"1912",35,"“I was afraid to push my way in among all this machinery in the dark,"
"1913",35,"and it was only with my last glimpse of light I discovered that my"
"1914",35,"store of matches had run low. It had never occurred to me until that"
"1915",35,"moment that there was any need to economise them, and I had wasted"
"1916",35,"almost half the box in astonishing the Overworlders, to whom fire was a"
"1917",35,"novelty. Now, as I say, I had four left, and while I stood in the dark,"
"1918",35,"a hand touched mine, lank fingers came feeling over my face, and I was"
"1919",35,"sensible of a peculiar unpleasant odour. I fancied I heard the"
"1920",35,"breathing of a crowd of those dreadful little beings about me. I felt"
"1921",35,"the box of matches in my hand being gently disengaged, and other hands"
"1922",35,"behind me plucking at my clothing. The sense of these unseen creatures"
"1923",35,"examining me was indescribably unpleasant. The sudden realisation of my"
"1924",35,"ignorance of their ways of thinking and doing came home to me very"
"1925",35,"vividly in the darkness. I shouted at them as loudly as I could. They"
"1926",35,"started away, and then I could feel them approaching me again. They"
"1927",35,"clutched at me more boldly, whispering odd sounds to each other. I"
"1928",35,"shivered violently, and shouted again—rather discordantly. This time"
"1929",35,"they were not so seriously alarmed, and they made a queer laughing"
"1930",35,"noise as they came back at me. I will confess I was horribly"
"1931",35,"frightened. I determined to strike another match and escape under the"
"1932",35,"protection of its glare. I did so, and eking out the flicker with a"
"1933",35,"scrap of paper from my pocket, I made good my retreat to the narrow"
"1934",35,"tunnel. But I had scarce entered this when my light was blown out and"
"1935",35,"in the blackness I could hear the Morlocks rustling like wind among"
"1936",35,"leaves, and pattering like the rain, as they hurried after me."
"1937",35,""
"1938",35,"“In a moment I was clutched by several hands, and there was no"
"1939",35,"mistaking that they were trying to haul me back. I struck another"
"1940",35,"light, and waved it in their dazzled faces. You can scarce imagine how"
"1941",35,"nauseatingly inhuman they looked—those pale, chinless faces and great,"
"1942",35,"lidless, pinkish-grey eyes!—as they stared in their blindness and"
"1943",35,"bewilderment. But I did not stay to look, I promise you: I retreated"
"1944",35,"again, and when my second match had ended, I struck my third. It had"
"1945",35,"almost burnt through when I reached the opening into the shaft. I lay"
"1946",35,"down on the edge, for the throb of the great pump below made me giddy."
"1947",35,"Then I felt sideways for the projecting hooks, and, as I did so, my"
"1948",35,"feet were grasped from behind, and I was violently tugged backward. I"
"1949",35,"lit my last match … and it incontinently went out. But I had my hand on"
"1950",35,"the climbing bars now, and, kicking violently, I disengaged myself from"
"1951",35,"the clutches of the Morlocks, and was speedily clambering up the shaft,"
"1952",35,"while they stayed peering and blinking up at me: all but one little"
"1953",35,"wretch who followed me for some way, and well-nigh secured my boot as a"
"1954",35,"trophy."
"1955",35,""
"1956",35,"“That climb seemed interminable to me. With the last twenty or thirty"
"1957",35,"feet of it a deadly nausea came upon me. I had the greatest difficulty"
"1958",35,"in keeping my hold. The last few yards was a frightful struggle against"
"1959",35,"this faintness. Several times my head swam, and I felt all the"
"1960",35,"sensations of falling. At last, however, I got over the well-mouth"
"1961",35,"somehow, and staggered out of the ruin into the blinding sunlight. I"
"1962",35,"fell upon my face. Even the soil smelt sweet and clean. Then I remember"
"1963",35,"Weena kissing my hands and ears, and the voices of others among the"
"1964",35,"Eloi. Then, for a time, I was insensible."
"1965",35,""
"1966",35,""
"1967",35,""
"1968",35,""
"1969",35," X."
"1970",35," When Night Came"
"1971",35,""
"1972",35,""
"1973",35,"“Now, indeed, I seemed in a worse case than before. Hitherto, except"
"1974",35,"during my night’s anguish at the loss of the Time Machine, I had felt a"
"1975",35,"sustaining hope of ultimate escape, but that hope was staggered by"
"1976",35,"these new discoveries. Hitherto I had merely thought myself impeded by"
"1977",35,"the childish simplicity of the little people, and by some unknown"
"1978",35,"forces which I had only to understand to overcome; but there was an"
"1979",35,"altogether new element in the sickening quality of the Morlocks—a"
"1980",35,"something inhuman and malign. Instinctively I loathed them. Before, I"
"1981",35,"had felt as a man might feel who had fallen into a pit: my concern was"
"1982",35,"with the pit and how to get out of it. Now I felt like a beast in a"
"1983",35,"trap, whose enemy would come upon him soon."
"1984",35,""
"1985",35,"“The enemy I dreaded may surprise you. It was the darkness of the new"
"1986",35,"moon. Weena had put this into my head by some at first incomprehensible"
"1987",35,"remarks about the Dark Nights. It was not now such a very difficult"
"1988",35,"problem to guess what the coming Dark Nights might mean. The moon was"
"1989",35,"on the wane: each night there was a longer interval of darkness. And I"
"1990",35,"now understood to some slight degree at least the reason of the fear of"
"1991",35,"the little Upperworld people for the dark. I wondered vaguely what foul"
"1992",35,"villainy it might be that the Morlocks did under the new moon. I felt"
"1993",35,"pretty sure now that my second hypothesis was all wrong. The Upperworld"
"1994",35,"people might once have been the favoured aristocracy, and the Morlocks"
"1995",35,"their mechanical servants: but that had long since passed away. The two"
"1996",35,"species that had resulted from the evolution of man were sliding down"
"1997",35,"towards, or had already arrived at, an altogether new relationship. The"
"1998",35,"Eloi, like the Carlovignan kings, had decayed to a mere beautiful"
"1999",35,"futility. They still possessed the earth on sufferance: since the"
"2000",35,"Morlocks, subterranean for innumerable generations, had come at last to"
"2001",35,"find the daylit surface intolerable. And the Morlocks made their"
"2002",35,"garments, I inferred, and maintained them in their habitual needs,"
"2003",35,"perhaps through the survival of an old habit of service. They did it as"
"2004",35,"a standing horse paws with his foot, or as a man enjoys killing animals"
"2005",35,"in sport: because ancient and departed necessities had impressed it on"
"2006",35,"the organism. But, clearly, the old order was already in part reversed."
"2007",35,"The Nemesis of the delicate ones was creeping on apace. Ages ago,"
"2008",35,"thousands of generations ago, man had thrust his brother man out of the"
"2009",35,"ease and the sunshine. And now that brother was coming back—changed!"
"2010",35,"Already the Eloi had begun to learn one old lesson anew. They were"
"2011",35,"becoming reacquainted with Fear. And suddenly there came into my head"
"2012",35,"the memory of the meat I had seen in the Underworld. It seemed odd how"
"2013",35,"it floated into my mind: not stirred up as it were by the current of my"
"2014",35,"meditations, but coming in almost like a question from outside. I tried"
"2015",35,"to recall the form of it. I had a vague sense of something familiar,"
"2016",35,"but I could not tell what it was at the time."
"2017",35,""
"2018",35,"“Still, however helpless the little people in the presence of their"
"2019",35,"mysterious Fear, I was differently constituted. I came out of this age"
"2020",35,"of ours, this ripe prime of the human race, when Fear does not paralyse"
"2021",35,"and mystery has lost its terrors. I at least would defend myself."
"2022",35,"Without further delay I determined to make myself arms and a fastness"
"2023",35,"where I might sleep. With that refuge as a base, I could face this"
"2024",35,"strange world with some of that confidence I had lost in realising to"
"2025",35,"what creatures night by night I lay exposed. I felt I could never sleep"
"2026",35,"again until my bed was secure from them. I shuddered with horror to"
"2027",35,"think how they must already have examined me."
"2028",35,""
"2029",35,"“I wandered during the afternoon along the valley of the Thames, but"
"2030",35,"found nothing that commended itself to my mind as inaccessible. All the"
"2031",35,"buildings and trees seemed easily practicable to such dexterous"
"2032",35,"climbers as the Morlocks, to judge by their wells, must be. Then the"
"2033",35,"tall pinnacles of the Palace of Green Porcelain and the polished gleam"
"2034",35,"of its walls came back to my memory; and in the evening, taking Weena"
"2035",35,"like a child upon my shoulder, I went up the hills towards the"
"2036",35,"south-west. The distance, I had reckoned, was seven or eight miles, but"
"2037",35,"it must have been nearer eighteen. I had first seen the place on a"
"2038",35,"moist afternoon when distances are deceptively diminished. In addition,"
"2039",35,"the heel of one of my shoes was loose, and a nail was working through"
"2040",35,"the sole—they were comfortable old shoes I wore about indoors—so that I"
"2041",35,"was lame. And it was already long past sunset when I came in sight of"
"2042",35,"the palace, silhouetted black against the pale yellow of the sky."
"2043",35,""
"2044",35,"“Weena had been hugely delighted when I began to carry her, but after a"
"2045",35,"while she desired me to let her down, and ran along by the side of me,"
"2046",35,"occasionally darting off on either hand to pick flowers to stick in my"
"2047",35,"pockets. My pockets had always puzzled Weena, but at the last she had"
"2048",35,"concluded that they were an eccentric kind of vases for floral"
"2049",35,"decoration. At least she utilised them for that purpose. And that"
"2050",35,"reminds me! In changing my jacket I found…”"
"2051",35,""
"2052",35,"_The Time Traveller paused, put his hand into his pocket, and silently"
"2053",35,"placed two withered flowers, not unlike very large white mallows, upon"
"2054",35,"the little table. Then he resumed his narrative._"
"2055",35,""
"2056",35,"“As the hush of evening crept over the world and we proceeded over the"
"2057",35,"hill crest towards Wimbledon, Weena grew tired and wanted to return to"
"2058",35,"the house of grey stone. But I pointed out the distant pinnacles of the"
"2059",35,"Palace of Green Porcelain to her, and contrived to make her understand"
"2060",35,"that we were seeking a refuge there from her Fear. You know that great"
"2061",35,"pause that comes upon things before the dusk? Even the breeze stops in"
"2062",35,"the trees. To me there is always an air of expectation about that"
"2063",35,"evening stillness. The sky was clear, remote, and empty save for a few"
"2064",35,"horizontal bars far down in the sunset. Well, that night the"
"2065",35,"expectation took the colour of my fears. In that darkling calm my"
"2066",35,"senses seemed preternaturally sharpened. I fancied I could even feel"
"2067",35,"the hollowness of the ground beneath my feet: could, indeed, almost see"
"2068",35,"through it the Morlocks on their ant-hill going hither and thither and"
"2069",35,"waiting for the dark. In my excitement I fancied that they would"
"2070",35,"receive my invasion of their burrows as a declaration of war. And why"
"2071",35,"had they taken my Time Machine?"
"2072",35,""
"2073",35,"“So we went on in the quiet, and the twilight deepened into night. The"
"2074",35,"clear blue of the distance faded, and one star after another came out."
"2075",35,"The ground grew dim and the trees black. Weena’s fears and her fatigue"
"2076",35,"grew upon her. I took her in my arms and talked to her and caressed"
"2077",35,"her. Then, as the darkness grew deeper, she put her arms round my neck,"
"2078",35,"and, closing her eyes, tightly pressed her face against my shoulder. So"
"2079",35,"we went down a long slope into a valley, and there in the dimness I"
"2080",35,"almost walked into a little river. This I waded, and went up the"
"2081",35,"opposite side of the valley, past a number of sleeping houses, and by a"
"2082",35,"statue—a Faun, or some such figure, _minus_ the head. Here too were"
"2083",35,"acacias. So far I had seen nothing of the Morlocks, but it was yet"
"2084",35,"early in the night, and the darker hours before the old moon rose were"
"2085",35,"still to come."
"2086",35,""
"2087",35,"“From the brow of the next hill I saw a thick wood spreading wide and"
"2088",35,"black before me. I hesitated at this. I could see no end to it, either"
"2089",35,"to the right or the left. Feeling tired—my feet, in particular, were"
"2090",35,"very sore—I carefully lowered Weena from my shoulder as I halted, and"
"2091",35,"sat down upon the turf. I could no longer see the Palace of Green"
"2092",35,"Porcelain, and I was in doubt of my direction. I looked into the"
"2093",35,"thickness of the wood and thought of what it might hide. Under that"
"2094",35,"dense tangle of branches one would be out of sight of the stars. Even"
"2095",35,"were there no other lurking danger—a danger I did not care to let my"
"2096",35,"imagination loose upon—there would still be all the roots to stumble"
"2097",35,"over and the tree-boles to strike against. I was very tired, too, after"
"2098",35,"the excitements of the day; so I decided that I would not face it, but"
"2099",35,"would pass the night upon the open hill."
"2100",35,""
"2101",35,"“Weena, I was glad to find, was fast asleep. I carefully wrapped her in"
"2102",35,"my jacket, and sat down beside her to wait for the moonrise. The"
"2103",35,"hillside was quiet and deserted, but from the black of the wood there"
"2104",35,"came now and then a stir of living things. Above me shone the stars,"
"2105",35,"for the night was very clear. I felt a certain sense of friendly"
"2106",35,"comfort in their twinkling. All the old constellations had gone from"
"2107",35,"the sky, however: that slow movement which is imperceptible in a"
"2108",35,"hundred human lifetimes, had long since rearranged them in unfamiliar"
"2109",35,"groupings. But the Milky Way, it seemed to me, was still the same"
"2110",35,"tattered streamer of star-dust as of yore. Southward (as I judged it)"
"2111",35,"was a very bright red star that was new to me; it was even more"
"2112",35,"splendid than our own green Sirius. And amid all these scintillating"
"2113",35,"points of light one bright planet shone kindly and steadily like the"
"2114",35,"face of an old friend."
"2115",35,""
"2116",35,"“Looking at these stars suddenly dwarfed my own troubles and all the"
"2117",35,"gravities of terrestrial life. I thought of their unfathomable"
"2118",35,"distance, and the slow inevitable drift of their movements out of the"
"2119",35,"unknown past into the unknown future. I thought of the great"
"2120",35,"precessional cycle that the pole of the earth describes. Only forty"
"2121",35,"times had that silent revolution occurred during all the years that I"
"2122",35,"had traversed. And during these few revolutions all the activity, all"
"2123",35,"the traditions, the complex organisations, the nations, languages,"
"2124",35,"literatures, aspirations, even the mere memory of Man as I knew him,"
"2125",35,"had been swept out of existence. Instead were these frail creatures who"
"2126",35,"had forgotten their high ancestry, and the white Things of which I went"
"2127",35,"in terror. Then I thought of the Great Fear that was between the two"
"2128",35,"species, and for the first time, with a sudden shiver, came the clear"
"2129",35,"knowledge of what the meat I had seen might be. Yet it was too"
"2130",35,"horrible! I looked at little Weena sleeping beside me, her face white"
"2131",35,"and starlike under the stars, and forthwith dismissed the thought."
"2132",35,""
"2133",35,"“Through that long night I held my mind off the Morlocks as well as I"
"2134",35,"could, and whiled away the time by trying to fancy I could find signs"
"2135",35,"of the old constellations in the new confusion. The sky kept very"
"2136",35,"clear, except for a hazy cloud or so. No doubt I dozed at times. Then,"
"2137",35,"as my vigil wore on, came a faintness in the eastward sky, like the"
"2138",35,"reflection of some colourless fire, and the old moon rose, thin and"
"2139",35,"peaked and white. And close behind, and overtaking it, and overflowing"
"2140",35,"it, the dawn came, pale at first, and then growing pink and warm. No"
"2141",35,"Morlocks had approached us. Indeed, I had seen none upon the hill that"
"2142",35,"night. And in the confidence of renewed day it almost seemed to me that"
"2143",35,"my fear had been unreasonable. I stood up and found my foot with the"
"2144",35,"loose heel swollen at the ankle and painful under the heel; so I sat"
"2145",35,"down again, took off my shoes, and flung them away."
"2146",35,""
"2147",35,"“I awakened Weena, and we went down into the wood, now green and"
"2148",35,"pleasant instead of black and forbidding. We found some fruit wherewith"
"2149",35,"to break our fast. We soon met others of the dainty ones, laughing and"
"2150",35,"dancing in the sunlight as though there was no such thing in nature as"
"2151",35,"the night. And then I thought once more of the meat that I had seen. I"
"2152",35,"felt assured now of what it was, and from the bottom of my heart I"
"2153",35,"pitied this last feeble rill from the great flood of humanity. Clearly,"
"2154",35,"at some time in the Long-Ago of human decay the Morlocks’ food had run"
"2155",35,"short. Possibly they had lived on rats and such-like vermin. Even now"
"2156",35,"man is far less discriminating and exclusive in his food than he"
"2157",35,"was—far less than any monkey. His prejudice against human flesh is no"
"2158",35,"deep-seated instinct. And so these inhuman sons of men——! I tried to"
"2159",35,"look at the thing in a scientific spirit. After all, they were less"
"2160",35,"human and more remote than our cannibal ancestors of three or four"
"2161",35,"thousand years ago. And the intelligence that would have made this"
"2162",35,"state of things a torment had gone. Why should I trouble myself? These"
"2163",35,"Eloi were mere fatted cattle, which the ant-like Morlocks preserved and"
"2164",35,"preyed upon—probably saw to the breeding of. And there was Weena"
"2165",35,"dancing at my side!"
"2166",35,""
"2167",35,"“Then I tried to preserve myself from the horror that was coming upon"
"2168",35,"me, by regarding it as a rigorous punishment of human selfishness. Man"
"2169",35,"had been content to live in ease and delight upon the labours of his"
"2170",35,"fellow-man, had taken Necessity as his watchword and excuse, and in the"
"2171",35,"fullness of time Necessity had come home to him. I even tried a"
"2172",35,"Carlyle-like scorn of this wretched aristocracy in decay. But this"
"2173",35,"attitude of mind was impossible. However great their intellectual"
"2174",35,"degradation, the Eloi had kept too much of the human form not to claim"
"2175",35,"my sympathy, and to make me perforce a sharer in their degradation and"
"2176",35,"their Fear."
"2177",35,""
"2178",35,"“I had at that time very vague ideas as to the course I should pursue."
"2179",35,"My first was to secure some safe place of refuge, and to make myself"
"2180",35,"such arms of metal or stone as I could contrive. That necessity was"
"2181",35,"immediate. In the next place, I hoped to procure some means of fire, so"
"2182",35,"that I should have the weapon of a torch at hand, for nothing, I knew,"
"2183",35,"would be more efficient against these Morlocks. Then I wanted to"
"2184",35,"arrange some contrivance to break open the doors of bronze under the"
"2185",35,"White Sphinx. I had in mind a battering ram. I had a persuasion that if"
"2186",35,"I could enter those doors and carry a blaze of light before me I should"
"2187",35,"discover the Time Machine and escape. I could not imagine the Morlocks"
"2188",35,"were strong enough to move it far away. Weena I had resolved to bring"
"2189",35,"with me to our own time. And turning such schemes over in my mind I"
"2190",35,"pursued our way towards the building which my fancy had chosen as our"
"2191",35,"dwelling."
"2192",35,""
"2193",35,""
"2194",35,""
"2195",35,""
"2196",35," XI."
"2197",35," The Palace of Green Porcelain"
"2198",35,""
"2199",35,""
"2200",35,"“I found the Palace of Green Porcelain, when we approached it about"
"2201",35,"noon, deserted and falling into ruin. Only ragged vestiges of glass"
"2202",35,"remained in its windows, and great sheets of the green facing had"
"2203",35,"fallen away from the corroded metallic framework. It lay very high upon"
"2204",35,"a turfy down, and looking north-eastward before I entered it, I was"
"2205",35,"surprised to see a large estuary, or even creek, where I judged"
"2206",35,"Wandsworth and Battersea must once have been. I thought then—though I"
"2207",35,"never followed up the thought—of what might have happened, or might be"
"2208",35,"happening, to the living things in the sea."
"2209",35,""
"2210",35,"“The material of the Palace proved on examination to be indeed"
"2211",35,"porcelain, and along the face of it I saw an inscription in some"
"2212",35,"unknown character. I thought, rather foolishly, that Weena might help"
"2213",35,"me to interpret this, but I only learnt that the bare idea of writing"
"2214",35,"had never entered her head. She always seemed to me, I fancy, more"
"2215",35,"human than she was, perhaps because her affection was so human."
"2216",35,""
"2217",35,"“Within the big valves of the door—which were open and broken—we found,"
"2218",35,"instead of the customary hall, a long gallery lit by many side windows."
"2219",35,"At the first glance I was reminded of a museum. The tiled floor was"
"2220",35,"thick with dust, and a remarkable array of miscellaneous objects was"
"2221",35,"shrouded in the same grey covering. Then I perceived, standing strange"
"2222",35,"and gaunt in the centre of the hall, what was clearly the lower part of"
"2223",35,"a huge skeleton. I recognised by the oblique feet that it was some"
"2224",35,"extinct creature after the fashion of the Megatherium. The skull and"
"2225",35,"the upper bones lay beside it in the thick dust, and in one place,"
"2226",35,"where rain-water had dropped through a leak in the roof, the thing"
"2227",35,"itself had been worn away. Further in the gallery was the huge skeleton"
"2228",35,"barrel of a Brontosaurus. My museum hypothesis was confirmed. Going"
"2229",35,"towards the side I found what appeared to be sloping shelves, and"
"2230",35,"clearing away the thick dust, I found the old familiar glass cases of"
"2231",35,"our own time. But they must have been air-tight to judge from the fair"
"2232",35,"preservation of some of their contents."
"2233",35,""
"2234",35,"“Clearly we stood among the ruins of some latter-day South Kensington!"
"2235",35,"Here, apparently, was the Palæontological Section, and a very splendid"
"2236",35,"array of fossils it must have been, though the inevitable process of"
"2237",35,"decay that had been staved off for a time, and had, through the"
"2238",35,"extinction of bacteria and fungi, lost ninety-nine hundredths of its"
"2239",35,"force, was nevertheless, with extreme sureness if with extreme slowness"
"2240",35,"at work again upon all its treasures. Here and there I found traces of"
"2241",35,"the little people in the shape of rare fossils broken to pieces or"
"2242",35,"threaded in strings upon reeds. And the cases had in some instances"
"2243",35,"been bodily removed—by the Morlocks, as I judged. The place was very"
"2244",35,"silent. The thick dust deadened our footsteps. Weena, who had been"
"2245",35,"rolling a sea urchin down the sloping glass of a case, presently came,"
"2246",35,"as I stared about me, and very quietly took my hand and stood beside"
"2247",35,"me."
"2248",35,""
"2249",35,"“And at first I was so much surprised by this ancient monument of an"
"2250",35,"intellectual age that I gave no thought to the possibilities it"
"2251",35,"presented. Even my preoccupation about the Time Machine receded a"
"2252",35,"little from my mind."
"2253",35,""
"2254",35,"“To judge from the size of the place, this Palace of Green Porcelain"
"2255",35,"had a great deal more in it than a Gallery of Palæontology; possibly"
"2256",35,"historical galleries; it might be, even a library! To me, at least in"
"2257",35,"my present circumstances, these would be vastly more interesting than"
"2258",35,"this spectacle of old-time geology in decay. Exploring, I found another"
"2259",35,"short gallery running transversely to the first. This appeared to be"
"2260",35,"devoted to minerals, and the sight of a block of sulphur set my mind"
"2261",35,"running on gunpowder. But I could find no saltpetre; indeed, no"
"2262",35,"nitrates of any kind. Doubtless they had deliquesced ages ago. Yet the"
"2263",35,"sulphur hung in my mind, and set up a train of thinking. As for the"
"2264",35,"rest of the contents of that gallery, though on the whole they were the"
"2265",35,"best preserved of all I saw, I had little interest. I am no specialist"
"2266",35,"in mineralogy, and I went on down a very ruinous aisle running parallel"
"2267",35,"to the first hall I had entered. Apparently this section had been"
"2268",35,"devoted to natural history, but everything had long since passed out of"
"2269",35,"recognition. A few shrivelled and blackened vestiges of what had once"
"2270",35,"been stuffed animals, desiccated mummies in jars that had once held"
"2271",35,"spirit, a brown dust of departed plants: that was all! I was sorry for"
"2272",35,"that, because I should have been glad to trace the patient"
"2273",35,"readjustments by which the conquest of animated nature had been"
"2274",35,"attained. Then we came to a gallery of simply colossal proportions, but"
"2275",35,"singularly ill-lit, the floor of it running downward at a slight angle"
"2276",35,"from the end at which I entered. At intervals white globes hung from"
"2277",35,"the ceiling—many of them cracked and smashed—which suggested that"
"2278",35,"originally the place had been artificially lit. Here I was more in my"
"2279",35,"element, for rising on either side of me were the huge bulks of big"
"2280",35,"machines, all greatly corroded and many broken down, but some still"
"2281",35,"fairly complete. You know I have a certain weakness for mechanism, and"
"2282",35,"I was inclined to linger among these; the more so as for the most part"
"2283",35,"they had the interest of puzzles, and I could make only the vaguest"
"2284",35,"guesses at what they were for. I fancied that if I could solve their"
"2285",35,"puzzles I should find myself in possession of powers that might be of"
"2286",35,"use against the Morlocks."
"2287",35,""
"2288",35,"“Suddenly Weena came very close to my side. So suddenly that she"
"2289",35,"startled me. Had it not been for her I do not think I should have"
"2290",35,"noticed that the floor of the gallery sloped at all. [Footnote: It may"
"2291",35,"be, of course, that the floor did not slope, but that the museum was"
"2292",35,"built into the side of a hill.—ED.] The end I had come in at was quite"
"2293",35,"above ground, and was lit by rare slit-like windows. As you went down"
"2294",35,"the length, the ground came up against these windows, until at last"
"2295",35,"there was a pit like the ‘area‘ of a London house before each, and only"
"2296",35,"a narrow line of daylight at the top. I went slowly along, puzzling"
"2297",35,"about the machines, and had been too intent upon them to notice the"
"2298",35,"gradual diminution of the light, until Weena’s increasing apprehensions"
"2299",35,"drew my attention. Then I saw that the gallery ran down at last into a"
"2300",35,"thick darkness. I hesitated, and then, as I looked round me, I saw that"
"2301",35,"the dust was less abundant and its surface less even. Further away"
"2302",35,"towards the dimness, it appeared to be broken by a number of small"
"2303",35,"narrow footprints. My sense of the immediate presence of the Morlocks"
"2304",35,"revived at that. I felt that I was wasting my time in the academic"
"2305",35,"examination of machinery. I called to mind that it was already far"
"2306",35,"advanced in the afternoon, and that I had still no weapon, no refuge,"
"2307",35,"and no means of making a fire. And then down in the remote blackness of"
"2308",35,"the gallery I heard a peculiar pattering, and the same odd noises I had"
"2309",35,"heard down the well."
"2310",35,""
"2311",35,"“I took Weena’s hand. Then, struck with a sudden idea, I left her and"
"2312",35,"turned to a machine from which projected a lever not unlike those in a"
"2313",35,"signal-box. Clambering upon the stand, and grasping this lever in my"
"2314",35,"hands, I put all my weight upon it sideways. Suddenly Weena, deserted"
"2315",35,"in the central aisle, began to whimper. I had judged the strength of"
"2316",35,"the lever pretty correctly, for it snapped after a minute’s strain, and"
"2317",35,"I rejoined her with a mace in my hand more than sufficient, I judged,"
"2318",35,"for any Morlock skull I might encounter. And I longed very much to kill"
"2319",35,"a Morlock or so. Very inhuman, you may think, to want to go killing"
"2320",35,"one’s own descendants! But it was impossible, somehow, to feel any"
"2321",35,"humanity in the things. Only my disinclination to leave Weena, and a"
"2322",35,"persuasion that if I began to slake my thirst for murder my Time"
"2323",35,"Machine might suffer, restrained me from going straight down the"
"2324",35,"gallery and killing the brutes I heard."
"2325",35,""
"2326",35,"“Well, mace in one hand and Weena in the other, I went out of that"
"2327",35,"gallery and into another and still larger one, which at the first"
"2328",35,"glance reminded me of a military chapel hung with tattered flags. The"
"2329",35,"brown and charred rags that hung from the sides of it, I presently"
"2330",35,"recognised as the decaying vestiges of books. They had long since"
"2331",35,"dropped to pieces, and every semblance of print had left them. But here"
"2332",35,"and there were warped boards and cracked metallic clasps that told the"
"2333",35,"tale well enough. Had I been a literary man I might, perhaps, have"
"2334",35,"moralised upon the futility of all ambition. But as it was, the thing"
"2335",35,"that struck me with keenest force was the enormous waste of labour to"
"2336",35,"which this sombre wilderness of rotting paper testified. At the time I"
"2337",35,"will confess that I thought chiefly of the _Philosophical Transactions_"
"2338",35,"and my own seventeen papers upon physical optics."
"2339",35,""
"2340",35,"“Then, going up a broad staircase, we came to what may once have been a"
"2341",35,"gallery of technical chemistry. And here I had not a little hope of"
"2342",35,"useful discoveries. Except at one end where the roof had collapsed,"
"2343",35,"this gallery was well preserved. I went eagerly to every unbroken case."
"2344",35,"And at last, in one of the really air-tight cases, I found a box of"
"2345",35,"matches. Very eagerly I tried them. They were perfectly good. They were"
"2346",35,"not even damp. I turned to Weena. ‘Dance,’ I cried to her in her own"
"2347",35,"tongue. For now I had a weapon indeed against the horrible creatures we"
"2348",35,"feared. And so, in that derelict museum, upon the thick soft carpeting"
"2349",35,"of dust, to Weena’s huge delight, I solemnly performed a kind of"
"2350",35,"composite dance, whistling _The Land of the Leal_ as cheerfully as I"
"2351",35,"could. In part it was a modest _cancan_, in part a step dance, in part"
"2352",35,"a skirt dance (so far as my tail-coat permitted), and in part original."
"2353",35,"For I am naturally inventive, as you know."
"2354",35,""
"2355",35,"“Now, I still think that for this box of matches to have escaped the"
"2356",35,"wear of time for immemorial years was a most strange, as for me it was"
"2357",35,"a most fortunate, thing. Yet, oddly enough, I found a far unlikelier"
"2358",35,"substance, and that was camphor. I found it in a sealed jar, that by"
"2359",35,"chance, I suppose, had been really hermetically sealed. I fancied at"
"2360",35,"first that it was paraffin wax, and smashed the glass accordingly. But"
"2361",35,"the odour of camphor was unmistakable. In the universal decay this"
"2362",35,"volatile substance had chanced to survive, perhaps through many"
"2363",35,"thousands of centuries. It reminded me of a sepia painting I had once"
"2364",35,"seen done from the ink of a fossil Belemnite that must have perished"
"2365",35,"and become fossilised millions of years ago. I was about to throw it"
"2366",35,"away, but I remembered that it was inflammable and burnt with a good"
"2367",35,"bright flame—was, in fact, an excellent candle—and I put it in my"
"2368",35,"pocket. I found no explosives, however, nor any means of breaking down"
"2369",35,"the bronze doors. As yet my iron crowbar was the most helpful thing I"
"2370",35,"had chanced upon. Nevertheless I left that gallery greatly elated."
"2371",35,""
"2372",35,"“I cannot tell you all the story of that long afternoon. It would"
"2373",35,"require a great effort of memory to recall my explorations in at all"
"2374",35,"the proper order. I remember a long gallery of rusting stands of arms,"
"2375",35,"and how I hesitated between my crowbar and a hatchet or a sword. I"
"2376",35,"could not carry both, however, and my bar of iron promised best against"
"2377",35,"the bronze gates. There were numbers of guns, pistols, and rifles. The"
"2378",35,"most were masses of rust, but many were of some new metal, and still"
"2379",35,"fairly sound. But any cartridges or powder there may once have been had"
"2380",35,"rotted into dust. One corner I saw was charred and shattered; perhaps,"
"2381",35,"I thought, by an explosion among the specimens. In another place was a"
"2382",35,"vast array of idols—Polynesian, Mexican, Grecian, Phœnician, every"
"2383",35,"country on earth, I should think. And here, yielding to an irresistible"
"2384",35,"impulse, I wrote my name upon the nose of a steatite monster from South"
"2385",35,"America that particularly took my fancy."
"2386",35,""
"2387",35,"“As the evening drew on, my interest waned. I went through gallery"
"2388",35,"after gallery, dusty, silent, often ruinous, the exhibits sometimes"
"2389",35,"mere heaps of rust and lignite, sometimes fresher. In one place I"
"2390",35,"suddenly found myself near the model of a tin mine, and then by the"
"2391",35,"merest accident I discovered, in an air-tight case, two dynamite"
"2392",35,"cartridges! I shouted ‘Eureka!’ and smashed the case with joy. Then"
"2393",35,"came a doubt. I hesitated. Then, selecting a little side gallery, I"
"2394",35,"made my essay. I never felt such a disappointment as I did in waiting"
"2395",35,"five, ten, fifteen minutes for an explosion that never came. Of course"
"2396",35,"the things were dummies, as I might have guessed from their presence. I"
"2397",35,"really believe that had they not been so, I should have rushed off"
"2398",35,"incontinently and blown Sphinx, bronze doors, and (as it proved) my"
"2399",35,"chances of finding the Time Machine, all together into non-existence."
"2400",35,""
"2401",35,"“It was after that, I think, that we came to a little open court within"
"2402",35,"the palace. It was turfed, and had three fruit-trees. So we rested and"
"2403",35,"refreshed ourselves. Towards sunset I began to consider our position."
"2404",35,"Night was creeping upon us, and my inaccessible hiding-place had still"
"2405",35,"to be found. But that troubled me very little now. I had in my"
"2406",35,"possession a thing that was, perhaps, the best of all defences against"
"2407",35,"the Morlocks—I had matches! I had the camphor in my pocket, too, if a"
"2408",35,"blaze were needed. It seemed to me that the best thing we could do"
"2409",35,"would be to pass the night in the open, protected by a fire. In the"
"2410",35,"morning there was the getting of the Time Machine. Towards that, as"
"2411",35,"yet, I had only my iron mace. But now, with my growing knowledge, I"
"2412",35,"felt very differently towards those bronze doors. Up to this, I had"
"2413",35,"refrained from forcing them, largely because of the mystery on the"
"2414",35,"other side. They had never impressed me as being very strong, and I"
"2415",35,"hoped to find my bar of iron not altogether inadequate for the work."
"2416",35,""
"2417",35,""
"2418",35,""
"2419",35,""
"2420",35," XII."
"2421",35," In the Darkness"
"2422",35,""
"2423",35,""
"2424",35,"“We emerged from the Palace while the sun was still in part above the"
"2425",35,"horizon. I was determined to reach the White Sphinx early the next"
"2426",35,"morning, and ere the dusk I purposed pushing through the woods that had"
"2427",35,"stopped me on the previous journey. My plan was to go as far as"
"2428",35,"possible that night, and then, building a fire, to sleep in the"
"2429",35,"protection of its glare. Accordingly, as we went along I gathered any"
"2430",35,"sticks or dried grass I saw, and presently had my arms full of such"
"2431",35,"litter. Thus loaded, our progress was slower than I had anticipated,"
"2432",35,"and besides Weena was tired. And I, also, began to suffer from"
"2433",35,"sleepiness too; so that it was full night before we reached the wood."
"2434",35,"Upon the shrubby hill of its edge Weena would have stopped, fearing the"
"2435",35,"darkness before us; but a singular sense of impending calamity, that"
"2436",35,"should indeed have served me as a warning, drove me onward. I had been"
"2437",35,"without sleep for a night and two days, and I was feverish and"
"2438",35,"irritable. I felt sleep coming upon me, and the Morlocks with it."
"2439",35,""
"2440",35,"“While we hesitated, among the black bushes behind us, and dim against"
"2441",35,"their blackness, I saw three crouching figures. There was scrub and"
"2442",35,"long grass all about us, and I did not feel safe from their insidious"
"2443",35,"approach. The forest, I calculated, was rather less than a mile across."
"2444",35,"If we could get through it to the bare hillside, there, as it seemed to"
"2445",35,"me, was an altogether safer resting-place; I thought that with my"
"2446",35,"matches and my camphor I could contrive to keep my path illuminated"
"2447",35,"through the woods. Yet it was evident that if I was to flourish matches"
"2448",35,"with my hands I should have to abandon my firewood; so, rather"
"2449",35,"reluctantly, I put it down. And then it came into my head that I would"
"2450",35,"amaze our friends behind by lighting it. I was to discover the"
"2451",35,"atrocious folly of this proceeding, but it came to my mind as an"
"2452",35,"ingenious move for covering our retreat."
"2453",35,""
"2454",35,"“I don’t know if you have ever thought what a rare thing flame must be"
"2455",35,"in the absence of man and in a temperate climate. The sun’s heat is"
"2456",35,"rarely strong enough to burn, even when it is focused by dewdrops, as"
"2457",35,"is sometimes the case in more tropical districts. Lightning may blast"
"2458",35,"and blacken, but it rarely gives rise to widespread fire. Decaying"
"2459",35,"vegetation may occasionally smoulder with the heat of its fermentation,"
"2460",35,"but this rarely results in flame. In this decadence, too, the art of"
"2461",35,"fire-making had been forgotten on the earth. The red tongues that went"
"2462",35,"licking up my heap of wood were an altogether new and strange thing to"
"2463",35,"Weena."
"2464",35,""
"2465",35,"“She wanted to run to it and play with it. I believe she would have"
"2466",35,"cast herself into it had I not restrained her. But I caught her up, and"
"2467",35,"in spite of her struggles, plunged boldly before me into the wood. For"
"2468",35,"a little way the glare of my fire lit the path. Looking back presently,"
"2469",35,"I could see, through the crowded stems, that from my heap of sticks the"
"2470",35,"blaze had spread to some bushes adjacent, and a curved line of fire was"
"2471",35,"creeping up the grass of the hill. I laughed at that, and turned again"
"2472",35,"to the dark trees before me. It was very black, and Weena clung to me"
"2473",35,"convulsively, but there was still, as my eyes grew accustomed to the"
"2474",35,"darkness, sufficient light for me to avoid the stems. Overhead it was"
"2475",35,"simply black, except where a gap of remote blue sky shone down upon us"
"2476",35,"here and there. I lit none of my matches because I had no hand free."
"2477",35,"Upon my left arm I carried my little one, in my right hand I had my"
"2478",35,"iron bar."
"2479",35,""
"2480",35,"“For some way I heard nothing but the crackling twigs under my feet,"
"2481",35,"the faint rustle of the breeze above, and my own breathing and the"
"2482",35,"throb of the blood-vessels in my ears. Then I seemed to know of a"
"2483",35,"pattering behind me. I pushed on grimly. The pattering grew more"
"2484",35,"distinct, and then I caught the same queer sound and voices I had heard"
"2485",35,"in the Underworld. There were evidently several of the Morlocks, and"
"2486",35,"they were closing in upon me. Indeed, in another minute I felt a tug at"
"2487",35,"my coat, then something at my arm. And Weena shivered violently, and"
"2488",35,"became quite still."
"2489",35,""
"2490",35,"“It was time for a match. But to get one I must put her down. I did so,"
"2491",35,"and, as I fumbled with my pocket, a struggle began in the darkness"
"2492",35,"about my knees, perfectly silent on her part and with the same peculiar"
"2493",35,"cooing sounds from the Morlocks. Soft little hands, too, were creeping"
"2494",35,"over my coat and back, touching even my neck. Then the match scratched"
"2495",35,"and fizzed. I held it flaring, and saw the white backs of the Morlocks"
"2496",35,"in flight amid the trees. I hastily took a lump of camphor from my"
"2497",35,"pocket, and prepared to light it as soon as the match should wane. Then"
"2498",35,"I looked at Weena. She was lying clutching my feet and quite"
"2499",35,"motionless, with her face to the ground. With a sudden fright I stooped"
"2500",35,"to her. She seemed scarcely to breathe. I lit the block of camphor and"
"2501",35,"flung it to the ground, and as it split and flared up and drove back"
"2502",35,"the Morlocks and the shadows, I knelt down and lifted her. The wood"
"2503",35,"behind seemed full of the stir and murmur of a great company!"
"2504",35,""
"2505",35,"“She seemed to have fainted. I put her carefully upon my shoulder and"
"2506",35,"rose to push on, and then there came a horrible realisation. In"
"2507",35,"manœuvring with my matches and Weena, I had turned myself about several"
"2508",35,"times, and now I had not the faintest idea in what direction lay my"
"2509",35,"path. For all I knew, I might be facing back towards the Palace of"
"2510",35,"Green Porcelain. I found myself in a cold sweat. I had to think rapidly"
"2511",35,"what to do. I determined to build a fire and encamp where we were. I"
"2512",35,"put Weena, still motionless, down upon a turfy bole, and very hastily,"
"2513",35,"as my first lump of camphor waned, I began collecting sticks and"
"2514",35,"leaves. Here and there out of the darkness round me the Morlocks’ eyes"
"2515",35,"shone like carbuncles."
"2516",35,""
"2517",35,"“The camphor flickered and went out. I lit a match, and as I did so,"
"2518",35,"two white forms that had been approaching Weena dashed hastily away."
"2519",35,"One was so blinded by the light that he came straight for me, and I"
"2520",35,"felt his bones grind under the blow of my fist. He gave a whoop of"
"2521",35,"dismay, staggered a little way, and fell down. I lit another piece of"
"2522",35,"camphor, and went on gathering my bonfire. Presently I noticed how dry"
"2523",35,"was some of the foliage above me, for since my arrival on the Time"
"2524",35,"Machine, a matter of a week, no rain had fallen. So, instead of casting"
"2525",35,"about among the trees for fallen twigs, I began leaping up and dragging"
"2526",35,"down branches. Very soon I had a choking smoky fire of green wood and"
"2527",35,"dry sticks, and could economise my camphor. Then I turned to where"
"2528",35,"Weena lay beside my iron mace. I tried what I could to revive her, but"
"2529",35,"she lay like one dead. I could not even satisfy myself whether or not"
"2530",35,"she breathed."
"2531",35,""
"2532",35,"“Now, the smoke of the fire beat over towards me, and it must have made"
"2533",35,"me heavy of a sudden. Moreover, the vapour of camphor was in the air."
"2534",35,"My fire would not need replenishing for an hour or so. I felt very"
"2535",35,"weary after my exertion, and sat down. The wood, too, was full of a"
"2536",35,"slumbrous murmur that I did not understand. I seemed just to nod and"
"2537",35,"open my eyes. But all was dark, and the Morlocks had their hands upon"
"2538",35,"me. Flinging off their clinging fingers I hastily felt in my pocket for"
"2539",35,"the match-box, and—it had gone! Then they gripped and closed with me"
"2540",35,"again. In a moment I knew what had happened. I had slept, and my fire"
"2541",35,"had gone out, and the bitterness of death came over my soul. The forest"
"2542",35,"seemed full of the smell of burning wood. I was caught by the neck, by"
"2543",35,"the hair, by the arms, and pulled down. It was indescribably horrible"
"2544",35,"in the darkness to feel all these soft creatures heaped upon me. I felt"
"2545",35,"as if I was in a monstrous spider’s web. I was overpowered, and went"
"2546",35,"down. I felt little teeth nipping at my neck. I rolled over, and as I"
"2547",35,"did so my hand came against my iron lever. It gave me strength. I"
"2548",35,"struggled up, shaking the human rats from me, and, holding the bar"
"2549",35,"short, I thrust where I judged their faces might be. I could feel the"
"2550",35,"succulent giving of flesh and bone under my blows, and for a moment I"
"2551",35,"was free."
"2552",35,""
"2553",35,"“The strange exultation that so often seems to accompany hard fighting"
"2554",35,"came upon me. I knew that both I and Weena were lost, but I determined"
"2555",35,"to make the Morlocks pay for their meat. I stood with my back to a"
"2556",35,"tree, swinging the iron bar before me. The whole wood was full of the"
"2557",35,"stir and cries of them. A minute passed. Their voices seemed to rise to"
"2558",35,"a higher pitch of excitement, and their movements grew faster. Yet none"
"2559",35,"came within reach. I stood glaring at the blackness. Then suddenly came"
"2560",35,"hope. What if the Morlocks were afraid? And close on the heels of that"
"2561",35,"came a strange thing. The darkness seemed to grow luminous. Very dimly"
"2562",35,"I began to see the Morlocks about me—three battered at my feet—and then"
"2563",35,"I recognised, with incredulous surprise, that the others were running,"
"2564",35,"in an incessant stream, as it seemed, from behind me, and away through"
"2565",35,"the wood in front. And their backs seemed no longer white, but reddish."
"2566",35,"As I stood agape, I saw a little red spark go drifting across a gap of"
"2567",35,"starlight between the branches, and vanish. And at that I understood"
"2568",35,"the smell of burning wood, the slumbrous murmur that was growing now"
"2569",35,"into a gusty roar, the red glow, and the Morlocks’ flight."
"2570",35,""
"2571",35,"“Stepping out from behind my tree and looking back, I saw, through the"
"2572",35,"black pillars of the nearer trees, the flames of the burning forest. It"
"2573",35,"was my first fire coming after me. With that I looked for Weena, but"
"2574",35,"she was gone. The hissing and crackling behind me, the explosive thud"
"2575",35,"as each fresh tree burst into flame, left little time for reflection."
"2576",35,"My iron bar still gripped, I followed in the Morlocks’ path. It was a"
"2577",35,"close race. Once the flames crept forward so swiftly on my right as I"
"2578",35,"ran that I was outflanked and had to strike off to the left. But at"
"2579",35,"last I emerged upon a small open space, and as I did so, a Morlock came"
"2580",35,"blundering towards me, and past me, and went on straight into the fire!"
"2581",35,""
"2582",35,"“And now I was to see the most weird and horrible thing, I think, of"
"2583",35,"all that I beheld in that future age. This whole space was as bright as"
"2584",35,"day with the reflection of the fire. In the centre was a hillock or"
"2585",35,"tumulus, surmounted by a scorched hawthorn. Beyond this was another arm"
"2586",35,"of the burning forest, with yellow tongues already writhing from it,"
"2587",35,"completely encircling the space with a fence of fire. Upon the hillside"
"2588",35,"were some thirty or forty Morlocks, dazzled by the light and heat, and"
"2589",35,"blundering hither and thither against each other in their bewilderment."
"2590",35,"At first I did not realise their blindness, and struck furiously at"
"2591",35,"them with my bar, in a frenzy of fear, as they approached me, killing"
"2592",35,"one and crippling several more. But when I had watched the gestures of"
"2593",35,"one of them groping under the hawthorn against the red sky, and heard"
"2594",35,"their moans, I was assured of their absolute helplessness and misery in"
"2595",35,"the glare, and I struck no more of them."
"2596",35,""
"2597",35,"“Yet every now and then one would come straight towards me, setting"
"2598",35,"loose a quivering horror that made me quick to elude him. At one time"
"2599",35,"the flames died down somewhat, and I feared the foul creatures would"
"2600",35,"presently be able to see me. I was thinking of beginning the fight by"
"2601",35,"killing some of them before this should happen; but the fire burst out"
"2602",35,"again brightly, and I stayed my hand. I walked about the hill among"
"2603",35,"them and avoided them, looking for some trace of Weena. But Weena was"
"2604",35,"gone."
"2605",35,""
"2606",35,"“At last I sat down on the summit of the hillock, and watched this"
"2607",35,"strange incredible company of blind things groping to and fro, and"
"2608",35,"making uncanny noises to each other, as the glare of the fire beat on"
"2609",35,"them. The coiling uprush of smoke streamed across the sky, and through"
"2610",35,"the rare tatters of that red canopy, remote as though they belonged to"
"2611",35,"another universe, shone the little stars. Two or three Morlocks came"
"2612",35,"blundering into me, and I drove them off with blows of my fists,"
"2613",35,"trembling as I did so."
"2614",35,""
"2615",35,"“For the most part of that night I was persuaded it was a nightmare. I"
"2616",35,"bit myself and screamed in a passionate desire to awake. I beat the"
"2617",35,"ground with my hands, and got up and sat down again, and wandered here"
"2618",35,"and there, and again sat down. Then I would fall to rubbing my eyes and"
"2619",35,"calling upon God to let me awake. Thrice I saw Morlocks put their heads"
"2620",35,"down in a kind of agony and rush into the flames. But, at last, above"
"2621",35,"the subsiding red of the fire, above the streaming masses of black"
"2622",35,"smoke and the whitening and blackening tree stumps, and the diminishing"
"2623",35,"numbers of these dim creatures, came the white light of the day."
"2624",35,""
"2625",35,"“I searched again for traces of Weena, but there were none. It was"
"2626",35,"plain that they had left her poor little body in the forest. I cannot"
"2627",35,"describe how it relieved me to think that it had escaped the awful fate"
"2628",35,"to which it seemed destined. As I thought of that, I was almost moved"
"2629",35,"to begin a massacre of the helpless abominations about me, but I"
"2630",35,"contained myself. The hillock, as I have said, was a kind of island in"
"2631",35,"the forest. From its summit I could now make out through a haze of"
"2632",35,"smoke the Palace of Green Porcelain, and from that I could get my"
"2633",35,"bearings for the White Sphinx. And so, leaving the remnant of these"
"2634",35,"damned souls still going hither and thither and moaning, as the day"
"2635",35,"grew clearer, I tied some grass about my feet and limped on across"
"2636",35,"smoking ashes and among black stems that still pulsated internally with"
"2637",35,"fire, towards the hiding-place of the Time Machine. I walked slowly,"
"2638",35,"for I was almost exhausted, as well as lame, and I felt the intensest"
"2639",35,"wretchedness for the horrible death of little Weena. It seemed an"
"2640",35,"overwhelming calamity. Now, in this old familiar room, it is more like"
"2641",35,"the sorrow of a dream than an actual loss. But that morning it left me"
"2642",35,"absolutely lonely again—terribly alone. I began to think of this house"
"2643",35,"of mine, of this fireside, of some of you, and with such thoughts came"
"2644",35,"a longing that was pain."
"2645",35,""
"2646",35,"“But, as I walked over the smoking ashes under the bright morning sky,"
"2647",35,"I made a discovery. In my trouser pocket were still some loose matches."
"2648",35,"The box must have leaked before it was lost."
"2649",35,""
"2650",35,""
"2651",35,""
"2652",35,""
"2653",35," XIII."
"2654",35," The Trap of the White Sphinx"
"2655",35,""
"2656",35,""
"2657",35,"“About eight or nine in the morning I came to the same seat of yellow"
"2658",35,"metal from which I had viewed the world upon the evening of my arrival."
"2659",35,"I thought of my hasty conclusions upon that evening and could not"
"2660",35,"refrain from laughing bitterly at my confidence. Here was the same"
"2661",35,"beautiful scene, the same abundant foliage, the same splendid palaces"
"2662",35,"and magnificent ruins, the same silver river running between its"
"2663",35,"fertile banks. The gay robes of the beautiful people moved hither and"
"2664",35,"thither among the trees. Some were bathing in exactly the place where I"
"2665",35,"had saved Weena, and that suddenly gave me a keen stab of pain. And"
"2666",35,"like blots upon the landscape rose the cupolas above the ways to the"
"2667",35,"Underworld. I understood now what all the beauty of the Overworld"
"2668",35,"people covered. Very pleasant was their day, as pleasant as the day of"
"2669",35,"the cattle in the field. Like the cattle, they knew of no enemies and"
"2670",35,"provided against no needs. And their end was the same."
"2671",35,""
"2672",35,"“I grieved to think how brief the dream of the human intellect had"
"2673",35,"been. It had committed suicide. It had set itself steadfastly towards"
"2674",35,"comfort and ease, a balanced society with security and permanency as"
"2675",35,"its watchword, it had attained its hopes—to come to this at last. Once,"
"2676",35,"life and property must have reached almost absolute safety. The rich"
"2677",35,"had been assured of his wealth and comfort, the toiler assured of his"
"2678",35,"life and work. No doubt in that perfect world there had been no"
"2679",35,"unemployed problem, no social question left unsolved. And a great quiet"
"2680",35,"had followed."
"2681",35,""
"2682",35,"“It is a law of nature we overlook, that intellectual versatility is"
"2683",35,"the compensation for change, danger, and trouble. An animal perfectly"
"2684",35,"in harmony with its environment is a perfect mechanism. Nature never"
"2685",35,"appeals to intelligence until habit and instinct are useless. There is"
"2686",35,"no intelligence where there is no change and no need of change. Only"
"2687",35,"those animals partake of intelligence that have to meet a huge variety"
"2688",35,"of needs and dangers."
"2689",35,""
"2690",35,"“So, as I see it, the Upperworld man had drifted towards his feeble"
"2691",35,"prettiness, and the Underworld to mere mechanical industry. But that"
"2692",35,"perfect state had lacked one thing even for mechanical"
"2693",35,"perfection—absolute permanency. Apparently as time went on, the feeding"
"2694",35,"of an Underworld, however it was effected, had become disjointed."
"2695",35,"Mother Necessity, who had been staved off for a few thousand years,"
"2696",35,"came back again, and she began below. The Underworld being in contact"
"2697",35,"with machinery, which, however perfect, still needs some little thought"
"2698",35,"outside habit, had probably retained perforce rather more initiative,"
"2699",35,"if less of every other human character, than the Upper. And when other"
"2700",35,"meat failed them, they turned to what old habit had hitherto forbidden."
"2701",35,"So I say I saw it in my last view of the world of Eight Hundred and Two"
"2702",35,"Thousand Seven Hundred and One. It may be as wrong an explanation as"
"2703",35,"mortal wit could invent. It is how the thing shaped itself to me, and"
"2704",35,"as that I give it to you."
"2705",35,""
"2706",35,"“After the fatigues, excitements, and terrors of the past days, and in"
"2707",35,"spite of my grief, this seat and the tranquil view and the warm"
"2708",35,"sunlight were very pleasant. I was very tired and sleepy, and soon my"
"2709",35,"theorising passed into dozing. Catching myself at that, I took my own"
"2710",35,"hint, and spreading myself out upon the turf I had a long and"
"2711",35,"refreshing sleep."
"2712",35,""
"2713",35,"“I awoke a little before sunsetting. I now felt safe against being"
"2714",35,"caught napping by the Morlocks, and, stretching myself, I came on down"
"2715",35,"the hill towards the White Sphinx. I had my crowbar in one hand, and"
"2716",35,"the other hand played with the matches in my pocket."
"2717",35,""
"2718",35,"“And now came a most unexpected thing. As I approached the pedestal of"
"2719",35,"the sphinx I found the bronze valves were open. They had slid down into"
"2720",35,"grooves."
"2721",35,""
"2722",35,"“At that I stopped short before them, hesitating to enter."
"2723",35,""
"2724",35,"“Within was a small apartment, and on a raised place in the corner of"
"2725",35,"this was the Time Machine. I had the small levers in my pocket. So"
"2726",35,"here, after all my elaborate preparations for the siege of the White"
"2727",35,"Sphinx, was a meek surrender. I threw my iron bar away, almost sorry"
"2728",35,"not to use it."
"2729",35,""
"2730",35,"“A sudden thought came into my head as I stooped towards the portal."
"2731",35,"For once, at least, I grasped the mental operations of the Morlocks."
"2732",35,"Suppressing a strong inclination to laugh, I stepped through the bronze"
"2733",35,"frame and up to the Time Machine. I was surprised to find it had been"
"2734",35,"carefully oiled and cleaned. I have suspected since that the Morlocks"
"2735",35,"had even partially taken it to pieces while trying in their dim way to"
"2736",35,"grasp its purpose."
"2737",35,""
"2738",35,"“Now as I stood and examined it, finding a pleasure in the mere touch"
"2739",35,"of the contrivance, the thing I had expected happened. The bronze"
"2740",35,"panels suddenly slid up and struck the frame with a clang. I was in the"
"2741",35,"dark—trapped. So the Morlocks thought. At that I chuckled gleefully."
"2742",35,""
"2743",35,"“I could already hear their murmuring laughter as they came towards me."
"2744",35,"Very calmly I tried to strike the match. I had only to fix on the"
"2745",35,"levers and depart then like a ghost. But I had overlooked one little"
"2746",35,"thing. The matches were of that abominable kind that light only on the"
"2747",35,"box."
"2748",35,""
"2749",35,"“You may imagine how all my calm vanished. The little brutes were close"
"2750",35,"upon me. One touched me. I made a sweeping blow in the dark at them"
"2751",35,"with the levers, and began to scramble into the saddle of the machine."
"2752",35,"Then came one hand upon me and then another. Then I had simply to fight"
"2753",35,"against their persistent fingers for my levers, and at the same time"
