"8838",36,"of the parapet."
"8839",36,""
"8840",36,"From this position a shrubbery hid the greater portion of Putney, but"
"8841",36,"we could see the river below, a bubbly mass of red weed, and the low"
"8842",36,"parts of Lambeth flooded and red. The red creeper swarmed up the trees"
"8843",36,"about the old palace, and their branches stretched gaunt and dead, and"
"8844",36,"set with shrivelled leaves, from amid its clusters. It was strange how"
"8845",36,"entirely dependent both these things were upon flowing water for their"
"8846",36,"propagation. About us neither had gained a footing; laburnums, pink"
"8847",36,"mays, snowballs, and trees of arbor-vitae, rose out of laurels and"
"8848",36,"hydrangeas, green and brilliant into the sunlight. Beyond Kensington"
"8849",36,"dense smoke was rising, and that and a blue haze hid the northward"
"8850",36,"hills."
"8851",36,""
"8852",36,"The artilleryman began to tell me of the sort of people who still"
"8853",36,"remained in London."
"8854",36,""
"8855",36,"“One night last week,” he said, “some fools got the electric light in"
"8856",36,"order, and there was all Regent Street and the Circus ablaze, crowded"
"8857",36,"with painted and ragged drunkards, men and women, dancing and shouting"
"8858",36,"till dawn. A man who was there told me. And as the day came they became"
"8859",36,"aware of a fighting-machine standing near by the Langham and looking"
"8860",36,"down at them. Heaven knows how long he had been there. It must have"
"8861",36,"given some of them a nasty turn. He came down the road towards them,"
"8862",36,"and picked up nearly a hundred too drunk or frightened to run away.”"
"8863",36,""
"8864",36,"Grotesque gleam of a time no history will ever fully describe!"
"8865",36,""
"8866",36,"From that, in answer to my questions, he came round to his grandiose"
"8867",36,"plans again. He grew enthusiastic. He talked so eloquently of the"
"8868",36,"possibility of capturing a fighting-machine that I more than half"
"8869",36,"believed in him again. But now that I was beginning to understand"
"8870",36,"something of his quality, I could divine the stress he laid on doing"
"8871",36,"nothing precipitately. And I noted that now there was no question that"
"8872",36,"he personally was to capture and fight the great machine."
"8873",36,""
"8874",36,"After a time we went down to the cellar. Neither of us seemed disposed"
"8875",36,"to resume digging, and when he suggested a meal, I was nothing loath."
"8876",36,"He became suddenly very generous, and when we had eaten he went away"
"8877",36,"and returned with some excellent cigars. We lit these, and his optimism"
"8878",36,"glowed. He was inclined to regard my coming as a great occasion."
"8879",36,""
"8880",36,"“There’s some champagne in the cellar,” he said."
"8881",36,""
"8882",36,"“We can dig better on this Thames-side burgundy,” said I."
"8883",36,""
"8884",36,"“No,” said he; “I am host today. Champagne! Great God! We’ve a heavy"
"8885",36,"enough task before us! Let us take a rest and gather strength while we"
"8886",36,"may. Look at these blistered hands!”"
"8887",36,""
"8888",36,"And pursuant to this idea of a holiday, he insisted upon playing cards"
"8889",36,"after we had eaten. He taught me euchre, and after dividing London"
"8890",36,"between us, I taking the northern side and he the southern, we played"
"8891",36,"for parish points. Grotesque and foolish as this will seem to the sober"
"8892",36,"reader, it is absolutely true, and what is more remarkable, I found the"
"8893",36,"card game and several others we played extremely interesting."
"8894",36,""
"8895",36,"Strange mind of man! that, with our species upon the edge of"
"8896",36,"extermination or appalling degradation, with no clear prospect before"
"8897",36,"us but the chance of a horrible death, we could sit following the"
"8898",36,"chance of this painted pasteboard, and playing the “joker” with vivid"
"8899",36,"delight. Afterwards he taught me poker, and I beat him at three tough"
"8900",36,"chess games. When dark came we decided to take the risk, and lit a"
"8901",36,"lamp."
"8902",36,""
"8903",36,"After an interminable string of games, we supped, and the artilleryman"
"8904",36,"finished the champagne. We went on smoking the cigars. He was no longer"
"8905",36,"the energetic regenerator of his species I had encountered in the"
"8906",36,"morning. He was still optimistic, but it was a less kinetic, a more"
"8907",36,"thoughtful optimism. I remember he wound up with my health, proposed in"
"8908",36,"a speech of small variety and considerable intermittence. I took a"
"8909",36,"cigar, and went upstairs to look at the lights of which he had spoken"
"8910",36,"that blazed so greenly along the Highgate hills."
"8911",36,""
"8912",36,"At first I stared unintelligently across the London valley. The"
"8913",36,"northern hills were shrouded in darkness; the fires near Kensington"
"8914",36,"glowed redly, and now and then an orange-red tongue of flame flashed up"
"8915",36,"and vanished in the deep blue night. All the rest of London was black."
"8916",36,"Then, nearer, I perceived a strange light, a pale, violet-purple"
"8917",36,"fluorescent glow, quivering under the night breeze. For a space I could"
"8918",36,"not understand it, and then I knew that it must be the red weed from"
"8919",36,"which this faint irradiation proceeded. With that realisation my"
"8920",36,"dormant sense of wonder, my sense of the proportion of things, awoke"
"8921",36,"again. I glanced from that to Mars, red and clear, glowing high in the"
"8922",36,"west, and then gazed long and earnestly at the darkness of Hampstead"
"8923",36,"and Highgate."
"8924",36,""
"8925",36,"I remained a very long time upon the roof, wondering at the grotesque"
"8926",36,"changes of the day. I recalled my mental states from the midnight"
"8927",36,"prayer to the foolish card-playing. I had a violent revulsion of"
"8928",36,"feeling. I remember I flung away the cigar with a certain wasteful"
"8929",36,"symbolism. My folly came to me with glaring exaggeration. I seemed a"
"8930",36,"traitor to my wife and to my kind; I was filled with remorse. I"
"8931",36,"resolved to leave this strange undisciplined dreamer of great things to"
"8932",36,"his drink and gluttony, and to go on into London. There, it seemed to"
"8933",36,"me, I had the best chance of learning what the Martians and my"
"8934",36,"fellowmen were doing. I was still upon the roof when the late moon"
"8935",36,"rose."
"8936",36,""
"8937",36,""
"8938",36,""
"8939",36,""
"8940",36,"VIII."
"8941",36,"DEAD LONDON."
"8942",36,""
"8943",36,""
"8944",36,"After I had parted from the artilleryman, I went down the hill, and by"
"8945",36,"the High Street across the bridge to Fulham. The red weed was"
"8946",36,"tumultuous at that time, and nearly choked the bridge roadway; but its"
"8947",36,"fronds were already whitened in patches by the spreading disease that"
"8948",36,"presently removed it so swiftly."
"8949",36,""
"8950",36,"At the corner of the lane that runs to Putney Bridge station I found a"
"8951",36,"man lying. He was as black as a sweep with the black dust, alive, but"
"8952",36,"helplessly and speechlessly drunk. I could get nothing from him but"
"8953",36,"curses and furious lunges at my head. I think I should have stayed by"
"8954",36,"him but for the brutal expression of his face."
"8955",36,""
"8956",36,"There was black dust along the roadway from the bridge onwards, and it"
"8957",36,"grew thicker in Fulham. The streets were horribly quiet. I got"
"8958",36,"food—sour, hard, and mouldy, but quite eatable—in a baker’s shop here."
"8959",36,"Some way towards Walham Green the streets became clear of powder, and I"
"8960",36,"passed a white terrace of houses on fire; the noise of the burning was"
"8961",36,"an absolute relief. Going on towards Brompton, the streets were quiet"
"8962",36,"again."
"8963",36,""
"8964",36,"Here I came once more upon the black powder in the streets and upon"
"8965",36,"dead bodies. I saw altogether about a dozen in the length of the Fulham"
"8966",36,"Road. They had been dead many days, so that I hurried quickly past"
"8967",36,"them. The black powder covered them over, and softened their outlines."
"8968",36,"One or two had been disturbed by dogs."
"8969",36,""
"8970",36,"Where there was no black powder, it was curiously like a Sunday in the"
"8971",36,"City, with the closed shops, the houses locked up and the blinds drawn,"
"8972",36,"the desertion, and the stillness. In some places plunderers had been at"
"8973",36,"work, but rarely at other than the provision and wine shops. A"
"8974",36,"jeweller’s window had been broken open in one place, but apparently the"
"8975",36,"thief had been disturbed, and a number of gold chains and a watch lay"
"8976",36,"scattered on the pavement. I did not trouble to touch them. Farther on"
"8977",36,"was a tattered woman in a heap on a doorstep; the hand that hung over"
"8978",36,"her knee was gashed and bled down her rusty brown dress, and a smashed"
"8979",36,"magnum of champagne formed a pool across the pavement. She seemed"
"8980",36,"asleep, but she was dead."
"8981",36,""
"8982",36,"The farther I penetrated into London, the profounder grew the"
"8983",36,"stillness. But it was not so much the stillness of death—it was the"
"8984",36,"stillness of suspense, of expectation. At any time the destruction that"
"8985",36,"had already singed the northwestern borders of the metropolis, and had"
"8986",36,"annihilated Ealing and Kilburn, might strike among these houses and"
"8987",36,"leave them smoking ruins. It was a city condemned and derelict. . . ."
"8988",36,""
"8989",36,"In South Kensington the streets were clear of dead and of black powder."
"8990",36,"It was near South Kensington that I first heard the howling. It crept"
"8991",36,"almost imperceptibly upon my senses. It was a sobbing alternation of"
"8992",36,"two notes, “Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,” keeping on perpetually. When I"
"8993",36,"passed streets that ran northward it grew in volume, and houses and"
"8994",36,"buildings seemed to deaden and cut it off again. It came in a full tide"
"8995",36,"down Exhibition Road. I stopped, staring towards Kensington Gardens,"
"8996",36,"wondering at this strange, remote wailing. It was as if that mighty"
"8997",36,"desert of houses had found a voice for its fear and solitude."
"8998",36,""
"8999",36,"“Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,” wailed that superhuman note—great waves of"
"9000",36,"sound sweeping down the broad, sunlit roadway, between the tall"
"9001",36,"buildings on each side. I turned northwards, marvelling, towards the"
"9002",36,"iron gates of Hyde Park. I had half a mind to break into the Natural"
"9003",36,"History Museum and find my way up to the summits of the towers, in"
"9004",36,"order to see across the park. But I decided to keep to the ground,"
"9005",36,"where quick hiding was possible, and so went on up the Exhibition Road."
"9006",36,"All the large mansions on each side of the road were empty and still,"
"9007",36,"and my footsteps echoed against the sides of the houses. At the top,"
"9008",36,"near the park gate, I came upon a strange sight—a bus overturned, and"
"9009",36,"the skeleton of a horse picked clean. I puzzled over this for a time,"
"9010",36,"and then went on to the bridge over the Serpentine. The voice grew"
"9011",36,"stronger and stronger, though I could see nothing above the housetops"
"9012",36,"on the north side of the park, save a haze of smoke to the northwest."
"9013",36,""
"9014",36,"“Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,” cried the voice, coming, as it seemed to me,"
"9015",36,"from the district about Regent’s Park. The desolating cry worked upon"
"9016",36,"my mind. The mood that had sustained me passed. The wailing took"
"9017",36,"possession of me. I found I was intensely weary, footsore, and now"
"9018",36,"again hungry and thirsty."
"9019",36,""
"9020",36,"It was already past noon. Why was I wandering alone in this city of the"
"9021",36,"dead? Why was I alone when all London was lying in state, and in its"
"9022",36,"black shroud? I felt intolerably lonely. My mind ran on old friends"
"9023",36,"that I had forgotten for years. I thought of the poisons in the"
"9024",36,"chemists’ shops, of the liquors the wine merchants stored; I recalled"
"9025",36,"the two sodden creatures of despair, who so far as I knew, shared the"
"9026",36,"city with myself. . . ."
"9027",36,""
"9028",36,"I came into Oxford Street by the Marble Arch, and here again were black"
"9029",36,"powder and several bodies, and an evil, ominous smell from the gratings"
"9030",36,"of the cellars of some of the houses. I grew very thirsty after the"
"9031",36,"heat of my long walk. With infinite trouble I managed to break into a"
"9032",36,"public-house and get food and drink. I was weary after eating, and went"
"9033",36,"into the parlour behind the bar, and slept on a black horsehair sofa I"
"9034",36,"found there."
"9035",36,""
"9036",36,"I awoke to find that dismal howling still in my ears, “Ulla, ulla,"
"9037",36,"ulla, ulla.” It was now dusk, and after I had routed out some biscuits"
"9038",36,"and a cheese in the bar—there was a meat safe, but it contained nothing"
"9039",36,"but maggots—I wandered on through the silent residential squares to"
"9040",36,"Baker Street—Portman Square is the only one I can name—and so came out"
"9041",36,"at last upon Regent’s Park. And as I emerged from the top of Baker"
"9042",36,"Street, I saw far away over the trees in the clearness of the sunset"
"9043",36,"the hood of the Martian giant from which this howling proceeded. I was"
"9044",36,"not terrified. I came upon him as if it were a matter of course. I"
"9045",36,"watched him for some time, but he did not move. He appeared to be"
"9046",36,"standing and yelling, for no reason that I could discover."
"9047",36,""
"9048",36,"I tried to formulate a plan of action. That perpetual sound of “Ulla,"
"9049",36,"ulla, ulla, ulla,” confused my mind. Perhaps I was too tired to be very"
"9050",36,"fearful. Certainly I was more curious to know the reason of this"
"9051",36,"monotonous crying than afraid. I turned back away from the park and"
"9052",36,"struck into Park Road, intending to skirt the park, went along under"
"9053",36,"the shelter of the terraces, and got a view of this stationary, howling"
"9054",36,"Martian from the direction of St. John’s Wood. A couple of hundred"
"9055",36,"yards out of Baker Street I heard a yelping chorus, and saw, first a"
"9056",36,"dog with a piece of putrescent red meat in his jaws coming headlong"
"9057",36,"towards me, and then a pack of starving mongrels in pursuit of him. He"
"9058",36,"made a wide curve to avoid me, as though he feared I might prove a"
"9059",36,"fresh competitor. As the yelping died away down the silent road, the"
"9060",36,"wailing sound of “Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,” reasserted itself."
"9061",36,""
"9062",36,"I came upon the wrecked handling-machine halfway to St. John’s Wood"
"9063",36,"station. At first I thought a house had fallen across the road. It was"
"9064",36,"only as I clambered among the ruins that I saw, with a start, this"
"9065",36,"mechanical Samson lying, with its tentacles bent and smashed and"
"9066",36,"twisted, among the ruins it had made. The forepart was shattered. It"
"9067",36,"seemed as if it had driven blindly straight at the house, and had been"
"9068",36,"overwhelmed in its overthrow. It seemed to me then that this might have"
"9069",36,"happened by a handling-machine escaping from the guidance of its"
"9070",36,"Martian. I could not clamber among the ruins to see it, and the"
"9071",36,"twilight was now so far advanced that the blood with which its seat was"
"9072",36,"smeared, and the gnawed gristle of the Martian that the dogs had left,"
"9073",36,"were invisible to me."
"9074",36,""
"9075",36,"Wondering still more at all that I had seen, I pushed on towards"
"9076",36,"Primrose Hill. Far away, through a gap in the trees, I saw a second"
"9077",36,"Martian, as motionless as the first, standing in the park towards the"
"9078",36,"Zoological Gardens, and silent. A little beyond the ruins about the"
"9079",36,"smashed handling-machine I came upon the red weed again, and found the"
"9080",36,"Regent’s Canal, a spongy mass of dark-red vegetation."
"9081",36,""
"9082",36,"As I crossed the bridge, the sound of “Ulla, ulla, ulla, ulla,” ceased."
"9083",36,"It was, as it were, cut off. The silence came like a thunderclap."
"9084",36,""
"9085",36,"The dusky houses about me stood faint and tall and dim; the trees"
"9086",36,"towards the park were growing black. All about me the red weed"
"9087",36,"clambered among the ruins, writhing to get above me in the dimness."
"9088",36,"Night, the mother of fear and mystery, was coming upon me. But while"
"9089",36,"that voice sounded the solitude, the desolation, had been endurable; by"
"9090",36,"virtue of it London had still seemed alive, and the sense of life about"
"9091",36,"me had upheld me. Then suddenly a change, the passing of something—I"
"9092",36,"knew not what—and then a stillness that could be felt. Nothing but this"
"9093",36,"gaunt quiet."
"9094",36,""
"9095",36,"London about me gazed at me spectrally. The windows in the white houses"
"9096",36,"were like the eye sockets of skulls. About me my imagination found a"
"9097",36,"thousand noiseless enemies moving. Terror seized me, a horror of my"
"9098",36,"temerity. In front of me the road became pitchy black as though it was"
"9099",36,"tarred, and I saw a contorted shape lying across the pathway. I could"
"9100",36,"not bring myself to go on. I turned down St. John’s Wood Road, and ran"
"9101",36,"headlong from this unendurable stillness towards Kilburn. I hid from"
"9102",36,"the night and the silence, until long after midnight, in a cabmen’s"
"9103",36,"shelter in Harrow Road. But before the dawn my courage returned, and"
"9104",36,"while the stars were still in the sky I turned once more towards"
"9105",36,"Regent’s Park. I missed my way among the streets, and presently saw"
"9106",36,"down a long avenue, in the half-light of the early dawn, the curve of"
"9107",36,"Primrose Hill. On the summit, towering up to the fading stars, was a"
"9108",36,"third Martian, erect and motionless like the others."
"9109",36,""
"9110",36,"An insane resolve possessed me. I would die and end it. And I would"
"9111",36,"save myself even the trouble of killing myself. I marched on recklessly"
"9112",36,"towards this Titan, and then, as I drew nearer and the light grew, I"
"9113",36,"saw that a multitude of black birds was circling and clustering about"
"9114",36,"the hood. At that my heart gave a bound, and I began running along the"
"9115",36,"road."
"9116",36,""
"9117",36,"I hurried through the red weed that choked St. Edmund’s Terrace (I"
"9118",36,"waded breast-high across a torrent of water that was rushing down from"
"9119",36,"the waterworks towards the Albert Road), and emerged upon the grass"
"9120",36,"before the rising of the sun. Great mounds had been heaped about the"
"9121",36,"crest of the hill, making a huge redoubt of it—it was the final and"
"9122",36,"largest place the Martians had made—and from behind these heaps there"
"9123",36,"rose a thin smoke against the sky. Against the sky line an eager dog"
"9124",36,"ran and disappeared. The thought that had flashed into my mind grew"
"9125",36,"real, grew credible. I felt no fear, only a wild, trembling exultation,"
"9126",36,"as I ran up the hill towards the motionless monster. Out of the hood"
"9127",36,"hung lank shreds of brown, at which the hungry birds pecked and tore."
"9128",36,""
"9129",36,"In another moment I had scrambled up the earthen rampart and stood upon"
"9130",36,"its crest, and the interior of the redoubt was below me. A mighty space"
"9131",36,"it was, with gigantic machines here and there within it, huge mounds of"
"9132",36,"material and strange shelter places. And scattered about it, some in"
"9133",36,"their overturned war-machines, some in the now rigid handling-machines,"
"9134",36,"and a dozen of them stark and silent and laid in a row, were the"
"9135",36,"Martians—_dead_!—slain by the putrefactive and disease bacteria against"
"9136",36,"which their systems were unprepared; slain as the red weed was being"
"9137",36,"slain; slain, after all man’s devices had failed, by the humblest"
"9138",36,"things that God, in his wisdom, has put upon this earth."
"9139",36,""
"9140",36,"For so it had come about, as indeed I and many men might have foreseen"
"9141",36,"had not terror and disaster blinded our minds. These germs of disease"
"9142",36,"have taken toll of humanity since the beginning of things—taken toll of"
"9143",36,"our prehuman ancestors since life began here. But by virtue of this"
"9144",36,"natural selection of our kind we have developed resisting power; to no"
"9145",36,"germs do we succumb without a struggle, and to many—those that cause"
"9146",36,"putrefaction in dead matter, for instance—our living frames are"
"9147",36,"altogether immune. But there are no bacteria in Mars, and directly"
"9148",36,"these invaders arrived, directly they drank and fed, our microscopic"
"9149",36,"allies began to work their overthrow. Already when I watched them they"
"9150",36,"were irrevocably doomed, dying and rotting even as they went to and"
"9151",36,"fro. It was inevitable. By the toll of a billion deaths man has bought"
"9152",36,"his birthright of the earth, and it is his against all comers; it would"
"9153",36,"still be his were the Martians ten times as mighty as they are. For"
"9154",36,"neither do men live nor die in vain."
"9155",36,""
"9156",36,"Here and there they were scattered, nearly fifty altogether, in that"
"9157",36,"great gulf they had made, overtaken by a death that must have seemed to"
"9158",36,"them as incomprehensible as any death could be. To me also at that time"
"9159",36,"this death was incomprehensible. All I knew was that these things that"
"9160",36,"had been alive and so terrible to men were dead. For a moment I"
"9161",36,"believed that the destruction of Sennacherib had been repeated, that"
"9162",36,"God had repented, that the Angel of Death had slain them in the night."
"9163",36,""
"9164",36,"I stood staring into the pit, and my heart lightened gloriously, even"
"9165",36,"as the rising sun struck the world to fire about me with his rays. The"
"9166",36,"pit was still in darkness; the mighty engines, so great and wonderful"
"9167",36,"in their power and complexity, so unearthly in their tortuous forms,"
"9168",36,"rose weird and vague and strange out of the shadows towards the light."
"9169",36,"A multitude of dogs, I could hear, fought over the bodies that lay"
"9170",36,"darkly in the depth of the pit, far below me. Across the pit on its"
"9171",36,"farther lip, flat and vast and strange, lay the great flying-machine"
"9172",36,"with which they had been experimenting upon our denser atmosphere when"
"9173",36,"decay and death arrested them. Death had come not a day too soon. At"
"9174",36,"the sound of a cawing overhead I looked up at the huge fighting-machine"
"9175",36,"that would fight no more for ever, at the tattered red shreds of flesh"
"9176",36,"that dripped down upon the overturned seats on the summit of Primrose"
"9177",36,"Hill."
"9178",36,""
"9179",36,"I turned and looked down the slope of the hill to where, enhaloed now"
"9180",36,"in birds, stood those other two Martians that I had seen overnight,"
"9181",36,"just as death had overtaken them. The one had died, even as it had been"
"9182",36,"crying to its companions; perhaps it was the last to die, and its voice"
"9183",36,"had gone on perpetually until the force of its machinery was exhausted."
"9184",36,"They glittered now, harmless tripod towers of shining metal, in the"
"9185",36,"brightness of the rising sun."
"9186",36,""
"9187",36,"All about the pit, and saved as by a miracle from everlasting"
"9188",36,"destruction, stretched the great Mother of Cities. Those who have only"
"9189",36,"seen London veiled in her sombre robes of smoke can scarcely imagine"
"9190",36,"the naked clearness and beauty of the silent wilderness of houses."
"9191",36,""
"9192",36,"Eastward, over the blackened ruins of the Albert Terrace and the"
"9193",36,"splintered spire of the church, the sun blazed dazzling in a clear sky,"
"9194",36,"and here and there some facet in the great wilderness of roofs caught"
"9195",36,"the light and glared with a white intensity."
"9196",36,""
"9197",36,"Northward were Kilburn and Hampsted, blue and crowded with houses;"
"9198",36,"westward the great city was dimmed; and southward, beyond the Martians,"
"9199",36,"the green waves of Regent’s Park, the Langham Hotel, the dome of the"
"9200",36,"Albert Hall, the Imperial Institute, and the giant mansions of the"
"9201",36,"Brompton Road came out clear and little in the sunrise, the jagged"
"9202",36,"ruins of Westminster rising hazily beyond. Far away and blue were the"
"9203",36,"Surrey hills, and the towers of the Crystal Palace glittered like two"
"9204",36,"silver rods. The dome of St. Paul’s was dark against the sunrise, and"
"9205",36,"injured, I saw for the first time, by a huge gaping cavity on its"
"9206",36,"western side."
"9207",36,""
"9208",36,"And as I looked at this wide expanse of houses and factories and"
"9209",36,"churches, silent and abandoned; as I thought of the multitudinous hopes"
"9210",36,"and efforts, the innumerable hosts of lives that had gone to build this"
"9211",36,"human reef, and of the swift and ruthless destruction that had hung"
"9212",36,"over it all; when I realised that the shadow had been rolled back, and"
"9213",36,"that men might still live in the streets, and this dear vast dead city"
"9214",36,"of mine be once more alive and powerful, I felt a wave of emotion that"
"9215",36,"was near akin to tears."
"9216",36,""
"9217",36,"The torment was over. Even that day the healing would begin. The"
"9218",36,"survivors of the people scattered over the country—leaderless, lawless,"
"9219",36,"foodless, like sheep without a shepherd—the thousands who had fled by"
"9220",36,"sea, would begin to return; the pulse of life, growing stronger and"
"9221",36,"stronger, would beat again in the empty streets and pour across the"
"9222",36,"vacant squares. Whatever destruction was done, the hand of the"
"9223",36,"destroyer was stayed. All the gaunt wrecks, the blackened skeletons of"
"9224",36,"houses that stared so dismally at the sunlit grass of the hill, would"
"9225",36,"presently be echoing with the hammers of the restorers and ringing with"
"9226",36,"the tapping of their trowels. At the thought I extended my hands"
"9227",36,"towards the sky and began thanking God. In a year, thought I—in a year."
"9228",36,". . ."
"9229",36,""
"9230",36,"With overwhelming force came the thought of myself, of my wife, and the"
"9231",36,"old life of hope and tender helpfulness that had ceased for ever."
"9232",36,""
"9233",36,""
"9234",36,""
"9235",36,""
"9236",36,"IX."
"9237",36,"WRECKAGE."
"9238",36,""
"9239",36,""
"9240",36,"And now comes the strangest thing in my story. Yet, perhaps, it is not"
"9241",36,"altogether strange. I remember, clearly and coldly and vividly, all"
"9242",36,"that I did that day until the time that I stood weeping and praising"
"9243",36,"God upon the summit of Primrose Hill. And then I forget."
"9244",36,""
"9245",36,"Of the next three days I know nothing. I have learned since that, so"
"9246",36,"far from my being the first discoverer of the Martian overthrow,"
"9247",36,"several such wanderers as myself had already discovered this on the"
"9248",36,"previous night. One man—the first—had gone to St. Martin’s-le-Grand,"
"9249",36,"and, while I sheltered in the cabmen’s hut, had contrived to telegraph"
"9250",36,"to Paris. Thence the joyful news had flashed all over the world; a"
"9251",36,"thousand cities, chilled by ghastly apprehensions, suddenly flashed"
"9252",36,"into frantic illuminations; they knew of it in Dublin, Edinburgh,"
"9253",36,"Manchester, Birmingham, at the time when I stood upon the verge of the"
"9254",36,"pit. Already men, weeping with joy, as I have heard, shouting and"
"9255",36,"staying their work to shake hands and shout, were making up trains,"
"9256",36,"even as near as Crewe, to descend upon London. The church bells that"
"9257",36,"had ceased a fortnight since suddenly caught the news, until all"
"9258",36,"England was bell-ringing. Men on cycles, lean-faced, unkempt, scorched"
"9259",36,"along every country lane shouting of unhoped deliverance, shouting to"
"9260",36,"gaunt, staring figures of despair. And for the food! Across the"
"9261",36,"Channel, across the Irish Sea, across the Atlantic, corn, bread, and"
"9262",36,"meat were tearing to our relief. All the shipping in the world seemed"
"9263",36,"going Londonward in those days. But of all this I have no memory. I"
"9264",36,"drifted—a demented man. I found myself in a house of kindly people, who"
"9265",36,"had found me on the third day wandering, weeping, and raving through"
"9266",36,"the streets of St. John’s Wood. They have told me since that I was"
"9267",36,"singing some insane doggerel about “The Last Man Left Alive! Hurrah!"
"9268",36,"The Last Man Left Alive!” Troubled as they were with their own affairs,"
"9269",36,"these people, whose name, much as I would like to express my gratitude"
"9270",36,"to them, I may not even give here, nevertheless cumbered themselves"
"9271",36,"with me, sheltered me, and protected me from myself. Apparently they"
"9272",36,"had learned something of my story from me during the days of my lapse."
"9273",36,""
"9274",36,"Very gently, when my mind was assured again, did they break to me what"
"9275",36,"they had learned of the fate of Leatherhead. Two days after I was"
"9276",36,"imprisoned it had been destroyed, with every soul in it, by a Martian."
"9277",36,"He had swept it out of existence, as it seemed, without any"
"9278",36,"provocation, as a boy might crush an ant hill, in the mere wantonness"
"9279",36,"of power."
"9280",36,""
"9281",36,"I was a lonely man, and they were very kind to me. I was a lonely man"
"9282",36,"and a sad one, and they bore with me. I remained with them four days"
"9283",36,"after my recovery. All that time I felt a vague, a growing craving to"
"9284",36,"look once more on whatever remained of the little life that seemed so"
"9285",36,"happy and bright in my past. It was a mere hopeless desire to feast"
"9286",36,"upon my misery. They dissuaded me. They did all they could to divert me"
"9287",36,"from this morbidity. But at last I could resist the impulse no longer,"
"9288",36,"and, promising faithfully to return to them, and parting, as I will"
"9289",36,"confess, from these four-day friends with tears, I went out again into"
"9290",36,"the streets that had lately been so dark and strange and empty."
"9291",36,""
"9292",36,"Already they were busy with returning people; in places even there were"
"9293",36,"shops open, and I saw a drinking fountain running water."
"9294",36,""
"9295",36,"I remember how mockingly bright the day seemed as I went back on my"
"9296",36,"melancholy pilgrimage to the little house at Woking, how busy the"
"9297",36,"streets and vivid the moving life about me. So many people were abroad"
"9298",36,"everywhere, busied in a thousand activities, that it seemed incredible"
"9299",36,"that any great proportion of the population could have been slain. But"
"9300",36,"then I noticed how yellow were the skins of the people I met, how"
"9301",36,"shaggy the hair of the men, how large and bright their eyes, and that"
"9302",36,"every other man still wore his dirty rags. Their faces seemed all with"
"9303",36,"one of two expressions—a leaping exultation and energy or a grim"
"9304",36,"resolution. Save for the expression of the faces, London seemed a city"
"9305",36,"of tramps. The vestries were indiscriminately distributing bread sent"
"9306",36,"us by the French government. The ribs of the few horses showed"
"9307",36,"dismally. Haggard special constables with white badges stood at the"
"9308",36,"corners of every street. I saw little of the mischief wrought by the"
"9309",36,"Martians until I reached Wellington Street, and there I saw the red"
"9310",36,"weed clambering over the buttresses of Waterloo Bridge."
"9311",36,""
"9312",36,"At the corner of the bridge, too, I saw one of the common contrasts of"
"9313",36,"that grotesque time—a sheet of paper flaunting against a thicket of the"
"9314",36,"red weed, transfixed by a stick that kept it in place. It was the"
"9315",36,"placard of the first newspaper to resume publication—the _Daily Mail_."
"9316",36,"I bought a copy for a blackened shilling I found in my pocket. Most of"
"9317",36,"it was in blank, but the solitary compositor who did the thing had"
"9318",36,"amused himself by making a grotesque scheme of advertisement stereo on"
"9319",36,"the back page. The matter he printed was emotional; the news"
"9320",36,"organisation had not as yet found its way back. I learned nothing fresh"
"9321",36,"except that already in one week the examination of the Martian"
"9322",36,"mechanisms had yielded astonishing results. Among other things, the"
"9323",36,"article assured me what I did not believe at the time, that the “Secret"
"9324",36,"of Flying,” was discovered. At Waterloo I found the free trains that"
"9325",36,"were taking people to their homes. The first rush was already over."
"9326",36,"There were few people in the train, and I was in no mood for casual"
"9327",36,"conversation. I got a compartment to myself, and sat with folded arms,"
"9328",36,"looking greyly at the sunlit devastation that flowed past the windows."
"9329",36,"And just outside the terminus the train jolted over temporary rails,"
"9330",36,"and on either side of the railway the houses were blackened ruins. To"
"9331",36,"Clapham Junction the face of London was grimy with powder of the Black"
"9332",36,"Smoke, in spite of two days of thunderstorms and rain, and at Clapham"
"9333",36,"Junction the line had been wrecked again; there were hundreds of"
"9334",36,"out-of-work clerks and shopmen working side by side with the customary"
"9335",36,"navvies, and we were jolted over a hasty relaying."
"9336",36,""
"9337",36,"All down the line from there the aspect of the country was gaunt and"
"9338",36,"unfamiliar; Wimbledon particularly had suffered. Walton, by virtue of"
"9339",36,"its unburned pine woods, seemed the least hurt of any place along the"
"9340",36,"line. The Wandle, the Mole, every little stream, was a heaped mass of"
"9341",36,"red weed, in appearance between butcher’s meat and pickled cabbage. The"
"9342",36,"Surrey pine woods were too dry, however, for the festoons of the red"
"9343",36,"climber. Beyond Wimbledon, within sight of the line, in certain nursery"
"9344",36,"grounds, were the heaped masses of earth about the sixth cylinder. A"
"9345",36,"number of people were standing about it, and some sappers were busy in"
"9346",36,"the midst of it. Over it flaunted a Union Jack, flapping cheerfully in"
"9347",36,"the morning breeze. The nursery grounds were everywhere crimson with"
"9348",36,"the weed, a wide expanse of livid colour cut with purple shadows, and"
"9349",36,"very painful to the eye. One’s gaze went with infinite relief from the"
"9350",36,"scorched greys and sullen reds of the foreground to the blue-green"
"9351",36,"softness of the eastward hills."
"9352",36,""
"9353",36,"The line on the London side of Woking station was still undergoing"
"9354",36,"repair, so I descended at Byfleet station and took the road to Maybury,"
"9355",36,"past the place where I and the artilleryman had talked to the hussars,"
"9356",36,"and on by the spot where the Martian had appeared to me in the"
"9357",36,"thunderstorm. Here, moved by curiosity, I turned aside to find, among a"
"9358",36,"tangle of red fronds, the warped and broken dog cart with the whitened"
"9359",36,"bones of the horse scattered and gnawed. For a time I stood regarding"
"9360",36,"these vestiges. . . ."
"9361",36,""
"9362",36,"Then I returned through the pine wood, neck-high with red weed here and"
"9363",36,"there, to find the landlord of the Spotted Dog had already found"
"9364",36,"burial, and so came home past the College Arms. A man standing at an"
"9365",36,"open cottage door greeted me by name as I passed."
"9366",36,""
"9367",36,"I looked at my house with a quick flash of hope that faded immediately."
"9368",36,"The door had been forced; it was unfast and was opening slowly as I"
"9369",36,"approached."
"9370",36,""
"9371",36,"It slammed again. The curtains of my study fluttered out of the open"
"9372",36,"window from which I and the artilleryman had watched the dawn. No one"
"9373",36,"had closed it since. The smashed bushes were just as I had left them"
"9374",36,"nearly four weeks ago. I stumbled into the hall, and the house felt"
"9375",36,"empty. The stair carpet was ruffled and discoloured where I had"
"9376",36,"crouched, soaked to the skin from the thunderstorm the night of the"
"9377",36,"catastrophe. Our muddy footsteps I saw still went up the stairs."
"9378",36,""
"9379",36,"I followed them to my study, and found lying on my writing-table still,"
"9380",36,"with the selenite paper weight upon it, the sheet of work I had left on"
"9381",36,"the afternoon of the opening of the cylinder. For a space I stood"
"9382",36,"reading over my abandoned arguments. It was a paper on the probable"
"9383",36,"development of Moral Ideas with the development of the civilising"
"9384",36,"process; and the last sentence was the opening of a prophecy: “In about"
"9385",36,"two hundred years,” I had written, “we may expect——” The sentence ended"
"9386",36,"abruptly. I remembered my inability to fix my mind that morning,"
"9387",36,"scarcely a month gone by, and how I had broken off to get my _Daily"
"9388",36,"Chronicle_ from the newsboy. I remembered how I went down to the garden"
"9389",36,"gate as he came along, and how I had listened to his odd story of “Men"
"9390",36,"from Mars.”"
"9391",36,""
"9392",36,"I came down and went into the dining room. There were the mutton and"
"9393",36,"the bread, both far gone now in decay, and a beer bottle overturned,"
"9394",36,"just as I and the artilleryman had left them. My home was desolate. I"
"9395",36,"perceived the folly of the faint hope I had cherished so long. And then"
"9396",36,"a strange thing occurred. “It is no use,” said a voice. “The house is"
"9397",36,"deserted. No one has been here these ten days. Do not stay here to"
"9398",36,"torment yourself. No one escaped but you.”"
"9399",36,""
"9400",36,"I was startled. Had I spoken my thought aloud? I turned, and the French"
"9401",36,"window was open behind me. I made a step to it, and stood looking out."
"9402",36,""
"9403",36,"And there, amazed and afraid, even as I stood amazed and afraid, were"
"9404",36,"my cousin and my wife—my wife white and tearless. She gave a faint cry."
"9405",36,""
"9406",36,"“I came,” she said. “I knew—knew——”"
"9407",36,""
"9408",36,"She put her hand to her throat—swayed. I made a step forward, and"
"9409",36,"caught her in my arms."
"9410",36,""
"9411",36,""
"9412",36,""
"9413",36,""
"9414",36,"X."
"9415",36,"THE EPILOGUE."
"9416",36,""
"9417",36,""
"9418",36,"I cannot but regret, now that I am concluding my story, how little I am"
"9419",36,"able to contribute to the discussion of the many debatable questions"
"9420",36,"which are still unsettled. In one respect I shall certainly provoke"
"9421",36,"criticism. My particular province is speculative philosophy. My"
"9422",36,"knowledge of comparative physiology is confined to a book or two, but"
"9423",36,"it seems to me that Carver’s suggestions as to the reason of the rapid"
"9424",36,"death of the Martians is so probable as to be regarded almost as a"
"9425",36,"proven conclusion. I have assumed that in the body of my narrative."
"9426",36,""
"9427",36,"At any rate, in all the bodies of the Martians that were examined after"
"9428",36,"the war, no bacteria except those already known as terrestrial species"
"9429",36,"were found. That they did not bury any of their dead, and the reckless"
"9430",36,"slaughter they perpetrated, point also to an entire ignorance of the"
"9431",36,"putrefactive process. But probable as this seems, it is by no means a"
"9432",36,"proven conclusion."
"9433",36,""
"9434",36,"Neither is the composition of the Black Smoke known, which the Martians"
"9435",36,"used with such deadly effect, and the generator of the Heat-Rays"
"9436",36,"remains a puzzle. The terrible disasters at the Ealing and South"
"9437",36,"Kensington laboratories have disinclined analysts for further"
"9438",36,"investigations upon the latter. Spectrum analysis of the black powder"
"9439",36,"points unmistakably to the presence of an unknown element with a"
"9440",36,"brilliant group of three lines in the green, and it is possible that it"
"9441",36,"combines with argon to form a compound which acts at once with deadly"
"9442",36,"effect upon some constituent in the blood. But such unproven"
"9443",36,"speculations will scarcely be of interest to the general reader, to"
"9444",36,"whom this story is addressed. None of the brown scum that drifted down"
"9445",36,"the Thames after the destruction of Shepperton was examined at the"
"9446",36,"time, and now none is forthcoming."
"9447",36,""
"9448",36,"The results of an anatomical examination of the Martians, so far as the"
"9449",36,"prowling dogs had left such an examination possible, I have already"
"9450",36,"given. But everyone is familiar with the magnificent and almost"
"9451",36,"complete specimen in spirits at the Natural History Museum, and the"
"9452",36,"countless drawings that have been made from it; and beyond that the"
"9453",36,"interest of their physiology and structure is purely scientific."
"9454",36,""
"9455",36,"A question of graver and universal interest is the possibility of"
"9456",36,"another attack from the Martians. I do not think that nearly enough"
"9457",36,"attention is being given to this aspect of the matter. At present the"
"9458",36,"planet Mars is in conjunction, but with every return to opposition I,"
"9459",36,"for one, anticipate a renewal of their adventure. In any case, we"
"9460",36,"should be prepared. It seems to me that it should be possible to define"
"9461",36,"the position of the gun from which the shots are discharged, to keep a"
"9462",36,"sustained watch upon this part of the planet, and to anticipate the"
"9463",36,"arrival of the next attack."
"9464",36,""
"9465",36,"In that case the cylinder might be destroyed with dynamite or artillery"
"9466",36,"before it was sufficiently cool for the Martians to emerge, or they"
"9467",36,"might be butchered by means of guns so soon as the screw opened. It"
"9468",36,"seems to me that they have lost a vast advantage in the failure of"
"9469",36,"their first surprise. Possibly they see it in the same light."
"9470",36,""
"9471",36,"Lessing has advanced excellent reasons for supposing that the Martians"
"9472",36,"have actually succeeded in effecting a landing on the planet Venus."
"9473",36,"Seven months ago now, Venus and Mars were in alignment with the sun;"
"9474",36,"that is to say, Mars was in opposition from the point of view of an"
"9475",36,"observer on Venus. Subsequently a peculiar luminous and sinuous marking"
"9476",36,"appeared on the unillumined half of the inner planet, and almost"
"9477",36,"simultaneously a faint dark mark of a similar sinuous character was"
"9478",36,"detected upon a photograph of the Martian disk. One needs to see the"
"9479",36,"drawings of these appearances in order to appreciate fully their"
"9480",36,"remarkable resemblance in character."
"9481",36,""
"9482",36,"At any rate, whether we expect another invasion or not, our views of"
"9483",36,"the human future must be greatly modified by these events. We have"
"9484",36,"learned now that we cannot regard this planet as being fenced in and a"
"9485",36,"secure abiding place for Man; we can never anticipate the unseen good"
"9486",36,"or evil that may come upon us suddenly out of space. It may be that in"
"9487",36,"the larger design of the universe this invasion from Mars is not"
"9488",36,"without its ultimate benefit for men; it has robbed us of that serene"
"9489",36,"confidence in the future which is the most fruitful source of"
"9490",36,"decadence, the gifts to human science it has brought are enormous, and"
"9491",36,"it has done much to promote the conception of the commonweal of"
"9492",36,"mankind. It may be that across the immensity of space the Martians have"
"9493",36,"watched the fate of these pioneers of theirs and learned their lesson,"
"9494",36,"and that on the planet Venus they have found a securer settlement. Be"
"9495",36,"that as it may, for many years yet there will certainly be no"
"9496",36,"relaxation of the eager scrutiny of the Martian disk, and those fiery"
"9497",36,"darts of the sky, the shooting stars, will bring with them as they fall"
"9498",36,"an unavoidable apprehension to all the sons of men."
"9499",36,""
"9500",36,"The broadening of men’s views that has resulted can scarcely be"
"9501",36,"exaggerated. Before the cylinder fell there was a general persuasion"
"9502",36,"that through all the deep of space no life existed beyond the petty"
"9503",36,"surface of our minute sphere. Now we see further. If the Martians can"
"9504",36,"reach Venus, there is no reason to suppose that the thing is impossible"
"9505",36,"for men, and when the slow cooling of the sun makes this earth"
"9506",36,"uninhabitable, as at last it must do, it may be that the thread of life"
"9507",36,"that has begun here will have streamed out and caught our sister planet"
"9508",36,"within its toils."
"9509",36,""
"9510",36,"Dim and wonderful is the vision I have conjured up in my mind of life"
"9511",36,"spreading slowly from this little seed bed of the solar system"
"9512",36,"throughout the inanimate vastness of sidereal space. But that is a"
"9513",36,"remote dream. It may be, on the other hand, that the destruction of the"
"9514",36,"Martians is only a reprieve. To them, and not to us, perhaps, is the"
"9515",36,"future ordained."
"9516",36,""
"9517",36,"I must confess the stress and danger of the time have left an abiding"
"9518",36,"sense of doubt and insecurity in my mind. I sit in my study writing by"
"9519",36,"lamplight, and suddenly I see again the healing valley below set with"
"9520",36,"writhing flames, and feel the house behind and about me empty and"
"9521",36,"desolate. I go out into the Byfleet Road, and vehicles pass me, a"
"9522",36,"butcher boy in a cart, a cabful of visitors, a workman on a bicycle,"
"9523",36,"children going to school, and suddenly they become vague and unreal,"
"9524",36,"and I hurry again with the artilleryman through the hot, brooding"
"9525",36,"silence. Of a night I see the black powder darkening the silent"
"9526",36,"streets, and the contorted bodies shrouded in that layer; they rise"
"9527",36,"upon me tattered and dog-bitten. They gibber and grow fiercer, paler,"
"9528",36,"uglier, mad distortions of humanity at last, and I wake, cold and"
"9529",36,"wretched, in the darkness of the night."
"9530",36,""
"9531",36,"I go to London and see the busy multitudes in Fleet Street and the"
"9532",36,"Strand, and it comes across my mind that they are but the ghosts of the"
"9533",36,"past, haunting the streets that I have seen silent and wretched, going"
"9534",36,"to and fro, phantasms in a dead city, the mockery of life in a"
"9535",36,"galvanised body. And strange, too, it is to stand on Primrose Hill, as"
"9536",36,"I did but a day before writing this last chapter, to see the great"
"9537",36,"province of houses, dim and blue through the haze of the smoke and"
"9538",36,"mist, vanishing at last into the vague lower sky, to see the people"
"9539",36,"walking to and fro among the flower beds on the hill, to see the"
"9540",36,"sight-seers about the Martian machine that stands there still, to hear"
"9541",36,"the tumult of playing children, and to recall the time when I saw it"
"9542",36,"all bright and clear-cut, hard and silent, under the dawn of that last"
"9543",36,"great day. . . ."
"9544",36,""
"9545",36,"And strangest of all is it to hold my wife’s hand again, and to think"
"9546",36,"that I have counted her, and that she has counted me, among the dead."

"9586",159,"INTRODUCTION."
"9587",159,""
"9588",159,""
"9589",159,"On February the First 1887, the _Lady Vain_ was lost by collision with"
"9590",159,"a derelict when about the latitude 1° S. and longitude 107° W."
"9591",159,""
"9592",159,"On January the Fifth, 1888—that is eleven months and four days after—my"
"9593",159,"uncle, Edward Prendick, a private gentleman, who certainly went aboard"
"9594",159,"the _Lady Vain_ at Callao, and who had been considered drowned, was"
"9595",159,"picked up in latitude 5° 3′ S. and longitude 101° W. in a small open"
"9596",159,"boat of which the name was illegible, but which is supposed to have"
"9597",159,"belonged to the missing schooner _Ipecacuanha_. He gave such a strange"
"9598",159,"account of himself that he was supposed demented. Subsequently he"
"9599",159,"alleged that his mind was a blank from the moment of his escape from"
"9600",159,"the _Lady Vain_. His case was discussed among psychologists at the time"
"9601",159,"as a curious instance of the lapse of memory consequent upon physical"
"9602",159,"and mental stress. The following narrative was found among his papers"
"9603",159,"by the undersigned, his nephew and heir, but unaccompanied by any"
"9604",159,"definite request for publication."
"9605",159,""
"9606",159,"The only island known to exist in the region in which my uncle was"
"9607",159,"picked up is Noble’s Isle, a small volcanic islet and uninhabited. It"
"9608",159,"was visited in 1891 by _H. M. S. Scorpion_. A party of sailors then"
"9609",159,"landed, but found nothing living thereon except certain curious white"
"9610",159,"moths, some hogs and rabbits, and some rather peculiar rats. So that"
"9611",159,"this narrative is without confirmation in its most essential"
"9612",159,"particular. With that understood, there seems no harm in putting this"
"9613",159,"strange story before the public in accordance, as I believe, with my"
"9614",159,"uncle’s intentions. There is at least this much in its behalf: my uncle"
"9615",159,"passed out of human knowledge about latitude 5° S. and longitude 105°"
"9616",159,"E., and reappeared in the same part of the ocean after a space of"
"9617",159,"eleven months. In some way he must have lived during the interval. And"
"9618",159,"it seems that a schooner called the _Ipecacuanha_ with a drunken"
"9619",159,"captain, John Davies, did start from Africa with a puma and certain"
"9620",159,"other animals aboard in January, 1887, that the vessel was well known"
"9621",159,"at several ports in the South Pacific, and that it finally disappeared"
"9622",159,"from those seas (with a considerable amount of copra aboard), sailing"
"9623",159,"to its unknown fate from Bayna in December, 1887, a date that tallies"
"9624",159,"entirely with my uncle’s story."
"9625",159,""
"9626",159,"CHARLES EDWARD PRENDICK."
"9627",159,""
"9628",159,""
"9629",159,""
"9630",159,""
"9631",159,"The Island of Doctor Moreau"
"9632",159,""
"9633",159,"(The Story written by Edward Prendick.)"
"9634",159,""
"9635",159,""
"9636",159,""
"9637",159,""
"9638",159,"I."
"9639",159,"IN THE DINGEY OF THE “LADY VAIN.”"
"9640",159,""
"9641",159,""
"9642",159,"I do not propose to add anything to what has already been written"
"9643",159,"concerning the loss of the _Lady Vain_. As everyone knows, she collided"
"9644",159,"with a derelict when ten days out from Callao. The longboat, with seven"
"9645",159,"of the crew, was picked up eighteen days after by H. M. gunboat"
"9646",159,"_Myrtle_, and the story of their terrible privations has become quite"
"9647",159,"as well known as the far more horrible _Medusa_ case. But I have to add"
"9648",159,"to the published story of the _Lady Vain_ another, possibly as horrible"
"9649",159,"and far stranger. It has hitherto been supposed that the four men who"
"9650",159,"were in the dingey perished, but this is incorrect. I have the best of"
"9651",159,"evidence for this assertion: I was one of the four men."
"9652",159,""
"9653",159,"But in the first place I must state that there never were _four_ men in"
"9654",159,"the dingey,—the number was three. Constans, who was “seen by the"
"9655",159,"captain to jump into the gig,”[1] luckily for us and unluckily for"
"9656",159,"himself did not reach us. He came down out of the tangle of ropes under"
"9657",159,"the stays of the smashed bowsprit, some small rope caught his heel as"
"9658",159,"he let go, and he hung for a moment head downward, and then fell and"
"9659",159,"struck a block or spar floating in the water. We pulled towards him,"
"9660",159,"but he never came up."
"9661",159,""
"9662",159," [1] _Daily News_, March 17, 1887."
"9663",159,""
"9664",159,""
"9665",159,"I say luckily for us he did not reach us, and I might almost say"
"9666",159,"luckily for himself; for we had only a small beaker of water and some"
"9667",159,"soddened ship’s biscuits with us, so sudden had been the alarm, so"
"9668",159,"unprepared the ship for any disaster. We thought the people on the"
"9669",159,"launch would be better provisioned (though it seems they were not), and"
"9670",159,"we tried to hail them. They could not have heard us, and the next"
"9671",159,"morning when the drizzle cleared,—which was not until past midday,—we"
"9672",159,"could see nothing of them. We could not stand up to look about us,"
"9673",159,"because of the pitching of the boat. The two other men who had escaped"
"9674",159,"so far with me were a man named Helmar, a passenger like myself, and a"
"9675",159,"seaman whose name I don’t know,—a short sturdy man, with a stammer."
"9676",159,""
"9677",159,"We drifted famishing, and, after our water had come to an end,"
"9678",159,"tormented by an intolerable thirst, for eight days altogether. After"
"9679",159,"the second day the sea subsided slowly to a glassy calm. It is quite"
"9680",159,"impossible for the ordinary reader to imagine those eight days. He has"
"9681",159,"not, luckily for himself, anything in his memory to imagine with. After"
"9682",159,"the first day we said little to one another, and lay in our places in"
"9683",159,"the boat and stared at the horizon, or watched, with eyes that grew"
"9684",159,"larger and more haggard every day, the misery and weakness gaining upon"
"9685",159,"our companions. The sun became pitiless. The water ended on the fourth"
"9686",159,"day, and we were already thinking strange things and saying them with"
"9687",159,"our eyes; but it was, I think, the sixth before Helmar gave voice to"
"9688",159,"the thing we had all been thinking. I remember our voices were dry and"
"9689",159,"thin, so that we bent towards one another and spared our words. I stood"
"9690",159,"out against it with all my might, was rather for scuttling the boat and"
"9691",159,"perishing together among the sharks that followed us; but when Helmar"
"9692",159,"said that if his proposal was accepted we should have drink, the sailor"
"9693",159,"came round to him."
"9694",159,""
"9695",159,"I would not draw lots however, and in the night the sailor whispered to"
"9696",159,"Helmar again and again, and I sat in the bows with my clasp-knife in my"
"9697",159,"hand, though I doubt if I had the stuff in me to fight; and in the"
"9698",159,"morning I agreed to Helmar’s proposal, and we handed halfpence to find"
"9699",159,"the odd man. The lot fell upon the sailor; but he was the strongest of"
"9700",159,"us and would not abide by it, and attacked Helmar with his hands. They"
"9701",159,"grappled together and almost stood up. I crawled along the boat to"
"9702",159,"them, intending to help Helmar by grasping the sailor’s leg; but the"
"9703",159,"sailor stumbled with the swaying of the boat, and the two fell upon the"
"9704",159,"gunwale and rolled overboard together. They sank like stones. I"
"9705",159,"remember laughing at that, and wondering why I laughed. The laugh"
"9706",159,"caught me suddenly like a thing from without."
"9707",159,""
"9708",159,"I lay across one of the thwarts for I know not how long, thinking that"
"9709",159,"if I had the strength I would drink sea-water and madden myself to die"
"9710",159,"quickly. And even as I lay there I saw, with no more interest than if"
"9711",159,"it had been a picture, a sail come up towards me over the sky-line. My"
"9712",159,"mind must have been wandering, and yet I remember all that happened,"
"9713",159,"quite distinctly. I remember how my head swayed with the seas, and the"
"9714",159,"horizon with the sail above it danced up and down; but I also remember"
"9715",159,"as distinctly that I had a persuasion that I was dead, and that I"
"9716",159,"thought what a jest it was that they should come too late by such a"
"9717",159,"little to catch me in my body."
"9718",159,""
"9719",159,"For an endless period, as it seemed to me, I lay with my head on the"
"9720",159,"thwart watching the schooner (she was a little ship, schooner-rigged"
"9721",159,"fore and aft) come up out of the sea. She kept tacking to and fro in a"
"9722",159,"widening compass, for she was sailing dead into the wind. It never"
"9723",159,"entered my head to attempt to attract attention, and I do not remember"
"9724",159,"anything distinctly after the sight of her side until I found myself in"
"9725",159,"a little cabin aft. There’s a dim half-memory of being lifted up to the"
"9726",159,"gangway, and of a big round countenance covered with freckles and"
"9727",159,"surrounded with red hair staring at me over the bulwarks. I also had a"
"9728",159,"disconnected impression of a dark face, with extraordinary eyes, close"
"9729",159,"to mine; but that I thought was a nightmare, until I met it again. I"
"9730",159,"fancy I recollect some stuff being poured in between my teeth; and that"
"9731",159,"is all."
"9732",159,""
"9733",159,""
"9734",159,""
"9735",159,""
"9736",159,"II."
"9737",159,"THE MAN WHO WAS GOING NOWHERE."
"9738",159,""
"9739",159,""
"9740",159,"The cabin in which I found myself was small and rather untidy. A"
"9741",159,"youngish man with flaxen hair, a bristly straw-coloured moustache, and"
"9742",159,"a dropping nether lip, was sitting and holding my wrist. For a minute"
"9743",159,"we stared at each other without speaking. He had watery grey eyes,"
"9744",159,"oddly void of expression. Then just overhead came a sound like an iron"
"9745",159,"bedstead being knocked about, and the low angry growling of some large"
"9746",159,"animal. At the same time the man spoke. He repeated his question,—“How"
"9747",159,"do you feel now?”"
"9748",159,""
"9749",159,"I think I said I felt all right. I could not recollect how I had got"
"9750",159,"there. He must have seen the question in my face, for my voice was"
"9751",159,"inaccessible to me."
"9752",159,""
"9753",159,"“You were picked up in a boat, starving. The name on the boat was the"
"9754",159,"_Lady Vain_, and there were spots of blood on the gunwale.”"
"9755",159,""
"9756",159,"At the same time my eye caught my hand, so thin that it looked like a"
"9757",159,"dirty skin-purse full of loose bones, and all the business of the boat"
"9758",159,"came back to me."
"9759",159,""
"9760",159,"“Have some of this,” said he, and gave me a dose of some scarlet stuff,"
"9761",159,"iced."
"9762",159,""
"9763",159,"It tasted like blood, and made me feel stronger."
"9764",159,""
"9765",159,"“You were in luck,” said he, “to get picked up by a ship with a medical"
"9766",159,"man aboard.” He spoke with a slobbering articulation, with the ghost of"
"9767",159,"a lisp."
"9768",159,""
"9769",159,"“What ship is this?” I said slowly, hoarse from my long silence."
"9770",159,""
"9771",159,"“It’s a little trader from Arica and Callao. I never asked where she"
"9772",159,"came from in the beginning,—out of the land of born fools, I guess. I’m"
"9773",159,"a passenger myself, from Arica. The silly ass who owns her,—he’s"
"9774",159,"captain too, named Davies,—he’s lost his certificate, or something. You"
"9775",159,"know the kind of man,—calls the thing the _Ipecacuanha_, of all silly,"
"9776",159,"infernal names; though when there’s much of a sea without any wind, she"
"9777",159,"certainly acts according.”"
"9778",159,""
"9779",159,"(Then the noise overhead began again, a snarling growl and the voice of"
"9780",159,"a human being together. Then another voice, telling some"
"9781",159,"“Heaven-forsaken idiot” to desist.)"
"9782",159,""
"9783",159,"“You were nearly dead,” said my interlocutor. “It was a very near"
"9784",159,"thing, indeed. But I’ve put some stuff into you now. Notice your arm’s"
"9785",159,"sore? Injections. You’ve been insensible for nearly thirty hours.”"
"9786",159,""
"9787",159,"I thought slowly. (I was distracted now by the yelping of a number of"
"9788",159,"dogs.) “Am I eligible for solid food?” I asked."
"9789",159,""
"9790",159,"“Thanks to me,” he said. “Even now the mutton is boiling.”"
"9791",159,""
"9792",159,"“Yes,” I said with assurance; “I could eat some mutton.”"
"9793",159,""
"9794",159,"“But,” said he with a momentary hesitation, “you know I’m dying to hear"
"9795",159,"of how you came to be alone in that boat. _Damn that howling_!” I"
"9796",159,"thought I detected a certain suspicion in his eyes."
"9797",159,""
"9798",159,"He suddenly left the cabin, and I heard him in violent controversy with"
"9799",159,"some one, who seemed to me to talk gibberish in response to him. The"
"9800",159,"matter sounded as though it ended in blows, but in that I thought my"
"9801",159,"ears were mistaken. Then he shouted at the dogs, and returned to the"
"9802",159,"cabin."
"9803",159,""
"9804",159,"“Well?” said he in the doorway. “You were just beginning to tell me.”"
"9805",159,""
"9806",159,"I told him my name, Edward Prendick, and how I had taken to Natural"
"9807",159,"History as a relief from the dulness of my comfortable independence."
"9808",159,""
"9809",159,"He seemed interested in this. “I’ve done some science myself. I did my"
"9810",159,"Biology at University College,—getting out the ovary of the earthworm"
"9811",159,"and the radula of the snail, and all that. Lord! It’s ten years ago."
"9812",159,"But go on! go on! tell me about the boat.”"
"9813",159,""
"9814",159,"He was evidently satisfied with the frankness of my story, which I told"
"9815",159,"in concise sentences enough, for I felt horribly weak; and when it was"
"9816",159,"finished he reverted at once to the topic of Natural History and his"
"9817",159,"own biological studies. He began to question me closely about Tottenham"
"9818",159,"Court Road and Gower Street. “Is Caplatzi still flourishing? What a"
"9819",159,"shop that was!” He had evidently been a very ordinary medical student,"
"9820",159,"and drifted incontinently to the topic of the music halls. He told me"
"9821",159,"some anecdotes."
"9822",159,""
"9823",159,"“Left it all,” he said, “ten years ago. How jolly it all used to be!"
"9824",159,"But I made a young ass of myself,—played myself out before I was"
"9825",159,"twenty-one. I daresay it’s all different now. But I must look up that"
"9826",159,"ass of a cook, and see what he’s done to your mutton.”"
"9827",159,""
"9828",159,"The growling overhead was renewed, so suddenly and with so much savage"
"9829",159,"anger that it startled me. “What’s that?” I called after him, but the"
"9830",159,"door had closed. He came back again with the boiled mutton, and I was"
"9831",159,"so excited by the appetising smell of it that I forgot the noise of the"
"9832",159,"beast that had troubled me."
"9833",159,""
"9834",159,"After a day of alternate sleep and feeding I was so far recovered as to"
"9835",159,"be able to get from my bunk to the scuttle, and see the green seas"
"9836",159,"trying to keep pace with us. I judged the schooner was running before"
"9837",159,"the wind. Montgomery—that was the name of the flaxen-haired man—came in"
"9838",159,"again as I stood there, and I asked him for some clothes. He lent me"
"9839",159,"some duck things of his own, for those I had worn in the boat had been"
"9840",159,"thrown overboard. They were rather loose for me, for he was large and"
"9841",159,"long in his limbs. He told me casually that the captain was three-parts"
"9842",159,"drunk in his own cabin. As I assumed the clothes, I began asking him"
"9843",159,"some questions about the destination of the ship. He said the ship was"
"9844",159,"bound to Hawaii, but that it had to land him first."
"9845",159,""
"9846",159,"“Where?” said I."
"9847",159,""
"9848",159,"“It’s an island, where I live. So far as I know, it hasn’t got a name.”"
"9849",159,""
"9850",159,"He stared at me with his nether lip dropping, and looked so wilfully"
"9851",159,"stupid of a sudden that it came into my head that he desired to avoid"
"9852",159,"my questions. I had the discretion to ask no more."
"9853",159,""
"9854",159,""
"9855",159,""
"9856",159,""
"9857",159,"III."
"9858",159,"THE STRANGE FACE."
"9859",159,""
"9860",159,""
"9861",159,"We left the cabin and found a man at the companion obstructing our way."
"9862",159,"He was standing on the ladder with his back to us, peering over the"
"9863",159,"combing of the hatchway. He was, I could see, a misshapen man, short,"
"9864",159,"broad, and clumsy, with a crooked back, a hairy neck, and a head sunk"
"9865",159,"between his shoulders. He was dressed in dark-blue serge, and had"
"9866",159,"peculiarly thick, coarse, black hair. I heard the unseen dogs growl"
"9867",159,"furiously, and forthwith he ducked back,—coming into contact with the"
"9868",159,"hand I put out to fend him off from myself. He turned with animal"
"9869",159,"swiftness."
"9870",159,""
"9871",159,"In some indefinable way the black face thus flashed upon me shocked me"
"9872",159,"profoundly. It was a singularly deformed one. The facial part"
"9873",159,"projected, forming something dimly suggestive of a muzzle, and the huge"
"9874",159,"half-open mouth showed as big white teeth as I had ever seen in a human"
"9875",159,"mouth. His eyes were blood-shot at the edges, with scarcely a rim of"
"9876",159,"white round the hazel pupils. There was a curious glow of excitement in"
"9877",159,"his face."
"9878",159,""
"9879",159,"“Confound you!” said Montgomery. “Why the devil don’t you get out of"
"9880",159,"the way?”"
"9881",159,""
"9882",159,"The black-faced man started aside without a word. I went on up the"
"9883",159,"companion, staring at him instinctively as I did so. Montgomery stayed"
"9884",159,"at the foot for a moment. “You have no business here, you know,” he"
"9885",159,"said in a deliberate tone. “Your place is forward.”"
"9886",159,""
"9887",159,"The black-faced man cowered. “They—won’t have me forward.” He spoke"
"9888",159,"slowly, with a queer, hoarse quality in his voice."
"9889",159,""
"9890",159,"“Won’t have you forward!” said Montgomery, in a menacing voice. “But I"
"9891",159,"tell you to go!” He was on the brink of saying something further, then"
"9892",159,"looked up at me suddenly and followed me up the ladder."
"9893",159,""
"9894",159,"I had paused half way through the hatchway, looking back, still"
"9895",159,"astonished beyond measure at the grotesque ugliness of this black-faced"
"9896",159,"creature. I had never beheld such a repulsive and extraordinary face"
"9897",159,"before, and yet—if the contradiction is credible—I experienced at the"
"9898",159,"same time an odd feeling that in some way I _had_ already encountered"
"9899",159,"exactly the features and gestures that now amazed me. Afterwards it"
"9900",159,"occurred to me that probably I had seen him as I was lifted aboard; and"
"9901",159,"yet that scarcely satisfied my suspicion of a previous acquaintance."
"9902",159,"Yet how one could have set eyes on so singular a face and yet have"
"9903",159,"forgotten the precise occasion, passed my imagination."
"9904",159,""
"9905",159,"Montgomery’s movement to follow me released my attention, and I turned"
"9906",159,"and looked about me at the flush deck of the little schooner. I was"
"9907",159,"already half prepared by the sounds I had heard for what I saw."
"9908",159,"Certainly I never beheld a deck so dirty. It was littered with scraps"
"9909",159,"of carrot, shreds of green stuff, and indescribable filth. Fastened by"
"9910",159,"chains to the mainmast were a number of grisly staghounds, who now"
"9911",159,"began leaping and barking at me, and by the mizzen a huge puma was"
"9912",159,"cramped in a little iron cage far too small even to give it turning"
"9913",159,"room. Farther under the starboard bulwark were some big hutches"
"9914",159,"containing a number of rabbits, and a solitary llama was squeezed in a"
"9915",159,"mere box of a cage forward. The dogs were muzzled by leather straps."
"9916",159,"The only human being on deck was a gaunt and silent sailor at the"
"9917",159,"wheel."
"9918",159,""
"9919",159,"The patched and dirty spankers were tense before the wind, and up aloft"
"9920",159,"the little ship seemed carrying every sail she had. The sky was clear,"
"9921",159,"the sun midway down the western sky; long waves, capped by the breeze"
"9922",159,"with froth, were running with us. We went past the steersman to the"
"9923",159,"taffrail, and saw the water come foaming under the stern and the"
"9924",159,"bubbles go dancing and vanishing in her wake. I turned and surveyed the"
"9925",159,"unsavoury length of the ship."
"9926",159,""
"9927",159,"“Is this an ocean menagerie?” said I."
"9928",159,""
"9929",159,"“Looks like it,” said Montgomery."
"9930",159,""
"9931",159,"“What are these beasts for? Merchandise, curios? Does the captain think"
"9932",159,"he is going to sell them somewhere in the South Seas?”"
"9933",159,""
"9934",159,"“It looks like it, doesn’t it?” said Montgomery, and turned towards the"
"9935",159,"wake again."
"9936",159,""
"9937",159,"Suddenly we heard a yelp and a volley of furious blasphemy from the"
"9938",159,"companion hatchway, and the deformed man with the black face came up"
"9939",159,"hurriedly. He was immediately followed by a heavy red-haired man in a"
"9940",159,"white cap. At the sight of the former the staghounds, who had all tired"
"9941",159,"of barking at me by this time, became furiously excited, howling and"
"9942",159,"leaping against their chains. The black hesitated before them, and this"
"9943",159,"gave the red-haired man time to come up with him and deliver a"
"9944",159,"tremendous blow between the shoulder-blades. The poor devil went down"
"9945",159,"like a felled ox, and rolled in the dirt among the furiously excited"
"9946",159,"dogs. It was lucky for him that they were muzzled. The red-haired man"
"9947",159,"gave a yawp of exultation and stood staggering, and as it seemed to me"
"9948",159,"in serious danger of either going backwards down the companion hatchway"
"9949",159,"or forwards upon his victim."
"9950",159,""
"9951",159,"So soon as the second man had appeared, Montgomery had started forward."
"9952",159,"“Steady on there!” he cried, in a tone of remonstrance. A couple of"
"9953",159,"sailors appeared on the forecastle. The black-faced man, howling in a"
"9954",159,"singular voice rolled about under the feet of the dogs. No one"
"9955",159,"attempted to help him. The brutes did their best to worry him, butting"
"9956",159,"their muzzles at him. There was a quick dance of their lithe"
"9957",159,"grey-figured bodies over the clumsy, prostrate figure. The sailors"
"9958",159,"forward shouted, as though it was admirable sport. Montgomery gave an"
"9959",159,"angry exclamation, and went striding down the deck, and I followed him."
"9960",159,"The black-faced man scrambled up and staggered forward, going and"
"9961",159,"leaning over the bulwark by the main shrouds, where he remained,"
"9962",159,"panting and glaring over his shoulder at the dogs. The red-haired man"
"9963",159,"laughed a satisfied laugh."
"9964",159,""
"9965",159,"“Look here, Captain,” said Montgomery, with his lisp a little"
"9966",159,"accentuated, gripping the elbows of the red-haired man, “this won’t"
"9967",159,"do!”"
"9968",159,""
"9969",159,"I stood behind Montgomery. The captain came half round, and regarded"
"9970",159,"him with the dull and solemn eyes of a drunken man. “Wha’ won’t do?” he"
"9971",159,"said, and added, after looking sleepily into Montgomery’s face for a"
"9972",159,"minute, “Blasted Sawbones!”"
"9973",159,""
"9974",159,"With a sudden movement he shook his arms free, and after two"
"9975",159,"ineffectual attempts stuck his freckled fists into his side pockets."
"9976",159,""
"9977",159,"“That man’s a passenger,” said Montgomery. “I’d advise you to keep your"
"9978",159,"hands off him.”"
"9979",159,""
"9980",159,"“Go to hell!” said the captain, loudly. He suddenly turned and"
"9981",159,"staggered towards the side. “Do what I like on my own ship,” he said."
"9982",159,""
"9983",159,"I think Montgomery might have left him then, seeing the brute was"
"9984",159,"drunk; but he only turned a shade paler, and followed the captain to"
"9985",159,"the bulwarks."
"9986",159,""
"9987",159,"“Look you here, Captain,” he said; “that man of mine is not to be"
"9988",159,"ill-treated. He has been hazed ever since he came aboard.”"
"9989",159,""
"9990",159,"For a minute, alcoholic fumes kept the captain speechless. “Blasted"
"9991",159,"Sawbones!” was all he considered necessary."
"9992",159,""
"9993",159,"I could see that Montgomery had one of those slow, pertinacious tempers"
"9994",159,"that will warm day after day to a white heat, and never again cool to"
"9995",159,"forgiveness; and I saw too that this quarrel had been some time"
"9996",159,"growing. “The man’s drunk,” said I, perhaps officiously; “you’ll do no"
"9997",159,"good.”"
"9998",159,""
"9999",159,"Montgomery gave an ugly twist to his dropping lip. “He’s always drunk."
"10000",159,"Do you think that excuses his assaulting his passengers?”"
"10001",159,""
"10002",159,"“My ship,” began the captain, waving his hand unsteadily towards the"
"10003",159,"cages, “was a clean ship. Look at it now!” It was certainly anything"
"10004",159,"but clean. “Crew,” continued the captain, “clean, respectable crew.”"
"10005",159,""
"10006",159,"“You agreed to take the beasts.”"
"10007",159,""
"10008",159,"“I wish I’d never set eyes on your infernal island. What the devil—want"
"10009",159,"beasts for on an island like that? Then, that man of yours—understood"
"10010",159,"he was a man. He’s a lunatic; and he hadn’t no business aft. Do you"
"10011",159,"think the whole damned ship belongs to you?”"
"10012",159,""
"10013",159,"“Your sailors began to haze the poor devil as soon as he came aboard.”"
"10014",159,""
"10015",159,"“That’s just what he is—he’s a devil! an ugly devil! My men can’t stand"
"10016",159,"him. _I_ can’t stand him. None of us can’t stand him. Nor _you_"
"10017",159,"either!”"
"10018",159,""
"10019",159,"Montgomery turned away. “_You_ leave that man alone, anyhow,” he said,"
"10020",159,"nodding his head as he spoke."
"10021",159,""
"10022",159,"But the captain meant to quarrel now. He raised his voice. “If he comes"
"10023",159,"this end of the ship again I’ll cut his insides out, I tell you. Cut"
"10024",159,"out his blasted insides! Who are _you_, to tell _me_ what _I’m_ to do?"
"10025",159,"I tell you I’m captain of this ship,—captain and owner. I’m the law"
"10026",159,"here, I tell you,—the law and the prophets. I bargained to take a man"
"10027",159,"and his attendant to and from Arica, and bring back some animals. I"
"10028",159,"never bargained to carry a mad devil and a silly Sawbones, a—”"
"10029",159,""
"10030",159,"Well, never mind what he called Montgomery. I saw the latter take a"
"10031",159,"step forward, and interposed. “He’s drunk,” said I. The captain began"
"10032",159,"some abuse even fouler than the last. “Shut up!” I said, turning on him"
"10033",159,"sharply, for I had seen danger in Montgomery’s white face. With that I"
"10034",159,"brought the downpour on myself."
"10035",159,""
"10036",159,"However, I was glad to avert what was uncommonly near a scuffle, even"
"10037",159,"at the price of the captain’s drunken ill-will. I do not think I have"
"10038",159,"ever heard quite so much vile language come in a continuous stream from"
"10039",159,"any man’s lips before, though I have frequented eccentric company"
"10040",159,"enough. I found some of it hard to endure, though I am a mild-tempered"
"10041",159,"man; but, certainly, when I told the captain to “shut up” I had"
"10042",159,"forgotten that I was merely a bit of human flotsam, cut off from my"
"10043",159,"resources and with my fare unpaid; a mere casual dependant on the"
"10044",159,"bounty, or speculative enterprise, of the ship. He reminded me of it"
"10045",159,"with considerable vigour; but at any rate I prevented a fight."
"10046",159,""
"10047",159,""
"10048",159,""
"10049",159,""
"10050",159,"IV."
"10051",159,"AT THE SCHOONER’S RAIL."
"10052",159,""
"10053",159,""
"10054",159,"That night land was sighted after sundown, and the schooner hove to."
"10055",159,"Montgomery intimated that was his destination. It was too far to see"
"10056",159,"any details; it seemed to me then simply a low-lying patch of dim blue"
"10057",159,"in the uncertain blue-grey sea. An almost vertical streak of smoke went"
"10058",159,"up from it into the sky. The captain was not on deck when it was"
"10059",159,"sighted. After he had vented his wrath on me he had staggered below,"
"10060",159,"and I understand he went to sleep on the floor of his own cabin. The"
"10061",159,"mate practically assumed the command. He was the gaunt, taciturn"
"10062",159,"individual we had seen at the wheel. Apparently he was in an evil"
"10063",159,"temper with Montgomery. He took not the slightest notice of either of"
"10064",159,"us. We dined with him in a sulky silence, after a few ineffectual"
"10065",159,"efforts on my part to talk. It struck me too that the men regarded my"
"10066",159,"companion and his animals in a singularly unfriendly manner. I found"
"10067",159,"Montgomery very reticent about his purpose with these creatures, and"
"10068",159,"about his destination; and though I was sensible of a growing curiosity"
"10069",159,"as to both, I did not press him."
"10070",159,""
"10071",159,"We remained talking on the quarter deck until the sky was thick with"
"10072",159,"stars. Except for an occasional sound in the yellow-lit forecastle and"
"10073",159,"a movement of the animals now and then, the night was very still. The"
"10074",159,"puma lay crouched together, watching us with shining eyes, a black heap"
"10075",159,"in the corner of its cage. Montgomery produced some cigars. He talked"
"10076",159,"to me of London in a tone of half-painful reminiscence, asking all"
"10077",159,"kinds of questions about changes that had taken place. He spoke like a"
"10078",159,"man who had loved his life there, and had been suddenly and irrevocably"
"10079",159,"cut off from it. I gossiped as well as I could of this and that. All"
"10080",159,"the time the strangeness of him was shaping itself in my mind; and as I"
"10081",159,"talked I peered at his odd, pallid face in the dim light of the"
"10082",159,"binnacle lantern behind me. Then I looked out at the darkling sea,"
