"11398",159,""

"11407",159,""
"11408",159,"It was extremely dark, this passage, after the blinding sunlight"
"11409",159,"reflected from the sulphurous ground. Its walls grew steep, and"

"11412",159,"floor of a chasm that was at first absolutely dark to me. I heard some"

"11418",159,""
"11419",159,""
"11420",159,""
"11421",159,""
"11422",159,"XII."
"11423",159,"THE SAYERS OF THE LAW."
"11424",159,""
"11425",159,""
"11426",159,"Then something cold touched my hand. I started violently, and saw close"
"11427",159,"to me a dim pinkish thing, looking more like a flayed child than"
"11428",159,"anything else in the world. The creature had exactly the mild but"
"11429",159,"repulsive features of a sloth, the same low forehead and slow gestures."
"11430",159,""
"11431",159,"As the first shock of the change of light passed, I saw about me more"

"11433",159,"me. My conductor had vanished. The place was a narrow passage between"
"11434",159,"high walls of lava, a crack in the knotted rock, and on either side"
"11435",159,"interwoven heaps of sea-mat, palm-fans, and reeds leaning against the"
"11436",159,"rock formed rough and impenetrably dark dens. The winding way up the"
"11437",159,"ravine between these was scarcely three yards wide, and was disfigured"
"11438",159,"by lumps of decaying fruit-pulp and other refuse, which accounted for"
"11439",159,"the disagreeable stench of the place."
"11440",159,""
"11441",159,"The little pink sloth-creature was still blinking at me when my Ape-man"
"11442",159,"reappeared at the aperture of the nearest of these dens, and beckoned"
"11443",159,"me in. As he did so a slouching monster wriggled out of one of the"
"11444",159,"places, further up this strange street, and stood up in featureless"
"11445",159,"silhouette against the bright green beyond, staring at me. I hesitated,"
"11446",159,"having half a mind to bolt the way I had come; and then, determined to"
"11447",159,"go through with the adventure, I gripped my nailed stick about the"
"11448",159,"middle and crawled into the little evil-smelling lean-to after my"
"11449",159,"conductor."
"11450",159,""
"11451",159,"It was a semi-circular space, shaped like the half of a bee-hive; and"
"11452",159,"against the rocky wall that formed the inner side of it was a pile of"
"11453",159,"variegated fruits, cocoa-nuts among others. Some rough vessels of lava"
"11454",159,"and wood stood about the floor, and one on a rough stool. There was no"
"11455",159,"fire. In the darkest corner of the hut sat a shapeless mass of darkness"
"11456",159,"that grunted “Hey!” as I came in, and my Ape-man stood in the dim light"
"11457",159,"of the doorway and held out a split cocoa-nut to me as I crawled into"
"11458",159,"the other corner and squatted down. I took it, and began gnawing it, as"
"11459",159,"serenely as possible, in spite of a certain trepidation and the nearly"
"11460",159,"intolerable closeness of the den. The little pink sloth-creature stood"
"11461",159,"in the aperture of the hut, and something else with a drab face and"
"11462",159,"bright eyes came staring over its shoulder."
"11463",159,""
"11464",159,"“Hey!” came out of the lump of mystery opposite. “It is a man.”"
"11465",159,""
"11466",159,"“It is a man,” gabbled my conductor, “a man, a man, a five-man, like"
"11467",159,"me.”"
"11468",159,""
"11469",159,"“Shut up!” said the voice from the dark, and grunted. I gnawed my"
"11470",159,"cocoa-nut amid an impressive stillness."
"11471",159,""
"11472",159,"I peered hard into the blackness, but could distinguish nothing."
"11473",159,""
"11474",159,"“It is a man,” the voice repeated. “He comes to live with us?”"
"11475",159,""
"11476",159,"It was a thick voice, with something in it—a kind of whistling"
"11477",159,"overtone—that struck me as peculiar; but the English accent was"
"11478",159,"strangely good."
"11479",159,""
"11480",159,"The Ape-man looked at me as though he expected something. I perceived"
"11481",159,"the pause was interrogative. “He comes to live with you,” I said."
"11482",159,""
"11483",159,"“It is a man. He must learn the Law.”"
"11484",159,""
"11485",159,"I began to distinguish now a deeper blackness in the black, a vague"
"11486",159,"outline of a hunched-up figure. Then I noticed the opening of the place"
"11487",159,"was darkened by two more black heads. My hand tightened on my stick."
"11488",159,""
"11489",159,"The thing in the dark repeated in a louder tone, “Say the words.” I had"
"11490",159,"missed its last remark. “Not to go on all-fours; that is the Law,” it"
"11491",159,"repeated in a kind of sing-song."
"11492",159,""
"11493",159,"I was puzzled."
"11494",159,""
"11495",159,"“Say the words,” said the Ape-man, repeating, and the figures in the"
"11496",159,"doorway echoed this, with a threat in the tone of their voices."
"11497",159,""
"11498",159,"I realised that I had to repeat this idiotic formula; and then began"
"11499",159,"the insanest ceremony. The voice in the dark began intoning a mad"
"11500",159,"litany, line by line, and I and the rest to repeat it. As they did so,"
"11501",159,"they swayed from side to side in the oddest way, and beat their hands"
"11502",159,"upon their knees; and I followed their example. I could have imagined I"
"11503",159,"was already dead and in another world. That dark hut, these grotesque"
"11504",159,"dim figures, just flecked here and there by a glimmer of light, and all"
"11505",159,"of them swaying in unison and chanting,"
"11506",159,""
"11507",159,"“Not to go on all-fours; that is the Law. Are we not Men?"
"11508",159,"“Not to suck up Drink; that is the Law. Are we not Men?"
"11509",159,"“Not to eat Fish or Flesh; that is the Law. Are we not Men?"
"11510",159,"“Not to claw the Bark of Trees; _that_ is the Law. Are we not Men?"
"11511",159,"“Not to chase other Men; _that_ is the Law. Are we not Men?”"
"11512",159,""
"11513",159,""
"11514",159,"And so from the prohibition of these acts of folly, on to the"
"11515",159,"prohibition of what I thought then were the maddest, most impossible,"
"11516",159,"and most indecent things one could well imagine. A kind of rhythmic"

"11519",159,"was upon me, but deep down within me the laughter and disgust struggled"
"11520",159,"together. We ran through a long list of prohibitions, and then the"
"11521",159,"chant swung round to a new formula."
"11522",159,""
"11523",159,"“_His_ is the House of Pain."
"11524",159,"“_His_ is the Hand that makes."
"11525",159,"“_His_ is the Hand that wounds."
"11526",159,"“_His_ is the Hand that heals.”"
"11527",159,""
"11528",159,""
"11529",159,"And so on for another long series, mostly quite incomprehensible"
"11530",159,"gibberish to me about _Him_, whoever he might be. I could have fancied"
"11531",159,"it was a dream, but never before have I heard chanting in a dream."
"11532",159,""
"11533",159,"“_His_ is the lightning flash,” we sang. “_His_ is the deep, salt sea.”"
"11534",159,""
"11535",159,"A horrible fancy came into my head that Moreau, after animalising these"
"11536",159,"men, had infected their dwarfed brains with a kind of deification of"
"11537",159,"himself. However, I was too keenly aware of white teeth and strong"
"11538",159,"claws about me to stop my chanting on that account."
"11539",159,""
"11540",159,"“_His_ are the stars in the sky.”"
"11541",159,""
"11542",159,""
"11543",159,"At last that song ended. I saw the Ape-man’s face shining with"
"11544",159,"perspiration; and my eyes being now accustomed to the darkness, I saw"
"11545",159,"more distinctly the figure in the corner from which the voice came. It"
"11546",159,"was the size of a man, but it seemed covered with a dull grey hair"
"11547",159,"almost like a Skye-terrier. What was it? What were they all? Imagine"
"11548",159,"yourself surrounded by all the most horrible cripples and maniacs it is"
"11549",159,"possible to conceive, and you may understand a little of my feelings"
"11550",159,"with these grotesque caricatures of humanity about me."
"11551",159,""
"11552",159,"“He is a five-man, a five-man, a five-man—like me,” said the Ape-man."
"11553",159,""
"11554",159,"I held out my hands. The grey creature in the corner leant forward."
"11555",159,""
"11556",159,"“Not to run on all-fours; that is the Law. Are we not Men?” he said."
"11557",159,""
"11558",159,"He put out a strangely distorted talon and gripped my fingers. The"
"11559",159,"thing was almost like the hoof of a deer produced into claws. I could"
"11560",159,"have yelled with surprise and pain. His face came forward and peered at"
"11561",159,"my nails, came forward into the light of the opening of the hut and I"
"11562",159,"saw with a quivering disgust that it was like the face of neither man"
"11563",159,"nor beast, but a mere shock of grey hair, with three shadowy"
"11564",159,"over-archings to mark the eyes and mouth."
"11565",159,""
"11566",159,"“He has little nails,” said this grisly creature in his hairy beard."
"11567",159,"“It is well.”"
"11568",159,""
"11569",159,"He threw my hand down, and instinctively I gripped my stick."
"11570",159,""
"11571",159,"“Eat roots and herbs; it is His will,” said the Ape-man."
"11572",159,""
"11573",159,"“I am the Sayer of the Law,” said the grey figure. “Here come all that"
"11574",159,"be new to learn the Law. I sit in the darkness and say the Law.”"
"11575",159,""
"11576",159,"“It is even so,” said one of the beasts in the doorway."
"11577",159,""
"11578",159,"“Evil are the punishments of those who break the Law. None escape.”"
"11579",159,""
"11580",159,"“None escape,” said the Beast Folk, glancing furtively at one another."
"11581",159,""
"11582",159,"“None, none,” said the Ape-man,—“none escape. See! I did a little"
"11583",159,"thing, a wrong thing, once. I jabbered, jabbered, stopped talking. None"
"11584",159,"could understand. I am burnt, branded in the hand. He is great. He is"
"11585",159,"good!”"
"11586",159,""
"11587",159,"“None escape,” said the grey creature in the corner."
"11588",159,""
"11589",159,"“None escape,” said the Beast People, looking askance at one another."
"11590",159,""
"11591",159,"“For every one the want that is bad,” said the grey Sayer of the Law."
"11592",159,"“What you will want we do not know; we shall know. Some want to follow"
"11593",159,"things that move, to watch and slink and wait and spring; to kill and"
"11594",159,"bite, bite deep and rich, sucking the blood. It is bad. ‘Not to chase"
"11595",159,"other Men; that is the Law. Are we not Men? Not to eat Flesh or Fish;"
"11596",159,"that is the Law. Are we not Men?’”"
"11597",159,""
"11598",159,"“None escape,” said a dappled brute standing in the doorway."
"11599",159,""
"11600",159,"“For every one the want is bad,” said the grey Sayer of the Law. “Some"
"11601",159,"want to go tearing with teeth and hands into the roots of things,"
"11602",159,"snuffing into the earth. It is bad.”"
"11603",159,""
"11604",159,"“None escape,” said the men in the door."
"11605",159,""
"11606",159,"“Some go clawing trees; some go scratching at the graves of the dead;"
"11607",159,"some go fighting with foreheads or feet or claws; some bite suddenly,"
"11608",159,"none giving occasion; some love uncleanness.”"
"11609",159,""
"11610",159,"“None escape,” said the Ape-man, scratching his calf."
"11611",159,""
"11612",159,"“None escape,” said the little pink sloth-creature."
"11613",159,""
"11614",159,"“Punishment is sharp and sure. Therefore learn the Law. Say the words.”"
"11615",159,""
"11616",159,"And incontinently he began again the strange litany of the Law, and"
"11617",159,"again I and all these creatures began singing and swaying. My head"
"11618",159,"reeled with this jabbering and the close stench of the place; but I"
"11619",159,"kept on, trusting to find presently some chance of a new development."
"11620",159,""
"11621",159,"“Not to go on all-fours; that is the Law. Are we not Men?”"
"11622",159,""
"11623",159,"We were making such a noise that I noticed nothing of a tumult outside,"
"11624",159,"until some one, who I think was one of the two Swine Men I had seen,"
"11625",159,"thrust his head over the little pink sloth-creature and shouted"
"11626",159,"something excitedly, something that I did not catch. Incontinently"
"11627",159,"those at the opening of the hut vanished; my Ape-man rushed out; the"
"11628",159,"thing that had sat in the dark followed him (I only observed that it"
"11629",159,"was big and clumsy, and covered with silvery hair), and I was left"
"11630",159,"alone. Then before I reached the aperture I heard the yelp of a"
"11631",159,"staghound."
"11632",159,""
"11633",159,"In another moment I was standing outside the hovel, my chair-rail in my"
"11634",159,"hand, every muscle of me quivering. Before me were the clumsy backs of"
"11635",159,"perhaps a score of these Beast People, their misshapen heads half"
"11636",159,"hidden by their shoulder-blades. They were gesticulating excitedly."
"11637",159,"Other half-animal faces glared interrogation out of the hovels. Looking"
"11638",159,"in the direction in which they faced, I saw coming through the haze"
"11639",159,"under the trees beyond the end of the passage of dens the dark figure"
"11640",159,"and awful white face of Moreau. He was holding the leaping staghound"
"11641",159,"back, and close behind him came Montgomery revolver in hand."
"11642",159,""
"11643",159,"For a moment I stood horror-struck. I turned and saw the passage behind"
"11644",159,"me blocked by another heavy brute, with a huge grey face and twinkling"
"11645",159,"little eyes, advancing towards me. I looked round and saw to the right"
"11646",159,"of me and a half-dozen yards in front of me a narrow gap in the wall of"
"11647",159,"rock through which a ray of light slanted into the shadows."
"11648",159,""
"11649",159,"“Stop!” cried Moreau as I strode towards this, and then, “Hold him!”"
"11650",159,""
"11651",159,"At that, first one face turned towards me and then others. Their"
"11652",159,"bestial minds were happily slow. I dashed my shoulder into a clumsy"
"11653",159,"monster who was turning to see what Moreau meant, and flung him forward"
"11654",159,"into another. I felt his hands fly round, clutching at me and missing"
"11655",159,"me. The little pink sloth-creature dashed at me, and I gashed down its"
"11656",159,"ugly face with the nail in my stick and in another minute was"
"11657",159,"scrambling up a steep side pathway, a kind of sloping chimney, out of"
"11658",159,"the ravine. I heard a howl behind me, and cries of “Catch him!” “Hold"
"11659",159,"him!” and the grey-faced creature appeared behind me and jammed his"
"11660",159,"huge bulk into the cleft. “Go on! go on!” they howled. I clambered up"
"11661",159,"the narrow cleft in the rock and came out upon the sulphur on the"
"11662",159,"westward side of the village of the Beast Men."
"11663",159,""
"11664",159,"That gap was altogether fortunate for me, for the narrow chimney,"
"11665",159,"slanting obliquely upward, must have impeded the nearer pursuers. I ran"
"11666",159,"over the white space and down a steep slope, through a scattered growth"
"11667",159,"of trees, and came to a low-lying stretch of tall reeds, through which"
"11668",159,"I pushed into a dark, thick undergrowth that was black and succulent"
"11669",159,"under foot. As I plunged into the reeds, my foremost pursuers emerged"
"11670",159,"from the gap. I broke my way through this undergrowth for some minutes."
"11671",159,"The air behind me and about me was soon full of threatening cries. I"
"11672",159,"heard the tumult of my pursuers in the gap up the slope, then the"
"11673",159,"crashing of the reeds, and every now and then the crackling crash of a"
"11674",159,"branch. Some of the creatures roared like excited beasts of prey. The"
"11675",159,"staghound yelped to the left. I heard Moreau and Montgomery shouting in"
"11676",159,"the same direction. I turned sharply to the right. It seemed to me even"
"11677",159,"then that I heard Montgomery shouting for me to run for my life."
"11678",159,""
"11679",159,"Presently the ground gave rich and oozy under my feet; but I was"
"11680",159,"desperate and went headlong into it, struggled through kneedeep, and so"
"11681",159,"came to a winding path among tall canes. The noise of my pursuers"
"11682",159,"passed away to my left. In one place three strange, pink, hopping"
"11683",159,"animals, about the size of cats, bolted before my footsteps. This"
"11684",159,"pathway ran up hill, across another open space covered with white"
"11685",159,"incrustation, and plunged into a canebrake again. Then suddenly it"
"11686",159,"turned parallel with the edge of a steep-walled gap, which came without"
"11687",159,"warning, like the ha-ha of an English park,—turned with an unexpected"
"11688",159,"abruptness. I was still running with all my might, and I never saw this"
"11689",159,"drop until I was flying headlong through the air."
"11690",159,""
"11691",159,"I fell on my forearms and head, among thorns, and rose with a torn ear"
"11692",159,"and bleeding face. I had fallen into a precipitous ravine, rocky and"
"11693",159,"thorny, full of a hazy mist which drifted about me in wisps, and with a"
"11694",159,"narrow streamlet from which this mist came meandering down the centre."
"11695",159,"I was astonished at this thin fog in the full blaze of daylight; but I"
"11696",159,"had no time to stand wondering then. I turned to my right, down-stream,"
"11697",159,"hoping to come to the sea in that direction, and so have my way open to"
"11698",159,"drown myself. It was only later I found that I had dropped my nailed"
"11699",159,"stick in my fall."
"11700",159,""
"11701",159,"Presently the ravine grew narrower for a space, and carelessly I"
"11702",159,"stepped into the stream. I jumped out again pretty quickly, for the"
"11703",159,"water was almost boiling. I noticed too there was a thin sulphurous"
"11704",159,"scum drifting upon its coiling water. Almost immediately came a turn in"
"11705",159,"the ravine, and the indistinct blue horizon. The nearer sea was"
"11706",159,"flashing the sun from a myriad facets. I saw my death before me; but I"
"11707",159,"was hot and panting, with the warm blood oozing out on my face and"
"11708",159,"running pleasantly through my veins. I felt more than a touch of"
"11709",159,"exultation too, at having distanced my pursuers. It was not in me then"
"11710",159,"to go out and drown myself yet. I stared back the way I had come."
"11711",159,""
"11712",159,"I listened. Save for the hum of the gnats and the chirp of some small"
"11713",159,"insects that hopped among the thorns, the air was absolutely still."
"11714",159,"Then came the yelp of a dog, very faint, and a chattering and"
"11715",159,"gibbering, the snap of a whip, and voices. They grew louder, then"
"11716",159,"fainter again. The noise receded up the stream and faded away. For a"
"11717",159,"while the chase was over; but I knew now how much hope of help for me"
"11718",159,"lay in the Beast People."
"11719",159,""
"11720",159,""
"11721",159,""
"11722",159,""
"11723",159,"XIII."
"11724",159,"A PARLEY."
"11725",159,""
"11726",159,""
"11727",159,"I turned again and went on down towards the sea. I found the hot stream"
"11728",159,"broadened out to a shallow, weedy sand, in which an abundance of crabs"
"11729",159,"and long-bodied, many-legged creatures started from my footfall. I"
"11730",159,"walked to the very edge of the salt water, and then I felt I was safe."
"11731",159,"I turned and stared, arms akimbo, at the thick green behind me, into"
"11732",159,"which the steamy ravine cut like a smoking gash. But, as I say, I was"
"11733",159,"too full of excitement and (a true saying, though those who have never"
"11734",159,"known danger may doubt it) too desperate to die."
"11735",159,""
"11736",159,"Then it came into my head that there was one chance before me yet."
"11737",159,"While Moreau and Montgomery and their bestial rabble chased me through"
"11738",159,"the island, might I not go round the beach until I came to their"
"11739",159,"enclosure,—make a flank march upon them, in fact, and then with a rock"
"11740",159,"lugged out of their loosely-built wall, perhaps, smash in the lock of"
"11741",159,"the smaller door and see what I could find (knife, pistol, or what not)"
"11742",159,"to fight them with when they returned? It was at any rate something to"
"11743",159,"try."
"11744",159,""
"11745",159,"So I turned to the westward and walked along by the water’s edge. The"
"11746",159,"setting sun flashed his blinding heat into my eyes. The slight Pacific"
"11747",159,"tide was running in with a gentle ripple. Presently the shore fell away"
"11748",159,"southward, and the sun came round upon my right hand. Then suddenly,"
"11749",159,"far in front of me, I saw first one and then several figures emerging"
"11750",159,"from the bushes,—Moreau, with his grey staghound, then Montgomery, and"
"11751",159,"two others. At that I stopped."
"11752",159,""
"11753",159,"They saw me, and began gesticulating and advancing. I stood watching"
"11754",159,"them approach. The two Beast Men came running forward to cut me off"
"11755",159,"from the undergrowth, inland. Montgomery came, running also, but"
"11756",159,"straight towards me. Moreau followed slower with the dog."
"11757",159,""
"11758",159,"At last I roused myself from my inaction, and turning seaward walked"
"11759",159,"straight into the water. The water was very shallow at first. I was"
"11760",159,"thirty yards out before the waves reached to my waist. Dimly I could"
"11761",159,"see the intertidal creatures darting away from my feet."
"11762",159,""
"11763",159,"“What are you doing, man?” cried Montgomery."
"11764",159,""
"11765",159,"I turned, standing waist deep, and stared at them. Montgomery stood"
"11766",159,"panting at the margin of the water. His face was bright-red with"
"11767",159,"exertion, his long flaxen hair blown about his head, and his dropping"
"11768",159,"nether lip showed his irregular teeth. Moreau was just coming up, his"
"11769",159,"face pale and firm, and the dog at his hand barked at me. Both men had"
"11770",159,"heavy whips. Farther up the beach stared the Beast Men."
"11771",159,""
"11772",159,"“What am I doing? I am going to drown myself,” said I."
"11773",159,""
"11774",159,"Montgomery and Moreau looked at each other. “Why?” asked Moreau."
"11775",159,""
"11776",159,"“Because that is better than being tortured by you.”"
"11777",159,""
"11778",159,"“I told you so,” said Montgomery, and Moreau said something in a low"
"11779",159,"tone."
"11780",159,""
"11781",159,"“What makes you think I shall torture you?” asked Moreau."
"11782",159,""
"11783",159,"“What I saw,” I said. “And those—yonder.”"
"11784",159,""
"11785",159,"“Hush!” said Moreau, and held up his hand."
"11786",159,""
"11787",159,"“I will not,” said I. “They were men: what are they now? I at least"
"11788",159,"will not be like them.”"
"11789",159,""
"11790",159,"I looked past my interlocutors. Up the beach were M’ling, Montgomery’s"
"11791",159,"attendant, and one of the white-swathed brutes from the boat. Farther"
"11792",159,"up, in the shadow of the trees, I saw my little Ape-man, and behind him"
"11793",159,"some other dim figures."
"11794",159,""
"11795",159,"“Who are these creatures?” said I, pointing to them and raising my"
"11796",159,"voice more and more that it might reach them. “They were men, men like"
"11797",159,"yourselves, whom you have infected with some bestial taint,—men whom"
"11798",159,"you have enslaved, and whom you still fear."
"11799",159,""
"11800",159,"“You who listen,” I cried, pointing now to Moreau and shouting past him"
"11801",159,"to the Beast Men,—“You who listen! Do you not see these men still fear"
"11802",159,"you, go in dread of you? Why, then, do you fear them? You are many—”"
"11803",159,""
"11804",159,"“For God’s sake,” cried Montgomery, “stop that, Prendick!”"
"11805",159,""
"11806",159,"“Prendick!” cried Moreau."
"11807",159,""
"11808",159,"They both shouted together, as if to drown my voice; and behind them"
"11809",159,"lowered the staring faces of the Beast Men, wondering, their deformed"
"11810",159,"hands hanging down, their shoulders hunched up. They seemed, as I"
"11811",159,"fancied, to be trying to understand me, to remember, I thought,"
"11812",159,"something of their human past."
"11813",159,""
"11814",159,"I went on shouting, I scarcely remember what,—that Moreau and"
"11815",159,"Montgomery could be killed, that they were not to be feared: that was"
"11816",159,"the burden of what I put into the heads of the Beast People. I saw the"
"11817",159,"green-eyed man in the dark rags, who had met me on the evening of my"
"11818",159,"arrival, come out from among the trees, and others followed him, to"
"11819",159,"hear me better. At last for want of breath I paused."
"11820",159,""
"11821",159,"“Listen to me for a moment,” said the steady voice of Moreau; “and then"
"11822",159,"say what you will.”"
"11823",159,""
"11824",159,"“Well?” said I."
"11825",159,""
"11826",159,"He coughed, thought, then shouted: “Latin, Prendick! bad Latin,"
"11827",159,"schoolboy Latin; but try and understand. _Hi non sunt homines; sunt"
"11828",159,"animalia qui nos habemus_—vivisected. A humanising process. I will"
"11829",159,"explain. Come ashore.”"
"11830",159,""
"11831",159,"I laughed. “A pretty story,” said I. “They talk, build houses. They"
"11832",159,"were men. It’s likely I’ll come ashore.”"
"11833",159,""
"11834",159,"“The water just beyond where you stand is deep—and full of sharks.”"
"11835",159,""
"11836",159,"“That’s my way,” said I. “Short and sharp. Presently.”"
"11837",159,""
"11838",159,"“Wait a minute.” He took something out of his pocket that flashed back"
"11839",159,"the sun, and dropped the object at his feet. “That’s a loaded"
"11840",159,"revolver,” said he. “Montgomery here will do the same. Now we are going"
"11841",159,"up the beach until you are satisfied the distance is safe. Then come"
"11842",159,"and take the revolvers.”"
"11843",159,""
"11844",159,"“Not I! You have a third between you.”"
"11845",159,""
"11846",159,"“I want you to think over things, Prendick. In the first place, I never"
"11847",159,"asked you to come upon this island. If we vivisected men, we should"
"11848",159,"import men, not beasts. In the next, we had you drugged last night, had"
"11849",159,"we wanted to work you any mischief; and in the next, now your first"
"11850",159,"panic is over and you can think a little, is Montgomery here quite up"
"11851",159,"to the character you give him? We have chased you for your good."
"11852",159,"Because this island is full of inimical phenomena. Besides, why should"
"11853",159,"we want to shoot you when you have just offered to drown yourself?”"
"11854",159,""
"11855",159,"“Why did you set—your people onto me when I was in the hut?”"
"11856",159,""
"11857",159,"“We felt sure of catching you, and bringing you out of danger."
"11858",159,"Afterwards we drew away from the scent, for your good.”"
"11859",159,""
"11860",159,"I mused. It seemed just possible. Then I remembered something again."
"11861",159,"“But I saw,” said I, “in the enclosure—”"
"11862",159,""
"11863",159,"“That was the puma.”"
"11864",159,""
"11865",159,"“Look here, Prendick,” said Montgomery, “you’re a silly ass! Come out"
"11866",159,"of the water and take these revolvers, and talk. We can’t do anything"
"11867",159,"more than we could do now.”"
"11868",159,""
"11869",159,"I will confess that then, and indeed always, I distrusted and dreaded"
"11870",159,"Moreau; but Montgomery was a man I felt I understood."
"11871",159,""
"11872",159,"“Go up the beach,” said I, after thinking, and added, “holding your"
"11873",159,"hands up.”"
"11874",159,""
"11875",159,"“Can’t do that,” said Montgomery, with an explanatory nod over his"
"11876",159,"shoulder. “Undignified.”"
"11877",159,""
"11878",159,"“Go up to the trees, then,” said I, “as you please.”"
"11879",159,""
"11880",159,"“It’s a damned silly ceremony,” said Montgomery."
"11881",159,""
"11882",159,"Both turned and faced the six or seven grotesque creatures, who stood"
"11883",159,"there in the sunlight, solid, casting shadows, moving, and yet so"
"11884",159,"incredibly unreal. Montgomery cracked his whip at them, and forthwith"
"11885",159,"they all turned and fled helter-skelter into the trees; and when"
"11886",159,"Montgomery and Moreau were at a distance I judged sufficient, I waded"
"11887",159,"ashore, and picked up and examined the revolvers. To satisfy myself"
"11888",159,"against the subtlest trickery, I discharged one at a round lump of"
"11889",159,"lava, and had the satisfaction of seeing the stone pulverised and the"
"11890",159,"beach splashed with lead. Still I hesitated for a moment."
"11891",159,""
"11892",159,"“I’ll take the risk,” said I, at last; and with a revolver in each hand"
"11893",159,"I walked up the beach towards them."
"11894",159,""
"11895",159,"“That’s better,” said Moreau, without affectation. “As it is, you have"
"11896",159,"wasted the best part of my day with your confounded imagination.” And"
"11897",159,"with a touch of contempt which humiliated me, he and Montgomery turned"
"11898",159,"and went on in silence before me."
"11899",159,""
"11900",159,"The knot of Beast Men, still wondering, stood back among the trees. I"
"11901",159,"passed them as serenely as possible. One started to follow me, but"
"11902",159,"retreated again when Montgomery cracked his whip. The rest stood"
"11903",159,"silent—watching. They may once have been animals; but I never before"
"11904",159,"saw an animal trying to think."
"11905",159,""
"11906",159,""
"11907",159,""
"11908",159,""
"11909",159,"XIV."
"11910",159,"DOCTOR MOREAU EXPLAINS."
"11911",159,""
"11912",159,""
"11913",159,"“And now, Prendick, I will explain,” said Doctor Moreau, so soon as we"
"11914",159,"had eaten and drunk. “I must confess that you are the most dictatorial"
"11915",159,"guest I ever entertained. I warn you that this is the last I shall do"
"11916",159,"to oblige you. The next thing you threaten to commit suicide about, I"
"11917",159,"shan’t do,—even at some personal inconvenience.”"
"11918",159,""
"11919",159,"He sat in my deck chair, a cigar half consumed in his white,"
"11920",159,"dexterous-looking fingers. The light of the swinging lamp fell on his"
"11921",159,"white hair; he stared through the little window out at the starlight. I"
"11922",159,"sat as far away from him as possible, the table between us and the"
"11923",159,"revolvers to hand. Montgomery was not present. I did not care to be"
"11924",159,"with the two of them in such a little room."
"11925",159,""
"11926",159,"“You admit that the vivisected human being, as you called it, is, after"
"11927",159,"all, only the puma?” said Moreau. He had made me visit that horror in"
"11928",159,"the inner room, to assure myself of its inhumanity."
"11929",159,""
"11930",159,"“It is the puma,” I said, “still alive, but so cut and mutilated as I"
"11931",159,"pray I may never see living flesh again. Of all vile—”"
"11932",159,""
"11933",159,"“Never mind that,” said Moreau; “at least, spare me those youthful"
"11934",159,"horrors. Montgomery used to be just the same. You admit that it is the"
"11935",159,"puma. Now be quiet, while I reel off my physiological lecture to you.”"
"11936",159,""
"11937",159,"And forthwith, beginning in the tone of a man supremely bored, but"
"11938",159,"presently warming a little, he explained his work to me. He was very"
"11939",159,"simple and convincing. Now and then there was a touch of sarcasm in his"
"11940",159,"voice. Presently I found myself hot with shame at our mutual positions."
"11941",159,""
"11942",159,"The creatures I had seen were not men, had never been men. They were"
"11943",159,"animals, humanised animals,—triumphs of vivisection."
"11944",159,""
"11945",159,"“You forget all that a skilled vivisector can do with living things,”"
"11946",159,"said Moreau. “For my own part, I’m puzzled why the things I have done"
"11947",159,"here have not been done before. Small efforts, of course, have been"
"11948",159,"made,—amputation, tongue-cutting, excisions. Of course you know a"
"11949",159,"squint may be induced or cured by surgery? Then in the case of"
"11950",159,"excisions you have all kinds of secondary changes, pigmentary"
"11951",159,"disturbances, modifications of the passions, alterations in the"
"11952",159,"secretion of fatty tissue. I have no doubt you have heard of these"
"11953",159,"things?”"
"11954",159,""
"11955",159,"“Of course,” said I. “But these foul creatures of yours—”"
"11956",159,""
"11957",159,"“All in good time,” said he, waving his hand at me; “I am only"
"11958",159,"beginning. Those are trivial cases of alteration. Surgery can do better"
"11959",159,"things than that. There is building up as well as breaking down and"
"11960",159,"changing. You have heard, perhaps, of a common surgical operation"
"11961",159,"resorted to in cases where the nose has been destroyed: a flap of skin"
"11962",159,"is cut from the forehead, turned down on the nose, and heals in the new"
"11963",159,"position. This is a kind of grafting in a new position of part of an"
"11964",159,"animal upon itself. Grafting of freshly obtained material from another"
"11965",159,"animal is also possible,—the case of teeth, for example. The grafting"
"11966",159,"of skin and bone is done to facilitate healing: the surgeon places in"
"11967",159,"the middle of the wound pieces of skin snipped from another animal, or"
"11968",159,"fragments of bone from a victim freshly killed. Hunter’s"
"11969",159,"cock-spur—possibly you have heard of that—flourished on the bull’s"
"11970",159,"neck; and the rhinoceros rats of the Algerian zouaves are also to be"
"11971",159,"thought of,—monsters manufactured by transferring a slip from the tail"
"11972",159,"of an ordinary rat to its snout, and allowing it to heal in that"
"11973",159,"position.”"
"11974",159,""
"11975",159,"“Monsters manufactured!” said I. “Then you mean to tell me—”"
"11976",159,""
"11977",159,"“Yes. These creatures you have seen are animals carven and wrought into"
"11978",159,"new shapes. To that, to the study of the plasticity of living forms, my"
"11979",159,"life has been devoted. I have studied for years, gaining in knowledge"
"11980",159,"as I go. I see you look horrified, and yet I am telling you nothing"
"11981",159,"new. It all lay in the surface of practical anatomy years ago, but no"
"11982",159,"one had the temerity to touch it. It is not simply the outward form of"
"11983",159,"an animal which I can change. The physiology, the chemical rhythm of"
"11984",159,"the creature, may also be made to undergo an enduring modification,—of"
"11985",159,"which vaccination and other methods of inoculation with living or dead"
"11986",159,"matter are examples that will, no doubt, be familiar to you. A similar"
"11987",159,"operation is the transfusion of blood,—with which subject, indeed, I"
"11988",159,"began. These are all familiar cases. Less so, and probably far more"
"11989",159,"extensive, were the operations of those mediaeval practitioners who"
"11990",159,"made dwarfs and beggar-cripples, show-monsters,—some vestiges of whose"
"11991",159,"art still remain in the preliminary manipulation of the young"
"11992",159,"mountebank or contortionist. Victor Hugo gives an account of them in"
"11993",159,"‘L’Homme qui Rit.’—But perhaps my meaning grows plain now. You begin to"
"11994",159,"see that it is a possible thing to transplant tissue from one part of"
"11995",159,"an animal to another, or from one animal to another; to alter its"
"11996",159,"chemical reactions and methods of growth; to modify the articulations"
"11997",159,"of its limbs; and, indeed, to change it in its most intimate structure."
"11998",159,""
"11999",159,"“And yet this extraordinary branch of knowledge has never been sought"
"12000",159,"as an end, and systematically, by modern investigators until I took it"
"12001",159,"up! Some such things have been hit upon in the last resort of surgery;"
"12002",159,"most of the kindred evidence that will recur to your mind has been"
"12003",159,"demonstrated as it were by accident,—by tyrants, by criminals, by the"
"12004",159,"breeders of horses and dogs, by all kinds of untrained clumsy-handed"
"12005",159,"men working for their own immediate ends. I was the first man to take"
"12006",159,"up this question armed with antiseptic surgery, and with a really"
"12007",159,"scientific knowledge of the laws of growth. Yet one would imagine it"
"12008",159,"must have been practised in secret before. Such creatures as the"
"12009",159,"Siamese Twins—And in the vaults of the Inquisition. No doubt their"
"12010",159,"chief aim was artistic torture, but some at least of the inquisitors"
"12011",159,"must have had a touch of scientific curiosity.”"
"12012",159,""
"12013",159,"“But,” said I, “these things—these animals talk!”"
"12014",159,""
"12015",159,"He said that was so, and proceeded to point out that the possibility of"
"12016",159,"vivisection does not stop at a mere physical metamorphosis. A pig may"
"12017",159,"be educated. The mental structure is even less determinate than the"
"12018",159,"bodily. In our growing science of hypnotism we find the promise of a"
"12019",159,"possibility of superseding old inherent instincts by new suggestions,"
"12020",159,"grafting upon or replacing the inherited fixed ideas. Very much indeed"

"12022",159,"modification and perversion of instinct; pugnacity is trained into"
"12023",159,"courageous self-sacrifice, and suppressed sexuality into religious"

"12025",159,"larynx, he continued,—in the incapacity to frame delicately different"
"12026",159,"sound-symbols by which thought could be sustained. In this I failed to"
"12027",159,"agree with him, but with a certain incivility he declined to notice my"
"12028",159,"objection. He repeated that the thing was so, and continued his account"
"12029",159,"of his work."
"12030",159,""
"12031",159,"I asked him why he had taken the human form as a model. There seemed to"
"12032",159,"me then, and there still seems to me now, a strange wickedness for that"
"12033",159,"choice."
"12034",159,""
"12035",159,"He confessed that he had chosen that form by chance. “I might just as"

"12037",159,"suppose there is something in the human form that appeals to the"
"12038",159,"artistic turn of mind more powerfully than any animal shape can. But"
"12039",159,"I’ve not confined myself to man-making. Once or twice—” He was silent,"
"12040",159,"for a minute perhaps. “These years! How they have slipped by! And here"
"12041",159,"I have wasted a day saving your life, and am now wasting an hour"

"12043",159,""
"12044",159,"“But,” said I, “I still do not understand. Where is your justification"
"12045",159,"for inflicting all this pain? The only thing that could excuse"
"12046",159,"vivisection to me would be some application—”"
"12047",159,""
"12048",159,"“Precisely,” said he. “But, you see, I am differently constituted. We"
"12049",159,"are on different platforms. You are a materialist.”"
"12050",159,""
"12051",159,"“I am _not_ a materialist,” I began hotly."
"12052",159,""
"12053",159,"“In my view—in my view. For it is just this question of pain that parts"
"12054",159,"us. So long as visible or audible pain turns you sick; so long as your"
"12055",159,"own pains drive you; so long as pain underlies your propositions about"
"12056",159,"sin,—so long, I tell you, you are an animal, thinking a little less"
"12057",159,"obscurely what an animal feels. This pain—”"
"12058",159,""
"12059",159,"I gave an impatient shrug at such sophistry."
"12060",159,""
"12061",159,"“Oh, but it is such a little thing! A mind truly opened to what science"
"12062",159,"has to teach must see that it is a little thing. It may be that save in"

"12066",159,"towards—Why, even on this earth, even among living things, what pain is"

"12068",159,""
"12069",159,"As he spoke he drew a little penknife from his pocket, opened the"

"12071",159,"choosing the place deliberately, he drove the blade into his leg and"

"12073",159,""
"12074",159,"“No doubt,” he said, “you have seen that before. It does not hurt a"

"12090",159,""
"12091",159,"“Then I am a religious man, Prendick, as every sane man must be. It may"

"12098",159,"Prendick, is the mark of the beast upon them,—the mark of the beast"

"12101",159,""
"12102",159,"“You see, I went on with this research just the way it led me. That is"
"12103",159,"the only way I ever heard of true research going. I asked a question,"
"12104",159,"devised some method of obtaining an answer, and got a fresh question."
"12105",159,"Was this possible or that possible? You cannot imagine what this means"

"12107",159,"cannot imagine the strange, colourless delight of these intellectual"
"12108",159,"desires! The thing before you is no longer an animal, a"
"12109",159,"fellow-creature, but a problem! Sympathetic pain,—all I know of it I"
"12110",159,"remember as a thing I used to suffer from years ago. I wanted—it was"
"12111",159,"the one thing I wanted—to find out the extreme limit of plasticity in a"
"12112",159,"living shape.”"
"12113",159,""
"12114",159,"“But,” said I, “the thing is an abomination—”"
"12115",159,""
"12116",159,"“To this day I have never troubled about the ethics of the matter,” he"
"12117",159,"continued. “The study of Nature makes a man at last as remorseless as"
"12118",159,"Nature. I have gone on, not heeding anything but the question I was"
"12119",159,"pursuing; and the material has—dripped into the huts yonder. It is"
"12120",159,"nearly eleven years since we came here, I and Montgomery and six"
"12121",159,"Kanakas. I remember the green stillness of the island and the empty"
"12122",159,"ocean about us, as though it was yesterday. The place seemed waiting"
"12123",159,"for me."
"12124",159,""
"12125",159,"“The stores were landed and the house was built. The Kanakas founded"
"12126",159,"some huts near the ravine. I went to work here upon what I had brought"
"12127",159,"with me. There were some disagreeable things happened at first. I began"

"12129",159,"scalpel. I took another sheep, and made a thing of pain and fear and"
"12130",159,"left it bound up to heal. It looked quite human to me when I had"

"12138",159,""
"12139",159,"“Then I took a gorilla I had; and upon that, working with infinite care"
"12140",159,"and mastering difficulty after difficulty, I made my first man. All the"

"12154",159,"English; gave him ideas of counting; even made the thing read the"
"12155",159,"alphabet. But at that he was slow, though I’ve met with idiots slower."
"12156",159,"He began with a clean sheet, mentally; had no memories left in his mind"

"12161",159,""
"12162",159,"“They were horribly afraid of him at first, somehow,—which offended me"

"12171",159,""
"12172",159,"“I rested from work for some days after this, and was in a mind to"

"12174",159,"Then I came upon the creature squatting up in a tree and gibbering at"

"12181",159,""
"12182",159,"“But that’s the story. All the Kanaka boys are dead now; one fell"

"12187",159,"at first, and then—"
"12188",159,""
"12189",159,"“What became of the other one?” said I, sharply,—“the other Kanaka who"
"12190",159,"was killed?”"
"12191",159,""
"12192",159,"“The fact is, after I had made a number of human creatures I made a"

"12194",159,""

"12196",159,""
"12197",159,"“It was killed.”"
"12198",159,""
"12199",159,"“I don’t understand,” said I; “do you mean to say—”"

"12213",159,""

"12215",159,""

"12217",159,"been going on; and there is still something in everything I do that"
"12218",159,"defeats me, makes me dissatisfied, challenges me to further effort."
"12219",159,"Sometimes I rise above my level, sometimes I fall below it; but always"

"12222",159,"strong; but often there is trouble with the hands and the"
"12223",159,"claws,—painful things, that I dare not shape too freely. But it is in"

"12226",159,"unaccountable blank ends, unexpected gaps. And least satisfactory of"
"12227",159,"all is something that I cannot touch, somewhere—I cannot determine"

"12229",159,"harm humanity, a strange hidden reservoir to burst forth suddenly and"
"12230",159,"inundate the whole being of the creature with anger, hate, or fear."
"12231",159,"These creatures of mine seemed strange and uncanny to you so soon as"

"12241",159,"revert. As soon as my hand is taken from them the beast begins to creep"
"12242",159,"back, begins to assert itself again.” Another long silence."
"12243",159,""
"12244",159,"“Then you take the things you make into those dens?” said I."
"12245",159,""
"12246",159,"“They go. I turn them out when I begin to feel the beast in them, and"
"12247",159,"presently they wander there. They all dread this house and me. There is"
"12248",159,"a kind of travesty of humanity over there. Montgomery knows about it,"
"12249",159,"for he interferes in their affairs. He has trained one or two of them"

"12255",159,"Sing hymns about ‘all thine.’ They build themselves their dens, gather"

"12260",159,"is a kind of upward striving in them, part vanity, part waste sexual"
"12261",159,"emotion, part waste curiosity. It only mocks me. I have some hope of"
"12262",159,"this puma. I have worked hard at her head and brain—"
"12263",159,""
"12264",159,"“And now,” said he, standing up after a long gap of silence, during"
"12265",159,"which we had each pursued our own thoughts, “what do you think? Are you"
"12266",159,"in fear of me still?”"
"12267",159,""
"12268",159,"I looked at him, and saw but a white-faced, white-haired man, with calm"
"12269",159,"eyes. Save for his serenity, the touch almost of beauty that resulted"
"12270",159,"from his set tranquillity and his magnificent build, he might have"
"12271",159,"passed muster among a hundred other comfortable old gentlemen. Then I"
"12272",159,"shivered. By way of answer to his second question, I handed him a"
"12273",159,"revolver with either hand."
"12274",159,""
"12275",159,"“Keep them,” he said, and snatched at a yawn. He stood up, stared at me"
"12276",159,"for a moment, and smiled. “You have had two eventful days,” said he. “I"
"12277",159,"should advise some sleep. I’m glad it’s all clear. Good-night.” He"
"12278",159,"thought me over for a moment, then went out by the inner door."
"12279",159,""
"12280",159,"I immediately turned the key in the outer one. I sat down again; sat"
"12281",159,"for a time in a kind of stagnant mood, so weary, emotionally, mentally,"
"12282",159,"and physically, that I could not think beyond the point at which he had"
"12283",159,"left me. The black window stared at me like an eye. At last with an"
"12284",159,"effort I put out the light and got into the hammock. Very soon I was"
"12285",159,"asleep."
