"13626",159,""
"13627",159,"I was perhaps a dozen seconds collecting myself. Then cried I, “Salute!"
"13628",159,"Bow down!”"
"13629",159,""
"13630",159,"His teeth flashed upon me in a snarl. “Who are _you_ that I should—”"
"13631",159,""

"13644",159,""
"13645",159,"I dismissed my three serfs with a wave of the hand, and went up the"

"13662",159,"could, but it was difficult to clear the thing of emotion."
"13663",159,""
"13664",159,"I began turning over in my mind the reason of Montgomery’s despair."
"13665",159,"“They will change,” he said; “they are sure to change.” And Moreau,"

"13675",159,""
"13676",159,"My thoughts were disturbed by a crying of sea-birds hurrying towards"

"13683",159,""
"13684",159,"Perhaps half a mile along the beach I became aware of one of my three"

"13689",159,""

"13691",159,""

"13695",159,""

"13697",159,""

"13699",159,""

"13703",159,""
"13704",159,"So in solitude I came round by the ravine of the Beast People, and"

"13714",159,""

"13721",159,""
"13722",159,"“I want food,” said I, almost apologetically, and drawing near."
"13723",159,""

"13726",159,""

"13736",159,""

"13739",159,"XXI."
"13740",159,"THE REVERSION OF THE BEAST FOLK."
"13741",159,""
"13742",159,""
"13743",159,"In this way I became one among the Beast People in the Island of Doctor"
"13744",159,"Moreau. When I awoke, it was dark about me. My arm ached in its"

"13748",159,""

"13755",159,"revolver."
"13756",159,""

"13758",159,""
"13759",159,"“_I_—Master.”"
"13760",159,""
"13761",159,"“Who are _you?_”"
"13762",159,""
"13763",159,"“They say there is no Master now. But I know, I know. I carried the"
"13764",159,"bodies into the sea, O Walker in the Sea! the bodies of those you slew."
"13765",159,"I am your slave, Master.”"
"13766",159,""
"13767",159,"“Are you the one I met on the beach?” I asked."
"13768",159,""
"13769",159,"“The same, Master.”"
"13770",159,""
"13771",159,"The Thing was evidently faithful enough, for it might have fallen upon"

"13775",159,""

"13782",159,""
"13783",159,"I felt in the darkness, and patted the Dog-man’s head. “It is well,” I"

"13785",159,""

"13791",159,""

"13800",159,""

"13804",159,""
"13805",159,"For a moment the opening of the hut was blackened by the exit of the"

"13819",159,""

"13824",159,""

"13828",159,""

"13830",159,""

"13832",159,""
"13833",159,"“The House of Pain is gone,” said I. “It will come again. The Master"

"13835",159,""

"13837",159,""

"13840",159,""
"13841",159,"“The Man with the Bandaged Arm speaks a strange thing,” said one of the"

"13843",159,""
"13844",159,"“I tell you it is so,” I said. “The Master and the House of Pain will"
"13845",159,"come again. Woe be to him who breaks the Law!”"
"13846",159,""
"13847",159,"They looked curiously at one another. With an affectation of"

"13850",159,""
"13851",159,"Then the Satyr raised a doubt. I answered him. Then one of the dappled"
"13852",159,"things objected, and an animated discussion sprang up round the fire."
"13853",159,"Every moment I began to feel more convinced of my present security. I"
"13854",159,"talked now without the catching in my breath, due to the intensity of"
"13855",159,"my excitement, that had troubled me at first. In the course of about an"
"13856",159,"hour I had really convinced several of the Beast Folk of the truth of"
"13857",159,"my assertions, and talked most of the others into a dubious state. I"
"13858",159,"kept a sharp eye for my enemy the Hyena-swine, but he never appeared."
"13859",159,"Every now and then a suspicious movement would startle me, but my"
"13860",159,"confidence grew rapidly. Then as the moon crept down from the zenith,"
"13861",159,"one by one the listeners began to yawn (showing the oddest teeth in the"
"13862",159,"light of the sinking fire), and first one and then another retired"
"13863",159,"towards the dens in the ravine; and I, dreading the silence and"
"13864",159,"darkness, went with them, knowing I was safer with several of them than"
"13865",159,"with one alone."
"13866",159,""
"13867",159,"In this manner began the longer part of my sojourn upon this Island of"
"13868",159,"Doctor Moreau. But from that night until the end came, there was but"
"13869",159,"one thing happened to tell save a series of innumerable small"
"13870",159,"unpleasant details and the fretting of an incessant uneasiness. So that"
"13871",159,"I prefer to make no chronicle for that gap of time, to tell only one"
"13872",159,"cardinal incident of the ten months I spent as an intimate of these"
"13873",159,"half-humanised brutes. There is much that sticks in my memory that I"
"13874",159,"could write,—things that I would cheerfully give my right hand to"
"13875",159,"forget; but they do not help the telling of the story."
"13876",159,""
"13877",159,"In the retrospect it is strange to remember how soon I fell in with"
"13878",159,"these monsters’ ways, and gained my confidence again. I had my quarrels"
"13879",159,"with them of course, and could show some of their teeth-marks still;"
"13880",159,"but they soon gained a wholesome respect for my trick of throwing"
"13881",159,"stones and for the bite of my hatchet. And my Saint-Bernard-man’s"
"13882",159,"loyalty was of infinite service to me. I found their simple scale of"
"13883",159,"honour was based mainly on the capacity for inflicting trenchant"
"13884",159,"wounds. Indeed, I may say—without vanity, I hope—that I held something"
"13885",159,"like pre-eminence among them. One or two, whom in a rare access of high"
"13886",159,"spirits I had scarred rather badly, bore me a grudge; but it vented"
"13887",159,"itself chiefly behind my back, and at a safe distance from my missiles,"
"13888",159,"in grimaces."
"13889",159,""
"13890",159,"The Hyena-swine avoided me, and I was always on the alert for him. My"
"13891",159,"inseparable Dog-man hated and dreaded him intensely. I really believe"
"13892",159,"that was at the root of the brute’s attachment to me. It was soon"
"13893",159,"evident to me that the former monster had tasted blood, and gone the"
"13894",159,"way of the Leopard-man. He formed a lair somewhere in the forest, and"
"13895",159,"became solitary. Once I tried to induce the Beast Folk to hunt him, but"
"13896",159,"I lacked the authority to make them co-operate for one end. Again and"
"13897",159,"again I tried to approach his den and come upon him unaware; but always"
"13898",159,"he was too acute for me, and saw or winded me and got away. He too made"
"13899",159,"every forest pathway dangerous to me and my ally with his lurking"
"13900",159,"ambuscades. The Dog-man scarcely dared to leave my side."
"13901",159,""
"13902",159,"In the first month or so the Beast Folk, compared with their latter"
"13903",159,"condition, were human enough, and for one or two besides my canine"
"13904",159,"friend I even conceived a friendly tolerance. The little pink"
"13905",159,"sloth-creature displayed an odd affection for me, and took to following"
"13906",159,"me about. The Monkey-man bored me, however; he assumed, on the strength"
"13907",159,"of his five digits, that he was my equal, and was for ever jabbering at"
"13908",159,"me,—jabbering the most arrant nonsense. One thing about him entertained"
"13909",159,"me a little: he had a fantastic trick of coining new words. He had an"
"13910",159,"idea, I believe, that to gabble about names that meant nothing was the"
"13911",159,"proper use of speech. He called it “Big Thinks” to distinguish it from"
"13912",159,"“Little Thinks,” the sane every-day interests of life. If ever I made a"
"13913",159,"remark he did not understand, he would praise it very much, ask me to"
"13914",159,"say it again, learn it by heart, and go off repeating it, with a word"
"13915",159,"wrong here or there, to all the milder of the Beast People. He thought"
"13916",159,"nothing of what was plain and comprehensible. I invented some very"
"13917",159,"curious “Big Thinks” for his especial use. I think now that he was the"
"13918",159,"silliest creature I ever met; he had developed in the most wonderful"
"13919",159,"way the distinctive silliness of man without losing one jot of the"
"13920",159,"natural folly of a monkey."
"13921",159,""
"13922",159,"This, I say, was in the earlier weeks of my solitude among these"
"13923",159,"brutes. During that time they respected the usage established by the"
"13924",159,"Law, and behaved with general decorum. Once I found another rabbit torn"
"13925",159,"to pieces,—by the Hyena-swine, I am assured,—but that was all. It was"
"13926",159,"about May when I first distinctly perceived a growing difference in"
"13927",159,"their speech and carriage, a growing coarseness of articulation, a"
"13928",159,"growing disinclination to talk. My Monkey-man’s jabber multiplied in"
"13929",159,"volume but grew less and less comprehensible, more and more simian."
"13930",159,"Some of the others seemed altogether slipping their hold upon speech,"
"13931",159,"though they still understood what I said to them at that time. (Can you"
"13932",159,"imagine language, once clear-cut and exact, softening and guttering,"
"13933",159,"losing shape and import, becoming mere lumps of sound again?) And they"
"13934",159,"walked erect with an increasing difficulty. Though they evidently felt"
"13935",159,"ashamed of themselves, every now and then I would come upon one or"
"13936",159,"another running on toes and finger-tips, and quite unable to recover"
"13937",159,"the vertical attitude. They held things more clumsily; drinking by"
"13938",159,"suction, feeding by gnawing, grew commoner every day. I realised more"
"13939",159,"keenly than ever what Moreau had told me about the “stubborn"
"13940",159,"beast-flesh.” They were reverting, and reverting very rapidly."
"13941",159,""
"13942",159,"Some of them—the pioneers in this, I noticed with some surprise, were"
"13943",159,"all females—began to disregard the injunction of decency, deliberately"
"13944",159,"for the most part. Others even attempted public outrages upon the"
"13945",159,"institution of monogamy. The tradition of the Law was clearly losing"
"13946",159,"its force. I cannot pursue this disagreeable subject."
"13947",159,""
"13948",159,"My Dog-man imperceptibly slipped back to the dog again; day by day he"
"13949",159,"became dumb, quadrupedal, hairy. I scarcely noticed the transition from"
"13950",159,"the companion on my right hand to the lurching dog at my side."
"13951",159,""
"13952",159,"As the carelessness and disorganisation increased from day to day, the"
"13953",159,"lane of dwelling places, at no time very sweet, became so loathsome"
"13954",159,"that I left it, and going across the island made myself a hovel of"
"13955",159,"boughs amid the black ruins of Moreau’s enclosure. Some memory of pain,"
"13956",159,"I found, still made that place the safest from the Beast Folk."
"13957",159,""
"13958",159,"It would be impossible to detail every step of the lapsing of these"
"13959",159,"monsters,—to tell how, day by day, the human semblance left them; how"
"13960",159,"they gave up bandagings and wrappings, abandoned at last every stitch"
"13961",159,"of clothing; how the hair began to spread over the exposed limbs; how"
"13962",159,"their foreheads fell away and their faces projected; how the"
"13963",159,"quasi-human intimacy I had permitted myself with some of them in the"
"13964",159,"first month of my loneliness became a shuddering horror to recall."
"13965",159,""
"13966",159,"The change was slow and inevitable. For them and for me it came without"
"13967",159,"any definite shock. I still went among them in safety, because no jolt"
"13968",159,"in the downward glide had released the increasing charge of explosive"
"13969",159,"animalism that ousted the human day by day. But I began to fear that"
"13970",159,"soon now that shock must come. My Saint-Bernard-brute followed me to"
"13971",159,"the enclosure every night, and his vigilance enabled me to sleep at"
"13972",159,"times in something like peace. The little pink sloth-thing became shy"
"13973",159,"and left me, to crawl back to its natural life once more among the"
"13974",159,"tree-branches. We were in just the state of equilibrium that would"
"13975",159,"remain in one of those “Happy Family” cages which animal-tamers"
"13976",159,"exhibit, if the tamer were to leave it for ever."
"13977",159,""
"13978",159,"Of course these creatures did not decline into such beasts as the"
"13979",159,"reader has seen in zoological gardens,—into ordinary bears, wolves,"
"13980",159,"tigers, oxen, swine, and apes. There was still something strange about"
"13981",159,"each; in each Moreau had blended this animal with that. One perhaps was"
"13982",159,"ursine chiefly, another feline chiefly, another bovine chiefly; but"
"13983",159,"each was tainted with other creatures,—a kind of generalised animalism"
"13984",159,"appearing through the specific dispositions. And the dwindling shreds"
"13985",159,"of the humanity still startled me every now and then,—a momentary"
"13986",159,"recrudescence of speech perhaps, an unexpected dexterity of the"
"13987",159,"fore-feet, a pitiful attempt to walk erect."
"13988",159,""
"13989",159,"I too must have undergone strange changes. My clothes hung about me as"
"13990",159,"yellow rags, through whose rents showed the tanned skin. My hair grew"
"13991",159,"long, and became matted together. I am told that even now my eyes have"
"13992",159,"a strange brightness, a swift alertness of movement."
"13993",159,""
"13994",159,"At first I spent the daylight hours on the southward beach watching for"
"13995",159,"a ship, hoping and praying for a ship. I counted on the _Ipecacuanha_"
"13996",159,"returning as the year wore on; but she never came. Five times I saw"
"13997",159,"sails, and thrice smoke; but nothing ever touched the island. I always"
"13998",159,"had a bonfire ready, but no doubt the volcanic reputation of the island"
"13999",159,"was taken to account for that."
"14000",159,""
"14001",159,"It was only about September or October that I began to think of making"
"14002",159,"a raft. By that time my arm had healed, and both my hands were at my"
"14003",159,"service again. At first, I found my helplessness appalling. I had never"
"14004",159,"done any carpentry or such-like work in my life, and I spent day after"
"14005",159,"day in experimental chopping and binding among the trees. I had no"
"14006",159,"ropes, and could hit on nothing wherewith to make ropes; none of the"
"14007",159,"abundant creepers seemed limber or strong enough, and with all my"
"14008",159,"litter of scientific education I could not devise any way of making"
"14009",159,"them so. I spent more than a fortnight grubbing among the black ruins"
"14010",159,"of the enclosure and on the beach where the boats had been burnt,"
"14011",159,"looking for nails and other stray pieces of metal that might prove of"
"14012",159,"service. Now and then some Beast-creature would watch me, and go"
"14013",159,"leaping off when I called to it. There came a season of thunder-storms"
"14014",159,"and heavy rain, which greatly retarded my work; but at last the raft"
"14015",159,"was completed."
"14016",159,""
"14017",159,"I was delighted with it. But with a certain lack of practical sense"
"14018",159,"which has always been my bane, I had made it a mile or more from the"
"14019",159,"sea; and before I had dragged it down to the beach the thing had fallen"
"14020",159,"to pieces. Perhaps it is as well that I was saved from launching it;"
"14021",159,"but at the time my misery at my failure was so acute that for some days"
"14022",159,"I simply moped on the beach, and stared at the water and thought of"
"14023",159,"death."
"14024",159,""
"14025",159,"I did not, however, mean to die, and an incident occurred that warned"
"14026",159,"me unmistakably of the folly of letting the days pass so,—for each"
"14027",159,"fresh day was fraught with increasing danger from the Beast People."
"14028",159,""
"14029",159,"I was lying in the shade of the enclosure wall, staring out to sea,"
"14030",159,"when I was startled by something cold touching the skin of my heel, and"
"14031",159,"starting round found the little pink sloth-creature blinking into my"
"14032",159,"face. He had long since lost speech and active movement, and the lank"
"14033",159,"hair of the little brute grew thicker every day and his stumpy claws"
"14034",159,"more askew. He made a moaning noise when he saw he had attracted my"
"14035",159,"attention, went a little way towards the bushes and looked back at me."
"14036",159,""
"14037",159,"At first I did not understand, but presently it occurred to me that he"
"14038",159,"wished me to follow him; and this I did at last,—slowly, for the day"
"14039",159,"was hot. When we reached the trees he clambered into them, for he could"
"14040",159,"travel better among their swinging creepers than on the ground. And"
"14041",159,"suddenly in a trampled space I came upon a ghastly group. My"
"14042",159,"Saint-Bernard-creature lay on the ground, dead; and near his body"
"14043",159,"crouched the Hyena-swine, gripping the quivering flesh with its"
"14044",159,"misshapen claws, gnawing at it, and snarling with delight. As I"
"14045",159,"approached, the monster lifted its glaring eyes to mine, its lips went"
"14046",159,"trembling back from its red-stained teeth, and it growled menacingly."
"14047",159,"It was not afraid and not ashamed; the last vestige of the human taint"
"14048",159,"had vanished. I advanced a step farther, stopped, and pulled out my"
"14049",159,"revolver. At last I had him face to face."
"14050",159,""
"14051",159,"The brute made no sign of retreat; but its ears went back, its hair"
"14052",159,"bristled, and its body crouched together. I aimed between the eyes and"
"14053",159,"fired. As I did so, the Thing rose straight at me in a leap, and I was"
"14054",159,"knocked over like a ninepin. It clutched at me with its crippled hand,"
"14055",159,"and struck me in the face. Its spring carried it over me. I fell under"
"14056",159,"the hind part of its body; but luckily I had hit as I meant, and it had"
"14057",159,"died even as it leapt. I crawled out from under its unclean weight and"
"14058",159,"stood up trembling, staring at its quivering body. That danger at least"
"14059",159,"was over; but this, I knew was only the first of the series of relapses"
"14060",159,"that must come."
"14061",159,""
"14062",159,"I burnt both of the bodies on a pyre of brushwood; but after that I saw"
"14063",159,"that unless I left the island my death was only a question of time. The"
"14064",159,"Beast People by that time had, with one or two exceptions, left the"
"14065",159,"ravine and made themselves lairs according to their taste among the"
"14066",159,"thickets of the island. Few prowled by day, most of them slept, and the"
"14067",159,"island might have seemed deserted to a new-comer; but at night the air"
"14068",159,"was hideous with their calls and howling. I had half a mind to make a"
"14069",159,"massacre of them; to build traps, or fight them with my knife. Had I"
"14070",159,"possessed sufficient cartridges, I should not have hesitated to begin"
"14071",159,"the killing. There could now be scarcely a score left of the dangerous"
"14072",159,"carnivores; the braver of these were already dead. After the death of"
"14073",159,"this poor dog of mine, my last friend, I too adopted to some extent the"
"14074",159,"practice of slumbering in the daytime in order to be on my guard at"
"14075",159,"night. I rebuilt my den in the walls of the enclosure, with such a"
"14076",159,"narrow opening that anything attempting to enter must necessarily make"
"14077",159,"a considerable noise. The creatures had lost the art of fire too, and"
"14078",159,"recovered their fear of it. I turned once more, almost passionately"
"14079",159,"now, to hammering together stakes and branches to form a raft for my"
"14080",159,"escape."
"14081",159,""
"14082",159,"I found a thousand difficulties. I am an extremely unhandy man (my"
"14083",159,"schooling was over before the days of Slöjd); but most of the"
"14084",159,"requirements of a raft I met at last in some clumsy, circuitous way or"
"14085",159,"other, and this time I took care of the strength. The only"
"14086",159,"insurmountable obstacle was that I had no vessel to contain the water I"
"14087",159,"should need if I floated forth upon these untravelled seas. I would"
"14088",159,"have even tried pottery, but the island contained no clay. I used to go"
"14089",159,"moping about the island trying with all my might to solve this one last"
"14090",159,"difficulty. Sometimes I would give way to wild outbursts of rage, and"
"14091",159,"hack and splinter some unlucky tree in my intolerable vexation. But I"
"14092",159,"could think of nothing."
"14093",159,""
"14094",159,"And then came a day, a wonderful day, which I spent in ecstasy. I saw a"
"14095",159,"sail to the southwest, a small sail like that of a little schooner; and"
"14096",159,"forthwith I lit a great pile of brushwood, and stood by it in the heat"
"14097",159,"of it, and the heat of the midday sun, watching. All day I watched that"
"14098",159,"sail, eating or drinking nothing, so that my head reeled; and the"
"14099",159,"Beasts came and glared at me, and seemed to wonder, and went away. It"
"14100",159,"was still distant when night came and swallowed it up; and all night I"
"14101",159,"toiled to keep my blaze bright and high, and the eyes of the Beasts"
"14102",159,"shone out of the darkness, marvelling. In the dawn the sail was nearer,"
"14103",159,"and I saw it was the dirty lug-sail of a small boat. But it sailed"
"14104",159,"strangely. My eyes were weary with watching, and I peered and could not"
"14105",159,"believe them. Two men were in the boat, sitting low down,—one by the"
"14106",159,"bows, the other at the rudder. The head was not kept to the wind; it"
"14107",159,"yawed and fell away."
"14108",159,""
"14109",159,"As the day grew brighter, I began waving the last rag of my jacket to"
"14110",159,"them; but they did not notice me, and sat still, facing each other. I"
"14111",159,"went to the lowest point of the low headland, and gesticulated and"
"14112",159,"shouted. There was no response, and the boat kept on her aimless"
"14113",159,"course, making slowly, very slowly, for the bay. Suddenly a great white"
"14114",159,"bird flew up out of the boat, and neither of the men stirred nor"
"14115",159,"noticed it; it circled round, and then came sweeping overhead with its"
"14116",159,"strong wings outspread."
"14117",159,""
"14118",159,"Then I stopped shouting, and sat down on the headland and rested my"
"14119",159,"chin on my hands and stared. Slowly, slowly, the boat drove past"
"14120",159,"towards the west. I would have swum out to it, but something—a cold,"
"14121",159,"vague fear—kept me back. In the afternoon the tide stranded the boat,"
"14122",159,"and left it a hundred yards or so to the westward of the ruins of the"
"14123",159,"enclosure. The men in it were dead, had been dead so long that they"
"14124",159,"fell to pieces when I tilted the boat on its side and dragged them out."
"14125",159,"One had a shock of red hair, like the captain of the _Ipecacuanha_, and"
"14126",159,"a dirty white cap lay in the bottom of the boat."
"14127",159,""
"14128",159,"As I stood beside the boat, three of the Beasts came slinking out of"
"14129",159,"the bushes and sniffing towards me. One of my spasms of disgust came"
"14130",159,"upon me. I thrust the little boat down the beach and clambered on board"
"14131",159,"her. Two of the brutes were Wolf-beasts, and came forward with"
"14132",159,"quivering nostrils and glittering eyes; the third was the horrible"
"14133",159,"nondescript of bear and bull. When I saw them approaching those"
"14134",159,"wretched remains, heard them snarling at one another and caught the"
"14135",159,"gleam of their teeth, a frantic horror succeeded my repulsion. I turned"
"14136",159,"my back upon them, struck the lug and began paddling out to sea. I"
"14137",159,"could not bring myself to look behind me."
"14138",159,""
"14139",159,"I lay, however, between the reef and the island that night, and the"
"14140",159,"next morning went round to the stream and filled the empty keg aboard"
"14141",159,"with water. Then, with such patience as I could command, I collected a"
"14142",159,"quantity of fruit, and waylaid and killed two rabbits with my last"
"14143",159,"three cartridges. While I was doing this I left the boat moored to an"
"14144",159,"inward projection of the reef, for fear of the Beast People."
"14145",159,""
"14146",159,""
"14147",159,""
"14148",159,""
"14149",159,"XXII."
"14150",159,"THE MAN ALONE."
"14151",159,""
"14152",159,""
"14153",159,"In the evening I started, and drove out to sea before a gentle wind"
"14154",159,"from the southwest, slowly, steadily; and the island grew smaller and"
"14155",159,"smaller, and the lank spire of smoke dwindled to a finer and finer line"
"14156",159,"against the hot sunset. The ocean rose up around me, hiding that low,"
"14157",159,"dark patch from my eyes. The daylight, the trailing glory of the sun,"
"14158",159,"went streaming out of the sky, was drawn aside like some luminous"
"14159",159,"curtain, and at last I looked into the blue gulf of immensity which the"
"14160",159,"sunshine hides, and saw the floating hosts of the stars. The sea was"
"14161",159,"silent, the sky was silent. I was alone with the night and silence."
"14162",159,""
"14163",159,"So I drifted for three days, eating and drinking sparingly, and"
"14164",159,"meditating upon all that had happened to me,—not desiring very greatly"
"14165",159,"then to see men again. One unclean rag was about me, my hair a black"
"14166",159,"tangle: no doubt my discoverers thought me a madman."
"14167",159,""
"14168",159,"It is strange, but I felt no desire to return to mankind. I was only"
"14169",159,"glad to be quit of the foulness of the Beast People. And on the third"
"14170",159,"day I was picked up by a brig from Apia to San Francisco. Neither the"
"14171",159,"captain nor the mate would believe my story, judging that solitude and"
"14172",159,"danger had made me mad; and fearing their opinion might be that of"
"14173",159,"others, I refrained from telling my adventure further, and professed to"
"14174",159,"recall nothing that had happened to me between the loss of the _Lady"
"14175",159,"Vain_ and the time when I was picked up again,—the space of a year."
"14176",159,""
"14177",159,"I had to act with the utmost circumspection to save myself from the"
"14178",159,"suspicion of insanity. My memory of the Law, of the two dead sailors,"
"14179",159,"of the ambuscades of the darkness, of the body in the canebrake,"
"14180",159,"haunted me; and, unnatural as it seems, with my return to mankind came,"
"14181",159,"instead of that confidence and sympathy I had expected, a strange"
"14182",159,"enhancement of the uncertainty and dread I had experienced during my"
"14183",159,"stay upon the island. No one would believe me; I was almost as queer to"
"14184",159,"men as I had been to the Beast People. I may have caught something of"
"14185",159,"the natural wildness of my companions. They say that terror is a"
"14186",159,"disease, and anyhow I can witness that for several years now a restless"
"14187",159,"fear has dwelt in my mind,—such a restless fear as a half-tamed lion"
"14188",159,"cub may feel."
"14189",159,""
"14190",159,"My trouble took the strangest form. I could not persuade myself that"
"14191",159,"the men and women I met were not also another Beast People, animals"
"14192",159,"half wrought into the outward image of human souls, and that they would"
"14193",159,"presently begin to revert,—to show first this bestial mark and then"
"14194",159,"that. But I have confided my case to a strangely able man,—a man who"
"14195",159,"had known Moreau, and seemed half to credit my story; a mental"
"14196",159,"specialist,—and he has helped me mightily, though I do not expect that"
"14197",159,"the terror of that island will ever altogether leave me. At most times"
"14198",159,"it lies far in the back of my mind, a mere distant cloud, a memory, and"
"14199",159,"a faint distrust; but there are times when the little cloud spreads"
"14200",159,"until it obscures the whole sky. Then I look about me at my fellow-men;"
"14201",159,"and I go in fear. I see faces, keen and bright; others dull or"
"14202",159,"dangerous; others, unsteady, insincere,—none that have the calm"
"14203",159,"authority of a reasonable soul. I feel as though the animal was surging"
"14204",159,"up through them; that presently the degradation of the Islanders will"
"14205",159,"be played over again on a larger scale. I know this is an illusion;"
"14206",159,"that these seeming men and women about me are indeed men and women,—men"
"14207",159,"and women for ever, perfectly reasonable creatures, full of human"
"14208",159,"desires and tender solicitude, emancipated from instinct and the slaves"
"14209",159,"of no fantastic Law,—beings altogether different from the Beast Folk."
"14210",159,"Yet I shrink from them, from their curious glances, their inquiries and"
"14211",159,"assistance, and long to be away from them and alone. For that reason I"
"14212",159,"live near the broad free downland, and can escape thither when this"
"14213",159,"shadow is over my soul; and very sweet is the empty downland then,"
"14214",159,"under the wind-swept sky."
"14215",159,""
"14216",159,"When I lived in London the horror was well-nigh insupportable. I could"
"14217",159,"not get away from men: their voices came through windows; locked doors"
"14218",159,"were flimsy safeguards. I would go out into the streets to fight with"
"14219",159,"my delusion, and prowling women would mew after me; furtive, craving"
"14220",159,"men glance jealously at me; weary, pale workers go coughing by me with"
"14221",159,"tired eyes and eager paces, like wounded deer dripping blood; old"
"14222",159,"people, bent and dull, pass murmuring to themselves; and, all"
"14223",159,"unheeding, a ragged tail of gibing children. Then I would turn aside"
"14224",159,"into some chapel,—and even there, such was my disturbance, it seemed"
"14225",159,"that the preacher gibbered “Big Thinks,” even as the Ape-man had done;"
"14226",159,"or into some library, and there the intent faces over the books seemed"
"14227",159,"but patient creatures waiting for prey. Particularly nauseous were the"
"14228",159,"blank, expressionless faces of people in trains and omnibuses; they"
"14229",159,"seemed no more my fellow-creatures than dead bodies would be, so that I"
"14230",159,"did not dare to travel unless I was assured of being alone. And even it"
"14231",159,"seemed that I too was not a reasonable creature, but only an animal"
"14232",159,"tormented with some strange disorder in its brain which sent it to"
"14233",159,"wander alone, like a sheep stricken with gid."
"14234",159,""
"14235",159,"This is a mood, however, that comes to me now, I thank God, more"
"14236",159,"rarely. I have withdrawn myself from the confusion of cities and"
"14237",159,"multitudes, and spend my days surrounded by wise books,—bright windows"
"14238",159,"in this life of ours, lit by the shining souls of men. I see few"
"14239",159,"strangers, and have but a small household. My days I devote to reading"
"14240",159,"and to experiments in chemistry, and I spend many of the clear nights"
"14241",159,"in the study of astronomy. There is—though I do not know how there is"
"14242",159,"or why there is—a sense of infinite peace and protection in the"
"14243",159,"glittering hosts of heaven. There it must be, I think, in the vast and"
"14244",159,"eternal laws of matter, and not in the daily cares and sins and"
"14245",159,"troubles of men, that whatever is more than animal within us must find"
"14246",159,"its solace and its hope. I _hope_, or I could not live."
"14247",159,""
"14248",159,""
"14249",159,"And so, in hope and solitude, my story ends."
"14250",159,""
"14251",159,"EDWARD PRENDICK."
"14252",159,""

"14259",159,"The substance of the chapter entitled “Doctor Moreau explains,” which"
"14260",159,"contains the essential idea of the story, appeared as a middle article"
"14261",159,"in the _Saturday Review_ in January, 1895. This is the only portion of"
"14262",159,"this story that has been previously published, and it has been entirely"
"14263",159,"recast to adapt it to the narrative form."

"14311",5230,"CHAPTER I."
"14312",5230,"THE STRANGE MAN’S ARRIVAL"
"14313",5230,""
"14314",5230,""
"14315",5230,"The stranger came early in February, one wintry day, through a biting"
"14316",5230,"wind and a driving snow, the last snowfall of the year, over the down,"
"14317",5230,"walking from Bramblehurst railway station, and carrying a little black"
"14318",5230,"portmanteau in his thickly gloved hand. He was wrapped up from head to"
"14319",5230,"foot, and the brim of his soft felt hat hid every inch of his face but"
"14320",5230,"the shiny tip of his nose; the snow had piled itself against his"
"14321",5230,"shoulders and chest, and added a white crest to the burden he carried."
"14322",5230,"He staggered into the “Coach and Horses” more dead than alive, and"
"14323",5230,"flung his portmanteau down. “A fire,” he cried, “in the name of human"
"14324",5230,"charity! A room and a fire!” He stamped and shook the snow from off"
"14325",5230,"himself in the bar, and followed Mrs. Hall into her guest parlour to"
"14326",5230,"strike his bargain. And with that much introduction, that and a couple"
"14327",5230,"of sovereigns flung upon the table, he took up his quarters in the inn."
"14328",5230,""
"14329",5230,"Mrs. Hall lit the fire and left him there while she went to prepare him"
"14330",5230,"a meal with her own hands. A guest to stop at Iping in the wintertime"
"14331",5230,"was an unheard-of piece of luck, let alone a guest who was no"
"14332",5230,"“haggler,” and she was resolved to show herself worthy of her good"
"14333",5230,"fortune. As soon as the bacon was well under way, and Millie, her"
"14334",5230,"lymphatic maid, had been brisked up a bit by a few deftly chosen"
"14335",5230,"expressions of contempt, she carried the cloth, plates, and glasses"
"14336",5230,"into the parlour and began to lay them with the utmost _éclat_."
"14337",5230,"Although the fire was burning up briskly, she was surprised to see that"
"14338",5230,"her visitor still wore his hat and coat, standing with his back to her"
"14339",5230,"and staring out of the window at the falling snow in the yard. His"
"14340",5230,"gloved hands were clasped behind him, and he seemed to be lost in"
"14341",5230,"thought. She noticed that the melting snow that still sprinkled his"
"14342",5230,"shoulders dripped upon her carpet. “Can I take your hat and coat, sir?”"
"14343",5230,"she said, “and give them a good dry in the kitchen?”"
"14344",5230,""
"14345",5230,"“No,” he said without turning."
"14346",5230,""
"14347",5230,"She was not sure she had heard him, and was about to repeat her"
"14348",5230,"question."
"14349",5230,""
"14350",5230,"He turned his head and looked at her over his shoulder. “I prefer to"
"14351",5230,"keep them on,” he said with emphasis, and she noticed that he wore big"
"14352",5230,"blue spectacles with sidelights, and had a bush side-whisker over his"
"14353",5230,"coat-collar that completely hid his cheeks and face."
"14354",5230,""
"14355",5230,"“Very well, sir,” she said. “_As_ you like. In a bit the room will be"
"14356",5230,"warmer.”"
"14357",5230,""
"14358",5230,"He made no answer, and had turned his face away from her again, and"
"14359",5230,"Mrs. Hall, feeling that her conversational advances were ill-timed,"
"14360",5230,"laid the rest of the table things in a quick staccato and whisked out"
"14361",5230,"of the room. When she returned he was still standing there, like a man"
"14362",5230,"of stone, his back hunched, his collar turned up, his dripping hat-brim"
"14363",5230,"turned down, hiding his face and ears completely. She put down the eggs"
"14364",5230,"and bacon with considerable emphasis, and called rather than said to"
"14365",5230,"him, “Your lunch is served, sir.”"
"14366",5230,""
"14367",5230,"“Thank you,” he said at the same time, and did not stir until she was"
"14368",5230,"closing the door. Then he swung round and approached the table with a"
"14369",5230,"certain eager quickness."
"14370",5230,""
"14371",5230,"As she went behind the bar to the kitchen she heard a sound repeated at"
"14372",5230,"regular intervals. Chirk, chirk, chirk, it went, the sound of a spoon"
"14373",5230,"being rapidly whisked round a basin. “That girl!” she said. “There! I"
"14374",5230,"clean forgot it. It’s her being so long!” And while she herself"
"14375",5230,"finished mixing the mustard, she gave Millie a few verbal stabs for her"
"14376",5230,"excessive slowness. She had cooked the ham and eggs, laid the table,"
"14377",5230,"and done everything, while Millie (help indeed!) had only succeeded in"
"14378",5230,"delaying the mustard. And him a new guest and wanting to stay! Then she"
"14379",5230,"filled the mustard pot, and, putting it with a certain stateliness upon"
"14380",5230,"a gold and black tea-tray, carried it into the parlour."
"14381",5230,""
"14382",5230,"She rapped and entered promptly. As she did so her visitor moved"
"14383",5230,"quickly, so that she got but a glimpse of a white object disappearing"
"14384",5230,"behind the table. It would seem he was picking something from the"
"14385",5230,"floor. She rapped down the mustard pot on the table, and then she"
"14386",5230,"noticed the overcoat and hat had been taken off and put over a chair in"
"14387",5230,"front of the fire, and a pair of wet boots threatened rust to her steel"
"14388",5230,"fender. She went to these things resolutely. “I suppose I may have them"
"14389",5230,"to dry now,” she said in a voice that brooked no denial."
"14390",5230,""
"14391",5230,"“Leave the hat,” said her visitor, in a muffled voice, and turning she"
"14392",5230,"saw he had raised his head and was sitting and looking at her."
"14393",5230,""
"14394",5230,"For a moment she stood gaping at him, too surprised to speak."
"14395",5230,""
"14396",5230,"He held a white cloth—it was a serviette he had brought with him—over"
"14397",5230,"the lower part of his face, so that his mouth and jaws were completely"
"14398",5230,"hidden, and that was the reason of his muffled voice. But it was not"
"14399",5230,"that which startled Mrs. Hall. It was the fact that all his forehead"
"14400",5230,"above his blue glasses was covered by a white bandage, and that another"
"14401",5230,"covered his ears, leaving not a scrap of his face exposed excepting"
"14402",5230,"only his pink, peaked nose. It was bright, pink, and shiny just as it"
"14403",5230,"had been at first. He wore a dark-brown velvet jacket with a high,"
"14404",5230,"black, linen-lined collar turned up about his neck. The thick black"
"14405",5230,"hair, escaping as it could below and between the cross bandages,"
"14406",5230,"projected in curious tails and horns, giving him the strangest"
"14407",5230,"appearance conceivable. This muffled and bandaged head was so unlike"
"14408",5230,"what she had anticipated, that for a moment she was rigid."
"14409",5230,""
"14410",5230,"He did not remove the serviette, but remained holding it, as she saw"
"14411",5230,"now, with a brown gloved hand, and regarding her with his inscrutable"
"14412",5230,"blue glasses. “Leave the hat,” he said, speaking very distinctly"
"14413",5230,"through the white cloth."
"14414",5230,""
"14415",5230,"Her nerves began to recover from the shock they had received. She"
"14416",5230,"placed the hat on the chair again by the fire. “I didn’t know, sir,”"
"14417",5230,"she began, “that—” and she stopped embarrassed."
"14418",5230,""
"14419",5230,"“Thank you,” he said drily, glancing from her to the door and then at"
"14420",5230,"her again."
"14421",5230,""
"14422",5230,"“I’ll have them nicely dried, sir, at once,” she said, and carried his"
"14423",5230,"clothes out of the room. She glanced at his white-swathed head and blue"
"14424",5230,"goggles again as she was going out of the door; but his napkin was"
"14425",5230,"still in front of his face. She shivered a little as she closed the"
"14426",5230,"door behind her, and her face was eloquent of her surprise and"
"14427",5230,"perplexity. “I _never_,” she whispered. “There!” She went quite softly"
"14428",5230,"to the kitchen, and was too preoccupied to ask Millie what she was"
"14429",5230,"messing about with _now_, when she got there."
"14430",5230,""
"14431",5230,"The visitor sat and listened to her retreating feet. He glanced"
"14432",5230,"inquiringly at the window before he removed his serviette, and resumed"
"14433",5230,"his meal. He took a mouthful, glanced suspiciously at the window, took"
"14434",5230,"another mouthful, then rose and, taking the serviette in his hand,"
"14435",5230,"walked across the room and pulled the blind down to the top of the"
"14436",5230,"white muslin that obscured the lower panes. This left the room in a"
"14437",5230,"twilight. This done, he returned with an easier air to the table and"
"14438",5230,"his meal."
"14439",5230,""
"14440",5230,"“The poor soul’s had an accident or an op’ration or somethin’,” said"
"14441",5230,"Mrs. Hall. “What a turn them bandages did give me, to be sure!”"
"14442",5230,""
"14443",5230,"She put on some more coal, unfolded the clothes-horse, and extended the"
"14444",5230,"traveller’s coat upon this. “And they goggles! Why, he looked more like"
"14445",5230,"a divin’ helmet than a human man!” She hung his muffler on a corner of"
"14446",5230,"the horse. “And holding that handkerchief over his mouth all the time."
"14447",5230,"Talkin’ through it! ... Perhaps his mouth was hurt too—maybe.”"
"14448",5230,""
"14449",5230,"She turned round, as one who suddenly remembers. “Bless my soul alive!”"
"14450",5230,"she said, going off at a tangent; “ain’t you done them taters _yet_,"
"14451",5230,"Millie?”"
"14452",5230,""
"14453",5230,"When Mrs. Hall went to clear away the stranger’s lunch, her idea that"
"14454",5230,"his mouth must also have been cut or disfigured in the accident she"
"14455",5230,"supposed him to have suffered, was confirmed, for he was smoking a"
"14456",5230,"pipe, and all the time that she was in the room he never loosened the"
"14457",5230,"silk muffler he had wrapped round the lower part of his face to put the"
"14458",5230,"mouthpiece to his lips. Yet it was not forgetfulness, for she saw he"
"14459",5230,"glanced at it as it smouldered out. He sat in the corner with his back"
"14460",5230,"to the window-blind and spoke now, having eaten and drunk and being"
"14461",5230,"comfortably warmed through, with less aggressive brevity than before."
"14462",5230,"The reflection of the fire lent a kind of red animation to his big"
"14463",5230,"spectacles they had lacked hitherto."
"14464",5230,""
"14465",5230,"“I have some luggage,” he said, “at Bramblehurst station,” and he asked"
"14466",5230,"her how he could have it sent. He bowed his bandaged head quite"
"14467",5230,"politely in acknowledgment of her explanation. “To-morrow?” he said."
"14468",5230,"“There is no speedier delivery?” and seemed quite disappointed when she"
"14469",5230,"answered, “No.” Was she quite sure? No man with a trap who would go"
"14470",5230,"over?"
"14471",5230,""
"14472",5230,"Mrs. Hall, nothing loath, answered his questions and developed a"
"14473",5230,"conversation. “It’s a steep road by the down, sir,” she said in answer"
"14474",5230,"to the question about a trap; and then, snatching at an opening, said,"
"14475",5230,"“It was there a carriage was upsettled, a year ago and more. A"
"14476",5230,"gentleman killed, besides his coachman. Accidents, sir, happen in a"
"14477",5230,"moment, don’t they?”"
"14478",5230,""
"14479",5230,"But the visitor was not to be drawn so easily. “They do,” he said"
"14480",5230,"through his muffler, eyeing her quietly through his impenetrable"
"14481",5230,"glasses."
"14482",5230,""
"14483",5230,"“But they take long enough to get well, don’t they? ... There was my"
"14484",5230,"sister’s son, Tom, jest cut his arm with a scythe, tumbled on it in the"
"14485",5230,"’ayfield, and, bless me! he was three months tied up sir. You’d hardly"
"14486",5230,"believe it. It’s regular given me a dread of a scythe, sir.”"
"14487",5230,""
"14488",5230,"“I can quite understand that,” said the visitor."
"14489",5230,""
"14490",5230,"“He was afraid, one time, that he’d have to have an op’ration—he was"
"14491",5230,"that bad, sir.”"
"14492",5230,""
"14493",5230,"The visitor laughed abruptly, a bark of a laugh that he seemed to bite"
"14494",5230,"and kill in his mouth. “_Was_ he?” he said."
"14495",5230,""
"14496",5230,"“He was, sir. And no laughing matter to them as had the doing for him,"
"14497",5230,"as I had—my sister being took up with her little ones so much. There"
"14498",5230,"was bandages to do, sir, and bandages to undo. So that if I may make so"
"14499",5230,"bold as to say it, sir—”"
"14500",5230,""
"14501",5230,"“Will you get me some matches?” said the visitor, quite abruptly. “My"
"14502",5230,"pipe is out.”"
"14503",5230,""
"14504",5230,"Mrs. Hall was pulled up suddenly. It was certainly rude of him, after"
"14505",5230,"telling him all she had done. She gasped at him for a moment, and"
"14506",5230,"remembered the two sovereigns. She went for the matches."
"14507",5230,""
"14508",5230,"“Thanks,” he said concisely, as she put them down, and turned his"
"14509",5230,"shoulder upon her and stared out of the window again. It was altogether"
"14510",5230,"too discouraging. Evidently he was sensitive on the topic of operations"
"14511",5230,"and bandages. She did not “make so bold as to say,” however, after all."
"14512",5230,"But his snubbing way had irritated her, and Millie had a hot time of it"
"14513",5230,"that afternoon."
"14514",5230,""
"14515",5230,"The visitor remained in the parlour until four o’clock, without giving"
"14516",5230,"the ghost of an excuse for an intrusion. For the most part he was quite"
"14517",5230,"still during that time; it would seem he sat in the growing darkness"
"14518",5230,"smoking in the firelight—perhaps dozing."
"14519",5230,""
"14520",5230,"Once or twice a curious listener might have heard him at the coals, and"
"14521",5230,"for the space of five minutes he was audible pacing the room. He seemed"
"14522",5230,"to be talking to himself. Then the armchair creaked as he sat down"
"14523",5230,"again."
"14524",5230,""
"14525",5230,""
"14526",5230,""
"14527",5230,""
"14528",5230,"CHAPTER II."
"14529",5230,"MR. TEDDY HENFREY’S FIRST IMPRESSIONS"
"14530",5230,""
"14531",5230,""
"14532",5230,"At four o’clock, when it was fairly dark and Mrs. Hall was screwing up"
"14533",5230,"her courage to go in and ask her visitor if he would take some tea,"
"14534",5230,"Teddy Henfrey, the clock-jobber, came into the bar. “My sakes! Mrs."
"14535",5230,"Hall,” said he, “but this is terrible weather for thin boots!” The snow"
"14536",5230,"outside was falling faster."
"14537",5230,""
"14538",5230,"Mrs. Hall agreed, and then noticed he had his bag with him. “Now you’re"
"14539",5230,"here, Mr. Teddy,” said she, “I’d be glad if you’d give th’ old clock in"
"14540",5230,"the parlour a bit of a look. ’Tis going, and it strikes well and"
"14541",5230,"hearty; but the hour-hand won’t do nuthin’ but point at six.”"
"14542",5230,""
"14543",5230,"And leading the way, she went across to the parlour door and rapped and"
"14544",5230,"entered."
"14545",5230,""
"14546",5230,"Her visitor, she saw as she opened the door, was seated in the armchair"
"14547",5230,"before the fire, dozing it would seem, with his bandaged head drooping"
"14548",5230,"on one side. The only light in the room was the red glow from the"
"14549",5230,"fire—which lit his eyes like adverse railway signals, but left his"
"14550",5230,"downcast face in darkness—and the scanty vestiges of the day that came"
"14551",5230,"in through the open door. Everything was ruddy, shadowy, and indistinct"
"14552",5230,"to her, the more so since she had just been lighting the bar lamp, and"
"14553",5230,"her eyes were dazzled. But for a second it seemed to her that the man"
"14554",5230,"she looked at had an enormous mouth wide open—a vast and incredible"
"14555",5230,"mouth that swallowed the whole of the lower portion of his face. It was"
"14556",5230,"the sensation of a moment: the white-bound head, the monstrous goggle"
"14557",5230,"eyes, and this huge yawn below it. Then he stirred, started up in his"
"14558",5230,"chair, put up his hand. She opened the door wide, so that the room was"
"14559",5230,"lighter, and she saw him more clearly, with the muffler held up to his"
"14560",5230,"face just as she had seen him hold the serviette before. The shadows,"
"14561",5230,"she fancied, had tricked her."
"14562",5230,""
"14563",5230,"“Would you mind, sir, this man a-coming to look at the clock, sir?” she"
"14564",5230,"said, recovering from the momentary shock."
"14565",5230,""
"14566",5230,"“Look at the clock?” he said, staring round in a drowsy manner, and"
"14567",5230,"speaking over his hand, and then, getting more fully awake,"
"14568",5230,"“certainly.”"
"14569",5230,""
"14570",5230,"Mrs. Hall went away to get a lamp, and he rose and stretched himself."
"14571",5230,"Then came the light, and Mr. Teddy Henfrey, entering, was confronted by"
"14572",5230,"this bandaged person. He was, he says, “taken aback.”"
"14573",5230,""
"14574",5230,"“Good afternoon,” said the stranger, regarding him—as Mr. Henfrey says,"
"14575",5230,"with a vivid sense of the dark spectacles—“like a lobster.”"
"14576",5230,""
"14577",5230,"“I hope,” said Mr. Henfrey, “that it’s no intrusion.”"
"14578",5230,""
"14579",5230,"“None whatever,” said the stranger. “Though, I understand,” he said"
"14580",5230,"turning to Mrs. Hall, “that this room is really to be mine for my own"
"14581",5230,"private use.”"
"14582",5230,""
"14583",5230,"“I thought, sir,” said Mrs. Hall, “you’d prefer the clock—”"
"14584",5230,""
"14585",5230,"“Certainly,” said the stranger, “certainly—but, as a rule, I like to be"
"14586",5230,"alone and undisturbed."
"14587",5230,""
"14588",5230,"“But I’m really glad to have the clock seen to,” he said, seeing a"
"14589",5230,"certain hesitation in Mr. Henfrey’s manner. “Very glad.” Mr. Henfrey"
"14590",5230,"had intended to apologise and withdraw, but this anticipation reassured"
"14591",5230,"him. The stranger turned round with his back to the fireplace and put"
"14592",5230,"his hands behind his back. “And presently,” he said, “when the"
"14593",5230,"clock-mending is over, I think I should like to have some tea. But not"
"14594",5230,"till the clock-mending is over.”"
"14595",5230,""
"14596",5230,"Mrs. Hall was about to leave the room—she made no conversational"
"14597",5230,"advances this time, because she did not want to be snubbed in front of"
"14598",5230,"Mr. Henfrey—when her visitor asked her if she had made any arrangements"
"14599",5230,"about his boxes at Bramblehurst. She told him she had mentioned the"
"14600",5230,"matter to the postman, and that the carrier could bring them over on"
"14601",5230,"the morrow. “You are certain that is the earliest?” he said."
"14602",5230,""
"14603",5230,"She was certain, with a marked coldness."
"14604",5230,""
"14605",5230,"“I should explain,” he added, “what I was really too cold and fatigued"
"14606",5230,"to do before, that I am an experimental investigator.”"
"14607",5230,""
"14608",5230,"“Indeed, sir,” said Mrs. Hall, much impressed."
"14609",5230,""
"14610",5230,"“And my baggage contains apparatus and appliances.”"
"14611",5230,""
"14612",5230,"“Very useful things indeed they are, sir,” said Mrs. Hall."
"14613",5230,""
"14614",5230,"“And I’m very naturally anxious to get on with my inquiries.”"
"14615",5230,""
"14616",5230,"“Of course, sir.”"
"14617",5230,""
"14618",5230,"“My reason for coming to Iping,” he proceeded, with a certain"
"14619",5230,"deliberation of manner, “was ... a desire for solitude. I do not wish"
"14620",5230,"to be disturbed in my work. In addition to my work, an accident—”"
"14621",5230,""
"14622",5230,"“I thought as much,” said Mrs. Hall to herself."
"14623",5230,""
"14624",5230,"“—necessitates a certain retirement. My eyes—are sometimes so weak and"
"14625",5230,"painful that I have to shut myself up in the dark for hours together."
"14626",5230,"Lock myself up. Sometimes—now and then. Not at present, certainly. At"
"14627",5230,"such times the slightest disturbance, the entry of a stranger into the"
"14628",5230,"room, is a source of excruciating annoyance to me—it is well these"
"14629",5230,"things should be understood.”"
"14630",5230,""
"14631",5230,"“Certainly, sir,” said Mrs. Hall. “And if I might make so bold as to"
"14632",5230,"ask—”"
"14633",5230,""
"14634",5230,"“That I think, is all,” said the stranger, with that quietly"
"14635",5230,"irresistible air of finality he could assume at will. Mrs. Hall"
"14636",5230,"reserved her question and sympathy for a better occasion."
"14637",5230,""
"14638",5230,"After Mrs. Hall had left the room, he remained standing in front of the"
"14639",5230,"fire, glaring, so Mr. Henfrey puts it, at the clock-mending. Mr."
"14640",5230,"Henfrey not only took off the hands of the clock, and the face, but"
"14641",5230,"extracted the works; and he tried to work in as slow and quiet and"
"14642",5230,"unassuming a manner as possible. He worked with the lamp close to him,"
"14643",5230,"and the green shade threw a brilliant light upon his hands, and upon"
"14644",5230,"the frame and wheels, and left the rest of the room shadowy. When he"
"14645",5230,"looked up, coloured patches swam in his eyes. Being constitutionally of"
"14646",5230,"a curious nature, he had removed the works—a quite unnecessary"
"14647",5230,"proceeding—with the idea of delaying his departure and perhaps falling"
"14648",5230,"into conversation with the stranger. But the stranger stood there,"
"14649",5230,"perfectly silent and still. So still, it got on Henfrey’s nerves. He"
"14650",5230,"felt alone in the room and looked up, and there, grey and dim, was the"
"14651",5230,"bandaged head and huge blue lenses staring fixedly, with a mist of"
"14652",5230,"green spots drifting in front of them. It was so uncanny to Henfrey"
"14653",5230,"that for a minute they remained staring blankly at one another. Then"
"14654",5230,"Henfrey looked down again. Very uncomfortable position! One would like"
"14655",5230,"to say something. Should he remark that the weather was very cold for"
"14656",5230,"the time of year?"
"14657",5230,""
"14658",5230,"He looked up as if to take aim with that introductory shot. “The"
"14659",5230,"weather—” he began."
"14660",5230,""
"14661",5230,"“Why don’t you finish and go?” said the rigid figure, evidently in a"
"14662",5230,"state of painfully suppressed rage. “All you’ve got to do is to fix the"
"14663",5230,"hour-hand on its axle. You’re simply humbugging—”"
"14664",5230,""
"14665",5230,"“Certainly, sir—one minute more. I overlooked—” and Mr. Henfrey"
"14666",5230,"finished and went."
"14667",5230,""
"14668",5230,"But he went feeling excessively annoyed. “Damn it!” said Mr. Henfrey to"
"14669",5230,"himself, trudging down the village through the thawing snow; “a man"
"14670",5230,"must do a clock at times, surely.”"
"14671",5230,""
"14672",5230,"And again, “Can’t a man look at you?—Ugly!”"
"14673",5230,""
"14674",5230,"And yet again, “Seemingly not. If the police was wanting you you"
"14675",5230,"couldn’t be more wropped and bandaged.”"
"14676",5230,""
"14677",5230,"At Gleeson’s corner he saw Hall, who had recently married the"
"14678",5230,"stranger’s hostess at the “Coach and Horses,” and who now drove the"
"14679",5230,"Iping conveyance, when occasional people required it, to Sidderbridge"
"14680",5230,"Junction, coming towards him on his return from that place. Hall had"
"14681",5230,"evidently been “stopping a bit” at Sidderbridge, to judge by his"
"14682",5230,"driving. “’Ow do, Teddy?” he said, passing."
"14683",5230,""
"14684",5230,"“You got a rum un up home!” said Teddy."
"14685",5230,""
"14686",5230,"Hall very sociably pulled up. “What’s that?” he asked."
"14687",5230,""
"14688",5230,"“Rum-looking customer stopping at the ‘Coach and Horses,’” said Teddy."
"14689",5230,"“My sakes!”"
"14690",5230,""
"14691",5230,"And he proceeded to give Hall a vivid description of his grotesque"
"14692",5230,"guest. “Looks a bit like a disguise, don’t it? I’d like to see a man’s"
"14693",5230,"face if I had him stopping in _my_ place,” said Henfrey. “But women are"
"14694",5230,"that trustful—where strangers are concerned. He’s took your rooms and"
"14695",5230,"he ain’t even given a name, Hall.”"
"14696",5230,""
"14697",5230,"“You don’t say so!” said Hall, who was a man of sluggish apprehension."
"14698",5230,""
"14699",5230,"“Yes,” said Teddy. “By the week. Whatever he is, you can’t get rid of"
"14700",5230,"him under the week. And he’s got a lot of luggage coming to-morrow, so"
"14701",5230,"he says. Let’s hope it won’t be stones in boxes, Hall.”"
"14702",5230,""
"14703",5230,"He told Hall how his aunt at Hastings had been swindled by a stranger"
"14704",5230,"with empty portmanteaux. Altogether he left Hall vaguely suspicious."
"14705",5230,"“Get up, old girl,” said Hall. “I s’pose I must see ’bout this.”"
"14706",5230,""
"14707",5230,"Teddy trudged on his way with his mind considerably relieved."
"14708",5230,""
"14709",5230,"Instead of “seeing ’bout it,” however, Hall on his return was severely"
"14710",5230,"rated by his wife on the length of time he had spent in Sidderbridge,"
"14711",5230,"and his mild inquiries were answered snappishly and in a manner not to"
"14712",5230,"the point. But the seed of suspicion Teddy had sown germinated in the"
"14713",5230,"mind of Mr. Hall in spite of these discouragements. “You wim’ don’t"
"14714",5230,"know everything,” said Mr. Hall, resolved to ascertain more about the"
"14715",5230,"personality of his guest at the earliest possible opportunity. And"
"14716",5230,"after the stranger had gone to bed, which he did about half-past nine,"
"14717",5230,"Mr. Hall went very aggressively into the parlour and looked very hard"
"14718",5230,"at his wife’s furniture, just to show that the stranger wasn’t master"
"14719",5230,"there, and scrutinised closely and a little contemptuously a sheet of"
"14720",5230,"mathematical computations the stranger had left. When retiring for the"
"14721",5230,"night he instructed Mrs. Hall to look very closely at the stranger’s"
"14722",5230,"luggage when it came next day."
"14723",5230,""
"14724",5230,"“You mind your own business, Hall,” said Mrs. Hall, “and I’ll mind"
"14725",5230,"mine.”"
"14726",5230,""
"14727",5230,"She was all the more inclined to snap at Hall because the stranger was"
"14728",5230,"undoubtedly an unusually strange sort of stranger, and she was by no"
"14729",5230,"means assured about him in her own mind. In the middle of the night she"
"14730",5230,"woke up dreaming of huge white heads like turnips, that came trailing"
"14731",5230,"after her, at the end of interminable necks, and with vast black eyes."
"14732",5230,"But being a sensible woman, she subdued her terrors and turned over and"
"14733",5230,"went to sleep again."

"14736",5230,""
"14737",5230,""
"14738",5230,"CHAPTER III."
"14739",5230,"THE THOUSAND AND ONE BOTTLES"
"14740",5230,""
"14741",5230,""
"14742",5230,"So it was that on the twenty-ninth day of February, at the beginning of"
"14743",5230,"the thaw, this singular person fell out of infinity into Iping village."
"14744",5230,"Next day his luggage arrived through the slush—and very remarkable"
"14745",5230,"luggage it was. There were a couple of trunks indeed, such as a"
"14746",5230,"rational man might need, but in addition there were a box of books—big,"
"14747",5230,"fat books, of which some were just in an incomprehensible"
"14748",5230,"handwriting—and a dozen or more crates, boxes, and cases, containing"
"14749",5230,"objects packed in straw, as it seemed to Hall, tugging with a casual"
"14750",5230,"curiosity at the straw—glass bottles. The stranger, muffled in hat,"
"14751",5230,"coat, gloves, and wrapper, came out impatiently to meet Fearenside’s"
"14752",5230,"cart, while Hall was having a word or so of gossip preparatory to"
"14753",5230,"helping bring them in. Out he came, not noticing Fearenside’s dog, who"
"14754",5230,"was sniffing in a _dilettante_ spirit at Hall’s legs. “Come along with"
"14755",5230,"those boxes,” he said. “I’ve been waiting long enough.”"
"14756",5230,""
"14757",5230,"And he came down the steps towards the tail of the cart as if to lay"
"14758",5230,"hands on the smaller crate."
"14759",5230,""
"14760",5230,"No sooner had Fearenside’s dog caught sight of him, however, than it"
"14761",5230,"began to bristle and growl savagely, and when he rushed down the steps"
"14762",5230,"it gave an undecided hop, and then sprang straight at his hand. “Whup!”"
"14763",5230,"cried Hall, jumping back, for he was no hero with dogs, and Fearenside"
"14764",5230,"howled, “Lie down!” and snatched his whip."
"14765",5230,""
"14766",5230,"They saw the dog’s teeth had slipped the hand, heard a kick, saw the"
"14767",5230,"dog execute a flanking jump and get home on the stranger’s leg, and"
"14768",5230,"heard the rip of his trousering. Then the finer end of Fearenside’s"
"14769",5230,"whip reached his property, and the dog, yelping with dismay, retreated"
"14770",5230,"under the wheels of the waggon. It was all the business of a swift"
"14771",5230,"half-minute. No one spoke, everyone shouted. The stranger glanced"
"14772",5230,"swiftly at his torn glove and at his leg, made as if he would stoop to"
"14773",5230,"the latter, then turned and rushed swiftly up the steps into the inn."
"14774",5230,"They heard him go headlong across the passage and up the uncarpeted"
"14775",5230,"stairs to his bedroom."
"14776",5230,""
"14777",5230,"“You brute, you!” said Fearenside, climbing off the waggon with his"
"14778",5230,"whip in his hand, while the dog watched him through the wheel. “Come"
"14779",5230,"here,” said Fearenside—“You’d better.”"
"14780",5230,""
"14781",5230,"Hall had stood gaping. “He wuz bit,” said Hall. “I’d better go and see"
"14782",5230,"to en,” and he trotted after the stranger. He met Mrs. Hall in the"
"14783",5230,"passage. “Carrier’s darg,” he said “bit en.”"
"14784",5230,""
"14785",5230,"He went straight upstairs, and the stranger’s door being ajar, he"
"14786",5230,"pushed it open and was entering without any ceremony, being of a"
"14787",5230,"naturally sympathetic turn of mind."
"14788",5230,""
"14789",5230,"The blind was down and the room dim. He caught a glimpse of a most"
"14790",5230,"singular thing, what seemed a handless arm waving towards him, and a"
"14791",5230,"face of three huge indeterminate spots on white, very like the face of"
"14792",5230,"a pale pansy. Then he was struck violently in the chest, hurled back,"
"14793",5230,"and the door slammed in his face and locked. It was so rapid that it"
"14794",5230,"gave him no time to observe. A waving of indecipherable shapes, a blow,"
"14795",5230,"and a concussion. There he stood on the dark little landing, wondering"
"14796",5230,"what it might be that he had seen."
"14797",5230,""
"14798",5230,"A couple of minutes after, he rejoined the little group that had formed"
"14799",5230,"outside the “Coach and Horses.” There was Fearenside telling about it"
"14800",5230,"all over again for the second time; there was Mrs. Hall saying his dog"
"14801",5230,"didn’t have no business to bite her guests; there was Huxter, the"
"14802",5230,"general dealer from over the road, interrogative; and Sandy Wadgers"
"14803",5230,"from the forge, judicial; besides women and children, all of them"
"14804",5230,"saying fatuities: “Wouldn’t let en bite _me_, I knows”; “’Tasn’t right"
"14805",5230,"_have_ such dargs”; “Whad ’_e_ bite ’n for, then?” and so forth."
"14806",5230,""
"14807",5230,"Mr. Hall, staring at them from the steps and listening, found it"
"14808",5230,"incredible that he had seen anything so very remarkable happen"
"14809",5230,"upstairs. Besides, his vocabulary was altogether too limited to express"
"14810",5230,"his impressions."
"14811",5230,""
"14812",5230,"“He don’t want no help, he says,” he said in answer to his wife’s"
"14813",5230,"inquiry. “We’d better be a-takin’ of his luggage in.”"
"14814",5230,""
"14815",5230,"“He ought to have it cauterised at once,” said Mr. Huxter; “especially"
"14816",5230,"if it’s at all inflamed.”"
"14817",5230,""
"14818",5230,"“I’d shoot en, that’s what I’d do,” said a lady in the group."
"14819",5230,""
"14820",5230,"Suddenly the dog began growling again."
"14821",5230,""
"14822",5230,"“Come along,” cried an angry voice in the doorway, and there stood the"
"14823",5230,"muffled stranger with his collar turned up, and his hat-brim bent down."
"14824",5230,"“The sooner you get those things in the better I’ll be pleased.” It is"
"14825",5230,"stated by an anonymous bystander that his trousers and gloves had been"
"14826",5230,"changed."
"14827",5230,""
"14828",5230,"“Was you hurt, sir?” said Fearenside. “I’m rare sorry the darg—”"
"14829",5230,""
"14830",5230,"“Not a bit,” said the stranger. “Never broke the skin. Hurry up with"
"14831",5230,"those things.”"
"14832",5230,""
"14833",5230,"He then swore to himself, so Mr. Hall asserts."
"14834",5230,""
"14835",5230,"Directly the first crate was, in accordance with his directions,"
"14836",5230,"carried into the parlour, the stranger flung himself upon it with"
"14837",5230,"extraordinary eagerness, and began to unpack it, scattering the straw"
"14838",5230,"with an utter disregard of Mrs. Hall’s carpet. And from it he began to"
"14839",5230,"produce bottles—little fat bottles containing powders, small and"
"14840",5230,"slender bottles containing coloured and white fluids, fluted blue"
"14841",5230,"bottles labeled Poison, bottles with round bodies and slender necks,"
"14842",5230,"large green-glass bottles, large white-glass bottles, bottles with"
"14843",5230,"glass stoppers and frosted labels, bottles with fine corks, bottles"
"14844",5230,"with bungs, bottles with wooden caps, wine bottles, salad-oil"
"14845",5230,"bottles—putting them in rows on the chiffonnier, on the mantel, on the"
"14846",5230,"table under the window, round the floor, on the bookshelf—everywhere."
"14847",5230,"The chemist’s shop in Bramblehurst could not boast half so many. Quite"
"14848",5230,"a sight it was. Crate after crate yielded bottles, until all six were"
"14849",5230,"empty and the table high with straw; the only things that came out of"
"14850",5230,"these crates besides the bottles were a number of test-tubes and a"
"14851",5230,"carefully packed balance."
"14852",5230,""
"14853",5230,"And directly the crates were unpacked, the stranger went to the window"
"14854",5230,"and set to work, not troubling in the least about the litter of straw,"
"14855",5230,"the fire which had gone out, the box of books outside, nor for the"
"14856",5230,"trunks and other luggage that had gone upstairs."
"14857",5230,""
"14858",5230,"When Mrs. Hall took his dinner in to him, he was already so absorbed in"
"14859",5230,"his work, pouring little drops out of the bottles into test-tubes, that"
"14860",5230,"he did not hear her until she had swept away the bulk of the straw and"
"14861",5230,"put the tray on the table, with some little emphasis perhaps, seeing"
"14862",5230,"the state that the floor was in. Then he half turned his head and"
"14863",5230,"immediately turned it away again. But she saw he had removed his"
"14864",5230,"glasses; they were beside him on the table, and it seemed to her that"
"14865",5230,"his eye sockets were extraordinarily hollow. He put on his spectacles"
"14866",5230,"again, and then turned and faced her. She was about to complain of the"
"14867",5230,"straw on the floor when he anticipated her."
"14868",5230,""
"14869",5230,"“I wish you wouldn’t come in without knocking,” he said in the tone of"
"14870",5230,"abnormal exasperation that seemed so characteristic of him."
"14871",5230,""
"14872",5230,"“I knocked, but seemingly—”"
"14873",5230,""
"14874",5230,"“Perhaps you did. But in my investigations—my really very urgent and"
"14875",5230,"necessary investigations—the slightest disturbance, the jar of a door—I"
"14876",5230,"must ask you—”"
"14877",5230,""
"14878",5230,"“Certainly, sir. You can turn the lock if you’re like that, you know."
"14879",5230,"Any time.”"
"14880",5230,""
"14881",5230,"“A very good idea,” said the stranger."
"14882",5230,""
"14883",5230,"“This stror, sir, if I might make so bold as to remark—”"
"14884",5230,""
"14885",5230,"“Don’t. If the straw makes trouble put it down in the bill.” And he"
"14886",5230,"mumbled at her—words suspiciously like curses."
"14887",5230,""
"14888",5230,"He was so odd, standing there, so aggressive and explosive, bottle in"
"14889",5230,"one hand and test-tube in the other, that Mrs. Hall was quite alarmed."
"14890",5230,"But she was a resolute woman. “In which case, I should like to know,"
"14891",5230,"sir, what you consider—”"
"14892",5230,""
"14893",5230,"“A shilling—put down a shilling. Surely a shilling’s enough?”"
"14894",5230,""
"14895",5230,"“So be it,” said Mrs. Hall, taking up the table-cloth and beginning to"
"14896",5230,"spread it over the table. “If you’re satisfied, of course—”"
"14897",5230,""
"14898",5230,"He turned and sat down, with his coat-collar toward her."
"14899",5230,""
"14900",5230,"All the afternoon he worked with the door locked and, as Mrs. Hall"
"14901",5230,"testifies, for the most part in silence. But once there was a"
"14902",5230,"concussion and a sound of bottles ringing together as though the table"
"14903",5230,"had been hit, and the smash of a bottle flung violently down, and then"
"14904",5230,"a rapid pacing athwart the room. Fearing “something was the matter,”"
"14905",5230,"she went to the door and listened, not caring to knock."
"14906",5230,""
"14907",5230,"“I can’t go on,” he was raving. “I _can’t_ go on. Three hundred"
"14908",5230,"thousand, four hundred thousand! The huge multitude! Cheated! All my"
"14909",5230,"life it may take me! ... Patience! Patience indeed! ... Fool! fool!”"
"14910",5230,""
"14911",5230,"There was a noise of hobnails on the bricks in the bar, and Mrs. Hall"
"14912",5230,"had very reluctantly to leave the rest of his soliloquy. When she"
"14913",5230,"returned the room was silent again, save for the faint crepitation of"
"14914",5230,"his chair and the occasional clink of a bottle. It was all over; the"
"14915",5230,"stranger had resumed work."
"14916",5230,""
"14917",5230,"When she took in his tea she saw broken glass in the corner of the room"
"14918",5230,"under the concave mirror, and a golden stain that had been carelessly"
"14919",5230,"wiped. She called attention to it."
"14920",5230,""
"14921",5230,"“Put it down in the bill,” snapped her visitor. “For God’s sake don’t"
"14922",5230,"worry me. If there’s damage done, put it down in the bill,” and he went"
"14923",5230,"on ticking a list in the exercise book before him."
"14924",5230,""
"14925",5230,"“I’ll tell you something,” said Fearenside, mysteriously. It was late"
"14926",5230,"in the afternoon, and they were in the little beer-shop of Iping"
"14927",5230,"Hanger."
"14928",5230,""
"14929",5230,"“Well?” said Teddy Henfrey."
"14930",5230,""
"14931",5230,"“This chap you’re speaking of, what my dog bit. Well—he’s black."
"14932",5230,"Leastways, his legs are. I seed through the tear of his trousers and"
"14933",5230,"the tear of his glove. You’d have expected a sort of pinky to show,"
"14934",5230,"wouldn’t you? Well—there wasn’t none. Just blackness. I tell you, he’s"
"14935",5230,"as black as my hat.”"
"14936",5230,""
"14937",5230,"“My sakes!” said Henfrey. “It’s a rummy case altogether. Why, his nose"
"14938",5230,"is as pink as paint!”"
"14939",5230,""
"14940",5230,"“That’s true,” said Fearenside. “I knows that. And I tell ’ee what I’m"
"14941",5230,"thinking. That marn’s a piebald, Teddy. Black here and white there—in"
"14942",5230,"patches. And he’s ashamed of it. He’s a kind of half-breed, and the"
"14943",5230,"colour’s come off patchy instead of mixing. I’ve heard of such things"
"14944",5230,"before. And it’s the common way with horses, as any one can see.”"
"14945",5230,""
"14946",5230,""
"14947",5230,""
"14948",5230,""
"14949",5230,"CHAPTER IV."
"14950",5230,"MR. CUSS INTERVIEWS THE STRANGER"
"14951",5230,""
"14952",5230,""
"14953",5230,"I have told the circumstances of the stranger’s arrival in Iping with a"
"14954",5230,"certain fulness of detail, in order that the curious impression he"
"14955",5230,"created may be understood by the reader. But excepting two odd"
"14956",5230,"incidents, the circumstances of his stay until the extraordinary day of"
"14957",5230,"the club festival may be passed over very cursorily. There were a"
"14958",5230,"number of skirmishes with Mrs. Hall on matters of domestic discipline,"
"14959",5230,"but in every case until late April, when the first signs of penury"
"14960",5230,"began, he over-rode her by the easy expedient of an extra payment. Hall"
"14961",5230,"did not like him, and whenever he dared he talked of the advisability"
"14962",5230,"of getting rid of him; but he showed his dislike chiefly by concealing"
"14963",5230,"it ostentatiously, and avoiding his visitor as much as possible. “Wait"
"14964",5230,"till the summer,” said Mrs. Hall sagely, “when the artisks are"
"14965",5230,"beginning to come. Then we’ll see. He may be a bit overbearing, but"
"14966",5230,"bills settled punctual is bills settled punctual, whatever you’d like"
"14967",5230,"to say.”"
"14968",5230,""
"14969",5230,"The stranger did not go to church, and indeed made no difference"
"14970",5230,"between Sunday and the irreligious days, even in costume. He worked, as"
"14971",5230,"Mrs. Hall thought, very fitfully. Some days he would come down early"
"14972",5230,"and be continuously busy. On others he would rise late, pace his room,"
"14973",5230,"fretting audibly for hours together, smoke, sleep in the armchair by"
"14974",5230,"the fire. Communication with the world beyond the village he had none."
"14975",5230,"His temper continued very uncertain; for the most part his manner was"
"14976",5230,"that of a man suffering under almost unendurable provocation, and once"
"14977",5230,"or twice things were snapped, torn, crushed, or broken in spasmodic"
"14978",5230,"gusts of violence. He seemed under a chronic irritation of the greatest"
"14979",5230,"intensity. His habit of talking to himself in a low voice grew steadily"
"14980",5230,"upon him, but though Mrs. Hall listened conscientiously she could make"
"14981",5230,"neither head nor tail of what she heard."
"14982",5230,""
"14983",5230,"He rarely went abroad by daylight, but at twilight he would go out"
"14984",5230,"muffled up invisibly, whether the weather were cold or not, and he"
"14985",5230,"chose the loneliest paths and those most overshadowed by trees and"
"14986",5230,"banks. His goggling spectacles and ghastly bandaged face under the"
"14987",5230,"penthouse of his hat, came with a disagreeable suddenness out of the"
"14988",5230,"darkness upon one or two home-going labourers, and Teddy Henfrey,"
"14989",5230,"tumbling out of the “Scarlet Coat” one night, at half-past nine, was"
"14990",5230,"scared shamefully by the stranger’s skull-like head (he was walking hat"
"14991",5230,"in hand) lit by the sudden light of the opened inn door. Such children"
"14992",5230,"as saw him at nightfall dreamt of bogies, and it seemed doubtful"
"14993",5230,"whether he disliked boys more than they disliked him, or the reverse;"
"14994",5230,"but there was certainly a vivid enough dislike on either side."
"14995",5230,""
"14996",5230,"It was inevitable that a person of so remarkable an appearance and"
"14997",5230,"bearing should form a frequent topic in such a village as Iping."
"14998",5230,"Opinion was greatly divided about his occupation. Mrs. Hall was"
"14999",5230,"sensitive on the point. When questioned, she explained very carefully"
"15000",5230,"that he was an “experimental investigator,” going gingerly over the"
"15001",5230,"syllables as one who dreads pitfalls. When asked what an experimental"
"15002",5230,"investigator was, she would say with a touch of superiority that most"
"15003",5230,"educated people knew such things as that, and would thus explain that"
"15004",5230,"he “discovered things.” Her visitor had had an accident, she said,"
"15005",5230,"which temporarily discoloured his face and hands, and being of a"
"15006",5230,"sensitive disposition, he was averse to any public notice of the fact."
"15007",5230,""
"15008",5230,"Out of her hearing there was a view largely entertained that he was a"
"15009",5230,"criminal trying to escape from justice by wrapping himself up so as to"
"15010",5230,"conceal himself altogether from the eye of the police. This idea sprang"
"15011",5230,"from the brain of Mr. Teddy Henfrey. No crime of any magnitude dating"
"15012",5230,"from the middle or end of February was known to have occurred."
"15013",5230,"Elaborated in the imagination of Mr. Gould, the probationary assistant"
"15014",5230,"in the National School, this theory took the form that the stranger was"
"15015",5230,"an Anarchist in disguise, preparing explosives, and he resolved to"
"15016",5230,"undertake such detective operations as his time permitted. These"
"15017",5230,"consisted for the most part in looking very hard at the stranger"
"15018",5230,"whenever they met, or in asking people who had never seen the stranger,"
"15019",5230,"leading questions about him. But he detected nothing."
"15020",5230,""
"15021",5230,"Another school of opinion followed Mr. Fearenside, and either accepted"
"15022",5230,"the piebald view or some modification of it; as, for instance, Silas"

"15024",5230,"fairs he’d make his fortune in no time,” and being a bit of a"

"15027",5230,"harmless lunatic. That had the advantage of accounting for everything"

"15029",5230,""
"15030",5230,"Between these main groups there were waverers and compromisers. Sussex"

"15034",5230,""
"15035",5230,"But whatever they thought of him, people in Iping, on the whole, agreed"

"15053",5230,""
