"15179",5230,"CHAPTER V."
"15180",5230,"THE BURGLARY AT THE VICARAGE"
"15181",5230,""
"15182",5230,""
"15183",5230,"The facts of the burglary at the vicarage came to us chiefly through"
"15184",5230,"the medium of the vicar and his wife. It occurred in the small hours of"
"15185",5230,"Whit Monday, the day devoted in Iping to the Club festivities. Mrs."
"15186",5230,"Bunting, it seems, woke up suddenly in the stillness that comes before"
"15187",5230,"the dawn, with the strong impression that the door of their bedroom had"
"15188",5230,"opened and closed. She did not arouse her husband at first, but sat up"
"15189",5230,"in bed listening. She then distinctly heard the pad, pad, pad of bare"
"15190",5230,"feet coming out of the adjoining dressing-room and walking along the"
"15191",5230,"passage towards the staircase. As soon as she felt assured of this, she"
"15192",5230,"aroused the Rev. Mr. Bunting as quietly as possible. He did not strike"
"15193",5230,"a light, but putting on his spectacles, her dressing-gown and his bath"
"15194",5230,"slippers, he went out on the landing to listen. He heard quite"
"15195",5230,"distinctly a fumbling going on at his study desk down-stairs, and then"
"15196",5230,"a violent sneeze."
"15197",5230,""

"15199",5230,"weapon, the poker, and descended the staircase as noiselessly as"
"15200",5230,"possible. Mrs. Bunting came out on the landing."
"15201",5230,""

"15209",5230,"now in the hall, and through the crack of the door he could see the"
"15210",5230,"desk and the open drawer and a candle burning on the desk. But the"
"15211",5230,"robber he could not see. He stood there in the hall undecided what to"
"15212",5230,"do, and Mrs. Bunting, her face white and intent, crept slowly"
"15213",5230,"downstairs after him. One thing kept Mr. Bunting’s courage; the"
"15214",5230,"persuasion that this burglar was a resident in the village."
"15215",5230,""

"15217",5230,"the housekeeping reserve of gold—two pounds ten in half sovereigns"

"15222",5230,""

"15232",5230,""

"15268",5230,"CHAPTER VI."
"15269",5230,"THE FURNITURE THAT WENT MAD"
"15270",5230,""
"15271",5230,""
"15272",5230,"Now it happened that in the early hours of Whit Monday, before Millie"
"15273",5230,"was hunted out for the day, Mr. Hall and Mrs. Hall both rose and went"
"15274",5230,"noiselessly down into the cellar. Their business there was of a private"
"15275",5230,"nature, and had something to do with the specific gravity of their"
"15276",5230,"beer. They had hardly entered the cellar when Mrs. Hall found she had"
"15277",5230,"forgotten to bring down a bottle of sarsaparilla from their joint-room."
"15278",5230,"As she was the expert and principal operator in this affair, Hall very"
"15279",5230,"properly went upstairs for it."
"15280",5230,""
"15281",5230,"On the landing he was surprised to see that the stranger’s door was"
"15282",5230,"ajar. He went on into his own room and found the bottle as he had been"
"15283",5230,"directed."
"15284",5230,""
"15285",5230,"But returning with the bottle, he noticed that the bolts of the front"
"15286",5230,"door had been shot back, that the door was in fact simply on the latch."
"15287",5230,"And with a flash of inspiration he connected this with the stranger’s"
"15288",5230,"room upstairs and the suggestions of Mr. Teddy Henfrey. He distinctly"
"15289",5230,"remembered holding the candle while Mrs. Hall shot these bolts"
"15290",5230,"overnight. At the sight he stopped, gaping, then with the bottle still"
"15291",5230,"in his hand went upstairs again. He rapped at the stranger’s door."
"15292",5230,"There was no answer. He rapped again; then pushed the door wide open"
"15293",5230,"and entered."
"15294",5230,""
"15295",5230,"It was as he expected. The bed, the room also, was empty. And what was"
"15296",5230,"stranger, even to his heavy intelligence, on the bedroom chair and"
"15297",5230,"along the rail of the bed were scattered the garments, the only"
"15298",5230,"garments so far as he knew, and the bandages of their guest. His big"
"15299",5230,"slouch hat even was cocked jauntily over the bed-post."
"15300",5230,""
"15301",5230,"As Hall stood there he heard his wife’s voice coming out of the depth"
"15302",5230,"of the cellar, with that rapid telescoping of the syllables and"
"15303",5230,"interrogative cocking up of the final words to a high note, by which"
"15304",5230,"the West Sussex villager is wont to indicate a brisk impatience."
"15305",5230,"“George! You gart whad a wand?”"
"15306",5230,""
"15307",5230,"At that he turned and hurried down to her. “Janny,” he said, over the"
"15308",5230,"rail of the cellar steps, “’tas the truth what Henfrey sez. ’E’s not in"
"15309",5230,"uz room, ’e en’t. And the front door’s onbolted.”"
"15310",5230,""
"15311",5230,"At first Mrs. Hall did not understand, and as soon as she did she"
"15312",5230,"resolved to see the empty room for herself. Hall, still holding the"
"15313",5230,"bottle, went first. “If ’e en’t there,” he said, “’is close are. And"
"15314",5230,"what’s ’e doin’ ’ithout ’is close, then? ’Tas a most curious business.”"
"15315",5230,""
"15316",5230,"As they came up the cellar steps they both, it was afterwards"
"15317",5230,"ascertained, fancied they heard the front door open and shut, but"
"15318",5230,"seeing it closed and nothing there, neither said a word to the other"
"15319",5230,"about it at the time. Mrs. Hall passed her husband in the passage and"
"15320",5230,"ran on first upstairs. Someone sneezed on the staircase. Hall,"
"15321",5230,"following six steps behind, thought that he heard her sneeze. She,"
"15322",5230,"going on first, was under the impression that Hall was sneezing. She"
"15323",5230,"flung open the door and stood regarding the room. “Of all the curious!”"
"15324",5230,"she said."
"15325",5230,""
"15326",5230,"She heard a sniff close behind her head as it seemed, and turning, was"
"15327",5230,"surprised to see Hall a dozen feet off on the topmost stair. But in"
"15328",5230,"another moment he was beside her. She bent forward and put her hand on"
"15329",5230,"the pillow and then under the clothes."
"15330",5230,""
"15331",5230,"“Cold,” she said. “He’s been up this hour or more.”"
"15332",5230,""

"15334",5230,"gathered themselves together, leapt up suddenly into a sort of peak,"
"15335",5230,"and then jumped headlong over the bottom rail. It was exactly as if a"
"15336",5230,"hand had clutched them in the centre and flung them aside. Immediately"
"15337",5230,"after, the stranger’s hat hopped off the bed-post, described a whirling"
"15338",5230,"flight in the air through the better part of a circle, and then dashed"
"15339",5230,"straight at Mrs. Hall’s face. Then as swiftly came the sponge from the"
"15340",5230,"washstand; and then the chair, flinging the stranger’s coat and"
"15341",5230,"trousers carelessly aside, and laughing drily in a voice singularly"
"15342",5230,"like the stranger’s, turned itself up with its four legs at Mrs. Hall,"
"15343",5230,"seemed to take aim at her for a moment, and charged at her. She"
"15344",5230,"screamed and turned, and then the chair legs came gently but firmly"
"15345",5230,"against her back and impelled her and Hall out of the room. The door"
"15346",5230,"slammed violently and was locked. The chair and bed seemed to be"
"15347",5230,"executing a dance of triumph for a moment, and then abruptly everything"
"15348",5230,"was still."
"15349",5230,""
"15350",5230,"Mrs. Hall was left almost in a fainting condition in Mr. Hall’s arms on"
"15351",5230,"the landing. It was with the greatest difficulty that Mr. Hall and"
"15352",5230,"Millie, who had been roused by her scream of alarm, succeeded in"
"15353",5230,"getting her downstairs, and applying the restoratives customary in such"
"15354",5230,"cases."
"15355",5230,""
"15356",5230,"“’Tas sperits,” said Mrs. Hall. “I know ’tas sperits. I’ve read in"
"15357",5230,"papers of en. Tables and chairs leaping and dancing...”"
"15358",5230,""
"15359",5230,"“Take a drop more, Janny,” said Hall. “’Twill steady ye.”"
"15360",5230,""
"15361",5230,"“Lock him out,” said Mrs. Hall. “Don’t let him come in again. I half"
"15362",5230,"guessed—I might ha’ known. With them goggling eyes and bandaged head,"
"15363",5230,"and never going to church of a Sunday. And all they bottles—more’n it’s"
"15364",5230,"right for any one to have. He’s put the sperits into the furniture...."
"15365",5230,"My good old furniture! ’Twas in that very chair my poor dear mother"
"15366",5230,"used to sit when I was a little girl. To think it should rise up"
"15367",5230,"against me now!”"
"15368",5230,""
"15369",5230,"“Just a drop more, Janny,” said Hall. “Your nerves is all upset.”"
"15370",5230,""
"15371",5230,"They sent Millie across the street through the golden five o’clock"
"15372",5230,"sunshine to rouse up Mr. Sandy Wadgers, the blacksmith. Mr. Hall’s"
"15373",5230,"compliments and the furniture upstairs was behaving most extraordinary."
"15374",5230,"Would Mr. Wadgers come round? He was a knowing man, was Mr. Wadgers,"
"15375",5230,"and very resourceful. He took quite a grave view of the case. “Arm"
"15376",5230,"darmed if thet ent witchcraft,” was the view of Mr. Sandy Wadgers. “You"
"15377",5230,"warnt horseshoes for such gentry as he.”"
"15378",5230,""
"15379",5230,"He came round greatly concerned. They wanted him to lead the way"
"15380",5230,"upstairs to the room, but he didn’t seem to be in any hurry. He"
"15381",5230,"preferred to talk in the passage. Over the way Huxter’s apprentice came"
"15382",5230,"out and began taking down the shutters of the tobacco window. He was"
"15383",5230,"called over to join the discussion. Mr. Huxter naturally followed over"
"15384",5230,"in the course of a few minutes. The Anglo-Saxon genius for"
"15385",5230,"parliamentary government asserted itself; there was a great deal of"
"15386",5230,"talk and no decisive action. “Let’s have the facts first,” insisted Mr."
"15387",5230,"Sandy Wadgers. “Let’s be sure we’d be acting perfectly right in bustin’"
"15388",5230,"that there door open. A door onbust is always open to bustin’, but ye"
"15389",5230,"can’t onbust a door once you’ve busted en.”"
"15390",5230,""
"15391",5230,"And suddenly and most wonderfully the door of the room upstairs opened"
"15392",5230,"of its own accord, and as they looked up in amazement, they saw"
"15393",5230,"descending the stairs the muffled figure of the stranger staring more"
"15394",5230,"blackly and blankly than ever with those unreasonably large blue glass"
"15395",5230,"eyes of his. He came down stiffly and slowly, staring all the time; he"
"15396",5230,"walked across the passage staring, then stopped."
"15397",5230,""
"15398",5230,"“Look there!” he said, and their eyes followed the direction of his"
"15399",5230,"gloved finger and saw a bottle of sarsaparilla hard by the cellar door."
"15400",5230,"Then he entered the parlour, and suddenly, swiftly, viciously, slammed"
"15401",5230,"the door in their faces."
"15402",5230,""
"15403",5230,"Not a word was spoken until the last echoes of the slam had died away."
"15404",5230,"They stared at one another. “Well, if that don’t lick everything!” said"
"15405",5230,"Mr. Wadgers, and left the alternative unsaid."
"15406",5230,""
"15407",5230,"“I’d go in and ask’n ’bout it,” said Wadgers, to Mr. Hall. “I’d d’mand"
"15408",5230,"an explanation.”"
"15409",5230,""
"15410",5230,"It took some time to bring the landlady’s husband up to that pitch. At"
"15411",5230,"last he rapped, opened the door, and got as far as, “Excuse me—”"
"15412",5230,""
"15413",5230,"“Go to the devil!” said the stranger in a tremendous voice, and “Shut"
"15414",5230,"that door after you.” So that brief interview terminated."
"15415",5230,""
"15416",5230,""
"15417",5230,""
"15418",5230,""
"15419",5230,"CHAPTER VII."
"15420",5230,"THE UNVEILING OF THE STRANGER"
"15421",5230,""
"15422",5230,""
"15423",5230,"The stranger went into the little parlour of the “Coach and Horses”"
"15424",5230,"about half-past five in the morning, and there he remained until near"
"15425",5230,"midday, the blinds down, the door shut, and none, after Hall’s repulse,"
"15426",5230,"venturing near him."
"15427",5230,""
"15428",5230,"All that time he must have fasted. Thrice he rang his bell, the third"
"15429",5230,"time furiously and continuously, but no one answered him. “Him and his"
"15430",5230,"‘go to the devil’ indeed!” said Mrs. Hall. Presently came an imperfect"
"15431",5230,"rumour of the burglary at the vicarage, and two and two were put"
"15432",5230,"together. Hall, assisted by Wadgers, went off to find Mr. Shuckleforth,"
"15433",5230,"the magistrate, and take his advice. No one ventured upstairs. How the"
"15434",5230,"stranger occupied himself is unknown. Now and then he would stride"
"15435",5230,"violently up and down, and twice came an outburst of curses, a tearing"
"15436",5230,"of paper, and a violent smashing of bottles."
"15437",5230,""
"15438",5230,"The little group of scared but curious people increased. Mrs. Huxter"
"15439",5230,"came over; some gay young fellows resplendent in black ready-made"
"15440",5230,"jackets and _piqué_ paper ties—for it was Whit Monday—joined the group"
"15441",5230,"with confused interrogations. Young Archie Harker distinguished himself"
"15442",5230,"by going up the yard and trying to peep under the window-blinds. He"
"15443",5230,"could see nothing, but gave reason for supposing that he did, and"
"15444",5230,"others of the Iping youth presently joined him."
"15445",5230,""
"15446",5230,"It was the finest of all possible Whit Mondays, and down the village"
"15447",5230,"street stood a row of nearly a dozen booths, a shooting gallery, and on"
"15448",5230,"the grass by the forge were three yellow and chocolate waggons and some"
"15449",5230,"picturesque strangers of both sexes putting up a cocoanut shy. The"
"15450",5230,"gentlemen wore blue jerseys, the ladies white aprons and quite"
"15451",5230,"fashionable hats with heavy plumes. Wodger, of the “Purple Fawn,” and"
"15452",5230,"Mr. Jaggers, the cobbler, who also sold old second-hand ordinary"
"15453",5230,"bicycles, were stretching a string of union-jacks and royal ensigns"
"15454",5230,"(which had originally celebrated the first Victorian Jubilee) across"
"15455",5230,"the road."
"15456",5230,""
"15457",5230,"And inside, in the artificial darkness of the parlour, into which only"
"15458",5230,"one thin jet of sunlight penetrated, the stranger, hungry we must"
"15459",5230,"suppose, and fearful, hidden in his uncomfortable hot wrappings, pored"
"15460",5230,"through his dark glasses upon his paper or chinked his dirty little"
"15461",5230,"bottles, and occasionally swore savagely at the boys, audible if"
"15462",5230,"invisible, outside the windows. In the corner by the fireplace lay the"
"15463",5230,"fragments of half a dozen smashed bottles, and a pungent twang of"
"15464",5230,"chlorine tainted the air. So much we know from what was heard at the"
"15465",5230,"time and from what was subsequently seen in the room."
"15466",5230,""
"15467",5230,"About noon he suddenly opened his parlour door and stood glaring"
"15468",5230,"fixedly at the three or four people in the bar. “Mrs. Hall,” he said."
"15469",5230,"Somebody went sheepishly and called for Mrs. Hall."
"15470",5230,""
"15471",5230,"Mrs. Hall appeared after an interval, a little short of breath, but all"
"15472",5230,"the fiercer for that. Hall was still out. She had deliberated over this"
"15473",5230,"scene, and she came holding a little tray with an unsettled bill upon"
"15474",5230,"it. “Is it your bill you’re wanting, sir?” she said."
"15475",5230,""
"15476",5230,"“Why wasn’t my breakfast laid? Why haven’t you prepared my meals and"
"15477",5230,"answered my bell? Do you think I live without eating?”"
"15478",5230,""
"15479",5230,"“Why isn’t my bill paid?” said Mrs. Hall. “That’s what I want to know.”"
"15480",5230,""
"15481",5230,"“I told you three days ago I was awaiting a remittance—”"
"15482",5230,""
"15483",5230,"“I told you two days ago I wasn’t going to await no remittances. You"
"15484",5230,"can’t grumble if your breakfast waits a bit, if my bill’s been waiting"
"15485",5230,"these five days, can you?”"
"15486",5230,""
"15487",5230,"The stranger swore briefly but vividly."
"15488",5230,""
"15489",5230,"“Nar, nar!” from the bar."
"15490",5230,""
"15491",5230,"“And I’d thank you kindly, sir, if you’d keep your swearing to"
"15492",5230,"yourself, sir,” said Mrs. Hall."
"15493",5230,""
"15494",5230,"The stranger stood looking more like an angry diving-helmet than ever."
"15495",5230,"It was universally felt in the bar that Mrs. Hall had the better of"
"15496",5230,"him. His next words showed as much."
"15497",5230,""
"15498",5230,"“Look here, my good woman—” he began."
"15499",5230,""
"15500",5230,"“Don’t ‘good woman’ _me_,” said Mrs. Hall."
"15501",5230,""
"15502",5230,"“I’ve told you my remittance hasn’t come.”"
"15503",5230,""
"15504",5230,"“Remittance indeed!” said Mrs. Hall."
"15505",5230,""
"15506",5230,"“Still, I daresay in my pocket—”"
"15507",5230,""
"15508",5230,"“You told me three days ago that you hadn’t anything but a sovereign’s"
"15509",5230,"worth of silver upon you.”"
"15510",5230,""
"15511",5230,"“Well, I’ve found some more—”"
"15512",5230,""
"15513",5230,"“’Ul-lo!” from the bar."
"15514",5230,""
"15515",5230,"“I wonder where you found it,” said Mrs. Hall."
"15516",5230,""
"15517",5230,"That seemed to annoy the stranger very much. He stamped his foot. “What"
"15518",5230,"do you mean?” he said."
"15519",5230,""
"15520",5230,"“That I wonder where you found it,” said Mrs. Hall. “And before I take"
"15521",5230,"any bills or get any breakfasts, or do any such things whatsoever, you"
"15522",5230,"got to tell me one or two things I don’t understand, and what nobody"
"15523",5230,"don’t understand, and what everybody is very anxious to understand. I"
"15524",5230,"want to know what you been doing t’my chair upstairs, and I want to"
"15525",5230,"know how ’tis your room was empty, and how you got in again. Them as"
"15526",5230,"stops in this house comes in by the doors—that’s the rule of the house,"
"15527",5230,"and that you _didn’t_ do, and what I want to know is how you _did_ come"
"15528",5230,"in. And I want to know—”"
"15529",5230,""
"15530",5230,"Suddenly the stranger raised his gloved hands clenched, stamped his"
"15531",5230,"foot, and said, “Stop!” with such extraordinary violence that he"
"15532",5230,"silenced her instantly."
"15533",5230,""
"15534",5230,"“You don’t understand,” he said, “who I am or what I am. I’ll show you."
"15535",5230,"By Heaven! I’ll show you.” Then he put his open palm over his face and"
"15536",5230,"withdrew it. The centre of his face became a black cavity. “Here,” he"
"15537",5230,"said. He stepped forward and handed Mrs. Hall something which she,"
"15538",5230,"staring at his metamorphosed face, accepted automatically. Then, when"
"15539",5230,"she saw what it was, she screamed loudly, dropped it, and staggered"
"15540",5230,"back. The nose—it was the stranger’s nose! pink and shining—rolled on"
"15541",5230,"the floor."
"15542",5230,""
"15543",5230,"Then he removed his spectacles, and everyone in the bar gasped. He took"
"15544",5230,"off his hat, and with a violent gesture tore at his whiskers and"
"15545",5230,"bandages. For a moment they resisted him. A flash of horrible"
"15546",5230,"anticipation passed through the bar. “Oh, my Gard!” said some one. Then"
"15547",5230,"off they came."
"15548",5230,""
"15549",5230,"It was worse than anything. Mrs. Hall, standing open-mouthed and"
"15550",5230,"horror-struck, shrieked at what she saw, and made for the door of the"
"15551",5230,"house. Everyone began to move. They were prepared for scars,"
"15552",5230,"disfigurements, tangible horrors, but nothing! The bandages and false"
"15553",5230,"hair flew across the passage into the bar, making a hobbledehoy jump to"
"15554",5230,"avoid them. Everyone tumbled on everyone else down the steps. For the"
"15555",5230,"man who stood there shouting some incoherent explanation, was a solid"
"15556",5230,"gesticulating figure up to the coat-collar of him, and"
"15557",5230,"then—nothingness, no visible thing at all!"
"15558",5230,""
"15559",5230,"People down the village heard shouts and shrieks, and looking up the"
"15560",5230,"street saw the “Coach and Horses” violently firing out its humanity."
"15561",5230,"They saw Mrs. Hall fall down and Mr. Teddy Henfrey jump to avoid"
"15562",5230,"tumbling over her, and then they heard the frightful screams of Millie,"
"15563",5230,"who, emerging suddenly from the kitchen at the noise of the tumult, had"
"15564",5230,"come upon the headless stranger from behind. These increased suddenly."
"15565",5230,""
"15566",5230,"Forthwith everyone all down the street, the sweetstuff seller, cocoanut"

"15569",5230,"running towards the inn, and in a miraculously short space of time a"

"15573",5230,"result was Babel. A small group supported Mrs. Hall, who was picked up"

"15575",5230,"evidence of a vociferous eye-witness. “O Bogey!” “What’s he been doin’,"
"15576",5230,"then?” “Ain’t hurt the girl, ’as ’e?” “Run at en with a knife, I"
"15577",5230,"believe.” “No ’ed, I tell ye. I don’t mean no manner of speaking. I"
"15578",5230,"mean _marn ’ithout a ’ed_!” “Narnsense! ’tis some conjuring trick.”"
"15579",5230,"“Fetched off ’is wrapping, ’e did—”"
"15580",5230,""
"15581",5230,"In its struggles to see in through the open door, the crowd formed"
"15582",5230,"itself into a straggling wedge, with the more adventurous apex nearest"
"15583",5230,"the inn. “He stood for a moment, I heerd the gal scream, and he turned."
"15584",5230,"I saw her skirts whisk, and he went after her. Didn’t take ten seconds."
"15585",5230,"Back he comes with a knife in uz hand and a loaf; stood just as if he"
"15586",5230,"was staring. Not a moment ago. Went in that there door. I tell ’e, ’e"
"15587",5230,"ain’t gart no ’ed at all. You just missed en—”"
"15588",5230,""
"15589",5230,"There was a disturbance behind, and the speaker stopped to step aside"
"15590",5230,"for a little procession that was marching very resolutely towards the"
"15591",5230,"house; first Mr. Hall, very red and determined, then Mr. Bobby Jaffers,"
"15592",5230,"the village constable, and then the wary Mr. Wadgers. They had come now"
"15593",5230,"armed with a warrant."
"15594",5230,""
"15595",5230,"People shouted conflicting information of the recent circumstances."
"15596",5230,"“’Ed or no ’ed,” said Jaffers, “I got to ’rest en, and ’rest en I"
"15597",5230,"_will_.”"
"15598",5230,""
"15599",5230,"Mr. Hall marched up the steps, marched straight to the door of the"
"15600",5230,"parlour and flung it open. “Constable,” he said, “do your duty.”"
"15601",5230,""
"15602",5230,"Jaffers marched in. Hall next, Wadgers last. They saw in the dim light"

"15604",5230,"gloved hand and a chunk of cheese in the other."
"15605",5230,""

"15607",5230,""

"15610",5230,""

"15711",5230,""
"15712",5230,"The shirt-sleeve planted a shrewd blow in Hall’s face that stopped his"
"15713",5230,"open-armed advance, and sent him backward into old Toothsome the"
"15714",5230,"sexton, and in another moment the garment was lifted up and became"
"15715",5230,"convulsed and vacantly flapping about the arms, even as a shirt that is"
"15716",5230,"being thrust over a man’s head. Jaffers clutched at it, and only helped"
"15717",5230,"to pull it off; he was struck in the mouth out of the air, and"
"15718",5230,"incontinently threw his truncheon and smote Teddy Henfrey savagely upon"
"15719",5230,"the crown of his head."
"15720",5230,""
"15721",5230,"“Look out!” said everybody, fencing at random and hitting at nothing."
"15722",5230,"“Hold him! Shut the door! Don’t let him loose! I got something! Here he"
"15723",5230,"is!” A perfect Babel of noises they made. Everybody, it seemed, was"
"15724",5230,"being hit all at once, and Sandy Wadgers, knowing as ever and his wits"
"15725",5230,"sharpened by a frightful blow in the nose, reopened the door and led"
"15726",5230,"the rout. The others, following incontinently, were jammed for a moment"
"15727",5230,"in the corner by the doorway. The hitting continued. Phipps, the"
"15728",5230,"Unitarian, had a front tooth broken, and Henfrey was injured in the"
"15729",5230,"cartilage of his ear. Jaffers was struck under the jaw, and, turning,"
"15730",5230,"caught at something that intervened between him and Huxter in the"
"15731",5230,"mêlée, and prevented their coming together. He felt a muscular chest,"
"15732",5230,"and in another moment the whole mass of struggling, excited men shot"
"15733",5230,"out into the crowded hall."
"15734",5230,""
"15735",5230,"“I got him!” shouted Jaffers, choking and reeling through them all, and"
"15736",5230,"wrestling with purple face and swelling veins against his unseen enemy."
"15737",5230,""
"15738",5230,"Men staggered right and left as the extraordinary conflict swayed"
"15739",5230,"swiftly towards the house door, and went spinning down the half-dozen"
"15740",5230,"steps of the inn. Jaffers cried in a strangled voice—holding tight,"
"15741",5230,"nevertheless, and making play with his knee—spun around, and fell"
"15742",5230,"heavily undermost with his head on the gravel. Only then did his"
"15743",5230,"fingers relax."
"15744",5230,""
"15745",5230,"There were excited cries of “Hold him!” “Invisible!” and so forth, and"
"15746",5230,"a young fellow, a stranger in the place whose name did not come to"
"15747",5230,"light, rushed in at once, caught something, missed his hold, and fell"
"15748",5230,"over the constable’s prostrate body. Half-way across the road a woman"
"15749",5230,"screamed as something pushed by her; a dog, kicked apparently, yelped"
"15750",5230,"and ran howling into Huxter’s yard, and with that the transit of the"
"15751",5230,"Invisible Man was accomplished. For a space people stood amazed and"
"15752",5230,"gesticulating, and then came panic, and scattered them abroad through"
"15753",5230,"the village as a gust scatters dead leaves."
"15754",5230,""
"15755",5230,"But Jaffers lay quite still, face upward and knees bent, at the foot of"
"15756",5230,"the steps of the inn."
"15757",5230,""

"15761",5230,"CHAPTER VIII."
"15762",5230,"IN TRANSIT"
"15763",5230,""
"15764",5230,""
"15765",5230,"The eighth chapter is exceedingly brief, and relates that Gibbons, the"
"15766",5230,"amateur naturalist of the district, while lying out on the spacious"
"15767",5230,"open downs without a soul within a couple of miles of him, as he"
"15768",5230,"thought, and almost dozing, heard close to him the sound as of a man"
"15769",5230,"coughing, sneezing, and then swearing savagely to himself; and looking,"
"15770",5230,"beheld nothing. Yet the voice was indisputable. It continued to swear"
"15771",5230,"with that breadth and variety that distinguishes the swearing of a"
"15772",5230,"cultivated man. It grew to a climax, diminished again, and died away in"
"15773",5230,"the distance, going as it seemed to him in the direction of Adderdean."
"15774",5230,"It lifted to a spasmodic sneeze and ended. Gibbons had heard nothing of"
"15775",5230,"the morning’s occurrences, but the phenomenon was so striking and"
"15776",5230,"disturbing that his philosophical tranquillity vanished; he got up"
"15777",5230,"hastily, and hurried down the steepness of the hill towards the"
"15778",5230,"village, as fast as he could go."
"15779",5230,""
"15780",5230,""
"15781",5230,""
"15782",5230,""
"15783",5230,"CHAPTER IX."
"15784",5230,"MR. THOMAS MARVEL"
"15785",5230,""
"15786",5230,""
"15787",5230,"You must picture Mr. Thomas Marvel as a person of copious, flexible"
"15788",5230,"visage, a nose of cylindrical protrusion, a liquorish, ample,"
"15789",5230,"fluctuating mouth, and a beard of bristling eccentricity. His figure"
"15790",5230,"inclined to embonpoint; his short limbs accentuated this inclination."
"15791",5230,"He wore a furry silk hat, and the frequent substitution of twine and"
"15792",5230,"shoe-laces for buttons, apparent at critical points of his costume,"
"15793",5230,"marked a man essentially bachelor."
"15794",5230,""
"15795",5230,"Mr. Thomas Marvel was sitting with his feet in a ditch by the roadside"
"15796",5230,"over the down towards Adderdean, about a mile and a half out of Iping."
"15797",5230,"His feet, save for socks of irregular open-work, were bare, his big"
"15798",5230,"toes were broad, and pricked like the ears of a watchful dog. In a"
"15799",5230,"leisurely manner—he did everything in a leisurely manner—he was"
"15800",5230,"contemplating trying on a pair of boots. They were the soundest boots"
"15801",5230,"he had come across for a long time, but too large for him; whereas the"
"15802",5230,"ones he had were, in dry weather, a very comfortable fit, but too"
"15803",5230,"thin-soled for damp. Mr. Thomas Marvel hated roomy shoes, but then he"
"15804",5230,"hated damp. He had never properly thought out which he hated most, and"
"15805",5230,"it was a pleasant day, and there was nothing better to do. So he put"
"15806",5230,"the four shoes in a graceful group on the turf and looked at them. And"
"15807",5230,"seeing them there among the grass and springing agrimony, it suddenly"
"15808",5230,"occurred to him that both pairs were exceedingly ugly to see. He was"
"15809",5230,"not at all startled by a voice behind him."
"15810",5230,""
"15811",5230,"“They’re boots, anyhow,” said the Voice."
"15812",5230,""
"15813",5230,"“They are—charity boots,” said Mr. Thomas Marvel, with his head on one"
"15814",5230,"side regarding them distastefully; “and which is the ugliest pair in"
"15815",5230,"the whole blessed universe, I’m darned if I know!”"
"15816",5230,""
"15817",5230,"“H’m,” said the Voice."
"15818",5230,""
"15819",5230,"“I’ve worn worse—in fact, I’ve worn none. But none so owdacious ugly—if"
"15820",5230,"you’ll allow the expression. I’ve been cadging boots—in particular—for"
"15821",5230,"days. Because I was sick of _them_. They’re sound enough, of course."
"15822",5230,"But a gentleman on tramp sees such a thundering lot of his boots. And"
"15823",5230,"if you’ll believe me, I’ve raised nothing in the whole blessed country,"
"15824",5230,"try as I would, but _them_. Look at ’em! And a good country for boots,"
"15825",5230,"too, in a general way. But it’s just my promiscuous luck. I’ve got my"
"15826",5230,"boots in this country ten years or more. And then they treat you like"
"15827",5230,"this.”"
"15828",5230,""
"15829",5230,"“It’s a beast of a country,” said the Voice. “And pigs for people.”"
"15830",5230,""
"15831",5230,"“Ain’t it?” said Mr. Thomas Marvel. “Lord! But them boots! It beats"
"15832",5230,"it.”"
"15833",5230,""
"15834",5230,"He turned his head over his shoulder to the right, to look at the boots"
"15835",5230,"of his interlocutor with a view to comparisons, and lo! where the boots"
"15836",5230,"of his interlocutor should have been were neither legs nor boots. He"
"15837",5230,"was irradiated by the dawn of a great amazement. “Where _are_ yer?”"
"15838",5230,"said Mr. Thomas Marvel over his shoulder and coming on all fours. He"
"15839",5230,"saw a stretch of empty downs with the wind swaying the remote"
"15840",5230,"green-pointed furze bushes."
"15841",5230,""
"15842",5230,"“Am I drunk?” said Mr. Marvel. “Have I had visions? Was I talking to"
"15843",5230,"myself? What the—”"
"15844",5230,""
"15845",5230,"“Don’t be alarmed,” said a Voice."
"15846",5230,""
"15847",5230,"“None of your ventriloquising _me_,” said Mr. Thomas Marvel, rising"
"15848",5230,"sharply to his feet. “Where _are_ yer? Alarmed, indeed!”"
"15849",5230,""
"15850",5230,"“Don’t be alarmed,” repeated the Voice."
"15851",5230,""
"15852",5230,"“_You’ll_ be alarmed in a minute, you silly fool,” said Mr. Thomas"
"15853",5230,"Marvel. “Where _are_ yer? Lemme get my mark on yer..."
"15854",5230,""
"15855",5230,"“Are yer _buried_?” said Mr. Thomas Marvel, after an interval."
"15856",5230,""
"15857",5230,"There was no answer. Mr. Thomas Marvel stood bootless and amazed, his"
"15858",5230,"jacket nearly thrown off."
"15859",5230,""
"15860",5230,"“Peewit,” said a peewit, very remote."
"15861",5230,""
"15862",5230,"“Peewit, indeed!” said Mr. Thomas Marvel. “This ain’t no time for"
"15863",5230,"foolery.” The down was desolate, east and west, north and south; the"
"15864",5230,"road with its shallow ditches and white bordering stakes, ran smooth"
"15865",5230,"and empty north and south, and, save for that peewit, the blue sky was"
"15866",5230,"empty too. “So help me,” said Mr. Thomas Marvel, shuffling his coat on"
"15867",5230,"to his shoulders again. “It’s the drink! I might ha’ known.”"
"15868",5230,""
"15869",5230,"“It’s not the drink,” said the Voice. “You keep your nerves steady.”"
"15870",5230,""
"15871",5230,"“Ow!” said Mr. Marvel, and his face grew white amidst its patches."
"15872",5230,"“It’s the drink!” his lips repeated noiselessly. He remained staring"
"15873",5230,"about him, rotating slowly backwards. “I could have _swore_ I heard a"
"15874",5230,"voice,” he whispered."
"15875",5230,""
"15876",5230,"“Of course you did.”"
"15877",5230,""
"15878",5230,"“It’s there again,” said Mr. Marvel, closing his eyes and clasping his"
"15879",5230,"hand on his brow with a tragic gesture. He was suddenly taken by the"
"15880",5230,"collar and shaken violently, and left more dazed than ever. “Don’t be a"
"15881",5230,"fool,” said the Voice."
"15882",5230,""
"15883",5230,"“I’m—off—my—blooming—chump,” said Mr. Marvel. “It’s no good. It’s"
"15884",5230,"fretting about them blarsted boots. I’m off my blessed blooming chump."
"15885",5230,"Or it’s spirits.”"
"15886",5230,""
"15887",5230,"“Neither one thing nor the other,” said the Voice. “Listen!”"
"15888",5230,""
"15889",5230,"“Chump,” said Mr. Marvel."
"15890",5230,""
"15891",5230,"“One minute,” said the Voice, penetratingly, tremulous with"
"15892",5230,"self-control."
"15893",5230,""
"15894",5230,"“Well?” said Mr. Thomas Marvel, with a strange feeling of having been"
"15895",5230,"dug in the chest by a finger."
"15896",5230,""
"15897",5230,"“You think I’m just imagination? Just imagination?”"
"15898",5230,""
"15899",5230,"“What else _can_ you be?” said Mr. Thomas Marvel, rubbing the back of"
"15900",5230,"his neck."
"15901",5230,""
"15902",5230,"“Very well,” said the Voice, in a tone of relief. “Then I’m going to"
"15903",5230,"throw flints at you till you think differently.”"
"15904",5230,""
"15905",5230,"“But where _are_ yer?”"
"15906",5230,""
"15907",5230,"The Voice made no answer. Whizz came a flint, apparently out of the"
"15908",5230,"air, and missed Mr. Marvel’s shoulder by a hair’s-breadth. Mr. Marvel,"
"15909",5230,"turning, saw a flint jerk up into the air, trace a complicated path,"
"15910",5230,"hang for a moment, and then fling at his feet with almost invisible"
"15911",5230,"rapidity. He was too amazed to dodge. Whizz it came, and ricochetted"
"15912",5230,"from a bare toe into the ditch. Mr. Thomas Marvel jumped a foot and"
"15913",5230,"howled aloud. Then he started to run, tripped over an unseen obstacle,"
"15914",5230,"and came head over heels into a sitting position."
"15915",5230,""
"15916",5230,"“_Now_,” said the Voice, as a third stone curved upward and hung in the"

"15918",5230,""
"15919",5230,"Mr. Marvel by way of reply struggled to his feet, and was immediately"
"15920",5230,"rolled over again. He lay quiet for a moment. “If you struggle any"

"15922",5230,""

"15928",5230,"The third flint fell."

"16040",5230,"CHAPTER X."
"16041",5230,"MR. MARVEL’S VISIT TO IPING"
"16042",5230,""
"16043",5230,""
"16044",5230,"After the first gusty panic had spent itself Iping became"
"16045",5230,"argumentative. Scepticism suddenly reared its head—rather nervous"
"16046",5230,"scepticism, not at all assured of its back, but scepticism"
"16047",5230,"nevertheless. It is so much easier not to believe in an invisible man;"
"16048",5230,"and those who had actually seen him dissolve into air, or felt the"
"16049",5230,"strength of his arm, could be counted on the fingers of two hands. And"
"16050",5230,"of these witnesses Mr. Wadgers was presently missing, having retired"
"16051",5230,"impregnably behind the bolts and bars of his own house, and Jaffers was"
"16052",5230,"lying stunned in the parlour of the “Coach and Horses.” Great and"
"16053",5230,"strange ideas transcending experience often have less effect upon men"
"16054",5230,"and women than smaller, more tangible considerations. Iping was gay"
"16055",5230,"with bunting, and everybody was in gala dress. Whit Monday had been"
"16056",5230,"looked forward to for a month or more. By the afternoon even those who"
"16057",5230,"believed in the Unseen were beginning to resume their little amusements"
"16058",5230,"in a tentative fashion, on the supposition that he had quite gone away,"
"16059",5230,"and with the sceptics he was already a jest. But people, sceptics and"
"16060",5230,"believers alike, were remarkably sociable all that day."
"16061",5230,""
"16062",5230,"Haysman’s meadow was gay with a tent, in which Mrs. Bunting and other"
"16063",5230,"ladies were preparing tea, while, without, the Sunday-school children"
"16064",5230,"ran races and played games under the noisy guidance of the curate and"
"16065",5230,"the Misses Cuss and Sackbut. No doubt there was a slight uneasiness in"
"16066",5230,"the air, but people for the most part had the sense to conceal whatever"
"16067",5230,"imaginative qualms they experienced. On the village green an inclined"
"16068",5230,"strong [rope?], down which, clinging the while to a pulley-swung"
"16069",5230,"handle, one could be hurled violently against a sack at the other end,"
"16070",5230,"came in for considerable favour among the adolescents, as also did the"
"16071",5230,"swings and the cocoanut shies. There was also promenading, and the"
"16072",5230,"steam organ attached to a small roundabout filled the air with a"
"16073",5230,"pungent flavour of oil and with equally pungent music. Members of the"
"16074",5230,"club, who had attended church in the morning, were splendid in badges"
"16075",5230,"of pink and green, and some of the gayer-minded had also adorned their"
"16076",5230,"bowler hats with brilliant-coloured favours of ribbon. Old Fletcher,"
"16077",5230,"whose conceptions of holiday-making were severe, was visible through"
"16078",5230,"the jasmine about his window or through the open door (whichever way"
"16079",5230,"you chose to look), poised delicately on a plank supported on two"
"16080",5230,"chairs, and whitewashing the ceiling of his front room."
"16081",5230,""
"16082",5230,"About four o’clock a stranger entered the village from the direction of"
"16083",5230,"the downs. He was a short, stout person in an extraordinarily shabby"
"16084",5230,"top hat, and he appeared to be very much out of breath. His cheeks were"
"16085",5230,"alternately limp and tightly puffed. His mottled face was apprehensive,"
"16086",5230,"and he moved with a sort of reluctant alacrity. He turned the corner of"
"16087",5230,"the church, and directed his way to the “Coach and Horses.” Among"
"16088",5230,"others old Fletcher remembers seeing him, and indeed the old gentleman"
"16089",5230,"was so struck by his peculiar agitation that he inadvertently allowed a"
"16090",5230,"quantity of whitewash to run down the brush into the sleeve of his coat"
"16091",5230,"while regarding him."
"16092",5230,""
"16093",5230,"This stranger, to the perceptions of the proprietor of the cocoanut"
"16094",5230,"shy, appeared to be talking to himself, and Mr. Huxter remarked the"

"16485",5230,"caught dismally in a swing. And then the whole tumultuous rush has"
"16486",5230,"passed and the Iping street with its gauds and flags is deserted save"
"16487",5230,"for the still raging unseen, and littered with cocoanuts, overthrown"
"16488",5230,"canvas screens, and the scattered stock in trade of a sweetstuff stall."
"16489",5230,"Everywhere there is a sound of closing shutters and shoving bolts, and"
"16490",5230,"the only visible humanity is an occasional flitting eye under a raised"
"16491",5230,"eyebrow in the corner of a window pane."
"16492",5230,""
"16493",5230,"The Invisible Man amused himself for a little while by breaking all the"
"16494",5230,"windows in the “Coach and Horses,” and then he thrust a street lamp"
"16495",5230,"through the parlour window of Mrs. Gribble. He it must have been who"
"16496",5230,"cut the telegraph wire to Adderdean just beyond Higgins’ cottage on the"
"16497",5230,"Adderdean road. And after that, as his peculiar qualities allowed, he"
"16498",5230,"passed out of human perceptions altogether, and he was neither heard,"
"16499",5230,"seen, nor felt in Iping any more. He vanished absolutely."
"16500",5230,""
"16501",5230,"But it was the best part of two hours before any human being ventured"
"16502",5230,"out again into the desolation of Iping street."
"16503",5230,""
"16504",5230,""
"16505",5230,""
"16506",5230,""
"16507",5230,"CHAPTER XIII."
"16508",5230,"MR. MARVEL DISCUSSES HIS RESIGNATION"
"16509",5230,""
"16510",5230,""
"16511",5230,"When the dusk was gathering and Iping was just beginning to peep"
"16512",5230,"timorously forth again upon the shattered wreckage of its Bank Holiday,"
"16513",5230,"a short, thick-set man in a shabby silk hat was marching painfully"
"16514",5230,"through the twilight behind the beechwoods on the road to Bramblehurst."
"16515",5230,"He carried three books bound together by some sort of ornamental"
"16516",5230,"elastic ligature, and a bundle wrapped in a blue table-cloth. His"
"16517",5230,"rubicund face expressed consternation and fatigue; he appeared to be in"
"16518",5230,"a spasmodic sort of hurry. He was accompanied by a voice other than his"
"16519",5230,"own, and ever and again he winced under the touch of unseen hands."
"16520",5230,""
"16521",5230,"“If you give me the slip again,” said the Voice, “if you attempt to"
"16522",5230,"give me the slip again—”"
"16523",5230,""
"16524",5230,"“Lord!” said Mr. Marvel. “That shoulder’s a mass of bruises as it is.”"
"16525",5230,""
"16526",5230,"“On my honour,” said the Voice, “I will kill you.”"
"16527",5230,""
"16528",5230,"“I didn’t try to give you the slip,” said Marvel, in a voice that was"
"16529",5230,"not far remote from tears. “I swear I didn’t. I didn’t know the blessed"
"16530",5230,"turning, that was all! How the devil was I to know the blessed turning?"
"16531",5230,"As it is, I’ve been knocked about—”"
"16532",5230,""
"16533",5230,"“You’ll get knocked about a great deal more if you don’t mind,” said"
"16534",5230,"the Voice, and Mr. Marvel abruptly became silent. He blew out his"
"16535",5230,"cheeks, and his eyes were eloquent of despair."
"16536",5230,""
"16537",5230,"“It’s bad enough to let these floundering yokels explode my little"
"16538",5230,"secret, without _your_ cutting off with my books. It’s lucky for some"
"16539",5230,"of them they cut and ran when they did! Here am I ... No one knew I was"
"16540",5230,"invisible! And now what am I to do?”"
"16541",5230,""
"16542",5230,"“What am _I_ to do?” asked Marvel, _sotto voce_."
"16543",5230,""
"16544",5230,"“It’s all about. It will be in the papers! Everybody will be looking"
"16545",5230,"for me; everyone on their guard—” The Voice broke off into vivid curses"
"16546",5230,"and ceased."
"16547",5230,""
"16548",5230,"The despair of Mr. Marvel’s face deepened, and his pace slackened."
"16549",5230,""
"16550",5230,"“Go on!” said the Voice."
"16551",5230,""
"16552",5230,"Mr. Marvel’s face assumed a greyish tint between the ruddier patches."
"16553",5230,""
"16554",5230,"“Don’t drop those books, stupid,” said the Voice, sharply—overtaking"
"16555",5230,"him."
"16556",5230,""
"16557",5230,"“The fact is,” said the Voice, “I shall have to make use of you...."
"16558",5230,"You’re a poor tool, but I must.”"
"16559",5230,""
"16560",5230,"“I’m a _miserable_ tool,” said Marvel."
"16561",5230,""
"16562",5230,"“You are,” said the Voice."
"16563",5230,""
"16564",5230,"“I’m the worst possible tool you could have,” said Marvel."
"16565",5230,""
"16566",5230,"“I’m not strong,” he said after a discouraging silence."
"16567",5230,""
"16568",5230,"“I’m not over strong,” he repeated."
"16569",5230,""
"16570",5230,"“No?”"
"16571",5230,""
"16572",5230,"“And my heart’s weak. That little business—I pulled it through, of"
"16573",5230,"course—but bless you! I could have dropped.”"
"16574",5230,""
"16575",5230,"“Well?”"
"16576",5230,""
"16577",5230,"“I haven’t the nerve and strength for the sort of thing you want.”"
"16578",5230,""
"16579",5230,"“_I’ll_ stimulate you.”"
"16580",5230,""
"16581",5230,"“I wish you wouldn’t. I wouldn’t like to mess up your plans, you know."
"16582",5230,"But I might—out of sheer funk and misery.”"
"16583",5230,""
"16584",5230,"“You’d better not,” said the Voice, with quiet emphasis."
"16585",5230,""
"16586",5230,"“I wish I was dead,” said Marvel."
"16587",5230,""
"16588",5230,"“It ain’t justice,” he said; “you must admit.... It seems to me I’ve a"
"16589",5230,"perfect right—”"
"16590",5230,""
"16591",5230,"“_Get_ on!” said the Voice."
"16592",5230,""
"16593",5230,"Mr. Marvel mended his pace, and for a time they went in silence again."
"16594",5230,""
"16595",5230,"“It’s devilish hard,” said Mr. Marvel."
"16596",5230,""
"16597",5230,"This was quite ineffectual. He tried another tack."
"16598",5230,""
"16599",5230,"“What do I make by it?” he began again in a tone of unendurable wrong."
"16600",5230,""
"16601",5230,"“Oh! _shut up_!” said the Voice, with sudden amazing vigour. “I’ll see"
"16602",5230,"to you all right. You do what you’re told. You’ll do it all right."
"16603",5230,"You’re a fool and all that, but you’ll do—”"
"16604",5230,""
"16605",5230,"“I tell you, sir, I’m not the man for it. Respectfully—but it _is_ so—”"
"16606",5230,""
"16607",5230,"“If you don’t shut up I shall twist your wrist again,” said the"
"16608",5230,"Invisible Man. “I want to think.”"
"16609",5230,""
"16610",5230,"Presently two oblongs of yellow light appeared through the trees, and"
"16611",5230,"the square tower of a church loomed through the gloaming. “I shall keep"
"16612",5230,"my hand on your shoulder,” said the Voice, “all through the village. Go"
"16613",5230,"straight through and try no foolery. It will be the worse for you if"
"16614",5230,"you do.”"
"16615",5230,""
"16616",5230,"“I know that,” sighed Mr. Marvel, “I know all that.”"
"16617",5230,""
"16618",5230,"The unhappy-looking figure in the obsolete silk hat passed up the"
"16619",5230,"street of the little village with his burdens, and vanished into the"
"16620",5230,"gathering darkness beyond the lights of the windows."
"16621",5230,""
"16622",5230,""
"16623",5230,""
"16624",5230,""
"16625",5230,"CHAPTER XIV."
"16626",5230,"AT PORT STOWE"
"16627",5230,""
"16628",5230,""
"16629",5230,"Ten o’clock the next morning found Mr. Marvel, unshaven, dirty, and"
"16630",5230,"travel-stained, sitting with the books beside him and his hands deep in"
"16631",5230,"his pockets, looking very weary, nervous, and uncomfortable, and"
"16632",5230,"inflating his cheeks at infrequent intervals, on the bench outside a"
"16633",5230,"little inn on the outskirts of Port Stowe. Beside him were the books,"
"16634",5230,"but now they were tied with string. The bundle had been abandoned in"
"16635",5230,"the pine-woods beyond Bramblehurst, in accordance with a change in the"
"16636",5230,"plans of the Invisible Man. Mr. Marvel sat on the bench, and although"
"16637",5230,"no one took the slightest notice of him, his agitation remained at"
"16638",5230,"fever heat. His hands would go ever and again to his various pockets"
"16639",5230,"with a curious nervous fumbling."
"16640",5230,""
"16641",5230,"When he had been sitting for the best part of an hour, however, an"
"16642",5230,"elderly mariner, carrying a newspaper, came out of the inn and sat down"
"16643",5230,"beside him. “Pleasant day,” said the mariner."
"16644",5230,""
"16645",5230,"Mr. Marvel glanced about him with something very like terror. “Very,”"
"16646",5230,"he said."
"16647",5230,""
"16648",5230,"“Just seasonable weather for the time of year,” said the mariner,"
"16649",5230,"taking no denial."
"16650",5230,""
"16651",5230,"“Quite,” said Mr. Marvel."
"16652",5230,""
"16653",5230,"The mariner produced a toothpick, and (saving his regard) was engrossed"
"16654",5230,"thereby for some minutes. His eyes meanwhile were at liberty to examine"
"16655",5230,"Mr. Marvel’s dusty figure, and the books beside him. As he had"
"16656",5230,"approached Mr. Marvel he had heard a sound like the dropping of coins"
"16657",5230,"into a pocket. He was struck by the contrast of Mr. Marvel’s appearance"
"16658",5230,"with this suggestion of opulence. Thence his mind wandered back again"
"16659",5230,"to a topic that had taken a curiously firm hold of his imagination."
"16660",5230,""
"16661",5230,"“Books?” he said suddenly, noisily finishing with the toothpick."
"16662",5230,""
"16663",5230,"Mr. Marvel started and looked at them. “Oh, yes,” he said. “Yes,"
"16664",5230,"they’re books.”"
"16665",5230,""
"16666",5230,"“There’s some extra-ordinary things in books,” said the mariner."
"16667",5230,""
"16668",5230,"“I believe you,” said Mr. Marvel."
"16669",5230,""
"16670",5230,"“And some extra-ordinary things out of ’em,” said the mariner."
"16671",5230,""
"16672",5230,"“True likewise,” said Mr. Marvel. He eyed his interlocutor, and then"
"16673",5230,"glanced about him."
"16674",5230,""
"16675",5230,"“There’s some extra-ordinary things in newspapers, for example,” said"
"16676",5230,"the mariner."
"16677",5230,""
"16678",5230,"“There are.”"
"16679",5230,""
"16680",5230,"“In _this_ newspaper,” said the mariner."
"16681",5230,""
"16682",5230,"“Ah!” said Mr. Marvel."
"16683",5230,""
"16684",5230,"“There’s a story,” said the mariner, fixing Mr. Marvel with an eye that"
"16685",5230,"was firm and deliberate; “there’s a story about an Invisible Man, for"
"16686",5230,"instance.”"
"16687",5230,""
"16688",5230,"Mr. Marvel pulled his mouth askew and scratched his cheek and felt his"
"16689",5230,"ears glowing. “What will they be writing next?” he asked faintly."
"16690",5230,"“Ostria, or America?”"
"16691",5230,""
"16692",5230,"“Neither,” said the mariner. “_Here_.”"
"16693",5230,""
"16694",5230,"“Lord!” said Mr. Marvel, starting."
"16695",5230,""

"16697",5230,"“I don’t of course mean here in this place, I mean hereabouts.”"
"16698",5230,""
"16699",5230,"“An Invisible Man!” said Mr. Marvel. “And what’s _he_ been up to?”"
"16700",5230,""

"16702",5230,"then amplifying, “every—blessed—thing.”"

"16705",5230,""

"16707",5230,""

"16709",5230,""

"16713",5230,""

"16715",5230,""
"16716",5230,"“But then, it’s an extra-ordinary story. There is a clergyman and a"

"16880",5230,"CHAPTER XV."
"16881",5230,"THE MAN WHO WAS RUNNING"
"16882",5230,""
"16883",5230,""
"16884",5230,"In the early evening time Dr. Kemp was sitting in his study in the"
"16885",5230,"belvedere on the hill overlooking Burdock. It was a pleasant little"
"16886",5230,"room, with three windows—north, west, and south—and bookshelves covered"
"16887",5230,"with books and scientific publications, and a broad writing-table, and,"
"16888",5230,"under the north window, a microscope, glass slips, minute instruments,"
"16889",5230,"some cultures, and scattered bottles of reagents. Dr. Kemp’s solar lamp"
"16890",5230,"was lit, albeit the sky was still bright with the sunset light, and his"
"16891",5230,"blinds were up because there was no offence of peering outsiders to"
"16892",5230,"require them pulled down. Dr. Kemp was a tall and slender young man,"

"16896",5230,""

"16914",5230,""

"16916",5230,""

"16924",5230,""

"16935",5230,""

"16937",5230,"and ran under a gate, and as they still wondered something—a wind—a"

"16946",5230,""

"16952",5230,"CHAPTER XVI."
"16953",5230,"IN THE “JOLLY CRICKETERS”"
"16954",5230,""
"16955",5230,""
"16956",5230,"The “Jolly Cricketers” is just at the bottom of the hill, where the"
"16957",5230,"tram-lines begin. The barman leant his fat red arms on the counter and"
"16958",5230,"talked of horses with an anaemic cabman, while a black-bearded man in"
"16959",5230,"grey snapped up biscuit and cheese, drank Burton, and conversed in"
"16960",5230,"American with a policeman off duty."
"16961",5230,""
"16962",5230,"“What’s the shouting about!” said the anaemic cabman, going off at a"
"16963",5230,"tangent, trying to see up the hill over the dirty yellow blind in the"

"16966",5230,""

"16974",5230,""

"16998",5230,""

"17113",5230,"CHAPTER XVII."
"17114",5230,"DR. KEMP’S VISITOR"
"17115",5230,""
"17116",5230,""
"17117",5230,"Dr. Kemp had continued writing in his study until the shots aroused"
"17118",5230,"him. Crack, crack, crack, they came one after the other."
"17119",5230,""
"17120",5230,"“Hullo!” said Dr. Kemp, putting his pen into his mouth again and"
"17121",5230,"listening. “Who’s letting off revolvers in Burdock? What are the asses"
"17122",5230,"at now?”"
"17123",5230,""
"17124",5230,"He went to the south window, threw it up, and leaning out stared down"
"17125",5230,"on the network of windows, beaded gas-lamps and shops, with its black"
"17126",5230,"interstices of roof and yard that made up the town at night. “Looks"
"17127",5230,"like a crowd down the hill,” he said, “by ‘The Cricketers,’” and"
"17128",5230,"remained watching. Thence his eyes wandered over the town to far away"
"17129",5230,"where the ships’ lights shone, and the pier glowed—a little"
"17130",5230,"illuminated, facetted pavilion like a gem of yellow light. The moon in"
"17131",5230,"its first quarter hung over the westward hill, and the stars were clear"
"17132",5230,"and almost tropically bright."
"17133",5230,""
"17134",5230,"After five minutes, during which his mind had travelled into a remote"
"17135",5230,"speculation of social conditions of the future, and lost itself at last"
"17136",5230,"over the time dimension, Dr. Kemp roused himself with a sigh, pulled"
"17137",5230,"down the window again, and returned to his writing desk."
"17138",5230,""
"17139",5230,"It must have been about an hour after this that the front-door bell"

"17141",5230,"since the shots. He sat listening. He heard the servant answer the"

"17143",5230,"“Wonder what that was,” said Dr. Kemp."
"17144",5230,""
"17145",5230,"He tried to resume his work, failed, got up, went downstairs from his"
"17146",5230,"study to the landing, rang, and called over the balustrade to the"

"17148",5230,"asked."
"17149",5230,""
"17150",5230,"“Only a runaway ring, sir,” she answered."
"17151",5230,""

"17153",5230,"and this time attacked his work resolutely. In a little while he was"

"17155",5230,"the clock and the subdued shrillness of his quill, hurrying in the very"
"17156",5230,"centre of the circle of light his lampshade threw on his table."
"17157",5230,""
"17158",5230,"It was two o’clock before Dr. Kemp had finished his work for the night."

"17160",5230,"coat and vest, when he noticed that he was thirsty. He took a candle"

"17162",5230,""

"17172",5230,""

"17464",5230,"CHAPTER XVIII."
"17465",5230,"THE INVISIBLE MAN SLEEPS"
"17466",5230,""
"17467",5230,""
"17468",5230,"Exhausted and wounded as the Invisible Man was, he refused to accept"
"17469",5230,"Kemp’s word that his freedom should be respected. He examined the two"
"17470",5230,"windows of the bedroom, drew up the blinds and opened the sashes, to"
"17471",5230,"confirm Kemp’s statement that a retreat by them would be possible."
"17472",5230,"Outside the night was very quiet and still, and the new moon was"
"17473",5230,"setting over the down. Then he examined the keys of the bedroom and the"
"17474",5230,"two dressing-room doors, to satisfy himself that these also could be"
"17475",5230,"made an assurance of freedom. Finally he expressed himself satisfied."
"17476",5230,"He stood on the hearth rug and Kemp heard the sound of a yawn."
"17477",5230,""
"17478",5230,"“I’m sorry,” said the Invisible Man, “if I cannot tell you all that I"
"17479",5230,"have done to-night. But I am worn out. It’s grotesque, no doubt. It’s"

"17481",5230,"morning, it is quite a possible thing. I have made a discovery. I meant"
"17482",5230,"to keep it to myself. I can’t. I must have a partner. And you.... We"
"17483",5230,"can do such things ... But to-morrow. Now, Kemp, I feel as though I"
"17484",5230,"must sleep or perish.”"
"17485",5230,""
"17486",5230,"Kemp stood in the middle of the room staring at the headless garment."
"17487",5230,"“I suppose I must leave you,” he said. “It’s—incredible. Three things"
"17488",5230,"happening like this, overturning all my preconceptions—would make me"
"17489",5230,"insane. But it’s real! Is there anything more that I can get you?”"
"17490",5230,""
"17491",5230,"“Only bid me good-night,” said Griffin."
"17492",5230,""
"17493",5230,"“Good-night,” said Kemp, and shook an invisible hand. He walked"
"17494",5230,"sideways to the door. Suddenly the dressing-gown walked quickly towards"
"17495",5230,"him. “Understand me!” said the dressing-gown. “No attempts to hamper"
"17496",5230,"me, or capture me! Or—”"
"17497",5230,""
"17498",5230,"Kemp’s face changed a little. “I thought I gave you my word,” he said."
"17499",5230,""

"17512",5230,""

"17514",5230,""

"17516",5230,""

"17518",5230,"room, ejaculating. Now and then he would argue with himself."
"17519",5230,""
"17520",5230,"“Invisible!” he said."
"17521",5230,""

"17528",5230,""

"17532",5230,""

"17620",5230,"CHAPTER XIX."
"17621",5230,"CERTAIN FIRST PRINCIPLES"
"17622",5230,""
"17623",5230,""

"17687",5230,""
"17688",5230,"“But I went to work—like a slave. And I had hardly worked and thought"
"17689",5230,"about the matter six months before light came through one of the meshes"
"17690",5230,"suddenly—blindingly! I found a general principle of pigments and"
"17691",5230,"refraction—a formula, a geometrical expression involving four"
"17692",5230,"dimensions. Fools, common men, even common mathematicians, do not know"
"17693",5230,"anything of what some general expression may mean to the student of"
"17694",5230,"molecular physics. In the books—the books that tramp has hidden—there"
"17695",5230,"are marvels, miracles! But this was not a method, it was an idea, that"
"17696",5230,"might lead to a method by which it would be possible, without changing"
"17697",5230,"any other property of matter—except, in some instances colours—to lower"
"17698",5230,"the refractive index of a substance, solid or liquid, to that of air—so"
"17699",5230,"far as all practical purposes are concerned.”"
"17700",5230,""
"17701",5230,"“Phew!” said Kemp. “That’s odd! But still I don’t see quite ... I can"
"17702",5230,"understand that thereby you could spoil a valuable stone, but personal"
"17703",5230,"invisibility is a far cry.”"
"17704",5230,""
"17705",5230,"“Precisely,” said Griffin. “But consider, visibility depends on the"
"17706",5230,"action of the visible bodies on light. Either a body absorbs light, or"
"17707",5230,"it reflects or refracts it, or does all these things. If it neither"
"17708",5230,"reflects nor refracts nor absorbs light, it cannot of itself be"
"17709",5230,"visible. You see an opaque red box, for instance, because the colour"
"17710",5230,"absorbs some of the light and reflects the rest, all the red part of"
"17711",5230,"the light, to you. If it did not absorb any particular part of the"
"17712",5230,"light, but reflected it all, then it would be a shining white box."
"17713",5230,"Silver! A diamond box would neither absorb much of the light nor"
"17714",5230,"reflect much from the general surface, but just here and there where"
"17715",5230,"the surfaces were favourable the light would be reflected and"
"17716",5230,"refracted, so that you would get a brilliant appearance of flashing"
"17717",5230,"reflections and translucencies—a sort of skeleton of light. A glass box"
"17718",5230,"would not be so brilliant, nor so clearly visible, as a diamond box,"
"17719",5230,"because there would be less refraction and reflection. See that? From"
"17720",5230,"certain points of view you would see quite clearly through it. Some"
"17721",5230,"kinds of glass would be more visible than others, a box of flint glass"
"17722",5230,"would be brighter than a box of ordinary window glass. A box of very"
"17723",5230,"thin common glass would be hard to see in a bad light, because it would"
"17724",5230,"absorb hardly any light and refract and reflect very little. And if you"
"17725",5230,"put a sheet of common white glass in water, still more if you put it in"
"17726",5230,"some denser liquid than water, it would vanish almost altogether,"
"17727",5230,"because light passing from water to glass is only slightly refracted or"
"17728",5230,"reflected or indeed affected in any way. It is almost as invisible as a"
"17729",5230,"jet of coal gas or hydrogen is in air. And for precisely the same"
"17730",5230,"reason!”"
"17731",5230,""
"17732",5230,"“Yes,” said Kemp, “that is pretty plain sailing.”"
"17733",5230,""
"17734",5230,"“And here is another fact you will know to be true. If a sheet of glass"
"17735",5230,"is smashed, Kemp, and beaten into a powder, it becomes much more"
"17736",5230,"visible while it is in the air; it becomes at last an opaque white"
"17737",5230,"powder. This is because the powdering multiplies the surfaces of the"
"17738",5230,"glass at which refraction and reflection occur. In the sheet of glass"
"17739",5230,"there are only two surfaces; in the powder the light is reflected or"
"17740",5230,"refracted by each grain it passes through, and very little gets right"
"17741",5230,"through the powder. But if the white powdered glass is put into water,"
"17742",5230,"it forthwith vanishes. The powdered glass and water have much the same"
"17743",5230,"refractive index; that is, the light undergoes very little refraction"
"17744",5230,"or reflection in passing from one to the other."
"17745",5230,""
"17746",5230,"“You make the glass invisible by putting it into a liquid of nearly the"
"17747",5230,"same refractive index; a transparent thing becomes invisible if it is"
"17748",5230,"put in any medium of almost the same refractive index. And if you will"
"17749",5230,"consider only a second, you will see also that the powder of glass"
"17750",5230,"might be made to vanish in air, if its refractive index could be made"
"17751",5230,"the same as that of air; for then there would be no refraction or"
"17752",5230,"reflection as the light passed from glass to air.”"
"17753",5230,""
"17754",5230,"“Yes, yes,” said Kemp. “But a man’s not powdered glass!”"
"17755",5230,""
"17756",5230,"“No,” said Griffin. “He’s more transparent!”"
"17757",5230,""
"17758",5230,"“Nonsense!”"
"17759",5230,""
"17760",5230,"“That from a doctor! How one forgets! Have you already forgotten your"
"17761",5230,"physics, in ten years? Just think of all the things that are"
"17762",5230,"transparent and seem not to be so. Paper, for instance, is made up of"
"17763",5230,"transparent fibres, and it is white and opaque only for the same reason"
"17764",5230,"that a powder of glass is white and opaque. Oil white paper, fill up"
"17765",5230,"the interstices between the particles with oil so that there is no"
"17766",5230,"longer refraction or reflection except at the surfaces, and it becomes"
"17767",5230,"as transparent as glass. And not only paper, but cotton fibre, linen"
"17768",5230,"fibre, wool fibre, woody fibre, and _bone_, Kemp, _flesh_, Kemp,"
"17769",5230,"_hair_, Kemp, _nails_ and _nerves_, Kemp, in fact the whole fabric of a"
"17770",5230,"man except the red of his blood and the black pigment of hair, are all"
"17771",5230,"made up of transparent, colourless tissue. So little suffices to make"
"17772",5230,"us visible one to the other. For the most part the fibres of a living"
"17773",5230,"creature are no more opaque than water.”"
"17774",5230,""
"17775",5230,"“Great Heavens!” cried Kemp. “Of course, of course! I was thinking only"
"17776",5230,"last night of the sea larvae and all jelly-fish!”"
"17777",5230,""
"17778",5230,"“_Now_ you have me! And all that I knew and had in mind a year after I"
"17779",5230,"left London—six years ago. But I kept it to myself. I had to do my work"
"17780",5230,"under frightful disadvantages. Oliver, my professor, was a scientific"
"17781",5230,"bounder, a journalist by instinct, a thief of ideas—he was always"
"17782",5230,"prying! And you know the knavish system of the scientific world. I"
"17783",5230,"simply would not publish, and let him share my credit. I went on"
"17784",5230,"working; I got nearer and nearer making my formula into an experiment,"
"17785",5230,"a reality. I told no living soul, because I meant to flash my work upon"
"17786",5230,"the world with crushing effect and become famous at a blow. I took up"
"17787",5230,"the question of pigments to fill up certain gaps. And suddenly, not by"
"17788",5230,"design but by accident, I made a discovery in physiology.”"
"17789",5230,""
"17790",5230,"“Yes?”"
"17791",5230,""
"17792",5230,"“You know the red colouring matter of blood; it can be made"
"17793",5230,"white—colourless—and remain with all the functions it has now!”"
"17794",5230,""
"17795",5230,"Kemp gave a cry of incredulous amazement."
"17796",5230,""
"17797",5230,"The Invisible Man rose and began pacing the little study. “You may well"

"17802",5230,"burning brightly and silently. In all my great moments I have been"
"17803",5230,"alone. ‘One could make an animal—a tissue—transparent! One could make"

"17809",5230,""

"17821",5230,"the cramped means! Three years I had of it—"
"17822",5230,""

"17824",5230,"complete it was impossible—impossible.”"
"17825",5230,""
"17826",5230,"“How?” asked Kemp."
"17827",5230,""
"17828",5230,"“Money,” said the Invisible Man, and went again to stare out of the"
"17829",5230,"window."
"17830",5230,""
"17831",5230,"He turned around abruptly. “I robbed the old man—robbed my father."
"17832",5230,""
"17833",5230,"“The money was not his, and he shot himself.”"

"17838",5230,"CHAPTER XX."
"17839",5230,"AT THE HOUSE IN GREAT PORTLAND STREET"
"17840",5230,""
"17841",5230,""
"17842",5230,"For a moment Kemp sat in silence, staring at the back of the headless"
"17843",5230,"figure at the window. Then he started, struck by a thought, rose, took"
"17844",5230,"the Invisible Man’s arm, and turned him away from the outlook."
"17845",5230,""
"17846",5230,"“You are tired,” he said, “and while I sit, you walk about. Have my"
"17847",5230,"chair.”"
"17848",5230,""
"17849",5230,"He placed himself between Griffin and the nearest window."
"17850",5230,""
"17851",5230,"For a space Griffin sat silent, and then he resumed abruptly:"
"17852",5230,""
"17853",5230,"“I had left the Chesilstowe cottage already,” he said, “when that"
"17854",5230,"happened. It was last December. I had taken a room in London, a large"
"17855",5230,"unfurnished room in a big ill-managed lodging-house in a slum near"
"17856",5230,"Great Portland Street. The room was soon full of the appliances I had"
"17857",5230,"bought with his money; the work was going on steadily, successfully,"
"17858",5230,"drawing near an end. I was like a man emerging from a thicket, and"
"17859",5230,"suddenly coming on some unmeaning tragedy. I went to bury him. My mind"
"17860",5230,"was still on this research, and I did not lift a finger to save his"
"17861",5230,"character. I remember the funeral, the cheap hearse, the scant"
"17862",5230,"ceremony, the windy frost-bitten hillside, and the old college friend"
"17863",5230,"of his who read the service over him—a shabby, black, bent old man with"
"17864",5230,"a snivelling cold."
"17865",5230,""
"17866",5230,"“I remember walking back to the empty house, through the place that had"
"17867",5230,"once been a village and was now patched and tinkered by the jerry"
"17868",5230,"builders into the ugly likeness of a town. Every way the roads ran out"
"17869",5230,"at last into the desecrated fields and ended in rubble heaps and rank"
"17870",5230,"wet weeds. I remember myself as a gaunt black figure, going along the"
"17871",5230,"slippery, shiny pavement, and the strange sense of detachment I felt"
"17872",5230,"from the squalid respectability, the sordid commercialism of the place."
"17873",5230,""
"17874",5230,"“I did not feel a bit sorry for my father. He seemed to me to be the"
"17875",5230,"victim of his own foolish sentimentality. The current cant required my"
"17876",5230,"attendance at his funeral, but it was really not my affair."
"17877",5230,""
"17878",5230,"“But going along the High Street, my old life came back to me for a"
"17879",5230,"space, for I met the girl I had known ten years since. Our eyes met."
"17880",5230,""
"17881",5230,"“Something moved me to turn back and talk to her. She was a very"
"17882",5230,"ordinary person."
"17883",5230,""
"17884",5230,"“It was all like a dream, that visit to the old places. I did not feel"
"17885",5230,"then that I was lonely, that I had come out from the world into a"
"17886",5230,"desolate place. I appreciated my loss of sympathy, but I put it down to"
"17887",5230,"the general inanity of things. Re-entering my room seemed like the"
"17888",5230,"recovery of reality. There were the things I knew and loved. There"
"17889",5230,"stood the apparatus, the experiments arranged and waiting. And now"
"17890",5230,"there was scarcely a difficulty left, beyond the planning of details."
"17891",5230,""
"17892",5230,"“I will tell you, Kemp, sooner or later, all the complicated processes."
"17893",5230,"We need not go into that now. For the most part, saving certain gaps I"
"17894",5230,"chose to remember, they are written in cypher in those books that tramp"
"17895",5230,"has hidden. We must hunt him down. We must get those books again. But"
"17896",5230,"the essential phase was to place the transparent object whose"
"17897",5230,"refractive index was to be lowered between two radiating centres of a"
"17898",5230,"sort of ethereal vibration, of which I will tell you more fully later."
"17899",5230,"No, not those Röntgen vibrations—I don’t know that these others of mine"
"17900",5230,"have been described. Yet they are obvious enough. I needed two little"
"17901",5230,"dynamos, and these I worked with a cheap gas engine. My first"
"17902",5230,"experiment was with a bit of white wool fabric. It was the strangest"
"17903",5230,"thing in the world to see it in the flicker of the flashes soft and"
"17904",5230,"white, and then to watch it fade like a wreath of smoke and vanish."
"17905",5230,""
"17906",5230,"“I could scarcely believe I had done it. I put my hand into the"
"17907",5230,"emptiness, and there was the thing as solid as ever. I felt it"
"17908",5230,"awkwardly, and threw it on the floor. I had a little trouble finding it"
"17909",5230,"again."
"17910",5230,""
"17911",5230,"“And then came a curious experience. I heard a miaow behind me, and"
"17912",5230,"turning, saw a lean white cat, very dirty, on the cistern cover outside"
"17913",5230,"the window. A thought came into my head. ‘Everything ready for you,’ I"
"17914",5230,"said, and went to the window, opened it, and called softly. She came"
"17915",5230,"in, purring—the poor beast was starving—and I gave her some milk. All"
"17916",5230,"my food was in a cupboard in the corner of the room. After that she"
"17917",5230,"went smelling round the room, evidently with the idea of making herself"
"17918",5230,"at home. The invisible rag upset her a bit; you should have seen her"
"17919",5230,"spit at it! But I made her comfortable on the pillow of my truckle-bed."
"17920",5230,"And I gave her butter to get her to wash.”"
"17921",5230,""
"17922",5230,"“And you processed her?”"
"17923",5230,""
"17924",5230,"“I processed her. But giving drugs to a cat is no joke, Kemp! And the"
"17925",5230,"process failed.”"
"17926",5230,""
"17927",5230,"“Failed!”"
"17928",5230,""
"17929",5230,"“In two particulars. These were the claws and the pigment stuff, what"
"17930",5230,"is it?—at the back of the eye in a cat. You know?”"
"17931",5230,""
"17932",5230,"“_Tapetum_.”"
"17933",5230,""

"17939",5230,""

"17954",5230,""

"17956",5230,""

"17979",5230,""

"17982",5230,"was hopeless, and, locking my door after me, wandered out into the"

"18052",5230,"“But this brought matters to a crisis. I did not know what he would do,"
"18053",5230,"nor even what he had the power to do. To move to fresh apartments would"
"18054",5230,"have meant delay; altogether I had barely twenty pounds left in the"
"18055",5230,"world, for the most part in a bank—and I could not afford that. Vanish!"
"18056",5230,"It was irresistible. Then there would be an inquiry, the sacking of my"
"18057",5230,"room."
"18058",5230,""
"18059",5230,"“At the thought of the possibility of my work being exposed or"
"18060",5230,"interrupted at its very climax, I became very angry and active. I"
"18061",5230,"hurried out with my three books of notes, my cheque-book—the tramp has"
"18062",5230,"them now—and directed them from the nearest Post Office to a house of"
"18063",5230,"call for letters and parcels in Great Portland Street. I tried to go"
"18064",5230,"out noiselessly. Coming in, I found my landlord going quietly upstairs;"
"18065",5230,"he had heard the door close, I suppose. You would have laughed to see"
"18066",5230,"him jump aside on the landing as I came tearing after him. He glared at"
"18067",5230,"me as I went by him, and I made the house quiver with the slamming of"
"18068",5230,"my door. I heard him come shuffling up to my floor, hesitate, and go"
"18069",5230,"down. I set to work upon my preparations forthwith."
"18070",5230,""
"18071",5230,"“It was all done that evening and night. While I was still sitting"
"18072",5230,"under the sickly, drowsy influence of the drugs that decolourise blood,"
"18073",5230,"there came a repeated knocking at the door. It ceased, footsteps went"
"18074",5230,"away and returned, and the knocking was resumed. There was an attempt"
"18075",5230,"to push something under the door—a blue paper. Then in a fit of"
"18076",5230,"irritation I rose and went and flung the door wide open. ‘Now then?’"
"18077",5230,"said I."
"18078",5230,""
"18079",5230,"“It was my landlord, with a notice of ejectment or something. He held"
"18080",5230,"it out to me, saw something odd about my hands, I expect, and lifted"
"18081",5230,"his eyes to my face."
"18082",5230,""
"18083",5230,"“For a moment he gaped. Then he gave a sort of inarticulate cry,"
"18084",5230,"dropped candle and writ together, and went blundering down the dark"
"18085",5230,"passage to the stairs. I shut the door, locked it, and went to the"
"18086",5230,"looking-glass. Then I understood his terror.... My face was white—like"
"18087",5230,"white stone."
"18088",5230,""
"18089",5230,"“But it was all horrible. I had not expected the suffering. A night of"
"18090",5230,"racking anguish, sickness and fainting. I set my teeth, though my skin"
"18091",5230,"was presently afire, all my body afire; but I lay there like grim"
"18092",5230,"death. I understood now how it was the cat had howled until I"
"18093",5230,"chloroformed it. Lucky it was I lived alone and untended in my room."
"18094",5230,"There were times when I sobbed and groaned and talked. But I stuck to"
"18095",5230,"it.... I became insensible and woke languid in the darkness."
"18096",5230,""
"18097",5230,"“The pain had passed. I thought I was killing myself and I did not"
"18098",5230,"care. I shall never forget that dawn, and the strange horror of seeing"
"18099",5230,"that my hands had become as clouded glass, and watching them grow"

"18103",5230,"vanished, and the little white nerves went last. I gritted my teeth and"

"18106",5230,"fingers."
"18107",5230,""
"18108",5230,"“I struggled up. At first I was as incapable as a swathed"
"18109",5230,"infant—stepping with limbs I could not see. I was weak and very hungry."
"18110",5230,"I went and stared at nothing in my shaving-glass, at nothing save where"
"18111",5230,"an attenuated pigment still remained behind the retina of my eyes,"
"18112",5230,"fainter than mist. I had to hang on to the table and press my forehead"
"18113",5230,"against the glass."
"18114",5230,""
"18115",5230,"“It was only by a frantic effort of will that I dragged myself back to"
"18116",5230,"the apparatus and completed the process."
"18117",5230,""

"18131",5230,""

"18133",5230,"in the middle of the room, and turned on the gas. Heavy blows began to"

"18142",5230,""

"18156",5230,""
"18157",5230,"“The old man, so far as I could understand his _patois_, agreed with"

"18166",5230,""

"18173",5230,""

"18180",5230,"farewell to the room left it for the last time.”"
"18181",5230,""
"18182",5230,"“You fired the house!” exclaimed Kemp."
"18183",5230,""
"18184",5230,"“Fired the house. It was the only way to cover my trail—and no doubt it"
"18185",5230,"was insured. I slipped the bolts of the front door quietly and went out"

"18188",5230,"was already teeming with plans of all the wild and wonderful things I"
