"18190",5230,""
"18191",5230,""
"18192",5230,""
"18193",5230,""
"18194",5230,"CHAPTER XXI."
"18195",5230,"IN OXFORD STREET"
"18196",5230,""
"18197",5230,""
"18198",5230,"“In going downstairs the first time I found an unexpected difficulty"
"18199",5230,"because I could not see my feet; indeed I stumbled twice, and there was"
"18200",5230,"an unaccustomed clumsiness in gripping the bolt. By not looking down,"
"18201",5230,"however, I managed to walk on the level passably well."
"18202",5230,""
"18203",5230,"“My mood, I say, was one of exaltation. I felt as a seeing man might"
"18204",5230,"do, with padded feet and noiseless clothes, in a city of the blind. I"
"18205",5230,"experienced a wild impulse to jest, to startle people, to clap men on"
"18206",5230,"the back, fling people’s hats astray, and generally revel in my"
"18207",5230,"extraordinary advantage."
"18208",5230,""
"18209",5230,"“But hardly had I emerged upon Great Portland Street, however (my"
"18210",5230,"lodging was close to the big draper’s shop there), when I heard a"
"18211",5230,"clashing concussion and was hit violently behind, and turning saw a man"
"18212",5230,"carrying a basket of soda-water syphons, and looking in amazement at"
"18213",5230,"his burden. Although the blow had really hurt me, I found something so"
"18214",5230,"irresistible in his astonishment that I laughed aloud. ‘The devil’s in"
"18215",5230,"the basket,’ I said, and suddenly twisted it out of his hand. He let go"
"18216",5230,"incontinently, and I swung the whole weight into the air."
"18217",5230,""
"18218",5230,"“But a fool of a cabman, standing outside a public house, made a sudden"
"18219",5230,"rush for this, and his extending fingers took me with excruciating"
"18220",5230,"violence under the ear. I let the whole down with a smash on the"
"18221",5230,"cabman, and then, with shouts and the clatter of feet about me, people"
"18222",5230,"coming out of shops, vehicles pulling up, I realised what I had done"
"18223",5230,"for myself, and cursing my folly, backed against a shop window and"
"18224",5230,"prepared to dodge out of the confusion. In a moment I should be wedged"
"18225",5230,"into a crowd and inevitably discovered. I pushed by a butcher boy, who"
"18226",5230,"luckily did not turn to see the nothingness that shoved him aside, and"
"18227",5230,"dodged behind the cab-man’s four-wheeler. I do not know how they"
"18228",5230,"settled the business. I hurried straight across the road, which was"
"18229",5230,"happily clear, and hardly heeding which way I went, in the fright of"
"18230",5230,"detection the incident had given me, plunged into the afternoon throng"
"18231",5230,"of Oxford Street."
"18232",5230,""
"18233",5230,"“I tried to get into the stream of people, but they were too thick for"
"18234",5230,"me, and in a moment my heels were being trodden upon. I took to the"
"18235",5230,"gutter, the roughness of which I found painful to my feet, and"
"18236",5230,"forthwith the shaft of a crawling hansom dug me forcibly under the"
"18237",5230,"shoulder blade, reminding me that I was already bruised severely. I"
"18238",5230,"staggered out of the way of the cab, avoided a perambulator by a"
"18239",5230,"convulsive movement, and found myself behind the hansom. A happy"
"18240",5230,"thought saved me, and as this drove slowly along I followed in its"
"18241",5230,"immediate wake, trembling and astonished at the turn of my adventure."
"18242",5230,"And not only trembling, but shivering. It was a bright day in January"
"18243",5230,"and I was stark naked and the thin slime of mud that covered the road"
"18244",5230,"was freezing. Foolish as it seems to me now, I had not reckoned that,"
"18245",5230,"transparent or not, I was still amenable to the weather and all its"
"18246",5230,"consequences."
"18247",5230,""
"18248",5230,"“Then suddenly a bright idea came into my head. I ran round and got"
"18249",5230,"into the cab. And so, shivering, scared, and sniffing with the first"
"18250",5230,"intimations of a cold, and with the bruises in the small of my back"
"18251",5230,"growing upon my attention, I drove slowly along Oxford Street and past"
"18252",5230,"Tottenham Court Road. My mood was as different from that in which I had"
"18253",5230,"sallied forth ten minutes ago as it is possible to imagine. This"
"18254",5230,"invisibility indeed! The one thought that possessed me was—how was I to"
"18255",5230,"get out of the scrape I was in."
"18256",5230,""
"18257",5230,"“We crawled past Mudie’s, and there a tall woman with five or six"
"18258",5230,"yellow-labelled books hailed my cab, and I sprang out just in time to"
"18259",5230,"escape her, shaving a railway van narrowly in my flight. I made off up"
"18260",5230,"the roadway to Bloomsbury Square, intending to strike north past the"
"18261",5230,"Museum and so get into the quiet district. I was now cruelly chilled,"
"18262",5230,"and the strangeness of my situation so unnerved me that I whimpered as"
"18263",5230,"I ran. At the northward corner of the Square a little white dog ran out"
"18264",5230,"of the Pharmaceutical Society’s offices, and incontinently made for me,"
"18265",5230,"nose down."
"18266",5230,""
"18267",5230,"“I had never realised it before, but the nose is to the mind of a dog"
"18268",5230,"what the eye is to the mind of a seeing man. Dogs perceive the scent of"
"18269",5230,"a man moving as men perceive his vision. This brute began barking and"
"18270",5230,"leaping, showing, as it seemed to me, only too plainly that he was"
"18271",5230,"aware of me. I crossed Great Russell Street, glancing over my shoulder"
"18272",5230,"as I did so, and went some way along Montague Street before I realised"
"18273",5230,"what I was running towards."
"18274",5230,""
"18275",5230,"“Then I became aware of a blare of music, and looking along the street"
"18276",5230,"saw a number of people advancing out of Russell Square, red shirts, and"
"18277",5230,"the banner of the Salvation Army to the fore. Such a crowd, chanting in"
"18278",5230,"the roadway and scoffing on the pavement, I could not hope to"
"18279",5230,"penetrate, and dreading to go back and farther from home again, and"

"18281",5230,"facing the museum railings, and stood there until the crowd should have"
"18282",5230,"passed. Happily the dog stopped at the noise of the band too,"
"18283",5230,"hesitated, and turned tail, running back to Bloomsbury Square again."
"18284",5230,""
"18285",5230,"“On came the band, bawling with unconscious irony some hymn about ‘When"
"18286",5230,"shall we see His face?’ and it seemed an interminable time to me before"

"18290",5230,"said one. ‘See what?’ said the other. ‘Why—them footmarks—bare. Like"
"18291",5230,"what you makes in mud.’"
"18292",5230,""
"18293",5230,"“I looked down and saw the youngsters had stopped and were gaping at"
"18294",5230,"the muddy footmarks I had left behind me up the newly whitened steps."
"18295",5230,"The passing people elbowed and jostled them, but their confounded"
"18296",5230,"intelligence was arrested. ‘Thud, thud, thud, when, thud, shall we see,"
"18297",5230,"thud, his face, thud, thud.’ ‘There’s a barefoot man gone up them"
"18298",5230,"steps, or I don’t know nothing,’ said one. ‘And he ain’t never come"
"18299",5230,"down again. And his foot was a-bleeding.’"
"18300",5230,""
"18301",5230,"“The thick of the crowd had already passed. ‘Looky there, Ted,’ quoth"
"18302",5230,"the younger of the detectives, with the sharpness of surprise in his"
"18303",5230,"voice, and pointed straight to my feet. I looked down and saw at once"
"18304",5230,"the dim suggestion of their outline sketched in splashes of mud. For a"
"18305",5230,"moment I was paralysed."
"18306",5230,""
"18307",5230,"“‘Why, that’s rum,’ said the elder. ‘Dashed rum! It’s just like the"
"18308",5230,"ghost of a foot, ain’t it?’ He hesitated and advanced with outstretched"
"18309",5230,"hand. A man pulled up short to see what he was catching, and then a"
"18310",5230,"girl. In another moment he would have touched me. Then I saw what to"
"18311",5230,"do. I made a step, the boy started back with an exclamation, and with a"
"18312",5230,"rapid movement I swung myself over into the portico of the next house."
"18313",5230,"But the smaller boy was sharp-eyed enough to follow the movement, and"
"18314",5230,"before I was well down the steps and upon the pavement, he had"
"18315",5230,"recovered from his momentary astonishment and was shouting out that the"
"18316",5230,"feet had gone over the wall."
"18317",5230,""
"18318",5230,"“They rushed round and saw my new footmarks flash into being on the"
"18319",5230,"lower step and upon the pavement. ‘What’s up?’ asked someone. ‘Feet!"
"18320",5230,"Look! Feet running!’"
"18321",5230,""
"18322",5230,"“Everybody in the road, except my three pursuers, was pouring along"
"18323",5230,"after the Salvation Army, and this blow not only impeded me but them."
"18324",5230,"There was an eddy of surprise and interrogation. At the cost of bowling"
"18325",5230,"over one young fellow I got through, and in another moment I was"
"18326",5230,"rushing headlong round the circuit of Russell Square, with six or seven"
"18327",5230,"astonished people following my footmarks. There was no time for"
"18328",5230,"explanation, or else the whole host would have been after me."
"18329",5230,""
"18330",5230,"“Twice I doubled round corners, thrice I crossed the road and came back"
"18331",5230,"upon my tracks, and then, as my feet grew hot and dry, the damp"
"18332",5230,"impressions began to fade. At last I had a breathing space and rubbed"
"18333",5230,"my feet clean with my hands, and so got away altogether. The last I saw"
"18334",5230,"of the chase was a little group of a dozen people perhaps, studying"
"18335",5230,"with infinite perplexity a slowly drying footprint that had resulted"
"18336",5230,"from a puddle in Tavistock Square, a footprint as isolated and"
"18337",5230,"incomprehensible to them as Crusoe’s solitary discovery."
"18338",5230,""
"18339",5230,"“This running warmed me to a certain extent, and I went on with a"
"18340",5230,"better courage through the maze of less frequented roads that runs"
"18341",5230,"hereabouts. My back had now become very stiff and sore, my tonsils were"
"18342",5230,"painful from the cabman’s fingers, and the skin of my neck had been"
"18343",5230,"scratched by his nails; my feet hurt exceedingly and I was lame from a"
"18344",5230,"little cut on one foot. I saw in time a blind man approaching me, and"
"18345",5230,"fled limping, for I feared his subtle intuitions. Once or twice"
"18346",5230,"accidental collisions occurred and I left people amazed, with"
"18347",5230,"unaccountable curses ringing in their ears. Then came something silent"
"18348",5230,"and quiet against my face, and across the Square fell a thin veil of"
"18349",5230,"slowly falling flakes of snow. I had caught a cold, and do as I would I"
"18350",5230,"could not avoid an occasional sneeze. And every dog that came in sight,"
"18351",5230,"with its pointing nose and curious sniffing, was a terror to me."
"18352",5230,""
"18353",5230,"“Then came men and boys running, first one and then others, and"
"18354",5230,"shouting as they ran. It was a fire. They ran in the direction of my"
"18355",5230,"lodging, and looking back down a street I saw a mass of black smoke"
"18356",5230,"streaming up above the roofs and telephone wires. It was my lodging"
"18357",5230,"burning; my clothes, my apparatus, all my resources indeed, except my"
"18358",5230,"cheque-book and the three volumes of memoranda that awaited me in Great"
"18359",5230,"Portland Street, were there. Burning! I had burnt my boats—if ever a"
"18360",5230,"man did! The place was blazing.”"
"18361",5230,""
"18362",5230,"The Invisible Man paused and thought. Kemp glanced nervously out of the"
"18363",5230,"window. “Yes?” he said. “Go on.”"
"18364",5230,""
"18365",5230,""
"18366",5230,""
"18367",5230,""
"18368",5230,"CHAPTER XXII."
"18369",5230,"IN THE EMPORIUM"
"18370",5230,""
"18371",5230,""
"18372",5230,"“So last January, with the beginning of a snowstorm in the air about"
"18373",5230,"me—and if it settled on me it would betray me!—weary, cold, painful,"
"18374",5230,"inexpressibly wretched, and still but half convinced of my invisible"
"18375",5230,"quality, I began this new life to which I am committed. I had no"
"18376",5230,"refuge, no appliances, no human being in the world in whom I could"
"18377",5230,"confide. To have told my secret would have given me away—made a mere"
"18378",5230,"show and rarity of me. Nevertheless, I was half-minded to accost some"
"18379",5230,"passer-by and throw myself upon his mercy. But I knew too clearly the"
"18380",5230,"terror and brutal cruelty my advances would evoke. I made no plans in"
"18381",5230,"the street. My sole object was to get shelter from the snow, to get"
"18382",5230,"myself covered and warm; then I might hope to plan. But even to me, an"
"18383",5230,"Invisible Man, the rows of London houses stood latched, barred, and"
"18384",5230,"bolted impregnably."
"18385",5230,""
"18386",5230,"“Only one thing could I see clearly before me—the cold exposure and"
"18387",5230,"misery of the snowstorm and the night."
"18388",5230,""
"18389",5230,"“And then I had a brilliant idea. I turned down one of the roads"
"18390",5230,"leading from Gower Street to Tottenham Court Road, and found myself"
"18391",5230,"outside Omniums, the big establishment where everything is to be"
"18392",5230,"bought—you know the place: meat, grocery, linen, furniture, clothing,"
"18393",5230,"oil paintings even—a huge meandering collection of shops rather than a"
"18394",5230,"shop. I had thought I should find the doors open, but they were closed,"
"18395",5230,"and as I stood in the wide entrance a carriage stopped outside, and a"
"18396",5230,"man in uniform—you know the kind of personage with ‘Omnium’ on his"
"18397",5230,"cap—flung open the door. I contrived to enter, and walking down the"
"18398",5230,"shop—it was a department where they were selling ribbons and gloves and"
"18399",5230,"stockings and that kind of thing—came to a more spacious region devoted"
"18400",5230,"to picnic baskets and wicker furniture."
"18401",5230,""
"18402",5230,"“I did not feel safe there, however; people were going to and fro, and"
"18403",5230,"I prowled restlessly about until I came upon a huge section in an upper"
"18404",5230,"floor containing multitudes of bedsteads, and over these I clambered,"
"18405",5230,"and found a resting-place at last among a huge pile of folded flock"
"18406",5230,"mattresses. The place was already lit up and agreeably warm, and I"
"18407",5230,"decided to remain where I was, keeping a cautious eye on the two or"
"18408",5230,"three sets of shopmen and customers who were meandering through the"
"18409",5230,"place, until closing time came. Then I should be able, I thought, to"
"18410",5230,"rob the place for food and clothing, and disguised, prowl through it"
"18411",5230,"and examine its resources, perhaps sleep on some of the bedding. That"
"18412",5230,"seemed an acceptable plan. My idea was to procure clothing to make"
"18413",5230,"myself a muffled but acceptable figure, to get money, and then to"
"18414",5230,"recover my books and parcels where they awaited me, take a lodging"
"18415",5230,"somewhere and elaborate plans for the complete realisation of the"
"18416",5230,"advantages my invisibility gave me (as I still imagined) over my"
"18417",5230,"fellow-men."
"18418",5230,""
"18419",5230,"“Closing time arrived quickly enough. It could not have been more than"
"18420",5230,"an hour after I took up my position on the mattresses before I noticed"
"18421",5230,"the blinds of the windows being drawn, and customers being marched"
"18422",5230,"doorward. And then a number of brisk young men began with remarkable"
"18423",5230,"alacrity to tidy up the goods that remained disturbed. I left my lair"
"18424",5230,"as the crowds diminished, and prowled cautiously out into the less"
"18425",5230,"desolate parts of the shop. I was really surprised to observe how"
"18426",5230,"rapidly the young men and women whipped away the goods displayed for"
"18427",5230,"sale during the day. All the boxes of goods, the hanging fabrics, the"
"18428",5230,"festoons of lace, the boxes of sweets in the grocery section, the"
"18429",5230,"displays of this and that, were being whipped down, folded up, slapped"
"18430",5230,"into tidy receptacles, and everything that could not be taken down and"
"18431",5230,"put away had sheets of some coarse stuff like sacking flung over them."
"18432",5230,"Finally all the chairs were turned up on to the counters, leaving the"
"18433",5230,"floor clear. Directly each of these young people had done, he or she"
"18434",5230,"made promptly for the door with such an expression of animation as I"
"18435",5230,"have rarely observed in a shop assistant before. Then came a lot of"
"18436",5230,"youngsters scattering sawdust and carrying pails and brooms. I had to"
"18437",5230,"dodge to get out of the way, and as it was, my ankle got stung with the"
"18438",5230,"sawdust. For some time, wandering through the swathed and darkened"
"18439",5230,"departments, I could hear the brooms at work. And at last a good hour"
"18440",5230,"or more after the shop had been closed, came a noise of locking doors."
"18441",5230,"Silence came upon the place, and I found myself wandering through the"
"18442",5230,"vast and intricate shops, galleries, show-rooms of the place, alone. It"
"18443",5230,"was very still; in one place I remember passing near one of the"
"18444",5230,"Tottenham Court Road entrances and listening to the tapping of"
"18445",5230,"boot-heels of the passers-by."
"18446",5230,""
"18447",5230,"“My first visit was to the place where I had seen stockings and gloves"
"18448",5230,"for sale. It was dark, and I had the devil of a hunt after matches,"
"18449",5230,"which I found at last in the drawer of the little cash desk. Then I had"
"18450",5230,"to get a candle. I had to tear down wrappings and ransack a number of"
"18451",5230,"boxes and drawers, but at last I managed to turn out what I sought; the"
"18452",5230,"box label called them lambswool pants, and lambswool vests. Then socks,"
"18453",5230,"a thick comforter, and then I went to the clothing place and got"
"18454",5230,"trousers, a lounge jacket, an overcoat and a slouch hat—a clerical sort"
"18455",5230,"of hat with the brim turned down. I began to feel a human being again,"
"18456",5230,"and my next thought was food."
"18457",5230,""
"18458",5230,"“Upstairs was a refreshment department, and there I got cold meat."
"18459",5230,"There was coffee still in the urn, and I lit the gas and warmed it up"
"18460",5230,"again, and altogether I did not do badly. Afterwards, prowling through"
"18461",5230,"the place in search of blankets—I had to put up at last with a heap of"
"18462",5230,"down quilts—I came upon a grocery section with a lot of chocolate and"
"18463",5230,"candied fruits, more than was good for me indeed—and some white"
"18464",5230,"burgundy. And near that was a toy department, and I had a brilliant"
"18465",5230,"idea. I found some artificial noses—dummy noses, you know, and I"
"18466",5230,"thought of dark spectacles. But Omniums had no optical department. My"
"18467",5230,"nose had been a difficulty indeed—I had thought of paint. But the"

"18470",5230,""
"18471",5230,"“My last thoughts before sleeping were the most agreeable I had had"
"18472",5230,"since the change. I was in a state of physical serenity, and that was"

"18484",5230,""

"18494",5230,""
"18495",5230,"“The pale London dawn had come, the place was full of a chilly grey"

"18501",5230,""
"18502",5230,"“Then far down the place, in the brighter light of some department"

"18514",5230,""
"18515",5230,"“Lying on the ground, I felt scared out of my wits. But—odd as it may"

"18520",5230,""
"18521",5230,"“I sprang to my feet, whipped a chair off the counter, and sent it"

"18524",5230,"footing, gave a view hallo, and came up the staircase hot after me. Up"

"18529",5230,""
"18530",5230,"“That’s it! Art pots. Well, I turned at the top step and swung round,"

"18544",5230,""

"18552",5230,""

"18554",5230,""

"18556",5230,"in losing the clothes. Then I went into the refreshment-room, drank a"
"18557",5230,"little milk I found there, and sat down by the fire to consider my"
"18558",5230,"position."
"18559",5230,""
"18560",5230,"“In a little while two assistants came in and began to talk over the"
"18561",5230,"business very excitedly and like the fools they were. I heard a"

"18571",5230,"vaguest plans of action in my mind.”"
"18572",5230,""
"18573",5230,""
"18574",5230,""
"18575",5230,""
"18576",5230,"CHAPTER XXIII."
"18577",5230,"IN DRURY LANE"
"18578",5230,""
"18579",5230,""
"18580",5230,"“But you begin now to realise,” said the Invisible Man, “the full"
"18581",5230,"disadvantage of my condition. I had no shelter—no covering—to get"
"18582",5230,"clothing was to forego all my advantage, to make myself a strange and"
"18583",5230,"terrible thing. I was fasting; for to eat, to fill myself with"
"18584",5230,"unassimilated matter, would be to become grotesquely visible again.”"
"18585",5230,""
"18586",5230,"“I never thought of that,” said Kemp."
"18587",5230,""
"18588",5230,"“Nor had I. And the snow had warned me of other dangers. I could not go"
"18589",5230,"abroad in snow—it would settle on me and expose me. Rain, too, would"
"18590",5230,"make me a watery outline, a glistening surface of a man—a bubble. And"
"18591",5230,"fog—I should be like a fainter bubble in a fog, a surface, a greasy"
"18592",5230,"glimmer of humanity. Moreover, as I went abroad—in the London air—I"
"18593",5230,"gathered dirt about my ankles, floating smuts and dust upon my skin. I"
"18594",5230,"did not know how long it would be before I should become visible from"
"18595",5230,"that cause also. But I saw clearly it could not be for long."
"18596",5230,""
"18597",5230,"“Not in London at any rate."
"18598",5230,""
"18599",5230,"“I went into the slums towards Great Portland Street, and found myself"
"18600",5230,"at the end of the street in which I had lodged. I did not go that way,"
"18601",5230,"because of the crowd halfway down it opposite to the still smoking"
"18602",5230,"ruins of the house I had fired. My most immediate problem was to get"
"18603",5230,"clothing. What to do with my face puzzled me. Then I saw in one of"
"18604",5230,"those little miscellaneous shops—news, sweets, toys, stationery,"
"18605",5230,"belated Christmas tomfoolery, and so forth—an array of masks and noses."
"18606",5230,"I realised that problem was solved. In a flash I saw my course. I"
"18607",5230,"turned about, no longer aimless, and went—circuitously in order to"
"18608",5230,"avoid the busy ways, towards the back streets north of the Strand; for"
"18609",5230,"I remembered, though not very distinctly where, that some theatrical"
"18610",5230,"costumiers had shops in that district."
"18611",5230,""
"18612",5230,"“The day was cold, with a nipping wind down the northward running"
"18613",5230,"streets. I walked fast to avoid being overtaken. Every crossing was a"
"18614",5230,"danger, every passenger a thing to watch alertly. One man as I was"
"18615",5230,"about to pass him at the top of Bedford Street, turned upon me abruptly"
"18616",5230,"and came into me, sending me into the road and almost under the wheel"
"18617",5230,"of a passing hansom. The verdict of the cab-rank was that he had had"
"18618",5230,"some sort of stroke. I was so unnerved by this encounter that I went"
"18619",5230,"into Covent Garden Market and sat down for some time in a quiet corner"
"18620",5230,"by a stall of violets, panting and trembling. I found I had caught a"
"18621",5230,"fresh cold, and had to turn out after a time lest my sneezes should"
"18622",5230,"attract attention."
"18623",5230,""
"18624",5230,"“At last I reached the object of my quest, a dirty, fly-blown little"
"18625",5230,"shop in a by-way near Drury Lane, with a window full of tinsel robes,"
"18626",5230,"sham jewels, wigs, slippers, dominoes and theatrical photographs. The"
"18627",5230,"shop was old-fashioned and low and dark, and the house rose above it"
"18628",5230,"for four storeys, dark and dismal. I peered through the window and,"
"18629",5230,"seeing no one within, entered. The opening of the door set a clanking"
"18630",5230,"bell ringing. I left it open, and walked round a bare costume stand,"
"18631",5230,"into a corner behind a cheval glass. For a minute or so no one came."
"18632",5230,"Then I heard heavy feet striding across a room, and a man appeared down"
"18633",5230,"the shop."
"18634",5230,""
"18635",5230,"“My plans were now perfectly definite. I proposed to make my way into"
"18636",5230,"the house, secrete myself upstairs, watch my opportunity, and when"
"18637",5230,"everything was quiet, rummage out a wig, mask, spectacles, and costume,"
"18638",5230,"and go into the world, perhaps a grotesque but still a credible figure."
"18639",5230,"And incidentally of course I could rob the house of any available"
"18640",5230,"money."
"18641",5230,""
"18642",5230,"“The man who had just entered the shop was a short, slight, hunched,"
"18643",5230,"beetle-browed man, with long arms and very short bandy legs. Apparently"
"18644",5230,"I had interrupted a meal. He stared about the shop with an expression"
"18645",5230,"of expectation. This gave way to surprise, and then to anger, as he saw"
"18646",5230,"the shop empty. ‘Damn the boys!’ he said. He went to stare up and down"
"18647",5230,"the street. He came in again in a minute, kicked the door to with his"
"18648",5230,"foot spitefully, and went muttering back to the house door."
"18649",5230,""
"18650",5230,"“I came forward to follow him, and at the noise of my movement he"
"18651",5230,"stopped dead. I did so too, startled by his quickness of ear. He"
"18652",5230,"slammed the house door in my face."
"18653",5230,""
"18654",5230,"“I stood hesitating. Suddenly I heard his quick footsteps returning,"
"18655",5230,"and the door reopened. He stood looking about the shop like one who was"
"18656",5230,"still not satisfied. Then, murmuring to himself, he examined the back"
"18657",5230,"of the counter and peered behind some fixtures. Then he stood doubtful."
"18658",5230,"He had left the house door open and I slipped into the inner room."
"18659",5230,""
"18660",5230,"“It was a queer little room, poorly furnished and with a number of big"
"18661",5230,"masks in the corner. On the table was his belated breakfast, and it was"
"18662",5230,"a confoundedly exasperating thing for me, Kemp, to have to sniff his"
"18663",5230,"coffee and stand watching while he came in and resumed his meal. And"
"18664",5230,"his table manners were irritating. Three doors opened into the little"
"18665",5230,"room, one going upstairs and one down, but they were all shut. I could"
"18666",5230,"not get out of the room while he was there; I could scarcely move"
"18667",5230,"because of his alertness, and there was a draught down my back. Twice I"
"18668",5230,"strangled a sneeze just in time."
"18669",5230,""
"18670",5230,"“The spectacular quality of my sensations was curious and novel, but"

"18681",5230,"was burning low, and scarcely thinking, I put on a little coal. The"

"18684",5230,"examination, he scarcely seemed satisfied. He stopped in the doorway"

"18686",5230,""
"18687",5230,"“I waited in the little parlour for an age, and at last he came up and"
"18688",5230,"opened the upstairs door. I just managed to get by him."
"18689",5230,""
"18690",5230,"“On the staircase he stopped suddenly, so that I very nearly blundered"

"18692",5230,"could have sworn,’ he said. His long hairy hand pulled at his lower"
"18693",5230,"lip. His eye went up and down the staircase. Then he grunted and went"

"18695",5230,""
"18696",5230,"“His hand was on the handle of a door, and then he stopped again with"

"18703",5230,"not follow him. I sat on the head of the staircase until his return."
"18704",5230,""
"18705",5230,"“Presently he came up again, still muttering. He opened the door of the"
"18706",5230,"room, and before I could enter, slammed it in my face."
"18707",5230,""
"18708",5230,"“I resolved to explore the house, and spent some time in doing so as"
"18709",5230,"noiselessly as possible. The house was very old and tumble-down, damp"
"18710",5230,"so that the paper in the attics was peeling from the walls, and rat"
"18711",5230,"infested. Some of the door handles were stiff and I was afraid to turn"
"18712",5230,"them. Several rooms I did inspect were unfurnished, and others were"
"18713",5230,"littered with theatrical lumber, bought second-hand, I judged, from its"
"18714",5230,"appearance. In one room next to his I found a lot of old clothes. I"
"18715",5230,"began routing among these, and in my eagerness forgot again the evident"
"18716",5230,"sharpness of his ears. I heard a stealthy footstep and, looking up just"
"18717",5230,"in time, saw him peering in at the tumbled heap and holding an"
"18718",5230,"old-fashioned revolver in his hand. I stood perfectly still while he"
"18719",5230,"stared about open-mouthed and suspicious. ‘It must have been her,’ he"
"18720",5230,"said slowly. ‘Damn her!’"
"18721",5230,""
"18722",5230,"“He shut the door quietly, and immediately I heard the key turn in the"
"18723",5230,"lock. Then his footsteps retreated. I realised abruptly that I was"

"18725",5230,"to window and back, and stood perplexed. A gust of anger came upon me."
"18726",5230,"But I decided to inspect the clothes before I did anything further, and"
"18727",5230,"my first attempt brought down a pile from an upper shelf. This brought"
"18728",5230,"him back, more sinister than ever. That time he actually touched me,"
"18729",5230,"jumped back with amazement and stood astonished in the middle of the"
"18730",5230,"room."
"18731",5230,""
"18732",5230,"“Presently he calmed a little. ‘Rats,’ he said in an undertone, fingers"
"18733",5230,"on lips. He was evidently a little scared. I edged quietly out of the"

"18738",5230,"opportunity. By this time I knew he was alone in the house, and so I"
"18739",5230,"made no more ado, but knocked him on the head.”"
"18740",5230,""
"18741",5230,"“Knocked him on the head?” exclaimed Kemp."
"18742",5230,""
"18743",5230,"“Yes—stunned him—as he was going downstairs. Hit him from behind with a"
"18744",5230,"stool that stood on the landing. He went downstairs like a bag of old"
"18745",5230,"boots.”"
"18746",5230,""
"18747",5230,"“But—I say! The common conventions of humanity—”"
"18748",5230,""
"18749",5230,"“Are all very well for common people. But the point was, Kemp, that I"
"18750",5230,"had to get out of that house in a disguise without his seeing me. I"
"18751",5230,"couldn’t think of any other way of doing it. And then I gagged him with"
"18752",5230,"a Louis Quatorze vest and tied him up in a sheet.”"
"18753",5230,""
"18754",5230,"“Tied him up in a sheet!”"
"18755",5230,""
"18756",5230,"“Made a sort of bag of it. It was rather a good idea to keep the idiot"
"18757",5230,"scared and quiet, and a devilish hard thing to get out of—head away"

"18768",5230,""

"18770",5230,""

"18931",5230,""
"18932",5230,"CHAPTER XXIV."
"18933",5230,"THE PLAN THAT FAILED"
"18934",5230,""
"18935",5230,""
"18936",5230,"“But now,” said Kemp, with a side glance out of the window, “what are"
"18937",5230,"we to do?”"
"18938",5230,""
"18939",5230,"He moved nearer his guest as he spoke in such a manner as to prevent"
"18940",5230,"the possibility of a sudden glimpse of the three men who were advancing"
"18941",5230,"up the hill road—with an intolerable slowness, as it seemed to Kemp."
"18942",5230,""
"18943",5230,"“What were you planning to do when you were heading for Port Burdock?"
"18944",5230,"_Had_ you any plan?”"
"18945",5230,""
"18946",5230,"“I was going to clear out of the country. But I have altered that plan"

"18954",5230,"things. I was using that tramp as a money box and luggage carrier,"
"18955",5230,"until I decided how to get my books and things sent over to meet me.”"
"18956",5230,""
"18957",5230,"“That’s clear.”"
"18958",5230,""

"18961",5230,""

"18965",5230,""

"18970",5230,""

"18983",5230,""

"18988",5230,""

"18990",5230,""

"18992",5230,""
"18993",5230,"“No one?” insisted Griffin."
"18994",5230,""

"19024",5230,""

"19026",5230,"Griffin, but I’m not agreeing, mind. _Why_ killing?”"

"19060",5230,""

"19108",5230,""
"19109",5230,""
"19110",5230,"CHAPTER XXV."
"19111",5230,"THE HUNTING OF THE INVISIBLE MAN"
"19112",5230,""
"19113",5230,""
"19114",5230,"For a space Kemp was too inarticulate to make Adye understand the swift"
"19115",5230,"things that had just happened. They stood on the landing, Kemp speaking"
"19116",5230,"swiftly, the grotesque swathings of Griffin still on his arm. But"
"19117",5230,"presently Adye began to grasp something of the situation."
"19118",5230,""
"19119",5230,"“He is mad,” said Kemp; “inhuman. He is pure selfishness. He thinks of"
"19120",5230,"nothing but his own advantage, his own safety. I have listened to such"
"19121",5230,"a story this morning of brutal self-seeking.... He has wounded men. He"
"19122",5230,"will kill them unless we can prevent him. He will create a panic."
"19123",5230,"Nothing can stop him. He is going out now—furious!”"
"19124",5230,""
"19125",5230,"“He must be caught,” said Adye. “That is certain.”"
"19126",5230,""
"19127",5230,"“But how?” cried Kemp, and suddenly became full of ideas. “You must"
"19128",5230,"begin at once. You must set every available man to work; you must"

"19132",5230,"trains and roads and shipping. The garrison must help. You must wire"

"19134",5230,"recovering some books of notes he counts of value. I will tell you of"
"19135",5230,"that! There is a man in your police station—Marvel.”"
"19136",5230,""

"19138",5230,""
"19139",5230,"“Says he hasn’t them. But he thinks the tramp has. And you must prevent"
"19140",5230,"him from eating or sleeping; day and night the country must be astir"
"19141",5230,"for him. Food must be locked up and secured, all food, so that he will"
"19142",5230,"have to break his way to it. The houses everywhere must be barred"
"19143",5230,"against him. Heaven send us cold nights and rain! The whole"
"19144",5230,"country-side must begin hunting and keep hunting. I tell you, Adye, he"
"19145",5230,"is a danger, a disaster; unless he is pinned and secured, it is"
"19146",5230,"frightful to think of the things that may happen.”"
"19147",5230,""
"19148",5230,"“What else can we do?” said Adye. “I must go down at once and begin"
"19149",5230,"organising. But why not come? Yes—you come too! Come, and we must hold"
"19150",5230,"a sort of council of war—get Hopps to help—and the railway managers. By"
"19151",5230,"Jove! it’s urgent. Come along—tell me as we go. What else is there we"
"19152",5230,"can do? Put that stuff down.”"
"19153",5230,""
"19154",5230,"In another moment Adye was leading the way downstairs. They found the"
"19155",5230,"front door open and the policemen standing outside staring at empty"
"19156",5230,"air. “He’s got away, sir,” said one."
"19157",5230,""
"19158",5230,"“We must go to the central station at once,” said Adye. “One of you go"
"19159",5230,"on down and get a cab to come up and meet us—quickly. And now, Kemp,"
"19160",5230,"what else?”"
"19161",5230,""
"19162",5230,"“Dogs,” said Kemp. “Get dogs. They don’t see him, but they wind him."
"19163",5230,"Get dogs.”"
"19164",5230,""
"19165",5230,"“Good,” said Adye. “It’s not generally known, but the prison officials"
"19166",5230,"over at Halstead know a man with bloodhounds. Dogs. What else?”"
"19167",5230,""
"19168",5230,"“Bear in mind,” said Kemp, “his food shows. After eating, his food"
"19169",5230,"shows until it is assimilated. So that he has to hide after eating. You"
"19170",5230,"must keep on beating. Every thicket, every quiet corner. And put all"
"19171",5230,"weapons—all implements that might be weapons, away. He can’t carry such"
"19172",5230,"things for long. And what he can snatch up and strike men with must be"
"19173",5230,"hidden away.”"
"19174",5230,""
"19175",5230,"“Good again,” said Adye. “We shall have him yet!”"
"19176",5230,""
"19177",5230,"“And on the roads,” said Kemp, and hesitated."
"19178",5230,""
"19179",5230,"“Yes?” said Adye."
"19180",5230,""
"19181",5230,"“Powdered glass,” said Kemp. “It’s cruel, I know. But think of what he"
"19182",5230,"may do!”"
"19183",5230,""
"19184",5230,"Adye drew the air in sharply between his teeth. “It’s unsportsmanlike."
"19185",5230,"I don’t know. But I’ll have powdered glass got ready. If he goes too"
"19186",5230,"far....”"
"19187",5230,""
"19188",5230,"“The man’s become inhuman, I tell you,” said Kemp. “I am as sure he"
"19189",5230,"will establish a reign of terror—so soon as he has got over the"
"19190",5230,"emotions of this escape—as I am sure I am talking to you. Our only"
"19191",5230,"chance is to be ahead. He has cut himself off from his kind. His blood"
"19192",5230,"be upon his own head.”"
"19193",5230,""
"19194",5230,""
"19195",5230,""
"19196",5230,""
"19197",5230,"CHAPTER XXVI."
"19198",5230,"THE WICKSTEED MURDER"
"19199",5230,""
"19200",5230,""
"19201",5230,"The Invisible Man seems to have rushed out of Kemp’s house in a state"
"19202",5230,"of blind fury. A little child playing near Kemp’s gateway was violently"
"19203",5230,"caught up and thrown aside, so that its ankle was broken, and"
"19204",5230,"thereafter for some hours the Invisible Man passed out of human"
"19205",5230,"perceptions. No one knows where he went nor what he did. But one can"
"19206",5230,"imagine him hurrying through the hot June forenoon, up the hill and on"
"19207",5230,"to the open downland behind Port Burdock, raging and despairing at his"
"19208",5230,"intolerable fate, and sheltering at last, heated and weary, amid the"
"19209",5230,"thickets of Hintondean, to piece together again his shattered schemes"
"19210",5230,"against his species. That seems the most probable refuge for him, for"
"19211",5230,"there it was he re-asserted himself in a grimly tragical manner about"
"19212",5230,"two in the afternoon."
"19213",5230,""
"19214",5230,"One wonders what his state of mind may have been during that time, and"
"19215",5230,"what plans he devised. No doubt he was almost ecstatically exasperated"
"19216",5230,"by Kemp’s treachery, and though we may be able to understand the"
"19217",5230,"motives that led to that deceit, we may still imagine and even"
"19218",5230,"sympathise a little with the fury the attempted surprise must have"
"19219",5230,"occasioned. Perhaps something of the stunned astonishment of his Oxford"
"19220",5230,"Street experiences may have returned to him, for he had evidently"
"19221",5230,"counted on Kemp’s co-operation in his brutal dream of a terrorised"
"19222",5230,"world. At any rate he vanished from human ken about midday, and no"
"19223",5230,"living witness can tell what he did until about half-past two. It was a"
"19224",5230,"fortunate thing, perhaps, for humanity, but for him it was a fatal"
"19225",5230,"inaction."
"19226",5230,""
"19227",5230,"During that time a growing multitude of men scattered over the"
"19228",5230,"countryside were busy. In the morning he had still been simply a"
"19229",5230,"legend, a terror; in the afternoon, by virtue chiefly of Kemp’s drily"
"19230",5230,"worded proclamation, he was presented as a tangible antagonist, to be"
"19231",5230,"wounded, captured, or overcome, and the countryside began organising"
"19232",5230,"itself with inconceivable rapidity. By two o’clock even he might still"
"19233",5230,"have removed himself out of the district by getting aboard a train, but"
"19234",5230,"after two that became impossible. Every passenger train along the lines"
"19235",5230,"on a great parallelogram between Southampton, Manchester, Brighton and"
"19236",5230,"Horsham, travelled with locked doors, and the goods traffic was almost"
"19237",5230,"entirely suspended. And in a great circle of twenty miles round Port"
"19238",5230,"Burdock, men armed with guns and bludgeons were presently setting out"
"19239",5230,"in groups of three and four, with dogs, to beat the roads and fields."
"19240",5230,""
"19241",5230,"Mounted policemen rode along the country lanes, stopping at every"
"19242",5230,"cottage and warning the people to lock up their houses, and keep"
"19243",5230,"indoors unless they were armed, and all the elementary schools had"
"19244",5230,"broken up by three o’clock, and the children, scared and keeping"
"19245",5230,"together in groups, were hurrying home. Kemp’s proclamation—signed"
"19246",5230,"indeed by Adye—was posted over almost the whole district by four or"
"19247",5230,"five o’clock in the afternoon. It gave briefly but clearly all the"
"19248",5230,"conditions of the struggle, the necessity of keeping the Invisible Man"
"19249",5230,"from food and sleep, the necessity for incessant watchfulness and for a"
"19250",5230,"prompt attention to any evidence of his movements. And so swift and"
"19251",5230,"decided was the action of the authorities, so prompt and universal was"
"19252",5230,"the belief in this strange being, that before nightfall an area of"
"19253",5230,"several hundred square miles was in a stringent state of siege. And"
"19254",5230,"before nightfall, too, a thrill of horror went through the whole"
"19255",5230,"watching nervous countryside. Going from whispering mouth to mouth,"
"19256",5230,"swift and certain over the length and breadth of the country, passed"
"19257",5230,"the story of the murder of Mr. Wicksteed."
"19258",5230,""
"19259",5230,"If our supposition that the Invisible Man’s refuge was the Hintondean"
"19260",5230,"thickets, then we must suppose that in the early afternoon he sallied"
"19261",5230,"out again bent upon some project that involved the use of a weapon. We"
"19262",5230,"cannot know what the project was, but the evidence that he had the iron"
"19263",5230,"rod in hand before he met Wicksteed is to me at least overwhelming."
"19264",5230,""
"19265",5230,"Of course we can know nothing of the details of that encounter. It"
"19266",5230,"occurred on the edge of a gravel pit, not two hundred yards from Lord"
"19267",5230,"Burdock’s lodge gate. Everything points to a desperate struggle—the"
"19268",5230,"trampled ground, the numerous wounds Mr. Wicksteed received, his"
"19269",5230,"splintered walking-stick; but why the attack was made, save in a"
"19270",5230,"murderous frenzy, it is impossible to imagine. Indeed the theory of"
"19271",5230,"madness is almost unavoidable. Mr. Wicksteed was a man of forty-five or"
"19272",5230,"forty-six, steward to Lord Burdock, of inoffensive habits and"
"19273",5230,"appearance, the very last person in the world to provoke such a"
"19274",5230,"terrible antagonist. Against him it would seem the Invisible Man used"
"19275",5230,"an iron rod dragged from a broken piece of fence. He stopped this quiet"
"19276",5230,"man, going quietly home to his midday meal, attacked him, beat down his"
"19277",5230,"feeble defences, broke his arm, felled him, and smashed his head to a"
"19278",5230,"jelly."
"19279",5230,""
"19280",5230,"Of course, he must have dragged this rod out of the fencing before he"
"19281",5230,"met his victim—he must have been carrying it ready in his hand. Only"
"19282",5230,"two details beyond what has already been stated seem to bear on the"
"19283",5230,"matter. One is the circumstance that the gravel pit was not in Mr."
"19284",5230,"Wicksteed’s direct path home, but nearly a couple of hundred yards out"
"19285",5230,"of his way. The other is the assertion of a little girl to the effect"
"19286",5230,"that, going to her afternoon school, she saw the murdered man"
"19287",5230,"“trotting” in a peculiar manner across a field towards the gravel pit."
"19288",5230,"Her pantomime of his action suggests a man pursuing something on the"
"19289",5230,"ground before him and striking at it ever and again with his"
"19290",5230,"walking-stick. She was the last person to see him alive. He passed out"
"19291",5230,"of her sight to his death, the struggle being hidden from her only by a"
"19292",5230,"clump of beech trees and a slight depression in the ground."
"19293",5230,""
"19294",5230,"Now this, to the present writer’s mind at least, lifts the murder out"
"19295",5230,"of the realm of the absolutely wanton. We may imagine that Griffin had"
"19296",5230,"taken the rod as a weapon indeed, but without any deliberate intention"
"19297",5230,"of using it in murder. Wicksteed may then have come by and noticed this"
"19298",5230,"rod inexplicably moving through the air. Without any thought of the"
"19299",5230,"Invisible Man—for Port Burdock is ten miles away—he may have pursued"
"19300",5230,"it. It is quite conceivable that he may not even have heard of the"
"19301",5230,"Invisible Man. One can then imagine the Invisible Man making"
"19302",5230,"off—quietly in order to avoid discovering his presence in the"
"19303",5230,"neighbourhood, and Wicksteed, excited and curious, pursuing this"
"19304",5230,"unaccountably locomotive object—finally striking at it."
"19305",5230,""
"19306",5230,"No doubt the Invisible Man could easily have distanced his middle-aged"
"19307",5230,"pursuer under ordinary circumstances, but the position in which"
"19308",5230,"Wicksteed’s body was found suggests that he had the ill luck to drive"
"19309",5230,"his quarry into a corner between a drift of stinging nettles and the"
"19310",5230,"gravel pit. To those who appreciate the extraordinary irascibility of"
"19311",5230,"the Invisible Man, the rest of the encounter will be easy to imagine."
"19312",5230,""
"19313",5230,"But this is pure hypothesis. The only undeniable facts—for stories of"
"19314",5230,"children are often unreliable—are the discovery of Wicksteed’s body,"
"19315",5230,"done to death, and of the blood-stained iron rod flung among the"
"19316",5230,"nettles. The abandonment of the rod by Griffin, suggests that in the"
"19317",5230,"emotional excitement of the affair, the purpose for which he took it—if"
"19318",5230,"he had a purpose—was abandoned. He was certainly an intensely"
"19319",5230,"egotistical and unfeeling man, but the sight of his victim, his first"
"19320",5230,"victim, bloody and pitiful at his feet, may have released some long"
"19321",5230,"pent fountain of remorse which for a time may have flooded whatever"
"19322",5230,"scheme of action he had contrived."
"19323",5230,""
"19324",5230,"After the murder of Mr. Wicksteed, he would seem to have struck across"
"19325",5230,"the country towards the downland. There is a story of a voice heard"
"19326",5230,"about sunset by a couple of men in a field near Fern Bottom. It was"
"19327",5230,"wailing and laughing, sobbing and groaning, and ever and again it"
"19328",5230,"shouted. It must have been queer hearing. It drove up across the middle"
"19329",5230,"of a clover field and died away towards the hills."
"19330",5230,""
"19331",5230,"That afternoon the Invisible Man must have learnt something of the"
"19332",5230,"rapid use Kemp had made of his confidences. He must have found houses"
"19333",5230,"locked and secured; he may have loitered about railway stations and"
"19334",5230,"prowled about inns, and no doubt he read the proclamations and realised"
"19335",5230,"something of the nature of the campaign against him. And as the evening"
"19336",5230,"advanced, the fields became dotted here and there with groups of three"
"19337",5230,"or four men, and noisy with the yelping of dogs. These men-hunters had"
"19338",5230,"particular instructions in the case of an encounter as to the way they"
"19339",5230,"should support one another. But he avoided them all. We may understand"
"19340",5230,"something of his exasperation, and it could have been none the less"
"19341",5230,"because he himself had supplied the information that was being used so"
"19342",5230,"remorselessly against him. For that day at least he lost heart; for"
"19343",5230,"nearly twenty-four hours, save when he turned on Wicksteed, he was a"
"19344",5230,"hunted man. In the night, he must have eaten and slept; for in the"
"19345",5230,"morning he was himself again, active, powerful, angry, and malignant,"
"19346",5230,"prepared for his last great struggle against the world."
"19347",5230,""
"19348",5230,""
"19349",5230,""
"19350",5230,""
"19351",5230,"CHAPTER XXVII."
"19352",5230,"THE SIEGE OF KEMP’S HOUSE"
"19353",5230,""
"19354",5230,""
"19355",5230,"Kemp read a strange missive, written in pencil on a greasy sheet of"
"19356",5230,"paper."
"19357",5230,""
"19358",5230,"“You have been amazingly energetic and clever,” this letter ran,"
"19359",5230,"“though what you stand to gain by it I cannot imagine. You are against"
"19360",5230,"me. For a whole day you have chased me; you have tried to rob me of a"
"19361",5230,"night’s rest. But I have had food in spite of you, I have slept in"
"19362",5230,"spite of you, and the game is only beginning. The game is only"
"19363",5230,"beginning. There is nothing for it, but to start the Terror. This"
"19364",5230,"announces the first day of the Terror. Port Burdock is no longer under"
"19365",5230,"the Queen, tell your Colonel of Police, and the rest of them; it is"
"19366",5230,"under me—the Terror! This is day one of year one of the new epoch—the"
"19367",5230,"Epoch of the Invisible Man. I am Invisible Man the First. To begin with"
"19368",5230,"the rule will be easy. The first day there will be one execution for"
"19369",5230,"the sake of example—a man named Kemp. Death starts for him to-day. He"
"19370",5230,"may lock himself away, hide himself away, get guards about him, put on"
"19371",5230,"armour if he likes—Death, the unseen Death, is coming. Let him take"
"19372",5230,"precautions; it will impress my people. Death starts from the pillar"
"19373",5230,"box by midday. The letter will fall in as the postman comes along, then"
"19374",5230,"off! The game begins. Death starts. Help him not, my people, lest Death"
"19375",5230,"fall upon you also. To-day Kemp is to die.”"
"19376",5230,""
"19377",5230,"Kemp read this letter twice, “It’s no hoax,” he said. “That’s his"
"19378",5230,"voice! And he means it.”"
"19379",5230,""
"19380",5230,"He turned the folded sheet over and saw on the addressed side of it the"
"19381",5230,"postmark Hintondean, and the prosaic detail “2d. to pay.”"
"19382",5230,""
"19383",5230,"He got up slowly, leaving his lunch unfinished—the letter had come by"
"19384",5230,"the one o’clock post—and went into his study. He rang for his"
"19385",5230,"housekeeper, and told her to go round the house at once, examine all"
"19386",5230,"the fastenings of the windows, and close all the shutters. He closed"
"19387",5230,"the shutters of his study himself. From a locked drawer in his bedroom"
"19388",5230,"he took a little revolver, examined it carefully, and put it into the"
"19389",5230,"pocket of his lounge jacket. He wrote a number of brief notes, one to"
"19390",5230,"Colonel Adye, gave them to his servant to take, with explicit"
"19391",5230,"instructions as to her way of leaving the house. “There is no danger,”"
"19392",5230,"he said, and added a mental reservation, “to you.” He remained"
"19393",5230,"meditative for a space after doing this, and then returned to his"
"19394",5230,"cooling lunch."
"19395",5230,""
"19396",5230,"He ate with gaps of thought. Finally he struck the table sharply. “We"
"19397",5230,"will have him!” he said; “and I am the bait. He will come too far.”"
"19398",5230,""
"19399",5230,"He went up to the belvedere, carefully shutting every door after him."
"19400",5230,"“It’s a game,” he said, “an odd game—but the chances are all for me,"
"19401",5230,"Mr. Griffin, in spite of your invisibility. Griffin _contra mundum_ ..."
"19402",5230,"with a vengeance.”"
"19403",5230,""
"19404",5230,"He stood at the window staring at the hot hillside. “He must get food"
"19405",5230,"every day—and I don’t envy him. Did he really sleep last night? Out in"
"19406",5230,"the open somewhere—secure from collisions. I wish we could get some"
"19407",5230,"good cold wet weather instead of the heat."
"19408",5230,""
"19409",5230,"“He may be watching me now.”"
"19410",5230,""
"19411",5230,"He went close to the window. Something rapped smartly against the"
"19412",5230,"brickwork over the frame, and made him start violently back."
"19413",5230,""
"19414",5230,"“I’m getting nervous,” said Kemp. But it was five minutes before he"
"19415",5230,"went to the window again. “It must have been a sparrow,” he said."
"19416",5230,""
"19417",5230,"Presently he heard the front-door bell ringing, and hurried downstairs."
"19418",5230,"He unbolted and unlocked the door, examined the chain, put it up, and"
"19419",5230,"opened cautiously without showing himself. A familiar voice hailed him."
"19420",5230,"It was Adye."
"19421",5230,""
"19422",5230,"“Your servant’s been assaulted, Kemp,” he said round the door."
"19423",5230,""
"19424",5230,"“What!” exclaimed Kemp."
"19425",5230,""
"19426",5230,"“Had that note of yours taken away from her. He’s close about here. Let"
"19427",5230,"me in.”"
"19428",5230,""
"19429",5230,"Kemp released the chain, and Adye entered through as narrow an opening"
"19430",5230,"as possible. He stood in the hall, looking with infinite relief at Kemp"
"19431",5230,"refastening the door. “Note was snatched out of her hand. Scared her"
"19432",5230,"horribly. She’s down at the station. Hysterics. He’s close here. What"
"19433",5230,"was it about?”"
"19434",5230,""
"19435",5230,"Kemp swore."
"19436",5230,""
"19437",5230,"“What a fool I was,” said Kemp. “I might have known. It’s not an hour’s"
"19438",5230,"walk from Hintondean. Already?”"
"19439",5230,""
"19440",5230,"“What’s up?” said Adye."
"19441",5230,""
"19442",5230,"“Look here!” said Kemp, and led the way into his study. He handed Adye"
"19443",5230,"the Invisible Man’s letter. Adye read it and whistled softly. “And"
"19444",5230,"you—?” said Adye."
"19445",5230,""
"19446",5230,"“Proposed a trap—like a fool,” said Kemp, “and sent my proposal out by"
"19447",5230,"a maid servant. To him.”"
"19448",5230,""
"19449",5230,"Adye followed Kemp’s profanity."
"19450",5230,""
"19451",5230,"“He’ll clear out,” said Adye."
"19452",5230,""
"19453",5230,"“Not he,” said Kemp."
"19454",5230,""
"19455",5230,"A resounding smash of glass came from upstairs. Adye had a silvery"
"19456",5230,"glimpse of a little revolver half out of Kemp’s pocket. “It’s a window,"
"19457",5230,"upstairs!” said Kemp, and led the way up. There came a second smash"
"19458",5230,"while they were still on the staircase. When they reached the study"
"19459",5230,"they found two of the three windows smashed, half the room littered"
"19460",5230,"with splintered glass, and one big flint lying on the writing table."
"19461",5230,"The two men stopped in the doorway, contemplating the wreckage. Kemp"
"19462",5230,"swore again, and as he did so the third window went with a snap like a"
"19463",5230,"pistol, hung starred for a moment, and collapsed in jagged, shivering"
"19464",5230,"triangles into the room."
"19465",5230,""
"19466",5230,"“What’s this for?” said Adye."
"19467",5230,""
"19468",5230,"“It’s a beginning,” said Kemp."
"19469",5230,""
"19470",5230,"“There’s no way of climbing up here?”"
"19471",5230,""
"19472",5230,"“Not for a cat,” said Kemp."
"19473",5230,""
"19474",5230,"“No shutters?”"
"19475",5230,""
"19476",5230,"“Not here. All the downstairs rooms—Hullo!”"
"19477",5230,""
"19478",5230,"Smash, and then whack of boards hit hard came from downstairs."
"19479",5230,"“Confound him!” said Kemp. “That must be—yes—it’s one of the bedrooms."
"19480",5230,"He’s going to do all the house. But he’s a fool. The shutters are up,"
"19481",5230,"and the glass will fall outside. He’ll cut his feet.”"
"19482",5230,""
"19483",5230,"Another window proclaimed its destruction. The two men stood on the"

"19485",5230,"something, and I’ll go down to the station and get the bloodhounds put"
"19486",5230,"on. That ought to settle him! They’re hard by—not ten minutes—”"
"19487",5230,""
"19488",5230,"Another window went the way of its fellows."
"19489",5230,""
"19490",5230,"“You haven’t a revolver?” asked Adye."
"19491",5230,""
"19492",5230,"Kemp’s hand went to his pocket. Then he hesitated. “I haven’t one—at"
"19493",5230,"least to spare.”"
"19494",5230,""
"19495",5230,"“I’ll bring it back,” said Adye, “you’ll be safe here.”"
"19496",5230,""
"19497",5230,"Kemp, ashamed of his momentary lapse from truthfulness, handed him the"
"19498",5230,"weapon."
"19499",5230,""
"19500",5230,"“Now for the door,” said Adye."
"19501",5230,""
"19502",5230,"As they stood hesitating in the hall, they heard one of the first-floor"

"19504",5230,"slip the bolts as silently as possible. His face was a little paler"
"19505",5230,"than usual. “You must step straight out,” said Kemp. In another moment"
"19506",5230,"Adye was on the doorstep and the bolts were dropping back into the"

"19509",5230,"steps. He crossed the lawn and approached the gate. A little breeze"
"19510",5230,"seemed to ripple over the grass. Something moved near him. “Stop a"
"19511",5230,"bit,” said a Voice, and Adye stopped dead and his hand tightened on the"
"19512",5230,"revolver."
"19513",5230,""
"19514",5230,"“Well?” said Adye, white and grim, and every nerve tense."
"19515",5230,""
"19516",5230,"“Oblige me by going back to the house,” said the Voice, as tense and"

"19522",5230,""

"19551",5230,""

"19563",5230,""

"19727",5230,"CHAPTER XXVIII."
"19728",5230,"THE HUNTER HUNTED"
"19729",5230,""
"19730",5230,""
"19731",5230,"Mr. Heelas, Mr. Kemp’s nearest neighbour among the villa holders, was"
"19732",5230,"asleep in his summer house when the siege of Kemp’s house began. Mr."
"19733",5230,"Heelas was one of the sturdy minority who refused to believe “in all"
"19734",5230,"this nonsense” about an Invisible Man. His wife, however, as he was"
"19735",5230,"subsequently to be reminded, did. He insisted upon walking about his"
"19736",5230,"garden just as if nothing was the matter, and he went to sleep in the"
"19737",5230,"afternoon in accordance with the custom of years. He slept through the"
"19738",5230,"smashing of the windows, and then woke up suddenly with a curious"
"19739",5230,"persuasion of something wrong. He looked across at Kemp’s house, rubbed"
"19740",5230,"his eyes and looked again. Then he put his feet to the ground, and sat"
"19741",5230,"listening. He said he was damned, but still the strange thing was"
"19742",5230,"visible. The house looked as though it had been deserted for"
"19743",5230,"weeks—after a violent riot. Every window was broken, and every window,"
"19744",5230,"save those of the belvedere study, was blinded by the internal"
"19745",5230,"shutters."
"19746",5230,""
"19747",5230,"“I could have sworn it was all right”—he looked at his watch—“twenty"
"19748",5230,"minutes ago.”"
"19749",5230,""
"19750",5230,"He became aware of a measured concussion and the clash of glass, far"
"19751",5230,"away in the distance. And then, as he sat open-mouthed, came a still"
"19752",5230,"more wonderful thing. The shutters of the drawing-room window were"
"19753",5230,"flung open violently, and the housemaid in her outdoor hat and"
"19754",5230,"garments, appeared struggling in a frantic manner to throw up the sash."
"19755",5230,"Suddenly a man appeared beside her, helping her—Dr. Kemp! In another"
"19756",5230,"moment the window was open, and the housemaid was struggling out; she"
"19757",5230,"pitched forward and vanished among the shrubs. Mr. Heelas stood up,"
"19758",5230,"exclaiming vaguely and vehemently at all these wonderful things. He saw"
"19759",5230,"Kemp stand on the sill, spring from the window, and reappear almost"
"19760",5230,"instantaneously running along a path in the shrubbery and stooping as"
"19761",5230,"he ran, like a man who evades observation. He vanished behind a"
"19762",5230,"laburnum, and appeared again clambering over a fence that abutted on"
"19763",5230,"the open down. In a second he had tumbled over and was running at a"
"19764",5230,"tremendous pace down the slope towards Mr. Heelas."
"19765",5230,""
"19766",5230,"“Lord!” cried Mr. Heelas, struck with an idea; “it’s that Invisible Man"
"19767",5230,"brute! It’s right, after all!”"
"19768",5230,""
"19769",5230,"With Mr. Heelas to think things like that was to act, and his cook"
"19770",5230,"watching him from the top window was amazed to see him come pelting"
"19771",5230,"towards the house at a good nine miles an hour. There was a slamming of"
"19772",5230,"doors, a ringing of bells, and the voice of Mr. Heelas bellowing like a"
"19773",5230,"bull. “Shut the doors, shut the windows, shut everything!—the Invisible"
"19774",5230,"Man is coming!” Instantly the house was full of screams and directions,"
"19775",5230,"and scurrying feet. He ran himself to shut the French windows that"
"19776",5230,"opened on the veranda; as he did so Kemp’s head and shoulders and knee"
"19777",5230,"appeared over the edge of the garden fence. In another moment Kemp had"
"19778",5230,"ploughed through the asparagus, and was running across the tennis lawn"
"19779",5230,"to the house."
"19780",5230,""
"19781",5230,"“You can’t come in,” said Mr. Heelas, shutting the bolts. “I’m very"
"19782",5230,"sorry if he’s after you, but you can’t come in!”"
"19783",5230,""
"19784",5230,"Kemp appeared with a face of terror close to the glass, rapping and"
"19785",5230,"then shaking frantically at the French window. Then, seeing his efforts"
"19786",5230,"were useless, he ran along the veranda, vaulted the end, and went to"
"19787",5230,"hammer at the side door. Then he ran round by the side gate to the"
"19788",5230,"front of the house, and so into the hill-road. And Mr. Heelas staring"
"19789",5230,"from his window—a face of horror—had scarcely witnessed Kemp vanish,"
"19790",5230,"ere the asparagus was being trampled this way and that by feet unseen."
"19791",5230,"At that Mr. Heelas fled precipitately upstairs, and the rest of the"
"19792",5230,"chase is beyond his purview. But as he passed the staircase window, he"
"19793",5230,"heard the side gate slam."
"19794",5230,""
"19795",5230,"Emerging into the hill-road, Kemp naturally took the downward"
"19796",5230,"direction, and so it was he came to run in his own person the very race"
"19797",5230,"he had watched with such a critical eye from the belvedere study only"
"19798",5230,"four days ago. He ran it well, for a man out of training, and though"
"19799",5230,"his face was white and wet, his wits were cool to the last. He ran with"
"19800",5230,"wide strides, and wherever a patch of rough ground intervened, wherever"
"19801",5230,"there came a patch of raw flints, or a bit of broken glass shone"
"19802",5230,"dazzling, he crossed it and left the bare invisible feet that followed"
"19803",5230,"to take what line they would."
"19804",5230,""
"19805",5230,"For the first time in his life Kemp discovered that the hill-road was"
"19806",5230,"indescribably vast and desolate, and that the beginnings of the town"
"19807",5230,"far below at the hill foot were strangely remote. Never had there been"
"19808",5230,"a slower or more painful method of progression than running. All the"
"19809",5230,"gaunt villas, sleeping in the afternoon sun, looked locked and barred;"
"19810",5230,"no doubt they were locked and barred—by his own orders. But at any rate"
"19811",5230,"they might have kept a lookout for an eventuality like this! The town"
"19812",5230,"was rising up now, the sea had dropped out of sight behind it, and"
"19813",5230,"people down below were stirring. A tram was just arriving at the hill"
"19814",5230,"foot. Beyond that was the police station. Was that footsteps he heard"
"19815",5230,"behind him? Spurt."
"19816",5230,""
"19817",5230,"The people below were staring at him, one or two were running, and his"
"19818",5230,"breath was beginning to saw in his throat. The tram was quite near now,"
"19819",5230,"and the “Jolly Cricketers” was noisily barring its doors. Beyond the"
"19820",5230,"tram were posts and heaps of gravel—the drainage works. He had a"
"19821",5230,"transitory idea of jumping into the tram and slamming the doors, and"
"19822",5230,"then he resolved to go for the police station. In another moment he had"
"19823",5230,"passed the door of the “Jolly Cricketers,” and was in the blistering"
"19824",5230,"fag end of the street, with human beings about him. The tram driver and"
"19825",5230,"his helper—arrested by the sight of his furious haste—stood staring"
"19826",5230,"with the tram horses unhitched. Further on the astonished features of"
"19827",5230,"navvies appeared above the mounds of gravel."
"19828",5230,""
"19829",5230,"His pace broke a little, and then he heard the swift pad of his"
"19830",5230,"pursuer, and leapt forward again. “The Invisible Man!” he cried to the"
"19831",5230,"navvies, with a vague indicative gesture, and by an inspiration leapt"
"19832",5230,"the excavation and placed a burly group between him and the chase. Then"
"19833",5230,"abandoning the idea of the police station he turned into a little side"
"19834",5230,"street, rushed by a greengrocer’s cart, hesitated for the tenth of a"
"19835",5230,"second at the door of a sweetstuff shop, and then made for the mouth of"
"19836",5230,"an alley that ran back into the main Hill Street again. Two or three"
"19837",5230,"little children were playing here, and shrieked and scattered at his"
"19838",5230,"apparition, and forthwith doors and windows opened and excited mothers"
"19839",5230,"revealed their hearts. Out he shot into Hill Street again, three"
"19840",5230,"hundred yards from the tram-line end, and immediately he became aware"
"19841",5230,"of a tumultuous vociferation and running people."
"19842",5230,""
"19843",5230,"He glanced up the street towards the hill. Hardly a dozen yards off ran"
"19844",5230,"a huge navvy, cursing in fragments and slashing viciously with a spade,"
"19845",5230,"and hard behind him came the tram conductor with his fists clenched. Up"
"19846",5230,"the street others followed these two, striking and shouting. Down"
"19847",5230,"towards the town, men and women were running, and he noticed clearly"
"19848",5230,"one man coming out of a shop-door with a stick in his hand. “Spread"
"19849",5230,"out! Spread out!” cried some one. Kemp suddenly grasped the altered"
"19850",5230,"condition of the chase. He stopped, and looked round, panting. “He’s"
"19851",5230,"close here!” he cried. “Form a line across—”"
"19852",5230,""
"19853",5230,"He was hit hard under the ear, and went reeling, trying to face round"
"19854",5230,"towards his unseen antagonist. He just managed to keep his feet, and he"
"19855",5230,"struck a vain counter in the air. Then he was hit again under the jaw,"
"19856",5230,"and sprawled headlong on the ground. In another moment a knee"
"19857",5230,"compressed his diaphragm, and a couple of eager hands gripped his"
"19858",5230,"throat, but the grip of one was weaker than the other; he grasped the"
"19859",5230,"wrists, heard a cry of pain from his assailant, and then the spade of"
"19860",5230,"the navvy came whirling through the air above him, and struck something"

"19862",5230,"his throat suddenly relaxed, and with a convulsive effort, Kemp loosed"
"19863",5230,"himself, grasped a limp shoulder, and rolled uppermost. He gripped the"
"19864",5230,"unseen elbows near the ground. “I’ve got him!” screamed Kemp. “Help!"
"19865",5230,"Help—hold! He’s down! Hold his feet!”"
"19866",5230,""
"19867",5230,"In another second there was a simultaneous rush upon the struggle, and"
"19868",5230,"a stranger coming into the road suddenly might have thought an"
"19869",5230,"exceptionally savage game of Rugby football was in progress. And there"
"19870",5230,"was no shouting after Kemp’s cry—only a sound of blows and feet and"
"19871",5230,"heavy breathing."
"19872",5230,""
"19873",5230,"Then came a mighty effort, and the Invisible Man threw off a couple of"

"19875",5230,"a hound to a stag, and a dozen hands gripped, clutched, and tore at the"
"19876",5230,"Unseen. The tram conductor suddenly got the neck and shoulders and"
"19877",5230,"lugged him back."
"19878",5230,""
"19879",5230,"Down went the heap of struggling men again and rolled over. There was,"
"19880",5230,"I am afraid, some savage kicking. Then suddenly a wild scream of"
"19881",5230,"“Mercy! Mercy!” that died down swiftly to a sound like choking."
"19882",5230,""
"19883",5230,"“Get back, you fools!” cried the muffled voice of Kemp, and there was a"
"19884",5230,"vigorous shoving back of stalwart forms. “He’s hurt, I tell you. Stand"
"19885",5230,"back!”"
"19886",5230,""
"19887",5230,"There was a brief struggle to clear a space, and then the circle of"
"19888",5230,"eager faces saw the doctor kneeling, as it seemed, fifteen inches in"
